Stocks stepped back in declining volume Thursday afternoon, as the big money apparently took a break from recent buying. The Nasdaq retreated 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today was running well below the previous session's pace. A pause at this juncture is no surprise. The…

The 88th Academy Awards are on Sunday, which means a flash-studded stroll down the red carpet for Hollywood's elite.For investors, there's this walk of fame: The IBD 50. This week's ingenues include Nvidia (NVDA), Michael Kors (KORS), Ross Stores (ROST), Ryanair (RYAAY) and Facebook (FB).Matt Damon was forced to fly solo on the Red Planet, but little did he know that Nvidia was right by his side -- chewing up the scenery. Lead visual effects studio Moving Picture Company used Nvidia Quadro graphics cards to help bring "The Martian" to life.The chipmaker's products power plenty of theatrical visual effects, but its recent earnings results were no illusion: Per-share earnings grew 21% in Q4, marking an eighth consecutive quarter of double-digit profit gains.The stock popped 8% on Feb. 18 following the Q4 beat and above-consensus guidance. Shares are currently forming a cup-shaped base.Nvidia closed down 0.7% in the stock market Friday.Kate Hudson and Olivia Wilde wore slinky Kors numbers to the Golden Globes last month, and this designer's gowns are almost certain to be spotted on the red carpet Sunday. The only question is who will show up draped in Michael Kors.Kors and other fashion houses like Coach (COH) and Kate Spade (KATE) have had a rough go of it lately, but Kors' holiday-quarter results exceeded expectations, sending its stock back on the road to stardom with a nearly 24% pop on Feb. 2. And IBD's apparel manufacturer's industry group is climbing the ranks.Kors shares closed Friday up 0.2% at 56.58. That's still a long way off from its all-time high of 101.04 two years ago on Feb. 28, 2014, but Hollywood, like Wall Street, loves a comeback story.Jennifer Lawrence will probably show up in Dior again, but after the Academy Awards -- and the after-parties -- it's a fair bet that celebs are probably rocking a comfy chic look the morning after.And consumers looking to dupe their favorite "just got out of SoulCycle" look might head to Ross Stores or TJX (TJX) for off-price brand names.Ross has been looking better than some of its struggling retail peers, particularly those in the department-store category. Shares are consolidating near a buy point of 56.78, and closed down 0.5% on Friday.Cowen & Co. recently called out Ross Stores as a "prudent retail (stock) holding in 2016" and one to consider should a recession strike again.European influences figure prominently in this year's Oscars nominees, from the Irish-American immigrant story in "Brooklyn" to the Cold War-era "Bridge of Spies" to three of the five foreign-language films up for awards.This Ireland-based European budget airline likely isn't the first choice of the rich and famous -- although Prince William once flew Ryanair to Scotland! -- but its most recent quarterly earnings soared higher than Harvey Weinstein's private jet.The famously bare-bones carrier logged a 25% bump in passengers and more than doubled its profit in Q3. Now, Ryanair has got its sights set on the business set as it hopes to gain share of that market.Shares dipped 0.4%. The stock is currently in an area of consolidation, with shares hovering around their 50-day line.Part of Hollywood Boulevard will be shut down, but social media will be hopping Sunday as celebs start trickling into the Dolby Theatre. Who wore what? Who's with whom? Who won what? Facebook will no doubt have the commentary.This year, the snark and "OMGs" can be accompanied by Facebook's newly unveiled Reactions feature that goes beyond a regular "Like" to include "Wow," "Sad," "Love" "Angry" and "Haha."Plus, the social networking giant is soon allowing Android fans to utilize its live-video feature after first launching the service for those with Apple (AAPL) iPhones. To share reactions to Oscar winner reactions (so friends can share their Reactions), click on "What's on your mind?" in Facebook's news feed.Shares edged down 0.1% Friday after hitting a new intraday high of 117.59 on Feb. 2.

Looking beyond the defensive sectors currently showing strength, apparel has been moving up the ranks. The apparel manufacturers' industry group is still low at 138 out of 197 in Friday's IBD, but it jumped from 165 just four weeks ago. That could be signaling a turnaround play. One of the leaders of the group is Michael Kors (KORS), which was among the hottest…

Today's IBD 50 list includes four highly-rated retailers that have shown strength lately, while giants like Wal-Mart (WMT) have been losing ground.The world's largest retailer cut its full-year forecast Thursday and now sees sales coming in about flat, dashing hopes that recent initiatives would spark faster growth.Meanwhile, consumers continue to watch their budgets closely, and that's helping discount clothiers Ross Stores (ROST), Five Below (FIVE) and deep discounter Dollar General (DG) outperform the market.At the high end of the retail spectrum, shares of luxury clothing and accessories brand Michael Kors (KORS) popped 24% on Feb. 2 after it reported quarterly earnings and sales growth that easily beat Wall Street estimates.The chain is well positioned to weather the current market uncertainty and rising competition from online retailers such as Amazon.com (AMZN), Morningstar and others say."They're one of the best" traditional brick-and-mortar retailers, Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar told IBD recently, referring to Ross.Ross doesn't tout luxury brands or even have an online shop. But it's outperformed rivals in part by purchasing "packaway" inventory -- goods bought at a low price and packed away for months or years for later sale, no matter what the current fashions are.Shares have formed a deep first-stage base with a 56.78 buy point. Ross, which which will report fourth-quarter results on March 1, closed down 0.2% Friday.Teen apparel discount chain Five Below is expected to report robust holiday sales when it announces Q4 earnings next month. On Jan. 7, the company raised its guidance for the nine-week period ended Jan. 2.CEO Joel Anderson said at the time in a written statement that, "given our holiday performance, we are raising our net sales outlook for the fourth quarter to a range of $323 million to $326 million and are narrowing our earnings per share guidance range to 75 cents to 76 cents."That's up from Five Below's earlier outlook for EPS of 74-76 cents on $318 million-$323 million in revenue. Shares lost 0.2% Friday.Deep discount general merchandise retailer Dollar General has seen earnings and revenue growth fall off in recent quarters, though the company continues to show remarkable stability.That led Morgan Stanley to raise its rating on Dollar General on Feb. 16 from equal-weight to overweight.Its shares have a 93 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 93% of all stocks in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. Dollar General slipped 0.8% Friday.The outlier in the group, Michael Kors, is a leader in the luxury clothing, accessories and footwear category.In its Feb. 2 fiscal Q3 earnings announcement, Kors reported a 7.4% rise in EPS to $1.59 on a 6.2% increase in revenue to $1.397 billion. Both were an upside surprise to Wall Street.The company forecasts fiscal 2016 sales of $4.65 billion, easily topping analyst consensus for $4.42 billion.Chairman and CEO John Idol said in the earnings statement, "As we look ahead, we are excited about our upcoming Spring collections that embody design innovation and underscore Michael Kors fashion leadership." Shares fell 1%.

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) shares rocketed nearly 24% Tuesday with results that crushed views for the holiday quarter despite a challenging season for many retailers.Michael Kors' stock jumped 23.9% to 50.11 on the stock market today, after the seller of high-end accessories and clothing saw earnings for the third quarter that ended Dec. 26 rise 7% from a year earlier to $1.59 a share, sailing past analysts' views for $1.46 a share. That was a much faster gain than the prior quarter, when the company saw only a 1% rise in earnings.Rival Coach (COH) dipped 0.2% on Tuesday. But Coach had shot up 23.9% in the prior five sessions to an 8-month high after upscale handbag and apparel maker and retailer reported better-than-expected results. Kate Spade (KATE), another handbag maker rose 2.9%.Michael Kors' revenue rose 6.3% to $1.40 billion, topping forecasts for $1.36 billion. That was a slightly slower pace than the prior quarter's gain of 6%.The company said accessories and footwear helped propel its strong performance. Retail net sales increased 11.1% from a year earlier to $766.2 million, driven primarily by e-commerce sales from the company's digital flagships and 114 net new-store openings since the end of the third quarter of fiscal 2015, the company said. However, same-store sales slipped 0.9% from a year earlier.On a constant currency basis, retail net sales grew 15.7%, and comparable store sales rose 2.0%. Wholesale net sales increased 0.3% from a year earlier to $575.5 million. On a constant currency basis, sales grew 3.0%. Licensing revenue increased 8.4% to $55.8 million.Total revenue in the Americas increased 0.4% from a year earlier to $1.06 billion on a reported basis, and rose 1.4% on a constant currency basis. European revenue grew 14.3% from a year earlier to $276 million on a reported basis, and surged 29.1% on a constant currency basis. Revenue in Japan soared 59.1% from a year earlier to $25.5 million on a reported basis, and soared 68% on a constant currency basis.The company expects fourth-quarter earnings per share to be between 93 cents and 97 cents. That's less than analyst estimates of $1 per share prior to the report. The company expects fourth-quarter revenue to be between $1.13 billion and $1.15 billion. That compares with analyst forecasts for $1.16 billion.

So, this is what it's come to. The IBD 50 now includes a stock about 50% off its peak, a few utilities and a couple of real estate investment trusts. That's par for the course in a market that -- albeit in an uptrend -- continues to lack in growth leadership. Instead, more predictable and safer stocks are cropping up…

Stocks were trading significantly lower going into the noon hour Tuesday as oil plunged again, sending a barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude back near $30 a barrel. The Nasdaq fell 1%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.2% apiece. Volume was tracking heavier than the same time Monday on both exchanges in the stock…

Stock opened to modest losses Tuesday, as global markets took a breather after a strong start to the week.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each started down 0.3%. The Dow opened to a 0.2% slip.Global markets sagged Tuesday as commodities prices backed way from gains and Britain's pound rebounded from a seven-year low -- both of which helped trip rallies from Shanghai to New York on Monday.BHP Billiton (BHP), one of the leaders of the FTSE 100's rally in London Monday, reported heavier-than-expected Q4 losses and slashed its dividend.  Regulators in China also added pressure, lowering the yuan's peg vs. the dollar.Leading benchmarks in China and Japan closed lower, but held to losses of less than 1%. In Europe, benchmark indexes traded down in the 0.5% range near midday.Oil slipped 2% early in Europe's trading session, then flattened by mid-morning. West Texas Intermediate spiked 6%, to near $32 a barrel, just before 9 a.m.. Saudi Arabia oil minister Ali Al-Naimi was scheduled to speak to oil executives this morning at an oil conference in Houston.Economic news likely to affect the U.S. stock market today includes Case-Shiller's 20-City Composite Home Price Index for December, due out at 9 a.m. ET. At 10 a.m., the Conference Board releases its February consumer confidence data and  the National Association of Realtors reports January existing home sales numbers.More than two-thirds of Dow stocks were in the red in premarket trade. But Home Depot (HD) lumbered ahead 4% after reporting a 17% gain in Q4 earnings, and a 9% revenue gain, both ahead of expectations.Management also boosted its full-year revenue guidance above consensus forecasts. Home Depot shares have been correcting since December, and caught below resistance at its 10-week moving average since early February.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) was the Dow's weakest stock, down 1% before the open. The managed care provider jumped 3% in rising volume on Monday.Western Digital (WDC) dropped 9% after announcing China-based Unisplendour had backed out of a $3.78 billion investment in the company.The change sends the $19 billion effort to merge with data storage peer Sandisk (SNDK) to plan B, which decreases the transaction's cash, raises the stock-per-share equation, and requires Western shareholders to approve the combination. SanDisk shares dropped 5% in premarket trade.Motorola (MSI) and Macy's (M) sparked up 6% each after healthy Q4 reports.In the IBD 50 stables, the few stocks posting premarket gains held to moves of less than 0.5%.Losses were also mild, led by Michael Kors (KORS), which slipped almost 2%, and Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), with a 1% decline.Kors rose 4% in above-average trade Monday to 57% above a late January low, in an advance that is being cradled by the stock's 10-day moving average. Shares ended the session still 46% below a February 2014 high.Ryanair dropped 2% in heavy trade Monday. That put shares back below their 50-day moving average, which could present the stock with resistance. But the chart shows a possible cup-base forming, and the stock is in the proper range to add a handle to that cup.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Being fashionably late may earn you cool points, but blowing off EBITDA margin targets by a whole year can make investors lose interest — fast.Kate Spade (KATE) shares raced out 10% to a 7-year-high 42.87 on the stock market today thanks to better-than-expected earnings and sales growth. But shares quickly reversed during the analyst conference call as margin discussions raised concerns. Shares closed down 25% to 29, well below their 200-day moving average and at 6-month lows.The handbag and fashion brand is reportedly rethinking its 2016 adjusted EBITDA margin guidance for 25% or more, and may push that goal from 2016 to 2017.The recently introduced Kate Spade Saturday brand, a less pricey alternative to the company's signature handbags and accessories, prompted gross profit as a percentage of net sales to dip to 58.6% from 61.8% a year ago. The more affordable line may be experiencing some growing pains."The timing of the 25% margin goal (shift) is entirely related to Saturday," said analyst Jim Chartier of Monness, Crespi, Hardt & Co."It's not the core brand. That brand is exceeding that target and exceeding internal expectations. It's really due to Kate Spade Saturday," echoes Imperial Capital analyst Mary Ross-Gilbert. "And having to make a greater investment in that brand, having to tweak that assortment, it's a lower margin business."Kate Spade's comparable direct-to-consumer net sales grew 30.4% in Q2, but are only expected to be in the high single digits in the back half of the year due to several factors, including fewer flash sales, a shift in the company's July Fourth sale into Q2 from Q3, and a number of store renovations, she said.Kate Spade before the open reported Q2 results that topped expectations. Earnings rose to 5 cents a share from a year-earlier loss of 12 cents a share. Revenue leapt 49% to $266 million, the second straight quarter of accelerating growth.If fickle fashionistas can see past the near term, these growing pains will eventually even out, say analysts. The company will meet its goals, but on a delayed timeline."I don't think it's a change in long-term fundamentals," agreed Chartier, "just a resetting of investor expectations."But Kate Spade's rise and reversal bring uncomfortable parallels to Michael Kors (KORS). The highflying fashion house in late May reported strong earnings and sales, but a dip in retail operating margins. The stock rallied the first day, but then tumbled the next session, and continued to trend low until the next report — when Kors suggested that markdowns are taking their toll.Kors shares fell 3.2% Tuesday.Meanwhile, Coach (COH), which was once a fashion stock leader, is still trying to stop the bleeding on sales and profit.Coach shares fell less than 1%.After the market close, watch and accessories maker and retailer Fossil (FOSL), reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings and sales. But it guided Q3 EPS estimates lower. Fossil,which makes watches under various brands such as Michael Kors, fell 4% late after closing down nearly 1%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter at IBD_Elow.
History's greatest stocks ride a supply and demand story.
If the demand for shares far exceeds the supply, the share price will rise, often to sustained gains.
This is why the S for Supply is a part of CAN SLIM. Let's look at six ways the S factor can help define a stock's true situation.

• No. 1. An overwhelming supply makes big moves hard to create. "It's hard to budge the price of a stock that has 5 billion shares outstanding because the supply is so large," IBD founder and Chairman William J. O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks."

The table at the right shows how true the observation is. The 14 stocks are the stocks in IBD's database with a float of 5 billion shares or more. How many have been market leaders in the past decade? Only one, Apple (AAPL).
• No. 2. The composition of the supply also matters. Companies in which CEOs have a significant stake do better than those in which CEOs have no skin in the game.

Executives who have no skin in the game are like politicians: It's easy to do dumb things with other people's money. Exposure adds pressure, and even a sharp mind runs a little sharper when the risks are personal.

• No. 3. Excessive stock splits affect supply. Some people believe splits help fuel gains because they make the stock seem affordable. IBD research doesn't support that notion. "Our study of the biggest winners found that only 18% of them had splits in the year preceding their great price advances," O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks."

• No. 4. Secondary offerings can work in a stock's favor — provided the cash goes to the company and is used for something dynamic. However, if the secondary offering is designed to help management dump shares, then that can hurt a stock and sometimes dilute shares by increasing the float.

Michael Kors (KORS) announced secondary offerings in March 2012, September 2012 and February 2013. Corrections from the closing price on the day of the announced offering were 28% over three months, 17% over two months and 20% over two months.
• No. 5. Corporate buybacks can shrink the supply of traded shares, creating a bullish balance between supply and demand. Buybacks also boost earnings per share and can even drive the market higher.
Research from Ed Yardeni of Yardeni Research and Jeffrey Kleintop of LPL Financial note buybacks as the chief driver of the bull run that began in 2009.

• No. 6. Trading volume remains the investor's most timely clue to supply. Learning how to read charts is a crucial skill.History's greatest stocks ride a supply and demand story.If the demand for shares far exceeds the supply, the share price will rise, often to sustained gains.This is why the S for Supply is a part of CAN SLIM. Unlike some of her peers, discounted merchandise hasn't cheapened the Kate Spade (KATE) brand. The purse maker's second-quarter earnings rose to 5 cents a share, reversing from a year-earlier 12-cent per-share loss, according to Thomson Reuters. Analysts had expected 0 cent for the quarter. Revenue jumped 49% to $266 million, beating views for $237.8 million. It was the second straight…

Stock futures burrowed into widening losses in premarket trade Tuesday, as oil prices slipped and earnings reports tripped a number of significant early moves. Dow futures were on the downtick, 0.9% below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were off 0.7%. Nasdaq 100 futures slipped 0.5%. Small caps outpaced the general declines, putting Russell 2000 futures down 1.3%. Stocks ended…

Stocks took a sharp step down early Tuesday, with oil prices, overseas action and earnings news factoring into early trade. The Dow and the S&P 500 each tumbled 1.6%. The Nasdaq slipped 1.2%. Small caps also felt the heat, with the Russell 2000 down 1.6%. Automakers were reporting sales for January -- traditionally the slowest month of the year for…

Facebook (FB), Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) are among stocks that would hold up well if the U.S. economy goes into recession, a Goldman Sachs report said.Although Goldman didn't say it's looking for a recession, and many economists say recession is still a remote possibility, the list comes amid recent red flags that some analysts have said could augur recession.Railroad shipments -- a forward-looking indicator -- have fallen amid unstable economic conditions. Industrial production has also been weak, and the strong dollar has hit exporters.David Kostin, Goldman Sachs' chief U.S. equity analyst, came up with the recommendations for recession stocks on the assumption that strong balance sheets and high domestics sales should outperform in a downturn, according to Bloomberg.In addition to Facebook, Starbucks and Visa, Goldman also named Alphabet (GOOGL,), Whole Foods Market (WFM), which continues to benefit from the trend in the U.S. toward healthy food, industrial giant 3M (MMM) and Verizon Communications (VZ), the top wireless service provider.Facebook closed up 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks rose 1.5%, Visa ticked 0.2% higher, and Alphabet rose less than 0.1%. Whole Foods ended up 0.9%, while 3M surged 5.2% after reporting strong earnings Tuesday.Verizon last Thursday reported that Q4 EPS shot up 25%  to 89 cents on a 3.2% rise in revenue to $34.25 billion, both topping estimates. Shares gained 2.6% Tuesday.Facebook reports Wednesday, and consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share to rise 26% to 68 cents a share on a 40% jump in revenue to $5.37 billion.Visa will report Thursday, and analysts see EPS up 8% to 68 cents on a 7% hike in revenue to $3.62 billion.Chipotle (CMG), Marathon Petroleum (MRO) and Michael Kors (KORS) made it on Goldman's list despite coming under major pressure recently.Chipotle's sales and stock have plunged since an E. coli outbreak at some locations. Marathon has sold off along with the rest of the energy sector as oil prices sank. And Michael Kors has been in an extended slide amid a shift in consumer tastes.On Tuesday, Chipotle shares rose 1.35%, Marathon rallied 3.8%, and Michael Kors rose climbed 2.9%.

Shuttered malls are so commonplace that there's an entire website dedicated to the string of "dead malls" across the country. But a "more benign environment," pent-up demand and easy year-over-year comparisons should give some retail chains a much-needed "opportunity for fundamental acceleration" this year, wrote Jefferies retail analysts Randal Konik and Edward Plank on Monday, calling out Tiffany & Co.[ticker…

Fossil (FOSL) said late Thursday that it was acquiring Fitbit (FIT) rival Misfit, but concerns about the impact of the Apple (AAPL) Watch and other wearables sent the watchmaker's stock crashing to a five-year low.Shares plummeted 36.5% to 32.39 by the close in the stock market today. Fossil stock has been in a downtrend for the past two years.Fossil, which launched its first connected-accessories line last month, said the $260 million Misfit buy will help position it to "win the connected consumer." But the acquisition was not enough to win over analysts.Cowen analyst Oliver Chen lowered his price target to 42 from 51 on further "downside potential" despite Fossil's "best-in-class multibrand portfolio, supply chain and distribution."Jefferies analyst Randal Konik slashed his price target to 68 from 90. While he remains bullish on the company's long-term story, several factors — including licensed-watch portfolio weakness and a "continued wall of worry over the Apple Watch" — prompted the cut."Our view has always been that the Apple Watch is not going to destroy the traditional watch market," he wrote. "Nevertheless, there are clear signs that wearable tech is gaining traction and changing the environment."Echoing what other analysts have said in the past, Konik believes that Fossil could benefit from the rise of wearables as new customers enter the marketplace. He also points out that minus its Kors segment (Fossil makes watches for Michael Kors (KORS), Fossil actually outperformed the overall U.S. watch market in Q3, "demonstrating that the company is still well-positioned to gain share."Fossil's Q3 earnings fell 39% to $1.19 a share, topping forecasts by 6 cents, but revenue missed consensus views for $794.4 million, sinking 14% to $771.3 million on a decline in its licensed-watch portfolio and currency headwinds.The company also cut its 2015 adjusted diluted EPS outlook to $5.60-6.20 from $6.20-$7.00.Fitbit, Apple Also Lose Key SupportFitbit shares fell 12% to a record low Friday after pricing a follow-on stock offering at 29 apiece, below Thursday's 31.68 closing price. Fitbit cut the number of shares it was selling to 3 million from 7 million. Existing shareholders sold 14 million Fitbit shares. It's unclear how much the Fossil-Misfit buy was pressuring Fitbit stock.Apple stock dropped 2.9%, undercutting its 50-day moving average. Wall Street analysts estimate that 6 million Apple Watch units were sold in Q2 and Q3 combined.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Apple Watch dominates, but new competition comingFossil Already Feeling The Heat From Apple Watch?

Chop, Chop, Chop.......and that is what stocks did again yesterday.....disappointing news from Macy's (M) (sent that stock down 13% ),  a lead article in the WSJ highlighting the headwinds that retailers face and weaker oil all factors in helping to push stocks lower. Unsold goods are beginning to pile up on the shelves.........and with retail sales numbers due tomorrow - this could prove to be a worrisome trend.... A glut - in the retail industry is NOT a good thing......Glut -  is defined as 'an excessive supply' - (think oil glut or housing glut or Merchandise glut).......  A glut is not necessarily a bad...I guess it depends on which side of that glut you are on......

For consumers - a merchandise glut - will be a win, win....Expect to see those "Everything MUST go signs....' or 'Super Sale' or 'Take an extra 30% off already discounted prices'.....well you get it right.....Retail analysts around the street are already prepping for weak results.......Macy's, Kohl's  (KSS), Michael Kors  (KORS), Ralph Lauren  (RL).....all experiencing slower sales leaving some 'extra merchandise' on the shelves..... department stores have a 'little bit' more than they want......Specialty stores experiencing slight 'build up' in inventories.......so the group comes under pressure...... (Notice all the adjectives suggest no big deal.....little bit, slight build up, extra merchandise).  None of them are telling us the truth......and Macy's laid it out yesterday......They are seeing an emerging consumer recession.....retailers will most likely take it on the chin this Christmas......

The SPDR S&P Retail ETF, (XRT) lays it out clearly...this  ETF is down 5.6% in 5 days.... and is down some 12% since the summer highs...(individual names have experienced even more dramatic moves).    Names like Lululemon (LULU), Nike (NKE), Under Armour  (UA), VF Corp  (VFC), Macy's, Kohl's, Nordstroms (JWN), DSW  (DSW), The Gap  (GPS), etc......all under pressure as we move into the most significant time of the year for these companies....expectations for a strong holiday shopping season may be a 'little bit' overdone.....so for stock investors in those names - it's a bit tough, for those companies - it's a bit tough,   but for consumers - the sales will create a frenzy of opportunity for more stuff you most likely DON'T really need.....but can't justify leaving on the shelf...I mean - It's On Sale!

And therein lies the opportunity for longer term investors.....retail stocks have been are ON SALE - But we have not seen the 'EVERYTHING MUST GO' signs just yet......but it is coming....and that will surely signal the bottom.........In the meantime - maybe, just maybe - the action in the retailers is challenging what those analysts  are telling us.....maybe the action is forewarning us of tougher times ahead?  Next up - and not new to the conversation at all.....OIL.......the mkt continues to be undermined by weak oil prices - U.S. crude stockpiles jumped by 6.3 million barrels last week.  Furthermore, Iraq - is sending some 19 million barrels supply directly to US ports this month.....This news caused oil prices to fall $1.28 to $42.93 - readying to test the October lows at $42.58. If the October lows in oil get violated - my sense is that the broader mkt  will not like that......

Which brings us right back to the FED......How is this idea of a rate hike going to work out - when it feels like the consumer is exhausted, the macro data does not support real strength, the dollar continues to move higher creating more distress and the ECB this morning hints of MORE stimulus to a struggling European economy?   This morning European mkts are all lower -  Uncle Mario hints at more stimulus......warning that"the signs of a sustained turnaround in core inflation had weakened...... Downside risks stemming from global growth and trade are clearly visible in the Euro zone."

while reminding us that the ECB still has a "range of instruments available in case more accommodation should be seen as necessary" And the mkts turn south.....at the same time - Rolls Royce cuts its 2016 forecast causing that stock to give up 20% in just a few clicks......FTSE -0.52%, CAC 40 - 0.86%, DAX - 0.40%, EUROSTOXX -0.62%, SPAIN -0.88% and ITALY -0.76%. Here at home - we have  full day of FED speakers....It kicks off with Bullard (9:05 a.m. ET), Yellen (9:30 a.m. ET), Lacker (9:45 a.m. ET), Evans (10:15 a.m. ET), Dudley (11:45 a.m. ET), and Fischer (6:00 p.m. ET).  Eco data includes Init Jobless Claims - exp of 270K, Cont Claims 2,155 mil, and the JOLTS report of 5.4 mil supposed job openings.......

Tomorrow retail sales are expected to show +0.3%, ex autos & gas of +0.4% - a miss will surely send those stocks lower.....and any upside surprise will ignite the algos causing any sellers left to get out of the way......And we will be off to the races......US futures are flat and trading will be driven by all the sure to be conflicting FED comments....Support continues to be at 2065 on the S&P with resistance at 2100.  No reason to break either way - just yet....Take good care. Kp

Today we'll look at Michael Kors (KORS) which designs, markets, and distributes luxury men's and women's designer goods, such as clothing, handbags, wallets, footwear, watches, and fragrances. The firm has a presence in over 85 countries, with more than 231 North American stores, and over 73 international locations. Key Fundamentals In the most recent quarter, earnings showed a nice jump…

Restoration Hardware (RH), Under Armour (UA) and Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) were likely among the retailers that saw a pickup in business last week as consumers stepped up the spending pace on items ranging from furniture to clothing, leading to a rise in a key chain-store gauge released Tuesday, and some retailer stocks also rose. The International Council of Shopping…

Michael Kors (KORS) strutted out much-better-than-expected earnings and sales growth Monday morning, but the reviews were unkind as Wall Street focused on increased markdowns taking their toll on profit margins — and Kors' outlook.The affordable luxury fashion house's earnings rose 49% to 91 cents a share, topping views for 81 cents. Revenue leapt 43% to $919.2 million vs. views of $851.7 million.But rapid expansion may be reducing Kors' brand exclusivity. Retail operating profit margin fell to 29.7% from 31.7% a year earlier, though that was a smaller decline than in its fiscal Q4. Kors has had to mark down prices on handbags, clothing and other products.The company sees Q2 retail gross margins declining by 50 basis points.Kors expects Q2 EPS of 85-87 cents, with revenue of $950 million to $960 million. That's below the forecasts of analysts, who project EPS of 89 cents on $959.5 million in revenue.Kors shares retreated 5.9% to 77.01 on the the stock market today, hitting a six-month low of 75.13 intraday. The stock has been retreating for the past several months, following margin concerns in its fiscal Q4 report.Several analysts, including Baird, Sterne Agee and Citigroup, had recently cut price targets on concerns that the bag maker's luxury halo was dimming.Wholesale sales rose 40% to $406.8 million, and licensing was up 30.5% to $32.1 million.But retail sales shot up 47.5% to $80.2 million, thanks to 115 net new stores and a 24.2% rise in same-store sales, the company said. As of June 28, there are 443 Kors retail stores, up from 328 last year. There were 605 total Kors stores globally as of the end of Q1."We saw continued strength across our retail, wholesale, and licensing segments, as well as in both the North American and International markets during the first quarter," said CEO John D. Idol."In North America, revenue increased 30%, with comparable store sales growth of 18.7%." He added that revenue grew 128% in Europe, as the company saw a 54.2% boost in same-store sales in the region. Japanese revenue rose 89%, with same-store sales growing 48.8%.Meanwhile Coach (COH), which has suffered sharply lower profit and sales in the face of Kors competition, reports quarterly results Tuesday. The handbag and accessories maker is trying to overhaul its sales strategy and fashion line, but that will take time. Coach shares rose 1.8% to 34.31, but are essentially trading at four-year lows.Kate Spade (KATE) fell 17 cents to 37.44.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter at IBD_Elow.

Upscale fashion companies Kate Spade (KATE) and Ralph Lauren (RL) gapped up after reporting strong quarterly results that indicated their turnaround efforts might be working. The results come after Michael Kors (KORS) on Wednesday beat fiscal second-quarter estimates and detailed plans to improve its weakened brand image. Kate Spade, which has moved away from the less profitable handbag space, reported…

Struggling fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) showed Wednesday it might still have some spark left as it beat analyst views on second-quarter results and disclosed plans to improve its weakened brand image, moves which sent shares of the once-hot company soaring. Kors leapt by nearly 14% at one point during trading on the stock market today. At the market close,…

Coach (COH) reported a profit decline that was not as steep as expected amid the fashion house's continuing turnaround efforts. Earnings fell 23% to 41 cents a share, a penny over views and an improvement over the previous five quarters' declines that ranged from 31% to 47%. Revenue missed analyst forecasts for $1.04 billion, sliding a little less than 1%…
Stock futures pointed sharply higher, but were off their early highs ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, following some mixed early economic news and as markets rallied in Europe.

Dow futures steered up 118.7 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures traded 25.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.1-point gain. Small caps were positive and steady, with Russell 2000 futures holding a 4-point gain.

The stock market today opens with a two-day rally under its belt, with both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending higher in their trading ranges on Tuesday. Both indexes remain below their 50-day moving averages, although the Nasdaq is positioned for a possible test of that line this week.

Personal spending rose 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, a welcome improvement from October's zero-gain showing and in line with economist expectations. Personal incomes rose 0.3%, a tad below October's 0.4% gain but better than views for a 0.2% advance.

Durable goods orders were flat for the month, sharply below October's (downwardly revised) 2.9% gain, but better than the 0.5% contraction projected by economist consensus. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.
At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.
The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.

Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.

Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.

In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.

Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).

Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.

Micron Technology (MU) tanked 7%, hurt by fiscal Q1 earnings results delivered late Tuesday. Tesla Motors (TSLA) shares fell Wednesday as more analysts wondered about the pricing of the Model X and GoPro (GPRO) had its price target cut.Robert Baird downgraded Tesla to neutral from outperform and cut its price target to 282 from 335.Baird said it was moving to the sidelines on Tesla as there was "limited visibility to positive catalysts until the release of the Model III prototype" and the analysts had to change their expectations on the automaker after pricing in the Model X.On Tuesday Morgan Stanley cut its Model X delivery forecast because the new car is pricier than expected.Tesla shares fell 3.9% to close at 231.96 in the stock market today, closing just above its 200-day moving average.Morgan Stanley cut the price target on camera maker GoPro to 35. GoPro shares plunged 4.3% to close at 29.33.Citigroup initiated coverage on yoga apparel maker Lululemon Athletica (LULU) with a buy rating and 69 price target. Lululemon shares rose 4.4% to 54.00.Citi also started coverage on affordable luxury label Michael Kors (KORS) with a sell rating and 38 price target. Michael Kors shares fell 1.5% to 42.72.Adobe Systems' (ADBE) price target was increased to 87 from 82 by FBR Capital. Late Tuesday Adobe Systems forecast fiscal 2016 revenue of $5.7 billion and non-GAAP earnings of $2.70 per share. Both numbers were well below Wall Street estimates.Adobe shares fell 5.3% to 80.65.Shale oil firm Oasis Petroleum's (OAS) price target was cut to 18 from 20 by Topeka Capital Markets.Oasis shares closed down 4.4% to 12.89.On Tuesday OPEC said it expects global oil investments to fall by $130 billion this year amid continued low oil prices and the U.S. Energy Information Administration raised its 2015 and 2016 global oil demand growth outlooks.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter @IBD_GRich.

U.S. teens still love Apple (AAPL), but they're like so over GoPro (GPRO), according to a new survey. Piper Jaffray surveyed 9,400 teens nationwide for its semiannual Taking Stock With Teens poll. It released the results late Tuesday.Apple iPhone ownership and purchase interest remain high among teens, the investment bank said.The fall survey showed that 67% of U.S. teens own an iPhone, up from 66% in the spring. Also, 74% of teens expect their next phone to be an iPhone vs. 72% in the spring survey.On the negative side, Apple Watch purchase intent declined to 8% in the fall survey, vs. 11% in the spring and 16% in fall 2014. Some 5% of teens say they own an Apple Watch, implying 55% market share among early smartwatch adopters, Piper Jaffray said.Apple climbed one spot to the No. 5 ranking for preferred watch brands among teens from upper-income households. The top watch brands are, in descending order, Rolex, Michael Kors (KORS), Casio, Fossil (FOSL) and Apple, Piper Jaffray said. Apple was No. 6 in the spring survey.Still, just 4.8% of upper-income teens picked Apple as their preferred watch brand. That's up from 2.7% in the spring and 1.2% from fall 2014.GoPro Demand Slowing With TeensThe teen survey offered downbeat data for action-camera maker GoPro.GoPro is still top-of-mind among teens, but purchase intent is decelerating, Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said in a report. In the fall survey, 1.1% of teens listed a GoPro as a top-two gift wish this upcoming holiday season, a deceleration from 1.6% in the spring.Family ownership of GoPro cameras is at 19.8% now vs. 17.9% in the spring survey, she said.Murphy downgraded GoPro stock late Tuesday to neutral from overweight, based in part on the survey results. She also slashed her price target to 25 from 54.Earlier Tuesday, Dougherty & Co. analyst Charles Anderson hacked his price target on GoPro stock to 32 from 70 on signs of weakening demand for GoPro cameras. However, he reiterated his buy rating on the stock based on valuation."While we believe in the GoPro brand and its ability to engage consumers through the stickiness of its content," Murphy said in her report, "we see near-term risk tied to the following: 1) consumer demand softening (signaled by teen survey); 2) recent pricing reductions that could cause gross margins to normalize (long-term plan: 42-44%); and 3) weakening trends in GoPro index on Amazon."Amazon Climbs Higher In SurveyAmazon.com (AMZN) remained the favorite e-commerce website for upper-income U.S. teens. It was the choice of 38.3% of such teens in the latest survey, up from 36.3% in the spring and 32.1% last fall. Nike (NKE) is a distant second at 8%.Penetration of Amazon Prime in households with teens rose to 47% this fall from 43% in the spring. Usage of the subscription program, which offers free two-day shipping and streaming video, is higher among those households with more income. For instance, 66% of households with incomes of $125,000 or greater subscribe to Amazon Prime, up from 63% in the spring.Instagram, Snapchat HotFacebook (FB)-owned Instagram was the top social network for teens at 33%, followed by Twitter (TWTR) (20%) and Snapchat (19%). Facebook ranked fourth at 15%.Instagram and Snapchat have seen rapid growth among teen users, while Facebook has been on a precipitous decline.Asked about the most-anticipated movie in the next 12 months, "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 2" from Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) was picked as No. 1 by 24% of teens."Star Wars: The Force Awakens" from Walt Disney (DIS) came in second at 16%, followed by "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice" and "The Divergent Series: Allegiant," each with 12% of votes.RELATED:Headphones, tablets top planned holiday 2015 gifts.

After a long growth spurt that outpaced other retail categories, handbags have lost the lead among women to dining and travel categories, according to a report out Wednesday from RBC Capital Markets. It may be a case of closets overstuffed with too many handbags, at least the kind of so-called affordable-luxury bags sold by fashion brands Michael Kors (KORS), Coach[ticker…

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) has been one of the retail sector's top performers this year, with an IBD Composite Rating of 97, a rapidly rising stock price and a knack for delivering robust earnings growth and grabbing market share. You can expect the retailer of cosmetics and salon products to keep up the growth pace as it introduces brands like Lancome…

Investors pumped up shares of struggling Vera Bradley (VRA) nearly 28% to 13.32 in the stock market today after the handbag company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue in the second quarter.Net income totaled $5.7 million, or 15 cents per share, 5 cents above Wall Street views, but still down 21% from last year's same period. Revenue rose 1.5% to $120.7 million, above the firm's prior forecast of $116-$120 million and above analysts' estimate for $115 million.Still, same-store sales, including e-commerce, fell 15% in the quarter, partially due to reduced promotional activity, the company said. But CEO Robert Wallstrom said comparable sales began to improve at the end of the Aug. 1-ended Q2, a positive change he attributed to new product offerings, improved in-store execution and initial marketing efforts."We have made meaningful progress but know our turnaround will take time," he stated.Vera Bradley sells handbags, luggage and other accessories at full-line Vera Bradley stores and at factory outlets in the U.S. and at 2,700 specialty retail locations, mostly in the U.S., as well as some department stores.The company said it expects third-quarter revenue of $120 million to $123 million, down from $125.2 million last year, and earnings of 19-21 cents per share, about flat from a year ago. Gross margin is seen rising from 52.5% last year to 56.8%-57.2%.For the full year, the company expects to earn 72-78 cents per share, down from $1 last year, on revenue of $487 million to $495 million, down from last year's $509 million. But gross margin is seen rising to 56.2%-56.4% from last year's 52.9%.Vera Bradley shares had been trending down for more than a year, and were especially hit hard after the last two disappointing earnings reports. Other fashion handbag and accessories companies have also struggled, including Michael Kors (KORS), Kate Spade (KATE) and Coach (COH), which is also attempting a turnaround.Michael Kors and Kate Spade closed up 4% and 3.1%, respectively, Wednesday. Coach ended 0.7% higher.

As if its stock hadn't been sinking enough since December, contemporary apparel and handbag company Vince Holding (VNCE) plunged 43.5% Friday to 5.24 after it reported a 50% drop in earnings and continued problems in its wholesale and off-price channels. From its initial public offering price of 20 in November 2013, Vince had traded as high as 39.08 a year…

G-III Apparel (GIII) — whose licensed brands include Calvin Klein, Levi's and Kenneth Cole — beat quarterly earnings and sales views and raised its full-year earnings guidance, though its stock price was down in midday trading.

The New York-based clothing manufacturer and distributor's fiscal Q2 earnings climbed 93% to 27 cents a share, above consensus estimates of 20 cents. Sales gained 12% to $474 million, topping views for $470 million.

G-III also raised its full-year EPS guidance to a range of $2.78 to $2.88 from its previous range of $2.66 to $2.76. Prior to G-III's Q2 report, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected full-year earnings of $2.75 a share.
In a statement, G-III CEO Morris Goldfarb said growth in the quarter "was driven by increases in our wholesale segment and an increase in comparable store sales from our G.H. Bass stores."
Despite the gains, G-III's stock price fell 3% in midday trading on the stock market today.
Meanwhile, shares of fellow apparel manufacturers Under Armour (UA) and Michael Kors (KORS) moved higher.
Like those and other stocks in IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group, G-III's share price is still trying to rebound from last week's broader market sell-off.

G-III sells everything from swimwear and accessories to outerwear and performance wear under its own Vilebrequin, Andrew Marc and Marc New York brands and has licenses under numerous other brands, including Calvin Klein, Levi's, Kenneth Cole, Karl Lagerfeld, Guess, Jessica Simpson and Tommy Hilfiger.
The company has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99, putting it atop the Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group. Other leaders include Carters (CRI), Under Armour and Oxford Industries (OXM).
Shares of Oxford, which reports Q2 results late Wednesday, were up 2.1% midday.

Fitbit (FIT) is expanding the retail distribution of its activity trackers by adding Macy's (M) stores to its lineup.
Macy's is rolling out Fitbit devices to its stores nationwide, Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said in a report Monday.
The distribution arrangement with Macy's is a "significant catalyst near term" for Fitbit in the fall and holiday shopping seasons, Murphy said.

Fitbit will be in about 650 Macy's stores before the holidays, she said. Her checks indicate that nearly 75% of Macy's stores are already selling Fitbit devices. She called it a "compelling new channel of domestic distribution" for Fitbit.

"Fitbit displays vary by location (within Macy's) but include displays within the fashion watch, men's and athletic departments," Murphy said. "Macy's will serve as an incremental point of distribution domestically and complement Kohl's (KSS), from a department store perspective which has carried Fitbit for 12 to 18 months."
Fitbit displays in Macy's could have a negative impact on sales of Fossil (FOSL) and Michael Kors (KORS) watches, she said.
Murphy rates Fitbit stock as overweight and Fossil and Kors as underweight.
Fitbit shares fell as low as 30.51 intraday, closing down 3.3% to 37.36. Macy's lost 3.5% to 57.12. Fossil slid 2.1% and Michael Kors 5%.

Traditional watch sales and Fitbit (FIT) numbers offer clues into how many Apple (AAPL) watches have been sold. Apple has kept under wraps the number of its smartwatches sold, but Bloomberg estimates that the tech giant has sold at least 1.9 million of the timepieces since their debut in March, based on reported revenue from the unit.
Sales of traditional watches also could help in estimating the number of watches sold. June watch sales fell 11% vs. a year ago as retailers sold $375 million in watches, according to the NPD Group.
"The Apple Watch is going to gain a significant amount of penetration," NPD's Fred Levin told Bloomberg. "The first couple of years will be difficult for watches in fashion categories."
Fossil (FOSL), which makes watches under its own brand and for Michael Kors (KORS), could take the biggest hit from Apple. Fossil reports earnings on Tuesday.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see Fossil's Q2 earnings falling 16.3% to 82 cents per share. Revenue is expected to fall 3.2% to $748.98 million for the first decline in years.
Michael Kors reported lower earnings and same-store sales last week.
Apple shares climbed 3.6% to close at 119.72 in the stock market today after losing 4.8% last week. Fossil shares closed up 0.4% to 64.52. Kors shares rose 3.3% to 45.27.

Watches under $1,000 are the most at risk of losing share to Apple, according to the report, as shoppers in that price range said they were the likeliest to buy an Apple Watch. Apple's low-end aluminum Sports model starts at $349 and the stainless-steel version starts at $549.

Fitbit numbers could be another clue for Apple Watch sales. The maker of fitness trackers said it sold 4.5 million devices in Q2, which was above the consensus estimate of 3.9 million. The Apple Watch also features a fitness and health tracker.
Fitbit shares ended the day up 1.1% to 43.15. Despite reporting strong numbers and guidance, the June IPO fell 14% on Thursday and 4% on Friday after spiking to a record high ahead of results.

Master This Sell Rule: Investing Tips On When To Sell Stocks

Riding stock price gains higher may be a piece of cake for most investors, but figuring out when to jump off is much tougher. After all, no one likes to wonder if any money got left on the table. That's why basic sell strategies such as the 20% to 25% profit-taking rule exist. This is a fairly predictable, tried and true method for locking in gains.

But for investors who have conviction that a stock has the potential to keep rising to even bigger gains, there are additional ways to help determine when it might be time to sell. Today's column focuses on a defensive sell signal: a sharp close below an uptrend line drawn on a weekly chart.

A stock that has been rallying for well over a year is bound to digest its gains. To help figure out if a stock's long uptrend might be starting to weaken, draw a trend line connecting at least three lows over a period of at least 18 weeks. The longer the trend line and the more lows you connect, the more reliable the line will be.

If the stock falls through the trend line, that's a red flag signaling a major trend shift is under way or may be about to occur. A breach of the trend line will often coincide with other sell signals, such as a break below the 10-week moving average.
If an investor doesn't act, downside risk may only grow.

Michael Kors (KORS), a December 2011 IPO, came public amid great fanfare, soaring 21% on its first day of trading. Shares of the fashion house had priced at 20 a share. After breaking out from a series of bases over the next few years, Kors hit a high of 101.04 the week ended Feb. 28, 2014.
Quarterly EPS growth was still solid, but had started to slow down from the mostly triple-digit gains of 2012 and early 2013.

Kors shares formed a cup-shaped base that featured more down weeks than up weeks in heavy trade. The stock added a handle with a 99.06 buy point. But the stock never broke out. It instead headed south.

If you drew a trend line connecting the lows from April 2013 to May 2014, you'd see how Kors fell 6% the week ended June 20, breaching not only the trend line but also the 10-week moving average in huge trade (1). Investors should have locked in gains on that dual signal. Those who didn't would've seen Kors sink further below the 10-week line for three more weeks, then really dive in huge trade (2).Master This Sell Rule: Investing Tips On When To Sell StocksRiding stock price gains higher may be a piece of cake for most investors, but figuring out when to jump off is much tougher. Coach (COH) continues its turnaround journey as the fashion house guided far above full-year revenue estimates and sees a return to positive North American comparisons by the end of fiscal 2016.
Shares of the maker of leather handbags and accessories peaked at 32.42 in morning trade but by midafternoon had eased to 30.80, up 1.2% in the stock market today.

Excluding transformation-related charges and acquisition costs, Q4 earnings topped forecasts by 2 cents but fell more than 47% to 31 cents. Revenue dipped almost 12% to $1 billion, helped by its May buyout of Stuart Weitzman. Analysts had expected $973 million.
Including one-time charges, Coach earned $11.7 million in Q4 net income on a GAAP basis, or 4 cents a share, compared with $75.2 million net income, or 27 cents a share, in Q4 2014.
As the brand works to maintain relevance with the fashion-savvy set, the early results of its transformation can be seen in its new designs and "modern luxury" concept store renovations.

CEO Victor Luis said Tuesday that the global introduction of its new concept stores will accelerate, and Coach will have a presence at New York Fashion Week next month, debuting a 75th anniversary collection that will hit shelves in February.
"Taken together, these initiatives are expected to drive a return to top line growth in FY16 and positive North American comps by the end of the year," he said.
During Q4, North American sales plunged 20%, a slight quarter-over-quarter improvement from Q3's 24% decline. Direct-to-consumer sales also fell 20%.
North American same-store sales in domestic stores fell 19% as Coach tamps down "eOutlet" events and promotional activity.
Internationally, overall sales fell 5%. China sales growth slowed from the previous quarter, rising only 5% as comps declined slightly. (In Q3, China sales rose 8% with positive comps.)
Japan sales fell 15% on the strong dollar.

For fiscal 2016, Coach sees its stand-alone brand revenue rising by "low-single digits" on a constant currency basis, with the expectation that currency woes will weigh on revenue growth by 200 basis points.
Including anticipated Stuart Weitzman brand sales of $335 million, Coach expects total revenue to grow in the "high-single digits."
Wall Street expects a 1% rise to revenue of $4.23 billion for the year.
Cantor Fitzgerald upgraded Coach to hold from sell on Tuesday, boosting its price target on the stock to 33 from 31.
Coach's makeover has been rather well-received so far.

"We view transformation efforts positively and are especially encouraged by outperformance of remodeled stores (comping positive), which should further boost sales as the company expects 40% of store base to be in the new concept by the end of FY16 (vs. 15% today)," wrote Jefferies analyst Randal Konik in a Tuesday note.
"Plus, we think new plans to introduce a modern-luxury sales associate uniform and Craftsmanship Bar dovetail nicely with other brand-elevating initiatives."
Wedbush called the last quarter a "challenging" one for handbags as department stores such as Macy's (M) ramped up sales and discounts.

"KORS has the highest direct exposure to the wholesale channel (nearly 50% of its North American sales), but beyond channel exposure, higher promotions at department stores and a slowing of the category in general also led to sluggish sales and increased discounting at retail locations," said Wedbush analyst Morry Brown in an Aug. 2 note.
When Michael Kors (KORS) reports Q1 results Thursday before the open, Wall Street anticipates earnings to fall almost 18% to 75 cents a share on a 3% revenue rise to $944 million.
Peer Kate Spade (KATE) discloses Q2 earnings before the market opens Wednesday. Analysts expect earnings to more than double to 11 cents a share on a 10% revenue climb to $293 million.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Fossil (FOSL) didn't mention Apple (AAPL) by name, but the watch maker said new competitors are making this year a tough one. "As we entered the year, we identified several disruptive factors that were going to make 2015 challenging," said CEO Kosta Kartsotis during Tuesday's post-earnings conference call. "We expected visibility would be difficult with new entrants moving into our…
Stock futures were up, but had pulled back from early highs ahead of Thursday's open despite a surprise jump in mid-Atlantic region manufacturing.

Dow futures traded 19.8 points above fair market value, down from a 33-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures held a 16.3-point gain, sticking close to earlier highs. S&P 500 futures pulled back to a 5.3-point gain.

The stock market today carries a bit less weight on its shoulders after the S&P 500 decisively punched past its 50-day moving average and the Nasdaq gained more altitude above that important line of support on Wednesday.

Investors drew confidence after minutes from the Fed's Oct. 28 meeting showed a majority of the Federal Open Market Committee in favor of a rate hike in December. Apple (AAPL) also factored into the day's gains, gapping up to a better-than-3% gain after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs.

The current uptrend still bears a heavy load of distribution days: six on the Nasdaq, five on the S&P 500. That is good cause to keep a cautious stance toward new purchases or stocks flashing sell signals.

A relatively light economic calendar opened with the Labor Department reporting weekly jobless claims eased to 271,000 in the week ended Nov. 14, down from 276,000 in the prior week. Economist consensus had forecast a pullback to 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average continued higher, to 270,750, marking its third straight advance.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey firmed up for November, rising to 1.9. That beat consensus expectations for a flat outcome. The index fell to a minus 4.5 reading in October following a minus 6 tally in September.
The Conference Board is set to release its leading economic indicators index for October at 10 a.m. ET.

On the Dow, UnitedHealth (UNH) dropped 6% in premarket action. The Minnetonka, Minn.-based managed care provider trimmed its full-year EPS guidance to $6, down from $6.25 to $6.35 and below consensus views for $6.32. The company said claims activity deteriorated and individual participation in insurance exchanges lagged.

Sellers kept up the pressure on retail and apparel makers, sending Best Buy (BBY) down 9% and Perry Ellis (PERY) to a 4% loss after mixed quarterly reports. Buckle (BKE) and Bon-Ton Stores (BONT) reported Q3 earnings misses, although the stocks remained unchanged in premarket trade.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) swept ahead 17%, topping the S&P 500 in premarket action. The owner of the K-cup coffee franchise trounced analysts' Q4 earnings expectations. Revenue fell less than forecast, and management boosted the quarterly dividend by 13% to 32.5 cents. Keurig shares ended Wednesday down 75% from a November high.

Salesforce.com (CRM) jabbed up 5% before the bell. A 50% EPS leap and a 24% gain in Q3 revenue narrowly cleared analyst consensus projections. Revenue and earnings projections for Q4 were in line with analyst views, and management hoisted full-year EPS guidance to just above consensus. The software-as-a-service leader ended Wednesday in buying range, a bit more than 1% above a 76.31 cup-base buy point.
Some China-based plays chalked off strong premarket moves.
Ctrip.com International (CTRP) soared 13% higher after delivering its Q3 results. The online travel site ended Wednesday 18% above an 80.30 buy point in a double-bottom base.

China-based micro-blogging site Weibo (WB) shot up 8% in premarket trade. It reported EPS of 10 cents, up from a 1-cent, per-share loss a year ago and above views for 6 cents. Revenue surged a better-than-forecast 48%. Shares of upscale fashion designer Vince Holding (VNCE) plunged Tuesday after the company issued weak guidance despite solid Q3 results. The company, whose cashmere sweaters, jackets and other apparel have appeared in such high-end retailers at Nordstrom (JWN) and Neiman Marcus, sees full-year EPS of 90-94 cents, with the midpoint below the analyst consensus of 94 cents. Stocks were off session lows in late trading Tuesday.

The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.1% gain. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were off by 0.5% and 0.1%, respectively. Turnover continued to run sharply higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Michael Kors (KORS) remained near its session low, with a 6% loss. Barclays, Citigroup and Sterne Agee all cut their price targets on the fashion house, which slumped to its lowest levels in five months. The company will report fiscal Q1 earnings Aug. 5. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 34% to 82 cents a share, which would mark the smallest gain in years.

Synaptics (SYNA) pared a 6% loss to 4%. The stock was downgraded to buy from strong buy at Tigress Financial. It is still 23% past a 69.10 buy point from a cup base. Synaptics recently agreed to buy Apple (AAPL) supplier Renesas SP Drivers for $475 million.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reversed an early gain and fell 2%. The downturn puts the stock nearly 2% below a 602.31 buy point from a first-stage cup-with-handle base. Recent price action has been lackluster, and the stock has had trouble staying above 600.

Chipmaker Intel (INTC), railroad operator CSX (CSX) and Internet search provider Yahoo (YHOO) will report quarterly results after the close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 34% to 82 cents a share, which would mark the smallest gain in years.Synaptics (SYNA) pared a 6% loss to 4%. The stock was downgraded to buy from strong buy at Tigress Financial. It is still 23% past a 69.10 buy point from a cup base. Synaptics recently agreed to buy Apple (AAPL) supplier Renesas SP Drivers for $475 million.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reversed an early gain and fell 2%. The downturn puts the stock nearly 2% below a 602.31 buy point from a first-stage cup-with-handle base. Recent price action has been lackluster, and the stock has had trouble staying above 600.Chipmaker Intel (INTC), railroad operator CSX (CSX) and Internet search provider Yahoo (YHOO) will report quarterly results after the close. All three were little changed in late trading.

Stocks continued to hold near session highs Monday afternoon following buyout news and comments from Fed officials. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 jumped 1.1% each. Both regained their 50-day moving averages. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today compared with the same time Friday. Trade was tracking about 1% higher on the NYSE and nearly 13% lower on the Nasdaq.

Among leading stocks, Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers (RBA) gapped above its 50-day line and jumped 5% on a upgrade. Canaccord Genuity raised shares to buy from hold and lifted its price target to 32 from 27. Ritchie Bros. is in a consolidation with a 30.95 buy point.

CyberArk Software (CYBR) gapped up, rallied 5% and regained its 50-day moving average. The line had acted as resistance as the stock bounced back after a sell signal in late June. But CyberArk still has more work to do to form a new base.

Nvidia (NVDA) climbed 4% in fast trade after bouncing back from early weakness. The stock cleared a 23.70 buy point from a consolidation. Shares of the graphics chip maker already surged 12% Friday on its Q2 results.

On the downside, shares of Chinese online retailer JD.com (JD) gapped down and slumped 6% on news that Alibaba (BABA) will invest $4.6 billion for a near 20% stake in Suning Commerce. With the loss, the correction in JD.com's handle stands at 18%. Stocks continued to ramp higher with an hour remaining in Tuesday's session. Small caps paced the upside as the Russell 2000 jumped nearly 1%.
A two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve began on Tuesday. The central bank will issue a new statement on its interest rate policy Wednesday.

The Nasdaq led the major indexes with a 0.6% gain. The Dow industrials rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 was up 0.3%. Volume was running fractionally higher on the NYSE and was 5% faster on the Nasdaq exchange, according to preliminary data.
Among IBD industry groups ranked in the top 20, Medical-Ethical Drugs, Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing and Computer-Hardware/Peripherals and Transport-Airline all rose 1% or more.

In the stock market today, Air Lease (AL) was aiming to reclaim its 50-day moving average after suffering a waterfall-like decline last week. The stock gained nearly 2% in heavy trading. On May 9, the aircraft leasing expert cleared a flat-base buy point at 38.25 and rallied 12% before backtracking.

Michael Kors (KORS), the country's fastest-growing luxury apparel and accessories chain, was fighting to stop a sharp three-day sell-off in which it dropped more than 5%. The stock bounced off an intraday low of 87.95 and gained nearly 1%. Volume was running nearly triple its 50-day average.

Kors continues to grow at a very fast clip. In the past four quarters, EPS growth averaged 63%. But analysts see profit growing 34% in the June fiscal first quarter, which would mark a second straight quarter of deceleration. Kors fell off the IBD Sector Leaders list in Tuesday's paper (see page B1).

While investors tend to focus on the latest quarter, great stock winners usually have superior long-term earnings and sales growth. IBD's Top Fundamentals Screen of the Day requires minimum 3-year growth rates of 25% for EPS and sales. The current list's three Chinese-based companies do much better than that.
YY Inc. (YY) is a social media platform the lets users take part in group voice or video activities, from online karaoke to gaming to conference calls.
YY boasts a 3-year EPS growth rate of 340%. In its most recent quarter, earnings rose 143% as revenue climbed 111%. YY will report Q2 earnings on Aug. 6. Wall Street expects a 66% advance.
YY shares fell nearly 3% to 74.02 on the stock market today. The stock has been consolidating since peaking on March 6 at 90.93.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) is a fast growing search engine operator and mobile security provider. Qihoo has a three-year EPS growth rate of 106%. In the latest quarter, Qihoo reported a 286% spike in earnings, with revenue soaring 141% as it grabs search share from market leader Baidu (BIDU). Wall Street sees EPS growth slowing to 18% as year-over-year comparisons get tougher.
Qihoo likely won't release earnings again until late August. But investors may take their cue from Baidu, which reports earnings late Thursday.

Qihoo shares fell 3 cents to 95.01 as it moves sideways following a retreat from its March 7 peak of 124.42. Qihoo is building a base, but it has flaws. (Baidu, which is not on the Top Fundamentals screen, edged up less than 1% to a new record high.)

Michael Kors (KORS) generates most of its sales in the U.S. and Europe, but the apparel and handbag fashion house is headquartered in Beijing. Kors has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 107%. Earnings rose 56% in its latest quarter as sales leapt 54%.

But since that report, shares have trended down amid concerns over lower margins and increasing discounts. There is growing concern that Kors products are losing their (affordable) luxury halo — much as rival Coach (COH) has stumbled.
Kors reports fiscal Q1 2015 earnings on Aug. 4. Analysts expect a 33% gain.
Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

Stocks swaggered higher at the open, wiping out all or most of the previous session's losses.
The Nasdaq gained 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%.
Volume was running higher across the board.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) and IBM (IBM), two heavy weightings in the Nasdaq and Dow respectively, announced a partnership to develop applications for business users of wireless devices. Each rose about 1.5% after the open. Apple accounts for 6.7% of the Nasdaq's weighting. IBM's weighting in the Dow is 6.9%.

On the downside, Michael Kors (KORS) eased 0.3% as it struggled in the wake of Tuesday's 7% gap-down loss in heavy volume. On Wednesday, William Blair & Co. downgraded Kors from outperform to market perform. An article in today's IBD noted that some analysts say that Kors could be losing its "luxury halo" as it offers more products at a discount.

Intel (INTC) rushed almost 7% higher on the chipmaker's strong quarterly report late Tuesday. Nineteen investment analysts today raised their price targets for Intel. Drexel Hamilton offered the highest new price target, 50.
Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs initiated coverage of Palo Alto Networks (PANW) with a buy recommendation and a 97 price target. The stock jumped 4%.

In housing-related news, the Mortgage Bankers Association's purchase applications index, which is a leading indicator for home sales and housing construction, skidded 8% from the previous week. However, the National Association of Home Builders' housing market index for July came in at 53, above views for 51 and at the high end of the range of estimates. Toll Brothers (TOL) and DR Horton (DHI) were up about 1% each.
The producer price index for June rose 0.4% vs. the consensus target of 0.3%. The PPI measures inflation at the wholesale level before it gets passed on to consumers.
Industrial production for June edged up 0.2%, missing the Street's 0.4% estimate.

The beige book report, which gathers anecdotal information on economic conditions, is due at 2 p.m. ET.Stocks swaggered higher at the open, wiping out all or most of the previous session's losses.The Nasdaq gained 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%.Volume was running higher across the board.In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) and IBM (IBM), two heavy weightings in the Nasdaq and Dow respectively, announced a partnership to develop applications for business users of wireless devices. One of the more compelling aspects of following the IPO market is learning about new companies with innovative products that are still in the nascent stages of growth. Three names in today's IPO Leaders screen have bullish fundamentals and sound charts. In all cases, earnings growth has been fueling price performance. Even better, strong growth is expected to continue. After…
Macy's (M) continues to plow ahead against e-commerce giants like Amazon as the department store retailer launches a same-day delivery pilot program.

Starting this fall, Macy's customers in Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, New Jersey, San Francisco, San Jose, Seattle and Washington, D.C., can get same-day deliveries for online and mobile purchases. The Bloomingdale's chain will offer same-day shipments in Chicago, LA, San Francisco and San Jose.
Macy's was downgraded by Sterne Agee last week to neutral from buy, partly on concerns of the department store losing its omnichannel edge over other retailers.

Macy's omnichannel strategy has involved turning all of its brick-and-mortar locations into mini-fulfillment centers, often shipping out online orders from the nearest store. But as Amazon (AMZN) expands fulfillment centers closer to major cities, retailers have had to ramp up their fulfillment strategies to keep pace.
The pilot program will use crowdsourced same-day delivery provider Deliv and mall owners such as Westfield and Simon.

Macy's and a slew of other merchants including big names such as Whole Foods (WFM), Walgreen (WAG) and Panera Bread (PNRA) — also have signed on to Apple (AAPL) Pay, the new mobile e-payment service system.
Shares of Macy's rose 0.2% to 59.71 in late afternoon trading on the stock market today today, finding support at the 50-day moving average.

Several leaders showing up in the Stock Spotlight have been moving sideways in a tight fashion.

That should be considered bullish. If a stock advances, then moves sideways, it means sellers are nowhere in sight and institutional buyers consider even the slightest weakness an opportunity to add shares.
A break above a three-weeks-tight pattern is a chance to add shares to an already successful position.

Luxury apparel retailer Michael Kors (KORS) has four straight weeks of weekly closes less than 1.5% apart and is down less than 1% for the week. That's good action for a stock that rocketed 24% over two weeks in February on the back of a good earnings report.

Another Stock Spotlight stock showing tight action is Gentherm (THRM), which manufactures electronic climate control systems for cars and trucks. It, too, had a big move — 12% — in the week ended March 7. It was little changed the following week and was little changed this week until Thursday, when it was up 1.04 to close at 33.29. It was going into the final day of the week up almost 5%, too much to qualify for a three-weeks-tight pattern.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) has closed for two straight weeks within the confines of a three-weeks-tight and is en route to complete the formation if it finishes the week little changed.
Valeant is also finding support at its 50-day moving average, the first visit to the support level since breaking out in January.

DrugmakerActavis (ACT) may also be completing a three-weeks-tight pattern after a big move up. It gained nearly 14% on a favorable earnings report in the week ended Feb. 21. It has pulled back slightly, trading tightly.

A Stock Spotlight issue that has had a successful test of its 10-week moving average is flash-drive maker SanDisk (SNDK). The stock has rallied for four days and hit a new high.Several leaders showing up in the Stock Spotlight have been moving sideways in a tight fashion.That should be considered bullish. Most Sector Leaders edged slightly lower in weak volume Thursday. But GasLog (GLOG) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) scored gains in above-average trade. GasLog surged 1.07, or 4%, to a new high of 28.50 as it continues to find support at its short-term, 10-day moving average. The stock is well extended after a strong rebound off the 50-day line in January.…
Stocks continued to linger in narrowly mixed territory ahead of the Federal Reserve's announcement at around 2 p.m. ET.
The Nasdaq eased 0.1%, while the S&P 500 was fractionally lower. But the Dow Jones industrial average managed a fractional gain. Volume was tracking lower across the board in the stock market today.

New Oriental Education & Technology Group (EDU) rallied 3% and bumped up against its 50-day moving average. The stock recently found supported at its 200-day line and has formed a double-bottom base with a traditional 33.78 buy point. But the stock also has a lower alternative entry that's noted in today's International Leaders.

Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2% after reversing higher. The upside reversal erased all of Tuesday's loss. Shares fell 2% Tuesday after Barclays started coverage with an underweight rating and an 85 price target. Overall, Michael Kors is still in a four-weeks-tight pattern with a 101.14 buy point.

On the downside, FireEye (FEYE) fell 5% in heavy trading. But the stock was off its session low after finding support at its 50-day line. This is its first test of the line after more than doubling from a breakout past a 44.99 buy point from an IPO base in January. The September new issue's lock-up period expires today, allowing insiders to sell shares.

SolarCity (SCTY) trimmed a 5% loss to 2%. The solar components and systems maker reported better-than-expected sales and earnings late Tuesday, but gave a disappointing outlook.
