Nobody likes being duped. But in the world of fashion, "dupes" mean coveted products that look and feel like consumers' favorite high-end brands, at a fraction of the price. The "accessible luxury" market — led these days by the likes of Michael Kors (KORS), Kate Spade (KATE) and breakout brand Vince Holding (VNCE) — is thriving partly because companies in…
The one thing that no fashion-conscious consumer wants to look like is cheap. And Coach (COH) has been looking cheap — cheaper than other brands, at least.

In the wake of plunging sales and increasing competition, the maker and retailer of leather handbags and accessories aims to bounce back with smarter sales and a smarter look. But Coach will likely preach patience at Thursday's analyst day. Even if successful, a turnaround could take years.

Coach and its logo-emblazoned leather bags were ubiquitous until recent years, when Michael Kors (KORS), Kate Spade (KATE) and Tory Burch started encroaching on its space, and look-at-this-bag fashion faded from the spotlight in favor of more recession-friendly modesty.

The brand "stuck with logos maybe a little bit longer than they should have," Macquarie analyst Liz Dunn told IBD. But fixing things that ain't broke can seem counterintuitive, and Coach rode on a C-encrusted wave of popularity until it petered out. Dunn says that the company has since "pulled back pretty significantly," with its logo on less than 20% of its merchandise now, compared to a peak of about one-third in the past.
High-end brands such as Gucci and Louis Vuitton have also toned down monogrammed merchandise, according to London-based Ledbury Research, a luxury-brand market research firm.

.Coach was once a pioneer in "accessible luxury," a market that appeals to middle-income consumers, but competition from up-and-comers plus a lack of fashionable edge have contributed to its backslide.
In its fiscal third quarter ending in March, Coach's earnings slid 19% vs. a year earlier to 68 cents a share. Revenue declined 7% to $1.1 billion, with North American same-store sales plunging 21%.
Coach shares, which shot up nearly 600% from their March 2009 low to their March 2012 peak, have lost nearly half their value since.
Meanwhile, Michael Kors sales surged 54% to $917.5 million in its March quarter as EPS jumped 56% to 78 cents.
Kate Spade has also leapt in popularity, with Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow calling the stock "one of the most attractive long-term growth stories in retail today" in a May research note.
On the upside, Coach remains hot in East Asia. China sales rose 25% in Q3.
Telsey Advisory Group analyst Dana Telsey attributes strong overseas appeal to the Coach brand's "newness" there, even as rivals have "swooped in" on its U.S. turf.
The Budget Bag Image

With its purses off trend, Coach has struggled to move its wares out the door. While the company has, until now, eschewed sales at its full-price stores, off-price Coach bags aren't exactly hard to find. The company has offered price cuts via third-party events such as preferred-customer events and flash sales on other sites, and its handbags and shoes can frequently be found on sale at department stores such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN).

Kors and Kate have lower-tier lines such as Michael by Michael Kors and Kate Spade Saturday, but Coach has traditionally gone with flash sales and factory stores to appeal to budget-conscious consumers.

Coach also may have overexpanded its factory outlets, which offer products at a lower price point. Coach closed three net retail stores in fiscal 2013 but opened 24 factory outlet stores. It opened 26 factory stores in 2012.

Sterne Agee's Boruchow estimates that factory "sales per square foot peaked at ~$2,700" in fiscal 2012, following saturation of full-price channels. However, "it now appears that the Factory business is bearing the brunt of the company's struggles."
Boruchow adds that Coach was believed to be "clearing virtually all of its excess inventory through Factory stores."
Coach reportedly will start sales of 30%-50% every June and January at its main locations. The goal is to get customers to forget that its products used to be a little cheaper almost all of the time.

The semi-annual sales strategy will "ultimately be brand enhancing, but in the intermediate term we could see sales fall," said Dunn to IBD, reaffirming in a note that "the first sale will likely be met with criticism from the investment community and confusion from customers."
CEO Victor Luis said that Coach's recent decision to "eliminate third-party events as well as limit the access and invitations to our factory flash site" hurt Internet sales in its Q3.
Time For A Makeover

A brand turnaround for Coach may take years, but it can be done. Burberry managed to "put itself back on the luxury map in less than 5 years," Ledbury Research said in a report. The U.K. apparel brand "shook off its mass/fashion association and counterfeit issues by reducing the visibility of the distinctive check \ from 2006."
Higher-end lines raised average prices while creating a "halo effect" on Burberry's other products.
Coach could do the same, but not without work.

"After a year of persistent traffic declines," said Wedbush Securities analyst Corinna Freedman in a research note, "we believe COH has to work much harder than it has in the past to bring customers back to the brand (at full price), as its turnaround is dependent on elevating the brand."
Bringing in new North American customers may also prove difficult, because the premium women's handbag market is fairly mature in North America, and Coach already has a large share.
Macquarie's Dunn said that Coach has room for growth overseas and in other categories, including men's, footwear and jewelry.
Coach has high hopes for Executive Creative Director Stuart Vevers, an award-winning designer who joined in 2013. His first ready-to-wear collection.

"It wasn't the bags that had everyone a-twitter," reported InStyle, a fashion publication, in February. "It was the head-to-toe looks — a markedly modern (even, dare we say it, edgy) departure from the past. News flash: Coach is cool."The one thing that no fashion-conscious consumer wants to look like is cheap. But fixing things that ain't broke can seem counterintuitive, and Coach rode on a C-encrusted wave of popularity until it petered out. Dunn says that the company has since "pulled back pretty significantly," with its logo on less than 20% of its merchandise now, compared to a peak of about one-third in the past.High-end brands such as Gucci and Louis Vuitton have also toned down monogrammed merchandise, according to London-based Ledbury Research, a luxury-brand market research firm..Coach was once a pioneer in "accessible luxury," a market that appeals to middle-income consumers, but competition from up-and-comers plus a lack of fashionable edge have contributed to its backslide.In its fiscal third quarter ending in March, Coach's earnings slid 19% vs. a year earlier to 68 cents a share. Revenue declined 7% to $1.1 billion, with North American same-store sales plunging 21%.Coach shares, which shot up nearly 600% from their March 2009 low to their March 2012 peak, have lost nearly half their value since.Meanwhile, Michael Kors sales surged 54% to $917.5 million in its March quarter as EPS jumped 56% to 78 cents.Kate Spade has also leapt in popularity, with Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow calling the stock "one of the most attractive long-term growth stories in retail today" in a May research note.On the upside, Coach remains hot in East Asia. China sales rose 25% in Q3.Telsey Advisory Group analyst Dana Telsey attributes strong overseas appeal to the Coach brand's "newness" there, even as rivals have "swooped in" on its U.S. turf.The Budget Bag ImageWith its purses off trend, Coach has struggled to move its wares out the door. While the company has, until now, eschewed sales at its full-price stores, off-price Coach bags aren't exactly hard to find. The company has offered price cuts via third-party events such as preferred-customer events and flash sales on other sites, and its handbags and shoes can frequently be found on sale at department stores such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN).Kors and Kate have lower-tier lines such as Michael by Michael Kors and Kate Spade Saturday, but Coach has traditionally gone with flash sales and factory stores to appeal to budget-conscious consumers.Coach also may have overexpanded its factory outlets, which offer products at a lower price point. Coach closed three net retail stores in fiscal 2013 but opened 24 factory outlet stores. It opened 26 factory stores in 2012.Sterne Agee's Boruchow estimates that factory "sales per square foot peaked at ~$2,700" in fiscal 2012, following saturation of full-price channels. However, "it now appears that the Factory business is bearing the brunt of the company's struggles."Boruchow adds that Coach was believed to be "clearing virtually all of its excess inventory through Factory stores."Coach reportedly will start sales of 30%-50% every June and January at its main locations. The goal is to get customers to forget that its products used to be a little cheaper almost all of the time.The semi-annual sales strategy will "ultimately be brand enhancing, but in the intermediate term we could see sales fall," said Dunn to IBD, reaffirming in a note that "the first sale will likely be met with criticism from the investment community and confusion from customers."CEO Victor Luis said that Coach's recent decision to "eliminate third-party events as well as limit the access and invitations to our factory flash site" hurt Internet sales in its Q3.Time For A MakeoverA brand turnaround for Coach may take years, but it can be done. Burberry managed to "put itself back on the luxury map in less than 5 years," Ledbury Research said in a report. The U.K. apparel brand "shook off its mass/fashion association and counterfeit issues by reducing the visibility of the distinctive check \ from 2006."Higher-end lines raised average prices while creating a "halo effect" on Burberry's other products.Coach could do the same, but not without work."After a year of persistent traffic declines," said Wedbush Securities analyst Corinna Freedman in a research note, "we believe COH has to work much harder than it has in the past to bring customers back to the brand (at full price), as its turnaround is dependent on elevating the brand."Bringing in new North American customers may also prove difficult, because the premium women's handbag market is fairly mature in North America, and Coach already has a large share.Macquarie's Dunn said that Coach has room for growth overseas and in other categories, including men's, footwear and jewelry.Coach has high hopes for Executive Creative Director Stuart Vevers, an award-winning designer who joined in 2013. His first ready-to-wear collection."It wasn't the bags that had everyone a-twitter," reported InStyle, a fashion publication, in February. "It was the head-to-toe looks — a markedly modern (even, dare we say it, edgy) departure from the past. News flash: Coach is cool."

Stocks strolled ahead in quiet volume Friday, keeping their composure a day after some heavy selling. The Nasdaq and S&P; 500 added 0.3% each. The IBD 50 rose 0.2%. Volume fell across the board, which might've been partly tied to caution in advance of the Federal Reserve's meeting set for Tuesday and Wednesday. In the wake of Thursday's distribution day,…

Facebook (FB) and Vipshop Holdings stand out as two institutional-quality new issues that are forming bases. Facebook is climbing the right side of a base and has crossed an important step in that process by regaining its 50-day moving average. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is a lowest-possible E. But there's still some time for that to improve before Facebook reaches…
Stocks were mildly lower early Friday amid lackluster data on consumer spending and sentiment.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each lost 0.2%, while the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today.

On the economic front, the Chicago PMI rose to 65.5 in May from 63 in April. Economists polled by Econoday had expected a pullback to 61. The University of Michigan's index on consumer sentiment for May came in at 81.9, below views for 82.5.
Earlier, the Commerce Department report that consumer spending unexpectedly slipped 0.1% in April — the first drop in a year.

Leaders down in volume were few in Friday's early going. But Alliance Fiber Optic Products (AFOP) fell 2% as it pulled back from a 10-session win streak. It's still 23% past a 17.91 buy point from a double-bottom base. In most cases, investors should take profits when they amount to 20% to 25%.
AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) was off its low, but still down 1%. The insurer fell a bit further below a 44.85 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. It had gained 5% before fading.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) rallied 4% after being upgraded to outperform from perform at Oppenheimer. Shares had already gained 5% Thursday in reaction to a round of positive developments from late Wednesday. Palo Alto gapped above a 72.60 buy point from a double-bottom base Thursday.

Michael Kors (KORS) rose 3% and climbed back above its 50-day moving average, which Kors had breached slightly on Thursday. Stocks opened with strong gains Tuesday, thanks to a round of upbeat economic reports.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 rose 0.5% to a record high. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.4%. Volume was tracking sharply higher in the stock market today compared with Friday's light preholiday levels.

In economic news, home prices rose 0.9% in March, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller index of 20 metropolitan areas. That marked the first gain in five months and topped the 0.7% consensus estimate by Econoday.
Consumer confidence edged up to 83 in May, or in line with views.
Earlier, orders for durable goods rose by a better-than-expected 0.8% in April.

In leading stocks, Cavium (CAVM) gapped up and rallied close to 5% to a record high. The stock cleared a 47.57 buy point from a base-on-base pattern. Cavium was one of several leading chip stocks featured in Friday's Your Weekly Review.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) climbed 2% and regained its 50-day moving average, thanks to an upgrade. Nomura raised the security software provider to buy from neutral and set a price target at 80. Palo Alto will report fiscal Q3 earnings after Wednesday's close.

Michael Kors (KORS) gapped up and rose 2% to a two-month high. The fashion house will unveil fiscal Q4 earnings Wednesday morning. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 36% to 68 cents a share. Michael Kors is shaping a cup base with a 101.14 buy point. The stock has been consolidating gains in mostly quiet fashion since February.

JinkoSolar (JKS) fell 1% after badly missing views. Before the open, the Chinese maker of solar cells and modules reported Q1 earnings of 40 cents per American depositary share, or 20 cents below views. But sales jumped 73% to $323.9 million vs. views for $288.65 million. Stocks opened with mild losses Wednesday after running higher in the past four sessions.

The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% each, while the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade was tracking a smidge higher and NYSE volume was running lower.

DSW (DSW) gapped down and plunged 25% on disappointing quarterly results. Before the open, the shoe retailer reported Q1 earnings of 42 cents a share, down from 50 cents a year ago. Sales slipped to $599 million from just over $601 million last year. Analysts had expected 48 cents a share on revenue of about $622.3 million. DSW also lowered its full-year outlook.

Michael Kors (KORS) was off its session low and nearly unchanged despite reporting upbeat quarterly results before the open. The company's stock slumped as much as 4% but found support near its 50-day line.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) gapped above its 50-day line and rallied 6% after handily beating views late Tuesday. The Chinese software and Internet search firm's earnings surged 286% to 54 cents a share, while sales leapt 141% to $265.1 million. The company has now delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit profit and revenue gains.

Toll Brothers (TOL) gapped up and climbed 3% to its best levels since early April after surpassing views. Helped by higher prices, the homebuilder's fiscal Q2 earnings surged to 35 cents a share, up from 9 cents in the year-ago period. Sales rose 67% to $860 million. Estimates were for 26 cents a share on revenue of $831 million.Stocks opened with mild losses Wednesday after running higher in the past four sessions.The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% each, while the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. It might still be snowing on the East Coast, but spring is officially here. Palm trees and sandy beaches are calling all Americans — not just students — to take a break from the snow and head to somewhere sunny.
But even those stuck in the latest snowstorm can still take advantage of spring. Here are six spring-break stocks on the Big Cap Leaders Screen of the Day.
Delta Air Lines (DAL) is on the list with the highest possible Composite Rating of 99. Shares soared 3.33% to 34.43 in the stock market Tuesday.
The airline offers flights to numerous warm destinations in the U.S., like Miami, San Diego and Honolulu, as well as to beach spots abroad like the Bahamas.

For those who can't unplug from the office, on Tuesday Delta announced it will have Wi-Fi service on Boeing (BA) 747 flights from Los Angeles and Atlanta to Tokyo. The company plans to add Wi-Fi services on all international flights by the end of next year.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) is also featured on the screen with a 99 rating. The airline will begin international flights to the Bahamas, Aruba and Jamaica starting in July. The airline is expanding its routes at home as well. On Monday, Southwest said it will more than double flights out of Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in the D.C. area. New routes include nonstop flights to Akron-Canton, Ohio; Indianapolis and Dallas. In December, Southwest bought American Airlines' (AAL) takeoff and landing spots at Reagan as part of American's merger deal with U.S. Air.
With the economy on an uptick, more travelers are heading to Las Vegas to try their luck in Sin City.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) has a 99 Composite Rating and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) enjoys a CR of 98.

Earlier this month, Sands applied to Singapore officials for permits to add 1,500 rooms to its Marina Bay Sands casino there. Sands also has operations in Macau, along with MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn.
Wynn shares fell more than 2% to 219.50 on Tuesday and Sands fell nearly 2% to 78.80. Both have fallen below their 50-day moving averages
If you want to look good while hitting the beach in Miami or the tables in Vegas, Michael Kors (KORS) has affordable luxury offerings like handbags and dresses to adorn spring-break revelers.
Kors has a 98 rating. Luxury brands outperformed their mid-market peers during the holiday season as middle-class consumers looked for deep discounts.

Take lots of pictures en route to Vegas or sporting a Kors bag at the beach and put them up on Facebook (FB) or its sister site Instagram. The social media giant has a 99 rating. Late Tuesday it announced plans to buy virtual reality company Oculus VR for $1.9 billion — perhaps you can take a virtual trip to Maui one day. Facebook has been on an acquisition spree recently, buying messaging service Whatsapp for $19 billion in February.It might still be snowing on the East Coast, but spring is officially here. Leading stocks from IBD's 33 sector groups fell Thursday, with many losing 4% or more, amid the market's renewed sell-off. GasLog (GLOG), which operates a fleet of ships that transport liquefied natural gas, had the best performance. The stock ended flat at 24.90 as it continues to hold up well despite the recent market slump. GasLog is just 3% off…

Most Sector Leaders fell Wednesday, with several reversing lower, after the market sold off following an unexpectedly hawkish outlook from Fed chief Janet Yellen. Volume was weak for most leaders, however, and a number of them managed to buck the downdraft. The top stocks in the Internet and medical sectors took the hardest hits, with declines ranging from 1% to…

Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Economic reports due Wednesday include the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for October, ADP private-sector payrolls for November, crude oil inventories for the week ended Oct. 31 and the Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications for the week ended Oct. 31.Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. Stock futures were on pace for a slightly higher start Wednesday, as the market looked to build on recent gains.
Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 3 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures gained 3 points and Dow futures rallied 23 points.

The S&P 500 hit another record high Monday, while the Nasdaq followed through and put the market back in an uptrend. A batch of upbeat economic reports boosted sentiment Monday, but the economic calender is empty for the stock market today.

In corporate news, Workday (WDAY) jumped 6% in premarket trading after delivering Q1 results above views late Tuesday. The cloud-based software firm also gave upbeat sales guidance for the current quarter. Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) was also up 6% in premarket trading in reaction to stellar quarterly results from late Tuesday.

Michael Kors (KORS) rallied 3% in premarket trading after topping views. The fashion house reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 78 cents a share, up 56% from a year ago. It beat by 10 cents. Net sales jumped 53% to $882 million vs. views of about $816.2 million. It also guided fiscal Q1 sales above views.

Security software maker Palo Alto Networks (PANW) will report fiscal Q3 results after the close. Earnings are expected at a dime a share, up 67% from a year ago. The stock cleared resistance at its 50-day line Tuesday.

Elsewhere, Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) raised its bid for Botox maker Allergan (AGN). It lifted the cash portion of its offer by $10 a share to $58.30. In April, Valeant offered $48.30 a share and a 0.83 share of its stock for each share of Allergan. Both were mildly lower in premarket trading.

Overseas markets were mostly higher, with the Shanghai composite and the Hang Seng gaining 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. European markets were up more modestly. The healthy eating movement and organic food are on the upswing, and WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) is cashing in. WhiteWave produces plant-based foods, coffee creamers, beverages and premium dairy products. The company's brands include Silk, Horizon Organic and TruMoo. It was spun off of by Dean Foods (DF) in October 2012. The stock has formed a nine-week flat base that has…

Apple (AAPL) leads retailers in highest sales per square foot, according to new market research data, as consumers continue to splurge on the pricey consumer electronics. Apple averages $4,551 in sales per square foot of retail space in the last 12 months, according to eMarketer Retail. The company's stores feature a sleek, minimalist design with rows of iPads, iPhones and…

As the retail first-quarter earnings train moves full speed ahead this week, investors will get an idea of how high-end players Tiffany & Co. (TIF) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) fared during the harsh winter when they report results on Wednesday.If followers are on the money, the two retailers likely saw both sales and earnings heat up during the quarter as consumers braved the cold weather and stepped up the pace of spending.Luxury consumers have been reaping the benefits of stock-market gains and increased home values, which have helped buoy spending at retailers that cater to this crowd — retailers like Williams-Sonoma and Tiffany.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect upscale jeweler Tiffany to see earnings rise 11% from a year earlier to 78 cents a share when it reports before the opening bell Wednesday. That would follow a 5% rise during the holiday fourth quarter. Sales are seen increasing 6.6% to $955.63 million. That would be up from a 5% increase in the prior quarter.High-end home-goods retailer Williams-Sonoma is seen showing a 7% increase in Q1 earnings to 44 cents a share when it deliver results after the close Wednesday. Analysts expect it to report a 6% increase in sales to $941.88 million.The high-end retail segment also includes players like upscale department store operator Nordstrom (JWN), which beat Q1 earnings views Thursday. Fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) and home furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware (RH) also cater to upscale consumers.Williams-Sonoma is likely getting a lift from the rise in home improvement spending amid the continued recovery in the housing market.Other members of IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Jewelry group, where Tiffany operates, include Signet Jewelers (SIG) and Fossil Group (FOSL).

Coach (COH) shares tumbled Tuesday after the luxury-handbag maker reported third-quarter North American same-store sales that plunged by double digits. Coach's Q3 earnings fell 19% to 68 cents. IPO bases — the very first bullish pattern a stock creates in its trading history — can be shorter than normal. Michael Kors' (KORS) version certainly fit that description.After its initial public offering (IPO), a stock's initial weeks in the market can be wild and unsettled. But at some point, the trading will settle down and a base can quickly form. A new IPO stock can also shoot up with unusual energy and give early shareholders a prodigious gain.But investors still need to study a stock chart to find the proper buy point, which can be harder to spot on a brand new chart than on a long-established one.The upscale accessories maker and retailer went public on the NYSE on Dec. 15, 2011. For Kors, the IPO base formed swiftly.From the first day, the stock traded above the offering price of 20 a share. A 12% surge the second week showed Kors was winning over institutional investors.In the fourth week of trading, Kors had its first decline (1) . A drop of less than 5% wasn't much to fuss about. It was hard to gauge volume with such a new stock, but the down week's trading, while higher than the prior week, wasn't excessive. That gave chart readers some reassurance.Two weeks later, in the week ended Jan. 20, 2012, Kors surged to a new high in heavy trading (2).That was the breakout for this IPO base. From a 27.68 buy point to the peak of 50.69 two months later, the stock vaulted 83%.To be sure, this IPO base was easy to miss. It is perhaps somewhat of a misnomer for an Investor's Corner series that goes under the banner of classic IPO bases. Even on IBD Leaderboard, the base was said to be too short to be a true IPO pattern.A two-week consolidation indeed can be too short for most stocks. But Kors had something relatively few stocks can boast — a potent set of fundamentals.Earnings per share had bulged 117% and 213% the two quarters leading up to the IPO. Sales growth was 60% and 61%, in line with previous quarters.As the market would learn after its fourth-quarter results, the company's fiscal 2011 and 2012 profit climbed 81% and 129%, respectively. Sales increased 58% and 62%. Pretax margin of 21.4% in fiscal 2012 was the highest ever; return on equity was a very robust 57.4%.With those numbers, Kors established itself not just as a leader in its category but also in the broad market.When a true leader like that forms a base that may seem too narrow in scope, don't ignore it. Study it carefully, especially if the market is in a confirmed uptrend.The stock formed its first conventional base from March to August of 2012. The breakout didn't produce much of a gain, as did a couple of subsequent bases. But Michael Kors started another strong advance in July 2013.(Editor's Note: Read the IPO Leaders column on Tuesday and Thursday for more insight.)

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) stock continued to fall out of favor despite solid second-quarter earnings and strong European sales, as the maker of luxury accessories and apparel reported slowing North America growth and a meek outlook for the upcoming holiday quarter.
The fashion house, which operates 473 retail stores, fell 10% to 70.16 in the stock market today.

Kors said it expects a low-double-digit same-store sales increase, with Q3 per-share earnings of $1.31-$1.34 on revenue of $1.27 billion-$1.3 billion vs. analyst expectations for per-share earnings of $1.34 on revenue of $1.31 billion.
Q2 earnings surged 40.8% to $1 a share, topping by 11 cents, and revenue jumped 42.7% to $1.06 billion, beating analyst forecasts for $978.6 million.

Overall Q2 same-store sales rose 16.4%, less than some analysts had expected, while Kors opened 121 net new stores. Last quarter, Kors reported 24.2% comps growth, and a year ago the company reported comps of 22.9%.

North American revenue rose 29.8% to $802.2 million, and same-store sales increased just 10.8%. European revenue skyrocketed 108.6% to $237.9 million on 41.1% comps, and sales in Japan surged 106.3% to $16.5 million on comps of 52.9%.
CEO John Idol defended guidance and same-store sales figures in the earnings call.
"Our lay of the land for the holiday season is somewhat more conservative," he said.

"One, we are concerned about (North American) mall traffic. .. . We do see the consumer being slightly more conservative, and I don't think that's only in our case. I think we're seeing that from many other companies. Secondly, we're conservative because we're not taking a promotional posture."
He added that comp store growth of 16.4% is "still a very, very strong performance by our company and I believe one of the best in the entire luxury industry."

The company also authorized a $1 billion share buyback program. For the year, Kors anticipates $4.13-$4.18 in per-share earnings vs. views for $4.10 and revenue of $4.3 billion-$4.4 billion vs. views for $4.4 billion.

Competitor Kate Spade (KATE), which releases quarterly earnings on Thursday, slid 2.8%. The major stock indexes closed with losses of more than 1% Wednesday after the indexes made bearish price reversals.
The Nasdaq, which had been up about 1% earlier, closed nearly 1.2% lower. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slid about 1.4%.
Volume rose across the board, early indications showed. Declining stocks led advancers by more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 11-to-4 on the NYSE.
The way the indexes reversed course Wednesday quickly dampened the bullish tone of the prior session, when the main indexes made a follow-through rally confirmation.
The number of stocks rising in big volume rapidly diminished in the final two hours of trading.

Apple (AAPL) was a highlight in the stock market today after the company unveiled a series of new products. It introduced the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, a larger tablet dubbed the iPad Pro, major improvements to its Apple TV franchise and other product upgrades.

But Apple shares fell 2%. Suppliers of components for Apple products were weaker, too. ARM Holdings (ARMH) fell 3%, Avago Technologies (AVGO) nearly 2%, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) more than 1%, Qorvo (QRVO) 3%, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) 1%.

MasterCard (MA) dropped 3%, sinking back to its 200-day moving average, after the credit-card company warned that profit growth would slow in the next few years. The stock has been below the 50-day moving average for a couple of weeks already.

Stericlycle (SRCL) tumbled 6%, dropping to its 50-day moving average, where it now looks for support. The stock closed 5% below the 143.79 buy point of flat base. The medical-waste handling company announced an offering of 7 million depositary shares that represent 10% of certain preferred stock.

WCI Communities (WCIC) went right back below its 25.74 buy point. Despite its fading star status, Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) is nevertheless expected to make solid gains as the purse maker reports fiscal second-quarter results before the market opens on Tuesday.
Wall Street expects earnings to rise 25.4% to 89 cents a share, a slowdown from the heftier double-digit and triple-digit gains of previous quarters. Revenue is seen jumping 32.2% to $978.6 million.

Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow said in a Monday note that "October appears to be another disappointing month" for retail amid elevated promotional activity and sluggish sales, though he is the "most bullish" on smaller accessory maker Kate Spade (KATE) and said Kors is one of the strongest stocks in the group.
Shares of Michael Kors were relatively flat in the stock market today. Kate Spade shares edged up 0.6%.

"While we acknowledge upside to numbers, we maintain our market perform rating on (Kors) shares, with the expected overhang from decelerating North America trends, increasing investment and normalizing margins," said William Blair analyst Amy Noblin in a Monday note.
But growth prospects are looking up in Europe.

"As North America slows, Europe becomes a key area of focus as Michael Kors enters close to 50% brand awareness in many of the region's larger markets, such as Germany and the United Kingdom," she added.
Last week, Janney Capital downgraded Kors to neutral from buy on "potential softening in the global luxury and European markets" and North American market maturation, among other factors.
In mid-October, Kors got a hold initiation from Stifel on potential market saturation and competition issues, though analyst David Schick said the brand is "here to stay."

Analysts had expressed concerns about Kors' dimming luxury halo, though far more concern circles competitor Coach (COH), whose view-topping Q1 was not enough to extinguish skepticism about the brand's attempted turnaround with new designs and lessened promotional activity.
RELATED:
Coach Earnings, Sales Tumble As Makeover Takes Time

Despite a new fall collection that opened to positive runway reviews, Coach's first-quarter results are still expected to slide as the maker of purses and accessories in the affordable luxury market slowly continues to engineer a brand makeover.
Coach (COH) reports before the open on Tuesday. Shares rose 0.5% by midafternoon in the stock market today, Monday.

"We believe new fall product will be the primary focus on the call, and while we are encouraged by the design and believe early interest has been positive... we do not believe it has materially moved the financial needle," said William Blair analyst Amy Noblin in a Sept. 30 note.
Wall Street expects Q1 earnings to tumble 41.6% to 45 cents a share from 77 cents in the same quarter last year and sees revenue dipping 12.7% to slightly more than $1 billion.

Last week's Q4 Baird Consumer Handbag Survey noted slightly higher overall U.S. demand for handbags, with Michael Kors (KORS) continuing to gain market share and smaller purse-maker Kate Spade (KATE) making "modest gains across the board."

"While Coach again led purchase intent on absolute basis (and showed sequential improvement), relatively lower gains contributed to further loss of share," said Baird analyst Mark R. Altschwager in the survey note.

"We found that Coach customers indicated lower frequency of shopping in branded stores. COH is accordingly closing (about) 70 underperforming full-price stores and renovating several flagships in (fiscal) 2015." Coach's fiscal 2015 has already begun.

Kors and Kate have been overshadowing the outlet- and logo-heavy Coach in recent years, though Coach has since hired designer Stuart Vevers to give its fall collection a fresh look and has significantly decreased promotional activity at its full-price stores. Whether its turnaround will prove successful remains to be seen.

Meanwhile, Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) received an upgrade from Bank of America to neutral from underperform, according to Benzinga, and D.A. Davidson downgraded teen retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) to neutral from buy.
L Brands shares rose 1.3% by midafternoon Monday. Zumiez shares traded down 2.3%.

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) received a hold initiation from Stifel, concerned with saturation and hotter competition as the brand's recent growth spurt begins to even out.Nevertheless, investors pushed shares of the handbag maker up 0.7% to 72.79 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today.While the popular brand has nabbed "significant market share in core categories" over a brief period, Stifel analyst David Schick cites management as admitting that current operating margins are "unsustainable" and the company is due to make catch-up investments."Our store checks suggest Kors remains a leader at rapidly bringing key runway trends to market. But operating margin could fall as comp boost from new footage decelerates and competitors are waking up (lessening the share gain opportunity of the past few years)."Kors' affordably upscale purses and accessories have stolen the spotlight from Coach (COH) in recent years, with Schick noting that Kors' store count has quadrupled to more than 400 locations in 3-1/2 years, while Coach required a decade to expand that much. Kors has competed well against trendy counterparts Kate Spade (KATE) and Tory Burch."Kors did the right thing, we think, in maximizing the opportunities in the marketplace, but we expect some natural deceleration and consolidation of the brand's growth," said Schick, who noted "more stagnant demand . . . of higher-income consumer mindshare."Plus, slowing Web traffic and online searches and lagging "intent to buy" were uncovered by a Stifel survey."In our view, the brand is here to stay and indeed vibrant," said Stifel's Schick, "but Kors will not be able to replicate the buzz and competitive opportunity of 2008-2012."Many remain bullish on Kors' growth prospects in Europe, and Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow said last week that the brand's European sales are becoming a "meaningful piece" of the business.Globally, sales of luxury goods are seen rising at the most laggard pace in five years amid heated political conflicts in Hong Kong and Russia, according to a Bain & Co. study cited by Bloomberg.Kors reports second-quarter results before the market opens on Nov. 4.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter at @IBD_Elow.RELATED:Michael Kors Strong In Europe, Weaker In U.S.?.

Top international stocks have reacted largely alongside the general market this week, rallying to end the day at or near highs Wednesday, and surrendering early gains to end low in ranges on Thursday.
Of IBD's 10 Top World Stocks, five are extended beyond buy points.

As for the others, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) is six days into a handle, tacked on to a seven-week cup and with a buy point at 45.80. The handle has corrected 10%, well within the rules, and volume has been quiet — exactly what you'd hope to see. Shares edged below their 50-day moving average Thursday, and you'd like to see the stock hold this level of support. The base is a third-stage structure.

China-based SouFun Holdings (SFUN) cleared a cup base buy point of 95.49 in heavy trade March 5. The real estate web portal then pulled back in a series of measured steps that steadied at the stock's 50-day moving average.

On a weekly chart, the pullback didn't look at all measured, down 8% through Thursday, triggering the automatic sell rule and hanging low in the week's range — a sign of weakness. It is a third-stage base, and if the stock retakes the buy point in heavy trade, the party is back on.

Fashion footwear and accessories maker Michael Kors (KORS), headquartered in Hong Kong but with its heart in New York, is just below a 101.14 buy point in a four-weeks-tight pattern. The stock cleared a second-stage base with a huge gap up breakout Feb. 4.

WuXi Pharmatech (WX) cleared a second-stage base Feb. 24, then ducked back to test support at its 10-week moving average. In the process, it undercut the cup base's 38.79 buy point by 11%, triggering the automatic sell rule. Like SouFun, it could retake the buy point. If it does so in heavy trade, it constitutes a valid breakout.
China's TAL Education Group (XRS) has been consolidating below a Jan. 22 high. It posted a big rebound from 10-week support in powerful trade Jan. 28, but has not capitalized on the move.

The wide weekly swing put the overall correction's depth at 24%. Technically it is in buying range, but given its lackadaisical behavior and the market's rising distribution day count, cautious investors may want to hold for a possible breakout above a 26.68 buy point.Top international stocks have reacted largely alongside the general market this week, rallying to end the day at or near highs Wednesday, and surrendering early gains to end low in ranges on Thursday.Of IBD's 10 Top World Stocks, five are extended beyond buy points.As for the others, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) is six days into a handle, tacked on to a seven-week cup and with a buy point at 45.80. The handle has corrected 10%, well within the rules, and volume has been quiet — exactly what you'd hope to see. Shares edged below their 50-day moving average Thursday, and you'd like to see the stock hold this level of support. The base is a third-stage structure.China-based SouFun Holdings (SFUN) cleared a cup base buy point of 95.49 in heavy trade March 5. The real estate web portal then pulled back in a series of measured steps that steadied at the stock's 50-day moving average.On a weekly chart, the pullback didn't look at all measured, down 8% through Thursday, triggering the automatic sell rule and hanging low in the week's range — a sign of weakness. It is a third-stage base, and if the stock retakes the buy point in heavy trade, the party is back on.Fashion footwear and accessories maker Michael Kors (KORS), headquartered in Hong Kong but with its heart in New York, is just below a 101.14 buy point in a four-weeks-tight pattern. The stock cleared a second-stage base with a huge gap up breakout Feb. 4.WuXi Pharmatech (WX) cleared a second-stage base Feb. 24, then ducked back to test support at its 10-week moving average. In the process, it undercut the cup base's 38.79 buy point by 11%, triggering the automatic sell rule. Like SouFun, it could retake the buy point. If it does so in heavy trade, it constitutes a valid breakout.China's TAL Education Group (XRS) has been consolidating below a Jan. 22 high. It posted a big rebound from 10-week support in powerful trade Jan. 28, but has not capitalized on the move.The wide weekly swing put the overall correction's depth at 24%. Technically it is in buying range, but given its lackadaisical behavior and the market's rising distribution day count, cautious investors may want to hold for a possible breakout above a 26.68 buy point.

International expansion remains a primary growth opportunity for brand owner Iconix Brand Group (ICON), according to a report by Nomura analyst Robert Drbul released Wednesday.

Iconix licenses its brands to retailers and manufacturers for use across a range of categories from clothes and accessories to fragrances and shoes. It handles the advertising, promotion and public relations in-house. It owns brands in the fashion, athletic, electronic, home and entertainment industries, including Candie's, Danskin, London Fog, Mossimo, Fieldcrest, Starter, Ed Hardy, Sharper Image and Joe Boxer. It owns interests in brands such as Peanuts.

Drbul's report comes a day after a meeting with CEO Neil Cole. International revenue has grown from 14% of sales in 2010 to 37% in 2013, Drbul notes. He estimates international will account for 40% of sales in 2014 and potentially more in 2015, given the debut of the Peanuts movie in 70 countries and 40 languages that November.

Iconix has seven international joint venture agreements with over 1,300 freestanding brand stores worldwide, over 30 international DTR (direct-to-retail) partnerships, and over 800 international licensing partners, says Drbul.

Iconix got a nice lift with the recent acquisition of the remaining 50% of Iconix Latin America from its joint venture partner, New Brands Group, for $42 million, which was announced on March 3. This region recognized approximately $22 million in royalty revenues in 2013, notes Drbul, and represents one of the company's "fastest growing international geographies."

"We additionally view the PEANUTS brand as a vehicle for growth, accounting for approximately (about) 20% of the business in 2013," he wrote. "We believe the Peanuts film debut in 2015 could provide significant earnings growth in the back half of 2015 into 2016, as Iconix will realize royalties from both ticket and merchandise sales around the event, which could also lead to additional longer-term licensing deals for the brand."
Iconix owns 35 brands that that represent about $13 billion in annual retail sales, says Drbul.
In the near-term, says Drbul, Iconix expects to continue growing the brand portfolio through its DTR agreements and further international expansion.
With these DTR deals, Iconix's brands get top shelf space and good product placement right on the aisle.
"We view the DTR agreements favorably, as they offer Iconix more control over brand presentation through Iconix's marketing expertise and trend direction," Drbul added.

Iconix is a part of IBD's Apparel-clothing manufacturing group, which also includes Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), Ralph Lauren Corp. (RL), Coach (COH) and Under Armour (UA). It wasn't such a happy Valentine's Day for Signet Jewelers (SIG) as the snow kept shoppers from buying loved ones jewelry and consumers continued to be cautious about spending. But analysts remain bullish on Tiffany & Co. (TIF).
Sterne Agee's Ike Boruchow lowered his quarterly earnings estimates on Signet as a "significant number of stores" were closed or had reduced hours due to storms in the Southeast and Northeast.
Boruchow estimates that the week before Valentine's Day is the second biggest week of the year for sales, accounting for around 15% of Q1 revenue.

Earlier this month, the National Retail Federation projected that only 19% of Valentine's Day gift givers would buy jewelry vs. 19.7% in 2013, with total jewelry sales of $3.9 billion this year vs. $4.4 billion a year ago.

Signet offered more discounts this year to get customers into its stores. Its Jared brand offered $100 in rewards for every $500 spent and its Kay division offered a "buy one, get one 50% off" deal for its Open Hearts collection.
Discounts have been popular since Thanksgiving and Christmas as consumers remain frugal with their spending and shop around for the best deal.

While Boruchow cut Signet's Q1 outlook, he raised the jeweler's price target to $86 from $77 on hopes that activist investor Corvex Management, which has a 7.8% stake in the company, will push for the company to sell its U.K. business.
Signet shares rose 0.33% to 79.54 in the stock market today.
Boruchow prefers high-end jeweler Tiffany's to Signet as affordable luxury brands continue to outperform their midrange competitors.
Tiffany's only generates 12%-13% of its revenue from the storm battered Northeast and Southeast and gets 50% of it sales from abroad. Signet gets over 40% of its revenue from the East Coast.
Tiffany's also doesn't employ large discounts to get consumers in the door, but instead relies on the little blue box and iconic brand name to lure shoppers.
Shares were up 0.4% to 88.54.

Other affordable luxury brands like fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) have performed well recently too. Earlier this month, it reported a jump in same-store sales and earnings that crushed analyst estimates led by watch and handbags sales as well as more recognition in Europe.

The stock market held on to strong gains with a little over one hour remaining in the session.
The Nasdaq rose 1%, the S&P 500 gained 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%. Volume was running lighter on both exchanges.

In the stock market today, a slew of earnings reports moved stocks. Upscale retailer Michael Kors (KORS) led the pack. Shares rose 17% after the company reported earnings growth of 73% with sales up 59%, well above estimates. It gave cheery guidance. The stock gapped back up through its 50-day moving average and was trading at an all-time high.
WisdomTree Investments (WETF) rose nearly 8%. It was down six of the last seven days, mostly on high volume. It appears to have found support at its 200-day moving average.

Elsewhere, Microsoft (MSFT) briefly reclaimed its 50-day moving average after promoting longtime executive Satya Nadella to CEO, replacing Steve Ballmer. The software giant also said co-founder Bill Gates has resigned as chairman to become technology adviser to Nadella.

Shares of Microsoft pared earlier gains and rose 0.2%. Jim Diedrich and his colleagues at Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities should send a thank-you note to the Federal Reserve.
Amid Fed tapering of its bond-buying program and the prospect of higher interest rates, the market has tilted toward stocks that the $1.3 billion fund favors.
"Since June 2013, higher growth, higher quality names got traction," said lead manager Diedrich.
That market rotation has translated into better absolute and relative performance for the fund.

It gained 36.86% in 2013 vs. 32.39% for the S&P 500, up from 15.12% and 16%, respectively, in 2012. The fund was up 37.82% over the 12 months going into Tuesday. "In recent months, investors have become more comfortable with the prospect of sustainability of (economic growth)," Diedrich said.
The fund began its current stake in Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) in July. Its position in the specialty drugmaker has been steady in recent months.
Shares soared 207% in the past 52 weeks.

"What we like about them is that they are Irish-domiciled and have an Irish tax rate," Diedrich said. Ireland's corporate rate is 12.5% vs. 35% in the U.S. "That's an advantage in its own right and in acquiring other companies."
That should make its takeover of Gentium even more accretive, Diedrich says.
In addition, Jazz should benefit from ongoing consolidation in its biopharma space.
Easier Analytics
The Nuveen mutual fund began its current stake in Tableau Software (DATA) in October. It added to that in the next three months.

"Tableau is a business analytics provider," Diedrich said. "Before, you needed someone in your IT department to write a program to extract and analyze corporate data. With Tableau's software, it's much easier for people to get data on their own."
Shares are up 218% since going public in May at 31.

The fund cut back its stake in Michael Kors (KORS) in December and January after big additions in October and November. The trims were made to meet redemptions, not because the fund had soured on Kors, Diedrich says.

"Their earnings have been fantastic," he added. "There's not a lot in retail and apparel that's been producing good earnings. Kors is a standout. It has continued to beat consensus views on earnings."
Shares are up 70% the past 52 weeks.

The fund added to Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) in November and December. "We can't find much that we like in consumer staples," Diedrich said. "But Green Mountain is a very efficient maker of K-Cup brewers. Earnings were decent."
The 10% stake taken in Green Mountain by Coca-Cola (KO) is a great confidence booster, Diedrich adds. Coke is supporting Green Mountain's effort to make a single-cup cold-drink maker.
"Will Coke like the economics of that machine? If they get a machine that works right, earnings could be meaningfully higher. But it's a wild card," Diedrich said.

Diedrich says LPL Financial (LPLA) stands to benefit from financial advisers leaving big financial firms to become independent registered investment advisers. The company also should benefit as rising interest rates generate more earnings on the float from customers' accounts.Jim Diedrich and his colleagues at Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities should send a thank-you note to the Federal Reserve.Amid Fed tapering of its bond-buying program and the prospect of higher interest rates, the market has tilted toward stocks that the $1.3 billion fund favors."Since June 2013, higher growth, higher quality names got traction," said lead manager Diedrich.That market rotation has translated into better absolute and relative performance for the fund.It gained 36.86% in 2013 vs. 32.39% for the S&P 500, up from 15.12% and 16%, respectively, in 2012. Michael Kors (KORS) dethroned Coach in recent years as the it handbag, but how is it faring against upstart Kate Spade in the battle for affordable luxury purses and clutches?Last year Kors posted a 72% jump in shares as sales rose $2.2 billion. Kors is slated to report fourth-quarter results May 28. Analysts expect the fashion house to report a 36% jump in earnings to 68 cents per share and sales to rise 37% to $816.7 million.Over the holidays, Kors increased its market share among 18-24-year-old women. According to a Cowen Consumer Tracking Survey, among women 18 to 34 years old, 30% preferred Michael Kors to Coach (COH) in December 2013, up from 24% in November 2013 and 20% in December 2012. For women who buy two to three handbags per year, the preference for Michael Kors hit a new high of 27% in December 2013 vs. 23% in November and 16% in December 2012.Kors handbags tend to sell for $200-$350, a pricey item but less so than an even more upscale Louis Vuitton bag.Kors' stock debut on the NYSE in December 2011, but Michael Kors the designer has been turning heads on runways around the world since 1981 when he launched the Michael Kors women's wear line.Kors is a more mature brand than Kate Spade (KATE) and, like Coach, has learned, older, established brands that don't always do better.In a report last month, Citi said Kors has four times the share of the global handbag market vs. Kate.But as with Kors' leap over Coach, Kate could be the next big thing, say analysts in the Citi report.Last week, Kate reported an adjusted loss from continuing operations of 6 cents per share, up from a loss of 16 cents in the year-ago quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting only a 4-cent loss. But sales jumped 33.5% to $328 million, its best gain in several years, on a 54% jump in its namesake Kate Spade brand as the company sheds its underperforming brands like Juicy Couture and Lucky Brand.Kate is known for its handbags with bright colors and bold stripes. The brand also makes home accessories, an area Coach and Kors don't have a large presence in.The brutal winter and tough economic conditions for consumers hit retailers overall, but luxury brands still seemed to do well during the holidays as shoppers splurged on the it bag of the season.It's debatable if the it bag was Kors or Kate, but it definitely wasn't Coach. In April, Coach reported a 19% drop in Q3 EPS to 68 cents while revenue fell 7.4% to $1.1 billion, and its North American same-store sales fell 21% on weakness in women's bags and accessories.Still, the story isn't over quite yet for Coach. The company is under the direction of a new management team and creative director as it looks to remake itself from something old into something new.Michael Kors shares edged higher in the stock market today. Kate Spade and Coach fell less than 1%.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.

The team at Vince Holding wasted no time getting its high-end contemporary fashion brand all glammed up with new products and categories after hitting the Wall Street runway late last year.Vince is a premium clothing brand known for its collection of everyday luxury essentials for women — from slouchy cashmere sweaters and understated leather jackets for colder temperatures to flowy silk blouses and linen pants for the warm seasons.Since going public in November, Vince (VNCE) has woven a new pattern for growth, which includes expanding its product offerings into new categories such as handbags. The idea is to evolve into a lifestyle brand and strengthen its position with the company's wholesale partners, including upscale department stores such as Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom (JWN) and Saks Fifth Avenue (owned by Canada's Hudson's Bay (HBC), as well as its own namesake retail stores.Men And Children NextIn addition to women's clothing, which accounts for about 85% of sales, Vince offers women's footwear through a licensing arrangement and is about to launch men's footwear with the same licensing partner, Brown Shoe (BWS). The line will come out in July, according to WWD.com.Vince also plans to launch children's apparel through a licensing partner in this year's second half. Early next year, the company plans to launch a handbag collection and other accessories."This is a company that starts with a very distinct point of view in apparel, which today makes up the majority of its business," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy."It's taking that everyday luxury aesthetic and pushing it into different categories," she said. "The biggest opportunity is their next big launch of handbags and accessories in early 2015."The move into handbags and accessories would put Vince in a market between players like "jet-set" lifestyle brand Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and traditional European luxury players such as Celine and Louis Vuitton, Murphy adds.Murphy says that Vince is positioned to fare well in this category. It's a premium brand that's priced closer to luxury than so-called "accessible luxury," she says, with sweaters from around $225 to $400, leather jackets at $995 and tops from $100 to $200."What's unique about its positioning is it's taking what we believe is white space in the handbag market," said Murphy.She expects Vince's handbags to be priced between $700 to $1,000 in department stores, which she says would be a "sweet spot."There are few brands around that price point, she says, which means Vince could capture not only the "trade-up consumer but the trade-down consumer."That price would compare with handbags priced at around $300 to $400, where there are many competitors — such as Michael Kors, Coach (COH), Tory Burch and Kate Spade (KATE).Sweet Spot In PricingThe luxury end of the market is priced between $1,200 and $3,000.As Vince extends into accessories, it has a "good opportunity" in that space, Murphy adds."It already has a captive audience in the premium wholesale market domestically because of how well it's performing in women's apparel," she said.Murphy says that Vince prevails as the No. 1 contemporary apparel brand in Nordstrom, Saks and Neiman Marcus.Vince has been faring handsomely on the financial front with its current lineup of products. In its fourth quarter ended Feb. 1, its first as a public company, earnings grew 15% to 23 cents a share. Sales grew 21% to $87.8 million.Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expect earnings to rise 21% to 88 cents a share in 2015. They see a 30% gain in 2016 and a 13% increase in 2017.Prior to the IPO and related restructuring transactions, Vince Holding was a diversified apparel company operating a broad portfolio of fashion brands, including Vince. As a result of the IPO and the related restructuring transaction, the non-Vince businesses were separated out, and Vince became the sole operating business of Vince Holding.Management is eying several growth drivers for the company in addition to expansion into new product categories.Covering New TerritoryAs of March 27, Vince had 28 stores in the U.S., 22 of which are full-price stores and six of which are outlet stores. It's on track to open six to eight new stores in the 2014 fiscal year, with a "strong pipeline for 2015 and beyond," said CEO Jill Granoff on the fourth-quarter conference call.Murphy estimates that Vince could grow its retail-store base domestically to 100 over time.As of Feb. 1, Vince products were sold to consumers via about 2,300 points of distribution through its wholesale partners.Vince's U.S. wholesale business represented 71% of sales in fiscal 2013, and international wholesale represented 8%.In fiscal 2013, Vince opened 90 new shop-in-shops globally in the wholesale channel, and it expects to open more."Given the success" of its shop-in-shop investments last year, it's planning to open an additional 15 to 25 domestic shops in fiscal 2014, to bring the total at the end of fiscal year to 26 to 36 domestic shops, Granoff said on the call.On the product front, the company is looking to expand its existing categories with an "increased focus" on outerwear and dresses, said Granoff. It's also planning to launch an "elevated" product assortment in its men's business in the fall.Vince is also pursuing international expansion, which includes opening free-standing stores.The company recently opened its second Vince store in Istanbul, Turkey, with its distribution partner. Vince is also actively looking to lease its first international showroom in Paris to further build the brand's European business, Granoff said.William Blair & Co. analyst Amy Noblin called Vince a "rapidly growing accessible-luxury brand" in her initiation report on the company.She said it's "well positioned" to capitalize on three trends including the "growth in the number of and wealth of global luxury consumers; a designer customer that is trading down; and consumers increasingly cross-shopping and mixing higher- and lower-end merchandise."Noblin says the Vince brand has developed a "cult following" for its everyday luxury essential products."The brand differentiates itself through a clean, modern and somewhat timeless aesthetic that is comfortable and effortless," she wrote.

Stocks picked up steam and pushed to fresh session highs Tuesday afternoon.

The Nasdaq rallied 0.8%, helped by biotechs and Internet stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.5%. Volume was tracking lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2%, bouncing back from a four-session losing streak. The stock appears to be forming a base but met resistance at its 10-week line last week. Michael Kors' earnings are slated to grow 58% to $3.12 a share this year.

Rival Kate Spade (KATE) rallied 3% and neared its 50-day line. It too appears to be building a new base. After losing money in the past five years, the apparel and accessories company is likely to earn a profit of 25 cents this year.

Diesel engine-maker Cummins (CMI) pared gains, but was still up 3%. Before Tuesday's open, the company beat revenue and earnings views for its first quarter. Cummins said demand for on-highway products in the U.S. offset global weakness in mining and power generation. Management also raised full-year revenue guidance to the high end of the consensus estimate.

On the downside, Spirit Airlines (SAVE) dropped 5% and sliced its 50-day line. Before the open, the deep discount air carrier beat expectations with Q1 earnings that grew 16% to 52 cents a share. Sales rose 18% to $438 million, or in line with views. Both marked a slowdown from the prior two quarters.Stocks picked up steam and pushed to fresh session highs Tuesday afternoon.The Nasdaq rallied 0.8%, helped by biotechs and Internet stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.5%. Volume was tracking lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today.Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2%, bouncing back from a four-session losing streak. Both marked a slowdown from the prior two quarters.
Agile younger companies often see king-sized gains in their younger years.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Young Guns, companies that launched their initial public offering in the last 15 years.
A second sorting finds the five Young Guns with highest daily trading volume, indicating funds that are accumulating shares. Here are the top five Young Guns by highest volume.

Concho Resources (CXO) tops the list. The Midland, Texas, oil and natural gas company went public in August 2007, at the dawn of the fracking revolution. Oil companies now use hydraulic fracturing and other new technologies to recover resources once thought unrecoverable.

Concho operates in the Permian Basin, a West Texas geologic formation rich in shale fields containing massive amounts of oil and natural gas. Some 507,200 shares of its stock trade daily. On Monday, it priced a follow-on public offering of 6.5 million shares — upsized from 6 million earlier — at 129 per share.

On Tuesday, Wunderlich Securities downgraded Concho to hold from buy, citing valuation, and cut its price target to 137 from 147. But TheStreet.com's Jim Cramer that day called Concho's offering the best so far in 2014. Cramer in a report called Permian the "great growth story right now."
Concho stock rose 1.6% in Tuesday stock market trading.

NXP Semiconductors (NXP) is a Netherlands-based chipmaker that specializes in analog and mixed-signal chips for everything from power management in portable devices to auto subsystems to wireless network gear. One of its customers is Apple (AAPL), which uses its chips in iPhones.
NXP went public in August 2010 and has an average daily trading volume of 362,000 shares a day. Its shares fell 3% Tuesday.

Fellow semiconductor maker Avago Technologies (AVGO) is based in Singapore, near manufacturing powerhouse China and other Asian tigers. Its radio-frequency (RF) chips are used in Apple and Samsung smartphones. Avago's stock was recently added to the S&P; 500 index, replacing LSI Logic, which it acquired. Avago's profit rose 29% in the latest quarter to 84 cents a share, and sales climbed 23%.
Avago is less than five years old, having launched its IPO in August 2009, and has daily trading volume of 229,500 shares.
CBRE Group (CBG) is a Los Angeles-based real estate investment and management company. Its growth has been propelled by acquisitions and a buoyant real estate market.

The company went public in June 2004 and, like most real estate companies, crashed in 2008-09. Unlike most, though, its recovery has been remarkable. After buying 11 companies in 2013, CBRE collected two more in the first quarter — one in the U.S., the other in Europe. It has daily trading volume of 225,500 shares. Its stock fell to a low of 2.38 on March 5, 2009, and rose 1,101% to a 28.59 close Tuesday, down less than 1%.

No. 5 is Michael Kors (KORS). No stranger to top-rated stock lists, Hong Kong-based Kors makes affordable luxury clothing and accessories, and sells them mostly in the U.S. In the 2-1/2 years since it went public in December 2011, its stock price has climbed 369% to a 93.71 close Tuesday, down 1% for the day. Investors trade an average 172,300 shares of Kors stock, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-ranked stocks.

The stock market closed higher Tuesday, taking a break from its recent heavy declines.
The Nasdaq snapped back 0.9% as it held around the 4000 price level and climbed from there. The S&P 500 rose 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.5%.
Indexes were erratic, making big gains in the morning, but sellers showed up at midday and again late in the session.
Early figures showed volume fell, which indicated that institutional investors weren't taking much advantage of lower share prices.
A broad collection of medical, technology, energy and cyclical stocks led the stock market today.

Earnings reports continue to sway leading stocks, and on Tuesday Michael Kors (KORS) was the earnings winner. The upscale fashion company beat fourth-quarter results and its shares gapped up more than 17%. Kors broke out of a flat base with an 84.68 buy point in huge volume.
In another bullish move, United Rentals (URI) climbed 3% as it found support following Monday's steep pullback to the 50-day moving average.

TransDigm Group (TDG) jumped from support at the 10-week line in heavy trading after the maker of aircraft components beat earnings and sales expectations for the December-ended quarter. Shares added 4%.

Acquisitions helped its earnings. Stocks were holding onto early gains by midday Tuesday, but volume was starting to trail off as the market sought to recover from Monday's sell-off. The market was digesting a slew of earnings reports.
The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.4%. Volume was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.

Upscale retailer Michael Kors (KORS) was the star of the day. It was up 17% after reporting earnings growth of 73% with sales up 59%, well above estimates. It gave cheery guidance. The stock gapped back up through its 50-day moving average and was trading at an all-time high.

Yum Brands (YUM), owner of the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC brands, rose 9% after reporting a 4% gain in earnings. That was its first earnings gain in four quarters. The stock broke back through its 200-day moving average and has been an underperformer in recent years.
Former leader ARM Holdings (ARMH) was down 6%, but off its lows of the morning. The British chipmaker reported a 30% gain in EPS, which equaled analysts' estimates.

Losses among IBD 50 stocks were moderate. Ambarella (AMBA) slipped furthest, down 3% to just below its 10-week moving average. It is in the fifth week of a consolidation.Stocks were holding onto early gains by midday Tuesday, but volume was starting to trail off as the market sought to recover from Monday's sell-off. Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. Botox maker Allergan (AGN), the target of its recent hostile takeover bid, rejected Valeant's $47 billion offer, citing Valeant's steep cost-cut proposals for the rejection. Stocks put in a second straight gain Monday, extending a recovery effort from last week's losses. Helped by Apple (AAPL), which won an upgrade from Barclays and a price-target hike at Morgan Stanley, the Nasdaq climbed 0.6%. Gains in Amazon.com (AMZN) and Google (GOOGL) also boosted the tech-heavy index. The S&P; 500 rose 0.5% and has already recouped more than…
Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) delivered a stunning second quarter as it wowed shoppers across Europe and North America with its chic luxury offerings.

The seller of high-end clothing and accessories said net income leapt 45% to 71 cents per share, topping views by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for 68 cents a share. Total revenue jumped 39% to $740.3 million, handily beating forecasts for $725.91 million.
Same-store sales in North America increased 21%, fueled by ongoing strength in its accessories and watch collection.
Shares surged nearly 6% in the stock market Tuesday.

Retail net sales increased 47% to $355.6 million, driven by a 23% increase in comps and 83 net new store openings since the end of Q2 of its last fiscal year. Wholesale net sales increased 30% to $351.9 million, and licensing revenue increased 65% to $32.9 million.
In Europe, sales soared 101%, as growing brand awareness continued to drive comp growth of 45%.
Kors has consistently topped analysts' sales and earnings forecasts since its IPO on Dec. 15, 2011.
"The brand is resonating very well with European consumers," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy.
Kors sees Q3 sales in the range of $845 million-$855 million. This assumes a same-store sales gain in the range of 15%-20%. It expects earnings of 83-85 cents a share.

For the full year, it sees total revenue of $2.9 billion-$3 billion vs. Wall Street forecasts for $2.99 billion. This assumes a comparable store sales increase of approximately 20%. Tech stocks slumped again Monday, but it could have been worse as the Nasdaq closed well off session lows. For the broader market, it wasn't so bad.
The Nasdaq slumped as much as 2% before closing with a loss of 1.2%. It closed above its 50-day moving average after briefly undercutting the support level.
The S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.2%. Preliminary data showed Nasdaq volume coming in close to Friday's level. NYSE volume fell 44%.
In the stock market today, leading growth stocks took it on the chin again. Nearly half the names in the IBD 50 lost 3% or more.

Biotechs took another hit as IBD's Medical-Biomed/Biotech group slumped around 4%. Selling continued in high-quality names like Biogen Idec (BIIB), down 2%, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), down 6%.

Other institutional-quality growth names like Netflix (NFLX), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell anywhere from 3% to 7%. Chipotle is the only one holding above its 10-week moving average, a key support level.

Elsewhere, Michael Kors (KORS) had been trading tightly in recent weeks after a breakout over 84.68, but sellers were in the stock Monday as shares fell 3%. It managed to close above its 10-week moving average, though, an encouraging sign in an unsettled market.

Shares of Apple (AAPL) bucked the trend and rose 1% after some analysts said the iPhone 6 is expected to roll out in late summer, or early fall. Apple's stock is working on a handle area of a long cup-with-handle base that started in September 2012. It still has a ways to go to get to a potential buy point of 575.23. Shares closed at 539.10, about 6% off its 52-week high.

Tomorrow, watch for earnings from G-III Apparel (GIII). It closed above its 50-day moving average after briefly undercutting the support level.The S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.2%.
