(See story here) Some analysts believe the electric-car maker's shares have raced ahead too far…
Though some retailers have reason to cheer, this year's holiday retail season is anything but rosy, say retail experts who routinely track the busiest buying season of the year.

With holiday sales now mostly in the bag, sales for November and December are seen up anywhere from 2.4% to 3.9%, depending on who is counting. But discounting — with all the big percentage-off sales that stores have advertised to lure shoppers — could eat into retailer profits.
The post-Christmas shopping week can help, but it won't make the season shine bright, most watchers say.

"It's coming so late in the game, you simply run out of time to make up for lost sales in the first eight weeks of the season," said Craig Johnson, president of retail consultancy Customer Growth Partners.
"Can gift cards and online salvage December?" asked Retail Metrics in a Tuesday report. Its answer: "Not likely."
Due to the later Thanksgiving, this year's shopping season was shorter than last year's season by a week.
Stores Less Crowded

ShopperTrak estimates that retail-store sales will be up only 2.4% in November and December, with traffic off by double digits as consumers did more comparison shopping online ahead of their visits to brick-and-mortar stores.

Michael Niemira, chief economist at the International Council of Shopping Centers, forecasts retail sales growth of 3.4% for November and December vs. 3% in last year's holiday season, with stronger sales in December than November because of a spike in online shopping during the month.
Cyber Monday, for example, came in December this year but in November last year.
The NPD Group expects 2.5% to 3% growth in holiday retail sales. Retail industry trade group the National Retail Federation has the rosiest forecast at 3.9% growth.

In-store retail sales for the week ended Sunday, Dec. 22, were down 3.1% from the same week last year, Retail Metrics reported on Tuesday. The drop was due in part to bad weather, though the Northeast had unseasonably warm weather over the weekend.
The week before, when winter storms hit the Midwest and East, sales were off 0.8%.
The analytics firm predicts that after-holiday markdowns will drive "robust" retail sales, especially the day after Christmas and on Saturday.

Despite improved consumer confidence, and a rising economy and stock market, some say the biggest problem with retail sales comes down to Americans' wages: They still aren't going up very much. This year's retailer effort — with longer store hours and earlier and continued promotions — "doesn't change demand," Johnson said.

"It doesn't put more dollars in your pocketbook. The single biggest driver of retail sales is growth in real disposable income. And real disposable income growth has been minuscule," he said, noting that it was up only 0.6% in November vs. a year earlier.
"On a per-capita basis it was down 0.1%. Essentially you have zero income growth, so it's little wonder you're not having significant retail growth," Johnson said.

"Consumers tapped out early," added Marshal Cohen, chief retail analyst with NPD Group, referring to how people shopped pre- and post-Black Friday deals. But he expected a lot of last-minute online shopping for gift cards.
Christmas Eve Stirrings
For the week ended Dec. 21, the ICSC-Goldman Sachs chain store sales index rose 1.4% from the prior week. In an ICSC-Goldman Sachs survey, 31% of consumers said they planned to shop on Christmas Eve.

"It's not a strong season when you look at the collective measures," said Niemira, referring to sales, margins and the breadth of discounting — even on the luxury end — which wasn't as noticeable last year.
It's not a broad-based improvement, he added.
"I have to worry about some of the margin erosion that has occurred, and that has an implication for profits," Niemira said. "Once the earnings data comes out you'll really know."
Since most retailers end their fiscal year in January, earnings for the holiday quarter won't start coming out until February at the earliest.
Home furnishings, luxury and footwear have been the strongest sectors, while teen apparel has lagged, retail experts say.
In Tuesday's report, Retail Metrics said Macy's (M) "was by far the most heavily shopped department store" through the holiday season, and especially this past weekend.
It said teen apparel chains, Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) in particular, "looked eerily quiet," despite storewide discounts of 40% to 50%.
Retail Metrics said it expects Aeropostale (ARO) and Abercrombie to post double-digit declines in same-store sales in Q4.

Leading in its same-store sales growth forecasts are the upscale home furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware (RH) and luxury apparel and accessories company Michael Kors (KORS) (an IBD 50 stock), with gains of 24.4% and 20.4%, respectively.
Appliance and furniture company Conn's (CONN) follows at 20%.
Retail Metrics expects that overall retail same-store sales will rise by 1.9% in November and 2.9% in December.

Wal-Mart (WMT) is expected to squeeze out a "meager" 0.3% increase in same-store sales in Q4, Retail Metrics said, noting that the mass-market retailer has dragged down its index for some time, posting positive comps in just six of the past 18 quarters.
Same-store sales at Target (TGT), hurt by a credit card security breach at the height of the shopping season, are seen falling 0.8% in Q4.
Footwear made it to the top 10 gift list this year for the first time, and was in the top three on Black Friday, says Cohen. Beneficiaries include Finish Line (FINL) and Foot Locker (FL), he says.

"Women grabbed boots and shoes in deals too good to pass up," he said. "It's clearly self-gifting."Though some retailers have reason to cheer, this year's holiday retail season is anything but rosy, say retail experts who routinely track the busiest buying season of the year.With holiday sales now mostly in the bag, sales for November and December are seen up anywhere from 2.4% to 3.9%, depending on who is counting. But discounting — with all the big percentage-off sales that stores have advertised to lure shoppers — could eat into retailer profits.The post-Christmas shopping week can help, but it won't make the season shine bright, most watchers say."It's coming so late in the game, you simply run out of time to make up for lost sales in the first eight weeks of the season," said Craig Johnson, president of retail consultancy Customer Growth Partners."Can gift cards and online salvage December?" asked Retail Metrics in a Tuesday report. But he expected a lot of last-minute online shopping for gift cards.Christmas Eve StirringsFor the week ended Dec. 21, the ICSC-Goldman Sachs chain store sales index rose 1.4% from the prior week. "Once the earnings data comes out you'll really know."Since most retailers end their fiscal year in January, earnings for the holiday quarter won't start coming out until February at the earliest.Home furnishings, luxury and footwear have been the strongest sectors, while teen apparel has lagged, retail experts say.In Tuesday's report, Retail Metrics said Macy's (M) "was by far the most heavily shopped department store" through the holiday season, and especially this past weekend.It said teen apparel chains, Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) in particular, "looked eerily quiet," despite storewide discounts of 40% to 50%.Retail Metrics said it expects Aeropostale (ARO) and Abercrombie to post double-digit declines in same-store sales in Q4.Leading in its same-store sales growth forecasts are the upscale home furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware (RH) and luxury apparel and accessories company Michael Kors (KORS) (an IBD 50 stock), with gains of 24.4% and 20.4%, respectively.Appliance and furniture company Conn's (CONN) follows at 20%.Retail Metrics expects that overall retail same-store sales will rise by 1.9% in November and 2.9% in December.Wal-Mart (WMT) is expected to squeeze out a "meager" 0.3% increase in same-store sales in Q4, Retail Metrics said, noting that the mass-market retailer has dragged down its index for some time, posting positive comps in just six of the past 18 quarters.Same-store sales at Target (TGT), hurt by a credit card security breach at the height of the shopping season, are seen falling 0.8% in Q4.Footwear made it to the top 10 gift list this year for the first time, and was in the top three on Black Friday, says Cohen. Beneficiaries include Finish Line (FINL) and Foot Locker (FL), he says."Women grabbed boots and shoes in deals too good to pass up," he said. "It's clearly self-gifting."

CyberArk Software (CYBR) gapped up, rallied 5% and regained its 50-day moving average. The line had acted as resistance as the stock bounced back after a sell signal in late June. But CyberArk still has more work to do to form a new base.

Nvidia (NVDA) climbed 4% in fast trade after bouncing back from early weakness. The stock cleared a 23.70 buy point from a consolidation. Shares of the graphics chip maker already surged 12% Friday on its Q2 results.

With the loss, the correction in JD.com's handle stands at 18%. "Affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors ' (KORS) sell-off this week makes one wonder: Is this a buy opportunity or a loud danger warning?
Michael Kors, which debuted on the NYSE just 10 months ago, peaked Friday at 57.35, or 16% past its 49.60 buy point.

But the retreat had some terror-filled moments. The first appeared Monday, as it fell 5% in fast trade. That tumble cost Michael Kors more than half of Friday's dramatic price gain, although even Monday's fast pace couldn't compare with Friday's volume.

The scariest moment appeared Tuesday: Michael Kors fell 4%, completely erasing Friday's huge gain. Even worse was Tuesday's volume, which screamed to its highest pace — 25 million shares — since the stock's IPO. Kors priced a share offering that day.
Yes, shares of Michael Kors had fallen back to the 5% buy range from its 49.60 buy point. But the nasty action of the decline could be enough to scare off anyone.
But the company's fundamentals remain solid.
It has logged triple-digit earnings gains in four of the past five quarters. Even that one double-digit rise, 87% in the December-ended quarter, was no black mark.
Sales gains in the past four quarters ranged from 58% to 71%, the latter being its highest in at least 3-1/2 years.
After-tax margin rose to 16.5% in Q1, also its highest in years. Each of the four most recent quarterly reports showed after-tax margin improvements over the respective year-earlier result.
Annual pretax margin hit 21% in fiscal 2012 ended in March, Michael Kors' third-straight improvement.
Return on equity remained strong, at 56%. The company's long-term debt as a ratio of shareholder equity fell from 211% two years ago to 81% one year ago to zero last year.
Those big debts one and two years ago helped prop up return on equity, but in an unhealthy manner. Michael Kors is better off with the lower (but still fabulous) ROE and without the IOUs.
Michael Kors leads the apparel manufacturers' group by its near-perfect EPS, Relative Price Strength and Composite Ratings.

So what's the bottom line? It's hard to believe that shares of this thriving business are done after 10 months. Remember, the first 15 years of a publicly traded stock are often the prime of its life.
But the fearsome manner that Michael Kors fell this week makes one believe that prudence may be called for.

The only problem with that approach is the buying range from the Aug. 17 breakout only runs as high as 52.08. Michael Kors is already basically at that price."Affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors ' (KORS) sell-off this week makes one wonder: Is this a buy opportunity or a loud danger warning?Michael Kors, which debuted on the NYSE just 10 months ago, peaked Friday at 57.35, or 16% past its 49.60 buy point.But the retreat had some terror-filled moments. The stock market scored its first up day of 2014 on Tuesday as a rash of leaders cleared bases or extended gains from fresh breakouts.Tech stocks lifted the Nasdaq to a 1% gain, while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials each rose 0.6%. (YY) powered 8% higher and out of buy range as it followed through on a Friday breakout. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.4%, weighed down by weak earnings from IBM (IBM). Shares fell 4% after fourth-quarter revenue came up short. The S&P 500 fell 0.1% while the Nasdaq added 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking lower than Tuesday.

In the stock market today, railroad operator Norfolk Southern (NSC) gapped up on strong earnings before the open. Shares rose 6% to an all-time high. Norfolk cleared a flat-base buy point of 89.09 in December. It's now 5.5% above the buy point.

Now that about three-quarters of S&P 500 companies have reported, Michael Kors (KORS), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Stratasys (SSYS) represent the few remaining chances to buy or sell an IBD 50 stock ahead of their quarterly results — if you can stomach the potential ups and downs that earnings season often brings.Continental Resources (CLR), Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) are also scheduled to report in the coming week, rounding out a list of big names in their respective industries.Michael Kors (No. 49 on the latest IBD 50 list) is expected to grow earnings per share 39% to 68 cents when it reports Nov. 5 before the market open.That would be the lowest quarterly growth since the seller of luxury apparel and accessories went public in December 2011, during which time its shares have surged more than 275%. Analysts forecast sales will rise 36%, also its slowest gain since its IPO.The former "Project Runway" judge's namesake company has taken the fashion world by storm. A recent Piper Jaffray survey of teens showed Michael Kors handbags were the second-most preferred by that age group — just behind old guard Coach (COH) — and rapidly taking market share.Kors also will be joining the S&P 500 soon, once Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) and NYSE Euronext (NYX) complete their merger, which was expected to close Nov. 4 but was delayed.Wall Street analysts think Jazz Pharma (No. 7) will post a 29% jump in Q3 EPS to $1.67 a share, the Irish company's lowest quarterly growth rate in years. Sales are expected to rise 58%, lighter than the past six quarters.Jazz's EPS Rating is a highest-possible 99, as is its Composite Rating, which combines five key fundamental gauges with stock-price performance. The stock has rallied 70% this year.FBR Capital began covering the specialty drugmaker recently with an outperform rating.Sturm Ruger (No. 19) also announces results Nov. 5 after hours. Analysts expect the gunmaker to report a 38% profit increase to $1.21 a share, which would be its lightest growth in eight quarters. Sales are seen growing 31%, also the slowest since Q2.The Southport, Conn.-based company scores a 99 EPS Rating, the highest possible.Shares fell 6% Oct. 24 after retailer Cabela's (CAB) cited a "significant deceleration" in firearms and ammunition sales as it missed its profit and sales targets. But Sturm Ruger has nearly recovered all those losses and is 4% off its 52-week high.Energy company Continental Resources (No. 33) is on tap for Nov. 6 and has been riding the North American shale energy boom that drilling techniques like hydraulic fracturing have unlocked.It is the largest landholder in the lucrative Bakken Shale, and analysts expect it to earn $1.48 a share, up 70% from a year earlier. Revenue is seen surging 53% to $970.67.Consensus estimates call for a 5% EPS gain when Stratasys (No. 15) reports Thursday before the opening bell. That's a sharp slowdown for the 3D printer maker, after 14 quarters of 29% or better growth. Analysts expect sales to surge 136%, its highest level in years.Stratasys boasts a 99 Composite Rating. Rival 3D Systems (DDD) last month reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings but cut its full-year forecast as it spends more to boost expansion.Priceline.com (No. 12) rounds out the top five IBD 50 leaders reporting this week. The online travel booking site, which gives results Thursday after the close, is expected to grow Q3 profit 31% to $16.22, an acceleration from Q2's 24% gain.Revenue growth is estimated to be 30%, which would be higher than the past six quarters. Priceline's share price has soared 69% this year. And its stock isn't the only highflier. It has a 99 for its EPS and Composite ratings.Among other IBD 50 leaders also reporting this week, MercadoLibre (MELI) (No. 34) is on tap for after hours Nov. 5. Analysts expect a 24% earnings increase to 73 cents a share.

Michael Kors (KORS) disappointed a lot of investors in 2012 and early this year by reporting excellent earnings, driving the stock price higher, then selling massive amounts of stock in secondary offerings that drove the price right back down.
But since its July 31 breakout, it's moved higher in a smooth fashion, now achieving a 19% gain from the buy point. The stock Thursday rose 1.77 to 77.49. Volume was 23% above average.

The luxury retailer has reported excellent earnings growth, with the last four quarters up 96%, 129%, 138% and 79%. Sales growth has also been strong, up 74%, 70%, 57% and 54%. Its return on equity, a measure of how efficiently management uses available capital, is a remarkable 53%.
The company markets luxury apparel, accessories and shoes in 85 countries through 237 stores and 2,677 wholesale accounts.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) climbed 3.29 to 106.12, breaking out of a base-on-base formation. Volume was a bit light for a breakout, at 36% above average.
Valeant has four straight years of earnings growth and an Earnings Stability Factor of 15 on a 1-to-99 scale in which low numbers correspond to steadier earnings.
EPS grew 33% in the most recent quarter, and analysts are expecting a 23% increase in the current quarter.
It has a best-possible Composite Rating of 99. It's made a huge move since posting a 2009 low.

Among Sector Leaders, the biggest loser Thursday was Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR). It shed 4.95, or 8%, to 60.68 and pierced its 50-day moving average in above-average volume. Investors without borders are seeing plenty of U.S.-listed foreign stocks with top ratings setting up or near buy points. Let's look at a few. Michael Kors (KORS): The Hong Kong-based affordable-luxury fashion house just last week hit the 20% profit mark from its 65.21 cup-with-handle buy point. That would be a fine spot to at least start taking profits. But…
Stocks were in a cheery mood again Tuesday, one day after the market resumed its uptrend.

The Dow Jones industrial average outpeformed, rising 0.7%. The blue-chip index made headlines because Alcoa (AA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Bank of America (BAC) will be dropped from the blue-chip index next week, replaced by Nike (NKE), Visa (V)and Goldman Sachs (GS). The changes will take effect Sept. 20 after the close.
The S&P 500 added 0.6% and the Nasdaq rose 0.5%. The Nasdaq gapped up at the open but was trading near its session low. NYSE and Nasdaq volume is tracking higher than Monday's action.
More positive economic data out of China fueled positive sentiment. August retail sales jumped 13.4% from a year ago while industrial production rose 10.4%.

In the stock market today, SS&C Technologies (SSNC) added 4% as it continues work on flat base with a potential buy point of 38.90. The company is a provider of financial services software with a consistent track record of earnings and sales growth.

Among the day's losers, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) slumped 2%. The stock's recent breakout from a cup-with-handle base hasn't made much progress. It cleared a buy point of 82.61 on Aug. 20 but the breakout never really got going. It's now 2% above that buy point.
Meanwhile, sellers were in Michael Kors (KORS) again. The stock pierced its 10-day moving average, falling 3%. It's now 13% above a cup-with-handle buy point of 65.21.

After the close, watch for earnings from Restoration Hardware (RH). Shares are now fractionally lower after a 2% gain earlier in the session. The luxury home-furnishings retailer is back in growth mode after coming out of a restructuring in November. The market closed with sharp losses Monday, despite that it erased erasing some of the damage.
A 5% drop in the Shanghai Composite overnight rattled Wall Street. Worries about tightening credit conditions compounded fears about reduced stimulus in the U.S.

The S&P 500 lost 1.2%, the Nasdaq 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.9%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in well below Friday's levels. Volume on Friday was unusually high due to quadruple witching options expiration.
The yield on the 10-year note increased another five basis points to 2.56%.
After the bell in the stock market today, Michael Kors (KORS) and VF Corp. (VFC) got some good news. Deutsche Bank initiated coverage of both stocks with buy ratings, CNBC reported.

Tenet Healthcare (THC) rallied on news it's acquiring fellow hospital operator Vanguard Health Systems (VHS) for about $1.8 billion. Shares of Tenet Healthcare rose 4.5% while Vanguard Health Systems surged 67%. The deal values Vanguard at 21 a share; it closed at 20.70.

Stocks recovered most of their early losses but were having trouble crossing into positive territory late Tuesday as traders sifted through a raft of earnings and economic data. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq each fell 0.7% early in the session but recovered. The Nasdaq was later up 0.2% while the S&P 500 was down 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average…
Stocks were on pace for a flat to slightly higher start Monday amid mixed overseas action.
Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures were up less than a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average were up 15 points in the stock market today.

The major indexes posted big gains last week, but failed to recoup the bulk of the prior week's sharp slide. Despite gains in the overall market last week, a number of market leaders such as Outerwall (OUTR), Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) and Taser International (TASR) got whacked.
U.S. stock futures still fared better than the mixed action overseas. The Greek stock market reopened for the first time in five weeks, plunging by nearly 23% before cutting losses.
But Germany's DAX and France's CAC-40 climbed 1% and 0.7%, respectively. The euro fell to 1.095 from 1.0984 late Friday.
Asian stock markets were firmly lower following weak manufacturing data. The Shanghai composite slumped 1.1%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.9%.
In economic news, personal income rose 0.4% in June, slightly above views for a 0.3% increase. Spending edged up 0.2%, matching views by Econoday. But that was the smallest gain in four months.
Factory data from Markit will be out at 9:45 a.m., and ISM's manufacturing report will be released at 10 a.m. Data on construction spending will also be out at 10 a.m.

In stocks, Tyson Foods (TSN) tumbled 8% in the premarket after posting disappointing quarterly results and cut its full-year earnings outlook. The company said its beef business suffered disruptions in the export market.

Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG) said it bought privately held Foresight Biotherapeutics for $300 million. Foresight makes a treatment for infectious conjunctivitis, or pink eye. The stock is 27% past its 34.09 buy point from a double-bottom base but is finding support at the 50-day moving average. Vipshop, which offers "flash sales" on its website, was the subject of positive comments in a Barron's article.

When IBD founder William O'Neil set out to discover the characteristics of winning stocks, his study came back with a resounding conclusion:Outstanding earnings growth in the most recent quarters is the single most important trait that identifies winners before they start their major price advances.The study — which analyzed the fundamentals and stock-price behavior of the best stocks during past bull markets — identified other common factors that exist in the formative stage of a future winner.Ultimately, explosive earnings growth, O'Neil explained, goes hand-in-hand with superior stock performance. Generally speaking, the bigger the earnings growth, the better.Specifically, look for a company's earnings per share up at least 25% vs. the year-ago level in the most recent quarter or two. Gains of 50%, 100% or more are typical of market leaders — before they make their huge price moves.That's the essence of the "C" in O'Neil's CAN SLIM investing strategy, which stands for current earnings growth.There's really no mystery about this connection. The most successful companies tend to generate the strongest profit gains, regardless of the economic cycle.Even during periods when corporate profits are weak, you still find standouts that achieve impressive earnings growth.Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), the name behind the popular single-cup Keurig brewers, posted EPS jumps of 45% and 58% the two latest quarters. Facebook's (FB) earnings soared 58% in Q2 as it leverages its social media service to generate mobile-ad revenue.Michael Kors (KORS), enjoying solid demand for its chic luxury merchandise, reported a 79% EPS rise in its last quarter.Several resources in IBD and Investors.com can help investors find companies with top earnings growth.The best way to get the latest quarterly earnings is to call up a quote on Investors.com. A table displays the company's most recent EPS percentage change plus sales growth, three-year earnings growth rate and other financials.The IBD Stock Checkup , another online tool, also shows the latest quarter's number, with a bonus: the average EPS growth over the past three quarters.MarketSmith, a sister charting and equity research service, includes the EPS for the four most recent periods.For a more comprehensive look at earnings performance, you can use the EPS Rating. The proprietary rating compares a company's two most recent quarters and the three-year profit performance against all stocks. It's listed in the Investors.com quotes and various tables in IBD.The minicharts for IBD 50 in Wednesday's edition are another place to view the most recent EPS and the average percentage gain over the past three quarters.

Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS), Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) and other companies serving the consumer market are in the upper echelon of leading stocks, demonstrating the resilient demand for certain indulgences amid a weak recovery — and now the government shutdown.
No one really needs a single-cup coffee brewer. But it's nice to wake up to a hot, fresh cup of joe instead of reheating what's left in the coffee pot.

The top five IBD 50 stocks selling products that are nice to have — affordable luxuries to a certain degree — are Nu Skin, Green Mountain, Lithia Motors (LAD), Herbalife (HLF) and Michael Kors (KORS).

Nu Skin, which leads at No. 2 on the IBD 50, is a mainstay on the list. The direct seller of skin care, nutritional and weight management products is based in Provo, Utah, but some 80% of its revenue comes from Asia. The Americas, though, have provided solid growth too, with sales there rising 17% in Q2.

The stock has been on a tear, soaring nearly 170% this year. Its 99 Composite Rating indicates Nu Skin's strong fundamentals — including 98 EPS, 97 Relative Strength and A Accumulation-Distribution scores — outperform 99% of all other stocks tracked by IBD.
Green Mountain, known for its Keurig brewers and staying power in the IBD 50, is No. 3.
Starbucks (SBUX) late last year rolled out its competing Verismo single-serve brewer, but Keurig still dominates the at-home segment with an 80%-90% share.
Vermont-based Green Mountain expanded beyond coffee and tea with its deal last month to add Campbell Soup (CPB) cups to its lineup.
Green Mountain's profit growth has accelerated the past two quarters from 27% to 45% and 58%, helping it earn a highest-possible EPS Rating of 99.
Lithia Motors, No. 6 on the list, has been helped by Americans' growing desire to buy shiny, new cars and finally ditch their old ones.
The Medford, Ore.-based new- and used-car seller operates 87 dealerships in 11 states, mostly west of the Mississippi. It targets smaller metro and rural areas with little competition.
The company, which boasts a 98 Composite Rating, has grown EPS by at least 42% in the past four quarters. Sales growth has held in the double-digits for 13 consecutive quarters.

Next up is No. 15 Herbalife, which has had its fair share of ups and downs the past year. The drama kicked into high gear late last year when activist investor Bill Ackman of Pershing Square bet $1 billion the stock would tank.

Since then, the marketer of nutritional and weight-loss supplements has seen its shares rally 170% as big investors like Carl Icahn and George Soros took long positions. Herbalife hit a new high Sept. 17 amid talk the company will aggressively buy back shares.

The ever-present Michael Kors rounds out the top five at No. 33. Shares of the former "Project Runway" judge's apparel line have nearly quadrupled from their December 2011 debut and are up 51% this year.

Profit and sales growth slowed down the past two quarters but remain robust at 79% and 54%, respectively.Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS), Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) and other companies serving the consumer market are in the upper echelon of leading stocks, demonstrating the resilient demand for certain indulgences amid a weak recovery — and now the government shutdown.No one really needs a single-cup coffee brewer. G-III Apparel Group (GIII) defied forecasts for lower second-quarter profit, easily beating second-quarter estimates and issuing a bullish full-year forecast, sending shares sharply higher Wednesday. The New York-based clothing and accessories maker, which has fashion licenses for brands such as Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger, Dockers, the NFL, NBA and other sports leagues, earned 17 cents a share in the quarter…
Investors will get a read on how luxury retailers fared in Q2 when Tiffany & Co. (TIF) and Signet Jewelers  (SIG) report earnings this week.
If analysts are on target, Tiffany will see an uptick in profit growth from the prior quarter, but a slight decline in the pace of sales gains, while Signet will see a slowdown in both measures.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Tiffany to report a 3% rise in earnings to 74 cents a share when the upscale jeweler reports results on Tuesday before the bell. That would compare with a 2% gain in Q1. They forecast the jeweler will post a 6.1% rise in sales to $941.37 million. That would compare with a 9% increase in Q1.

The Street sees Signet showing a 1% decline in earnings to 83 cents a share when it reports early Thursday. That would be down from Q1’s solid 18% EPS gain for the operator of Kay Jewelers and Jared The Galleria Of Jewelry. Sales likely rose 6.6% to $909.90 million. That would compare with a 10% increase in Q1.

Signet and Tiffany shares fell fractionally Monday afternoon, but are close to record highs, especially Tiffany.A slew of retailers have showed disappointing results this earnings season as many mid-to-low end consumer have pared spending on discretionary goods. Through August 22, 33% of retailers that had reported had missed views, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. That’s well above the long-term average of 19%, Perkins says.

But upscale chains have generally have fared better. Michael Kors  (KORS) reported much-better-than expected quarterly results earlier this month. The fund managers have earned props as successful investors by making sure many names in their small portfolio are innovators, such as Michael Kors (KORS), up 41% this year; Facebook (FB), up 44% this…

VF Corp. (VFC) missed third-quarter revenue forecasts, but strong Vans and overseas sales helped the apparel maker top earnings estimates. The Greensboro, N.C.-based company also announced a 4-for-1 stock split and hiked its quarterly dividend by 21% to $1.05 a share. Shares gapped up to a new high after VF reported profit of $3.91 a share ex items, up 11%…
The bets are in that a wide swath of retailers will share the winner's circle in the race to lure consumers this holiday season.

If analysts' forecasts are on the money, retailers that cater to the upper-income crowd — such as fashion house and IBD 50 stock Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and upscale jeweler Tiffany & Co. (TIF) — should keep up the fast pace for the holiday period. So should department stores such as strong third-quarter performerMacy's (M), home furnishings retailers such as Haverty Furniture Cos. (HVT) and sporting goods stores like Cabela's (CAB)and Big 5 Sporting Goods (BGFV).
"It's going to be a bit mixed," said Ken Perkins, president of analysis firm Retail Metrics.
Third-quarter reports from major retailers in the last few days have given hints of how "mixed" the showing may be.

Macy's set a high bar, posting third-quarter earnings Wednesday that sailed past views and giving positive commentary on the outlook for the fourth quarter. It's clear from the comments of Macy's CEO Terry Lundgren that Macy's is in "good shape" for the holiday, Perkins says.
Who Can Spend?

But the next day, retail industry bellwether Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) posted results that raised concerns about spending by lower- to moderate-income consumers. The giant discounter beat analysts' earnings forecasts by 1 cent, but missed views on revenue and saw its third consecutive quarterly decline in same-store sales. It also gave a disappointing fourth-quarter earnings outlook that was slightly below consensus.

Value-priced department store operator Kohl's (KSS) also reported lackluster third-quarter results Thursday, missing earnings estimates by 5 cents. It cut its fourth-quarter outlook on prospects for softer holiday sales.

"The reports from Wal-Mart and Kohl's suggest the low- to moderate-income consumer is still feeling pressured," Perkins said. "It's going to be a barbell effect once again this holiday, with high-end retailers exposed to a higher-end consumer doing far better because their customers have more disposable income to spend on discretionary purchases."

Retailers head into the holiday season as worries over jobs, the economy and fiscal policy uncertainty have taken some of the cheer out of holiday gift-buying for many Americans, particularly low- to middle-income consumers.
That's sparked heated competition for a share of holiday spending.

"The holiday will be extremely competitive and very promotional with the potential for a modest upside, given that expectations are low and that gas prices have come down so much and are expected to come down more," Perkins said.
The lower gas prices are a "wild card" in terms of how that will impact spending, he adds. And the savings could be "significant."
The consumer mood is "cautious," adds Michael Niemira, chief economist for the International Council of Shopping Centers.

"Consumers are not so upbeat," he said. "But you've got to believe that with somewhat better employment, somewhat better economic numbers generally and lower gas prices, consumer confidence will march higher too and support holiday spending."
Holiday Outlook Tallies

Niemira forecasts a 3.4% gain from a year ago in GAFO (general merchandise, apparel and accessories, furniture and other) sales for November-December. That would be a "tad" stronger than last year's 3% increase, he says.

"For sales to be spectacular this holiday, it all depends on consumer sentiment, which now is rocky," said Jharonne Martis, director of consumer research for Thomson Reuters. "Consumers are very concerned about the government's leadership ability and job security. If they feel their jobs are being threatened, they're going to hold back on spending."
Analysts expect that the retail industry will see a 4% gain in fourth-quarter earnings from a year ago, according to Retail Metrics. For most chains, the fourth quarter runs November through January.
The forecast compares against an 8.2% gain in fourth-quarter earnings in 2012, Perkins says. But, he adds, then the industry was up against the easy comparison underlying a 2.5% rise in 2011.

The home furnishings segment and entertainment segments of retailing are expected to see the biggest gain in fourth-quarter earnings with a 13% rise for each, Perkins says. Both are projected to see the biggest sales increases among the categories, each with an 8% rise.
The home furnishings niche has stores like high-end Restoration Hardware Holdings (RH) plus Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) and Haverty.
Home And Away
These players are benefiting from the housing recovery and rising home prices that have spurred consumers to spruce up with new furniture and home decor.
"A lot of analysts are commenting that because consumers have invested so much money in their houses, they might actually spend more on them at the holiday season," Martis said.
Home improvement chains such as Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's Cos. (LOW) should fare well, she adds.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect fourth-quarter same-store sales for the home improvement segment to rise 4% vs. a year earlier, Martis notes. That compares with an estimated 1.9% rise for the industry overall, as of readings on Wednesday, and a 2.4% gain excluding Wal-Mart, she says.
The entertainment segment includes outdoor retailer Cabela's and sporting goods retailer Big 5 Sporting Goods, both of which are expected to see double-digit earnings gains in the fourth quarter.
Sporting goods stores are likely spots for holiday buying, as they "tend to offer what young adults and teens really like," with broad offerings of branded apparel and footwear, Perkins says.

The department store segment should be another top performer this holiday, with an estimated 12% rise in fourth-quarter earnings, Perkins says. The group includes J.C. Penney (JCP), Macy's and Dillard's (DDS).

"Much of the group's growth is expected to come from J.C. Penney, which is expected to cut last year's huge loss in half this year as it works hard to get back to its roots and discounts aggressively this holiday season," Perkins said.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see J.C. Penney's fourth-quarter earnings rising 54% from a year earlier, while earnings at Macy's are expected to be up 5% and Dillard's is forecast to see a 7% rise.
'Wealth Effect' Felt

"The luxury markets remain strong," said Lawrence Creatura, portfolio manager for Federated Investors. "The more-affluent consumers are feeling a wealth effect from the stock market and other increases in asset value."
Among beneficiaries of the more flush high-end consumer's position are retailers such as department store Nordstrom (JWN), Michael Kors, Tiffany and Restoration Hardware, Perkins says.
"Kors has a brand that's on fire and its fashion has been received extremely well among high-end consumers," Perkins said.
He notes that it's expected to see a 34% increase in fiscal third-quarter earnings, its holiday quarter. Kors holds the No. 32 spot on the current IBD 50 list, a roster of top-rated growth stocks.

Niemira says the luxury segment has been performing better than the industry overall, and continues to do so. It's been seeing same-store sales growth of 4% year over year in recent months, a rate he sees continuing in the fourth quarter. That would be double the 2% increase in fourth-quarter comps that he projects for the industry.

Auto parts retailers are expected to see an 11% jump in fourth-quarter earnings, as consumers have revved up spending on new cars and also are sprucing up old ones. The segment includes retailers such as O'Reilly Automotive (ORL) and AutoZone (AZO).

Hipster and Bohemian-style apparel retailer Urban Outfitters (URBN) is expected to see a 14.5% jump in fourth-quarter comps at its Free People chain, making it the industry's best performer, says Martis.
"What analysts love about this company is their ability to sell unique merchandise at full price, and they're impressed with management's ability to control inventory."

Online retailer Amazon.com (AMZN) is expected to be piping hot this holiday season, too. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect it to see a stunning 215.9% surge in fourth-quarter earnings, Martis says.The bets are in that a wide swath of retailers will share the winner's circle in the race to lure consumers this holiday season.If analysts' forecasts are on the money, retailers that cater to the upper-income crowd — such as fashion house and IBD 50 stock Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and upscale jeweler Tiffany & Co. (TIF) — should keep up the fast pace for the holiday period. So should department stores such as strong third-quarter performerMacy's (M), home furnishings retailers such as Haverty Furniture Cos. (HVT) and sporting goods stores like Cabela's (CAB)and Big 5 Sporting Goods (BGFV)."It's going to be a bit mixed," said Ken Perkins, president of analysis firm Retail Metrics.Third-quarter reports from major retailers in the last few days have given hints of how "mixed" the showing may be.Macy's set a high bar, posting third-quarter earnings Wednesday that sailed past views and giving positive commentary on the outlook for the fourth quarter. It's clear from the comments of Macy's CEO Terry Lundgren that Macy's is in "good shape" for the holiday, Perkins says.Who Can Spend?But the next day, retail industry bellwether Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) posted results that raised concerns about spending by lower- to moderate-income consumers. The giant discounter beat analysts' earnings forecasts by 1 cent, but missed views on revenue and saw its third consecutive quarterly decline in same-store sales. It also gave a disappointing fourth-quarter earnings outlook that was slightly below consensus.Value-priced department store operator Kohl's (KSS) also reported lackluster third-quarter results Thursday, missing earnings estimates by 5 cents. It cut its fourth-quarter outlook on prospects for softer holiday sales."The reports from Wal-Mart and Kohl's suggest the low- to moderate-income consumer is still feeling pressured," Perkins said. "It's going to be a barbell effect once again this holiday, with high-end retailers exposed to a higher-end consumer doing far better because their customers have more disposable income to spend on discretionary purchases."Retailers head into the holiday season as worries over jobs, the economy and fiscal policy uncertainty have taken some of the cheer out of holiday gift-buying for many Americans, particularly low- to middle-income consumers.That's sparked heated competition for a share of holiday spending."The holiday will be extremely competitive and very promotional with the potential for a modest upside, given that expectations are low and that gas prices have come down so much and are expected to come down more," Perkins said. Newly public companies such as Michael Kors (KORS) and Facebook (FB) have been outperforming older ones like Priceline (PCLN), whose earnings report Thursday could put it further behind the hottest, youngest stocks.IBD's Young Guns Screen Of The Day features highly rated companies that have gone public in the last 15 years.Facebook is the youngest of the Young Guns with an IPO date of May 2012, while Priceline's IPO in March 1999 makes it the oldest on the list of 20 stocks.Analysts expect the travel site to earn $9.38 a share for Q2, but EPS growth of 19% would be the slowest in years. Revenue is seen rising 25% to $1.66 billionMeanwhile, Michael Kors, which went public in December 2011, reported Tuesday that Q1 EPS soared 79% to 61 cents a share, beating expectations by 12 cents. Revenue rose 54.5% to $640.9 million, also above estimates.Kors is also ranked No. 29 on the prestigious IBD 50 list, and shares climbed 3.7% to 70.39.LinkedIn (LNKD) went public in May 2011, and the professional networking site's premium paid service for attracting serious job seekers helped send Q2 earnings up 138% to 38 cents per share, beating views by 7 cents.Facebook also makes the screen, after posting its first strong quarter since going public. The social networking leader had been struggling with revenue growth as it works to improve mobile advertising, but mobile ad sales jumped 75% in Q2 vs. Q1.That lifted EPS up 58% year over year to 19 cents, beating estimates.Yandex (YNDX), Russia's top search engine, went public in May 2011 and last month reported a 47% jump in quarterly earnings to 28 cents a share. Revenue also rose as paid ad clicks were up 29%. Yandex raised its full-year EPS outlook.Tangoe (TNGO), which went public in July 2011, provides on-demand software for companies. Analysts are expecting the company to post a 60% jump in EPS to 16 cents, when it reports earnings Wednesday. Revenue is also seen rising.Spirit Airlines (SAVE) rounds out the top six youngest of the Young Guns. Its fees, which extend to even carry-on bags, pushed the discount airline's EPS up 29% to 63 cents.Related: SunPower, Tesla Among Top 5 Earnings Estimate Beaters

Stock futures changed their tune and pointed to a slightly weaker start for the stock market today. Nasdaq 100 futures fell 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures lost a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 12 points.
The stock market ended a six-week winning streak last week amid a pickup in distribution days, which prompted a downgrade of the market outlook.

Stock markets overseas were mixed. In Europe, France's CAC-40 slipped 0.2% after Friday's series of attacks by the Islamic State that left more than 100 dead. Germany's DAX rose 0.2%, and London's FTSE climbed 0.3%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 1%, and Japan's Nikkei slumped 1.7%. But the Shanghai composite reversed higher to a 0.7% gain.
Crude oil jumped more than 2% to $41.68 a barrel on potential supply disruptions. Oil prices hit their lowest levels in over two months last week.
Safe-haven instruments such as bonds and the dollar were trading higher. Gold was also higher, up about 1% to $1,091.20 an ounce.
In economic news, the Empire State index for November came in at minus 10.7 vs. the consensus estimate of minus 5 from Econoday.
A number of central bank officials will be speaking throughout the week, starting Tuesday with Fed Governor Jerome Powell. The minutes from the Fed's October meeting are due Wednesday.

In stocks, Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) fell 6% in premarket trading despite news of it being bought by Marriott International (MAR) for $12.2 billion in cash and stock. The deal would create the world's biggest hotel chain.

Dillard's (DDS) slumped 10% in premarket trading after posting disappointing quarterly results. The department store operator said it earned $1.19 a share, including an after-tax credit of 16 cents a share. Sales slipped to $1.435 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.20 on revenue of $1.49 billion. Rival Macy's (M) plunged 20% last week on disappointing quarterly sales and a weak outlook.

Airline stocks were lower in premaket activity on concerns on Friday's attacks on tourism. Shares of American Airlines Group (AAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL), United Continental (UAL) and Ryanair (RYAAY) were off more than 1%.
Both the NYSE and the Nasdaq will observe a minute of silence at 9:25 a.m. ET for the victims in the Paris terrorist attack Friday.

Here's the secret to making money with international stocks: Forget that they're international stocks.In other words, apply the same rules as you would with domestic names. That's what IBD does in its daily International Leaders section.International Leaders mainly showcases the best-rated stocks in IBD's database of companies that are based abroad. So don't be surprised if you see a company that also does a lot of business in the U.S.Global And LocalTake Michael Kors (KORS), the hot luxury apparel maker and operator of 352 retail stores. The company is incorporated in Hong Kong. Yet North America made up 84% of its September-quarter revenue while Europe made up nearly the rest.No matter that the company operates in, say, China, where language, customs, laws and taxes are completely alien to U.S. investors. Regular column readers are familiar with such current Chinese leaders as web portal Sina (SINA), search engine Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), flash-sale online retailer Vipshop (VIPS), social networker YY (YY) and real estate listings website SouFun (SFUN).And yes, you'd know all about software developer NQ Mobile (NQ) as well. Maybe too well.From Israel, you would have gotten to know Perion Networks (PERI), a developer of software that customizes email products. Spain's Grifols (GRFS) makes blood-related products. And what of Chicago Bridge And Iron (CBI)? Did you know it's not based in Chicago, or that it has precious little to do with bridges or iron?Not all stocks featured in this column go on to become superb winners. Perion currently has a 69 Composite Rating and is sinking further below its 200-day moving average.International Leaders isn't limited to foreign stocks listed in the U.S. Reporters screen for the best stocks on foreign bourses, while limiting the search to the best stocks on exchanges that U.S. investors will have access to. So Australia, Hong Kong, Japan and Canada are in. Only registered foreign institutional investors can access India.International Leaders goes beyond individual stocks. The Daily World Map portrays returns of benchmark ETFs from each of 16 major markets (China has two, one big-cap, one small-cap), both for that day and for year-to-date.Economics also raises its ugly head from time to time. Read the column to stay abreast of the crisis in the EU, growth in China and unrest in Brazil. Follow the links of how an event in Brussels or Boston can impact Berlin or Beijing. The world is connected as never before, and that's not always a good thing.Look, too, at the Top World Stocks, a computer-generated daily table of 10 great names (fewer in lean times) that meet IBD's stringent standards for fundamentals and stock strength.

Retailers saw a disappointing start to the holiday shopping season with soft November sales gains reported Thursday, as deep discounts throughout the month failed to spark a spending splurge. The report signals tough sledding ahead as retailers round the holidays' home stretch. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 1.9% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins,…

Stocks held near their session lows Friday afternoon amid some mixed economic data and continued tension over Syria. The Nasdaq dropped 0.7%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 lost 0.3% each. All of the major averages pretty much erased Thursday's good work. Volume continued to track lower in the stock market today ahead of the long…

Consumer confidence figures show that the split between the highest-income households and everyone else continues to widen rapidly, as home and stock price gains impact sentiment and spending. The overall Consumer Confidence Index rose half a point in August to 81.5, the Conference Board said Tuesday, better than expected. Those making $50,000 and above shot up 6.6 points to 110.7,…

The New Highs list is not as large or robust as we've seen, and some of the names aren't true market leaders. But that's to be expected when the market is in a correction. Still, some noteworthy names appear, proving they can thrive even in a correction. Social networker Facebook (FB) spurted to a new high for its young trading…

Stocks lost ground and ended near session lows Friday, spooked a bit by comments from Secretary of State John Kerry that outlined a case for U.S. military intervention in Syria.Most Sector Leaders fell with the market, but a couple of names bucked the trend.Michael Kors (KORS) was a bright spot. Shares gained 0.94 to 74.09 in heavy volume. Recent breakout attempts for the stock didn't make much progress, but its latest breakout over a cup-with-handle buy point of 65.21 is doing well. It's now 14% past the buy point.SouFun Holdings (SFUN) also outperformed, rising 2.87 to 41.77 in fast trade. The company operates a real estate Internet portal in China and boasts formidable growth, with a five-year earnings growth rate of 71% and sales growth rate of 50%. SouFun needs to consolidate gains before a new buy point emerges. Its 10-week moving average, now around 33, is a logical support level. Shares soared over a buy point of 27.90 during the week ended July 19, rising 23%.Meanwhile, NetEase (NTES) plunged below its 10-day short-term moving average, falling 4.08 to 70.74 in above-average trade. The company develops and operates some of China's most popular online games. It's now 9% above a recent buy point of 65.18. Its 10-week moving average is around 66.Actavis (ACT) eased 0.19 to 135.18 in soft turnover. It's still holding above a recent flat-base buy point of 133.10 but the breakout hasn't made much headway.The company's proposed $8.5 billion acquisition of Warner Chilcott (WCRX) is on track to close sometime in the fourth quarter. On Thursday, three independent proxy advisory firms recommended that Actavis shareholders vote in favor of the merger. The vote is scheduled for Sept. 10.

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) hit the Wall Street runway with head-turning first-quarter profit Tuesday as its chic luxury goods continued to win over shoppers in North America and Europe. The high-end clothing and accessories seller said earnings in its June 29 quarter soared 79% to 61 cents a share, sailing past a consensus forecast of 49 cents from analysts polled…

An exchange traded fund created to track a basket of initial public offerings — Renaissance IPO ETF (IPO) — had its own IPO on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday, aptly trading under the ticker IPO. The ETF created by Renaissance Capital of Greenwich, Conn. — the 800-pound gorilla in IPO research and investment management — started trading at $20…
Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.
That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.
The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. But the S&P 500 now has eight distribution days, which is pushing the envelope.
Volume in the stock market today climbed 8% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Chinese real-estate info and marketing website SouFun Holdings (SFUN), which shot up 11% Monday, tacked on 7% and hit a new high in reasonably fast trade. SouFun has soared 176% since it broke out July 16 from a six-month consolidation. SouFun said Monday it will debut its new financial services platform, SouFun Financial Services Channel, Dec. 16. Through this platform, the company will be able to offer third-party financial services to SouFun's home-buying members, real estate agents, developers and providers of home-improvement products and services. And look for SouFun to offer its own financial products in coming months.

Nutritional and weight-loss products maker Herbalife (HLF), famous for its network-style marketing model, shot up 7% in heavy volume and struck a new high. The company won a court decision in Belgium, where a consumer group alleged that the company operated as a sort of Ponzi scheme. In overturning a lower court's decision, an appeals court disagreed.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) crashed 20% in monster volume, piercing well below its 10-day line and leaving in its wake a huge gap. This is Krispy Kreme's third straight loss, and its second with heavy volume.

The company's Q3 report (for the three months through October) showed earnings rose 33% to 16 cents, while sales climbed 7% to $114.2 million. Both metrics came up shy of estimates, which had been running at 15 cents on $115 million.

Also disheartening, Krispy Kreme guided Q4 earnings in the range of 11 cents to 14 cents. The Street had been looking for 14 cents, the upper end of this band. Even worse, the company's full-year guidance for 2015, 71 cents to 76 cents, was shy of the consensus, which was at 77 cents.Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. Outlet centers have gained momentum the past couple of years as high-end retailers and brands have moved to feed the consumer's hunger for value in a slowly improving economy.

Upscale retailers like Nordstrom (JWN) and luxury handbag and accessories designer and retailer Coach (COH)have expanded their outlet store operations as they look to draw a new customer base and expand their multichannel efforts.

Nordstrom Rack is the off-price retail division of Nordstrom offering customers on-trend apparel, accessories, and shoes at an everyday savings of 30% to 70% off. The Rack carries merchandise from Nordstrom stores and Nordstrom.com, as well as specially purchased items from many of the top brands sold at Nordstrom, spokeswoman Kate DeToye told IBD via email.

The Rack is part of a larger growth story for the company with growth coming from online, full-line stores, and the Rack. Nordstrom has 127 Rack stores across the U.S., with plans to have 141 stores by the end of this year and 230 stores by the end of 2016.

The Rack is a strong contributor to the total Nordstrom offering, says DeToye, and Rack stores are "extremely productive" in terms of sales per square foot. Last year, the Rack exceeded $2.5 billion in total sales.

Nordstrom selects Rack locations where there's an opportunity to serve more customers. The idea is to locate the stores so they are as convenient and accessible as possible. Only five of its Rack stores nationwide are in outlet centers.
Coach also has big plans to expand its factory stores. Coach had 193 factory stores and 351 full-price stores in North America at the close of fiscal 2013, which ended June 29.
It plans to open about 20 new stores in fiscal 2014 ending June 28, at least 15 of which will be factory outlets, says spokeswoman Andrea Shaw Resnick.
Coach sees outlet stores as a way to serve a different set of customers than those who shop at its full-price stores.

"For years we've explained that it is a very different customer that shops in the respective channels," said Resnick. "The full-price customer wants what's hot now, while the factory consumer wants brands but is value/price conscious and is willing to 'wait'," she said.
About 85% of what is sold in factory stores is made for factory, she adds, with the remainder full-price discontinued product from previous seasons/years.
"Full-price has to lead the brand and provide halo and buzz and fashion credibility," said Resnick.
"But factory represents a growth opportunity in North America as the channel continues to evolve."

Coach is the second-largest company by market cap in IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturers group, after VF Corp. (VFC) and before Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), while Nordstrom is third largest in the Retail-Department Stores industry group after Macy's (M) and Kohl's Corp. (KSS) .

Related: Americans Love Outlet Mall Shopping, So Do Developers.Outlet centers have gained momentum the past couple of years as high-end retailers and brands have moved to feed the consumer's hunger for value in a slowly improving economy.Upscale retailers like Nordstrom (JWN) and luxury handbag and accessories designer and retailer Coach (COH)have expanded their outlet store operations as they look to draw a new customer base and expand their multichannel efforts.Nordstrom Rack is the off-price retail division of Nordstrom offering customers on-trend apparel, accessories, and shoes at an everyday savings of 30% to 70% off. The Rack carries merchandise from Nordstrom stores and Nordstrom.com, as well as specially purchased items from many of the top brands sold at Nordstrom, spokeswoman Kate DeToye told IBD via email.The Rack is part of a larger growth story for the company with growth coming from online, full-line stores, and the Rack. Nordstrom has 127 Rack stores across the U.S., with plans to have 141 stores by the end of this year and 230 stores by the end of 2016.The Rack is a strong contributor to the total Nordstrom offering, says DeToye, and Rack stores are "extremely productive" in terms of sales per square foot. Last year, the Rack exceeded $2.5 billion in total sales.Nordstrom selects Rack locations where there's an opportunity to serve more customers. The idea is to locate the stores so they are as convenient and accessible as possible. Only five of its Rack stores nationwide are in outlet centers.Coach also has big plans to expand its factory stores. Coach had 193 factory stores and 351 full-price stores in North America at the close of fiscal 2013, which ended June 29.It plans to open about 20 new stores in fiscal 2014 ending June 28, at least 15 of which will be factory outlets, says spokeswoman Andrea Shaw Resnick.Coach sees outlet stores as a way to serve a different set of customers than those who shop at its full-price stores."For years we've explained that it is a very different customer that shops in the respective channels," said Resnick. "The full-price customer wants what's hot now, while the factory consumer wants brands but is value/price conscious and is willing to 'wait'," she said.About 85% of what is sold in factory stores is made for factory, she adds, with the remainder full-price discontinued product from previous seasons/years."Full-price has to lead the brand and provide halo and buzz and fashion credibility," said Resnick."But factory represents a growth opportunity in North America as the channel continues to evolve."Coach is the second-largest company by market cap in IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturers group, after VF Corp. (VFC) and before Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), while Nordstrom is third largest in the Retail-Department Stores industry group after Macy's (M) and Kohl's Corp. (KSS) .Related: Americans Love Outlet Mall Shopping, So Do Developers.
Analysts expect apparel company Oxford Industries (OXM) to deliver strong sales and earnings gains when it reports fiscal second-quarter results after the close on Tuesday.

The Atlanta-based company, which owns the Tommy Bahama and other clothing lines, is expected to post earnings of 98 cents a share, according to a poll of Thomson Reuters analysts. That would represent a gain of 51% from the prior year.
If Oxford meets or beats the earnings estimate, it would mark the biggest quarterly gain in six quarters.
Revenue is seen rising 18% to $243.48 million for the quarter, which ended in July.

Oxford is best known for its Tommy Bahama line of men's and women's sportswear and related products, which accounts for more than 60% of overall sales. Its other lines, considered attainable luxury brands, include Lilly Pulitzer, Lanier Clothes and Ben Sherman.

The company has produced steady financial growth through the years, with the occasional hiccup. During its fiscal first quarter, for example, earnings declined 27% amid higher costs related to its expansion of the Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer brands.
That was the first bottom-line dip in at least a dozen quarters, though analysts expect the expansion efforts to pay off in coming quarters.
Oxford shares rose slightly to 64.11 in midday trading in the stock market today. The stock touched a record high of 69.28 on Aug. 5.

Other stocks in IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group that have reached new highs in recent weeks include VF Corp. Leading growth stocks continue to act well in the market. Many are holding gains nicely after powerful breakouts, and others are still within buying range. Some are setting up for potential moves higher. A market rally needs broad leadership, and there's plenty of it.Actavis (ACT), formerly known as Watson Pharmaceuticals, cleared a flat base last week, rising 6% in strong trade. The generic drug maker is still within range, less than 1% past a buy point of 133.10. The company's second-quarter earnings report last week showed accelerating growth from the first quarter, with profit up 42% from a year ago to $2.01 a share. Sales rose 47% to $1.99 billion.In May, Actavis agreed to acquire Irish drugmaker  Warner-Chilcott (WCRX) for roughly $8.5 billion. The deal will greatly expand Actavis' women's health and urology business, but Actavis will reportedly have to divest some overlapping operations to secure approval from the Federal Trade Commission.Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), meanwhile, is working on a cup-with-handle base. After a big run already, it's a late-stage base. After a 27% pullback, Regeneron has climbed to within 6% of its all-time high. Despite recent price strength, its Relative Strength line is lagging. Regeneron's flagship drug, Eylea, is used to treat age-related wet macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.And Michael Kors (KORS) has been consolidating gains since February. It tried to break out in late May to no avail and settled into another consolidation. The current consolidation could be looked at as a new cup-with-handle pattern with a potential buy point of 65.21, or simply a long handle area in a larger base with a potential entry of 66.28. Either way, it's consolidating gains constructively. Investors will get a look at fiscal Q1 numbers when the company reports Aug. 6 before the open. Profit is seen rising 44% to 49 cents a share, with sales up 38% to $570.8 million.

A slew of foreign leaders suddenly are rebounding from their 10-week lines, but volume behavior may not be up to snuff. Three of China's hottest ADRs fell fast to their 10-week lines and rebounded in the past two days. Let's take a closer look.Social-networking site YY (YY) peaked Oct. 3, reversed lower and began a 20% swoon through Tuesday's low. The stock lost ground in three of those four sessions. The worst was Tuesday's 15% crash, which saw YY slice its 10-week line as volume surged 122% above normal.Wednesday's 5% gain spurred 71% higher-than-average volume. YY closed that day virtually on the 10-week line. Thursday saw YY rise 7%, although volume was just average.Fast upside volume is key to a successful rebound, but YY's wasn't as fast as what it recorded on the decline. That's troubling.Real estate info site SouFun Holdings (SFUN) topped out Sept. 10, then retreated as much as 18% through Tuesday's low. Sept. 11 saw the start of a three-day, 16% losing streak. Each session saw ugly-high volume.Two more sessions, Oct. 3 and Oct. 9, saw losses of 8% (on 173% higher volume) and 9% (on 99% higher volume, respectively. Those losses carried more than a whiff of panic.Tuesday's rout brought SouFun to test its 10-week line. The stock on Wednesday rose 7% on 78% higher volume, then gained 8% Thursday on just average volume. Like YY, the rebound sessions aren't drawing the same level of action as the sell-offs.Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), whose 14-month-old search engine is causing some perspiration at  Baidu's (BIDU) headquarters, followed much the same pattern as that seen in YY and SouFun.Qihoo peaked Sept. 11, then corrected 21% through Wednesday's low. Qihoo's 4% rise Thursday helped it firmly regain its 10-week line.But volume was a touch below average, in line with YY and SouFun's action. At the same time, Tuesday's sell-off saw Qihoo's volume rise 47% above normal — well below the panicky surges seen in YY and SouFun.Are there other stocks that are newly buyable? Yes. Look at fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) (which could use some more upside volume), Russian search engine Yandex (YNDX) and Canadian drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX). But keep an eye on volume, which could yet prove to be a problem.

JPMorgan Mid Cap Growth Select has been on a roll, its above-average performance driven by consumer discretionary and technology stocks. The $1.8 billion fund, managed by Christopher Jones and Timothy Parton, is up 32.58% year to date vs. 28.48% for its midcap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. and 26.38% for the S&P 500. The biggest contributor to performance in…
Major averages slipped a bit Monday, but the selling was a little more intense under the surface as several growth stocks underperformed.
On the downside, Michael Kors (KORS) lost 0.97 to 75.01 in light trade. Early Monday, Jefferies downgraded the "affordable luxury" brand to hold from buy.

Michael Kors broke out over 65.21 in late July and could be poised for its first visit to its 10-week moving average, currently around 72. During a confirmed market uptrend, a stock is buyable at the 10-week line when it comes down to the support level for the first time and finds support.

Meanwhile, LinkedIn (LNKD) slumped 4.34 to 239.56 in heavy volume but finished in the top half of its trading range. It came down to its 10-week line for the first time after its July breakout over 203.01. It fell below the support level but closed above it.
On a tough day for growth stocks overall, Actavis (ACT) outperformed, rising to 3.10 to 138.60 in average volume. It's now 4% above a recent flat-base buy point of 133.10.

The company's $8.5 billion merger with Warner Chilcott (WCRX) was recently approved by shareholders and is expected to close sometime in the fourth quarter. As a result of the deal, Actavis won't be as dependent on its core generics as it once was. Warner Chilcott specializes in branded drugs for women's health, gastroenterology, dermatology and urology.

EQT Midstream Partners (EQM) also bucked the trend, rising 0.72 to 49.37 in soft trade. The company is one of the leading natural gas producers in the Appalachian Basin in Pennsylvania and West Virginia. EQT Midstream tried to clear a cup-with-handle buy point of 50.72 last week, but volume was missing. Five Below (FIVE) became the latest in the trend of follow-on stock offerings, which tend to trigger immediate sell-offs, but Michael Kors (KORS) shows that company shares can resume uptrends later. Discount teen retailer Five Below was down 6% at 45.65 on the stock market today after its announcement late Tuesday that selling shareholders will offer up to 7.1 million…

A gradual but steady improvement in the economy may help put consumers in more of a buying mood this holiday season, leading to a moderate lift in retail sales over the Christmas period, according to a forecast by Deloitte released today. But others are less optimistic. ShopperTrak last week forecast GAFO sales for the holiday season of November and December…

Most Sector Leaders rose Thursday, led by Chinese Internet stocks. But volume again was mostly below average. BitAuto Holdings (BITA), an auto marketing company that offers reviews, pricing and other services, continued to hit new highs. It jumped 1.92, or 8%, to 25.46 in the biggest volume of its five-session run. The stock is up a whopping 24% this week…

Yandex (YNDX), based in the Netherlands but providing Internet search and content in Russia, fell 31 cents, or 1%, to 26.40. That puts the stock just 1% past its 26.07 buy point from a cup-shaped base. One thing missing from this breakout is a clear volume surge. Yandex put in its big move April 25, gapping higher and rising 16%…
Stocks rallied in light volume Tuesday, one day after a wave of selling knocked the Nasdaq nearly 6% off its recent high.
At the close, the Nasdaq rose 0.9%, the S&P 500 added 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in well below Monday's levels.

In the after-hours session, data analytics firm Tableau Software (DATA) soared 16% after reporting non-GAAP profit of 20 cents a share, easily topping the consensus estimate for break-even earnings. Revenue surged 95% to $81.5 million, well above the estimate for $67 million.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), meanwhile, rose 1% in late trading after the restaurant chain reported profit of $1.10 a share, 3 cents ahead of views and a 22% increase from a year ago. Sales rose 12% to $341.5 million, slightly below expectations. Same-store sales at company-owned stores rose 5.2%. Wall Street seemed to like news that same-store sales for the first five weeks of 2014 were up 4.8%, well ahead of last year's pace of 0.2%.

In the stock market today, Michael Kors (KORS) vaulted 17% on strong earnings. Profit and sales growth accelerated sharply from the prior quarter, rising 73% and 59%, respectively. Same-store sales in North America rose 24%. In Europe, they rose 73%. Fund ownership in Kors has nearly doubled over the past year, from 551 funds at the end of 2012 to 958 funds at the end of 2013.

Elsewhere, TransDigm Group (TDG) bounced off its 10-week moving average again after a November breakout. Shares rose 4%. Earlier today, the maker of components for commercial aircraft reported its second straight quarter of accelerating sales growth, fueled by recent acquisitions.

On the downside, U.K.-based chip designer ARM Holdings (ARMH) sank 4%. Earnings of 26 cents a share matched expectations, rising 30% from a year ago. But sales growth decelerated sharply from the prior quarter, rising just 17% to $313.2 million, hurt by slower growth in smartphone sales. It was the smallest increase in six quarters.

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) will give investors a read on the spending habits of the luxury consumer when the high-end fashion house hits the Wall Street runway with financial results Tuesday before the bell.
If followers are on target, the seller of luxury clothing and accessories will show that its affluent customers continue to spend at a healthy clip.

Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters see earnings rising 44% to 49 cents a share. They expect sales to climb 37.5% to $570.52 million. That would be the slowest pace for both sales and profits the company has seen since its December 2011 IPO.
But analysts are still upbeat about the quarter. Kors has consistently topped quarterly sales and earnings forecasts since its IPO. And this quarter will likely be no different, say two analysts.
"My expectations are for a beat on sales and earnings," said William Blair & Co. analyst Amy Noblin. "The question is the magnitude."
What gives Noblin confidence in the quarter are her wholesale and retail channel checks, which show the brand continues to see strong "sell-through" at full price and minimal markdowns, she says.
"The brand momentum remains strong," she said. "The brand is hot. They've got the products the consumer wants."

The growth drivers: Kors is aggressively expanding its store base and converting wholesale locations into "shop-in-shops," which results in a big lift in productivity, she says. And it's seeing continued growth in brand awareness and product category extensions.
Cowen and Co. analyst Faye Landes also expects a beat, according to her preview report on the quarter.

"We are modeling Kors Q1 revenue and earnings that are both well above sell-side consensus, as our proprietary data shows very healthy demand trends," she wrote. "Recent same-store sales growth has been at levels that have been seen only rarely, and data from the proprietary Cowen consumer survey gives us no reason to suspect any softness in demand or loss of momentum for the brand."
She forecasts Kors will see Q1 comps climb 30% vs. a year earlier.

Kors expected strong performance would follow a report of a challenging fourth quarter for rival Coach (COH) on July 30. The luxury designer of handbags and other accessories saw its same-store sales slip 1.7% vs. a year as amid tough competition from brands such as Kors. It also announced several management changes, including the departure of two key executives.

Also out Tuesday morning, watch and jewelry maker and retailer Fossil (FOSL) reports quarterly earnings. In addition to its own Fossil-brand wares, the company makes watches for many upscale brands, including Kors.

Luxury designer of accessories, clothing, and home products Ralph Lauren (RL) will report first-quarter financial results on Wednesday before the bell. Its showing should also give investors some insight into the high-end consumer's spending habits.Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) will give investors a read on the spending habits of the luxury consumer when the high-end fashion house hits the Wall Street runway with financial results Tuesday before the bell.If followers are on target, the seller of luxury clothing and accessories will show that its affluent customers continue to spend at a healthy clip.Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters see earnings rising 44% to 49 cents a share.
