The market correction gained steam Monday as major averages sold off again in higher volume. The Nasdaq led the way, falling 2.6%. The S&P 500 gave up 2.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.1%. The IBD 50 slumped 3.2%. The Nasdaq's 2.6% decline was its worst since June 1, 2012. The Dow closed below its 200-day moving average…

Sector Leaders gave a mixed showing Wednesday with most ending little changed.LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 3.09 to 197.60, snapping a three-session slide. But there wasn't any power behind the comeback. Turnover dropped 36% below average in one of the lightest sessions of the month. It closed nearly 3% below a 203.01 buy point from a cup base cleared July 18 in heavy volume.The operator of a social networking website for professionals will report second-quarter earnings Aug. 1. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see its bottom line rising 94% to 31 cents a share. But that would be down from growth of 192% to 267% in the past three periods.Michael Kors (KORS) extended its win streak to four sessions, gaining 49 cents to 63.89. Volume ended 11% above average, the first heavy-volume gain since June 28. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a 65.21 buy point.Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) slipped 56 cents to 46.15 for its second straight loss. Volume picked up from Tuesday's pace, but ended 32% below average. In recent weeks, the stock has met resistance near the round number 50 as a potential base forms.On Wednesday, the drugmaker announced the start of a phase-two study of its bread-and-butter Acthar for patients with Lou Gehrig's disease.Questcor gets nearly all its revenue from Acthar, which is used to treat about 19 conditions.Thinly traded HCI Group (HCI)was a big mover Wednesday. It tumbled 2.26, or 6%, to 34.60, snapping a nine-session advance. Intraday, the stock slumped 10% below a 36.14 buy point from a cup base cleared Tuesday. Volume surged nearly four times average in Wednesday's session.

The 15 or so Sector Leaders were mixed Thursday, with a breakout among them highlighting the day's action. LinkedIn (LNKD) cleared the 203.01 buy point of a cup-without-handle base in volume about 50% above its average. Shares rose 6.22, or 3%, to 204.16. The operator of the popular social website for professionals had been basing for 12 weeks, the second…

Most Sector Leaders staged comebacks Wednesday after falling the prior session. But the bulk of them rallied in soft volume. Web.com Group (WWWW) was one exception. The stock rallied 1.15, or 4%, to 27.32 in strong volume. It notched an all-time high and closed 19% past a 22.94 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared June 19. At the end…

PVH (PVH), owner of Van Heusen, Izod and other brands, is expected to report a jump in revenue when it announces results after the market closes on Monday. But analysts expect the clothing company's profit growth to slow.

PVH is seen reporting a 9.6% rise in earnings to $1.37 per share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That would end four straight quarters of accelerating growth. But revenue is expected to jump 41.5% to $1.89 billion. Both may reflect the impact of its Warnaco acquisition earlier this year.
Shares rose 17 cents to 130.14 in the stock market today ahead of earnings. The stock hit a record high of 134.98 on Aug. 2.

Apparel makers have been performing well lately, with G-III Apparel Group (GII) reporting a 31% rise in earnings and updated outlook last week. G-III has the license for Calvin Klein suits, outerwear and handbags while PVH owns the Calvin Klein jeans and underwear lines.
G-III shares, which shot up nearly 16% last week on strong earnings results, dipped 8 cents to 52.89 Monday afternoon.
PVH also has a licensing agreement with Michael Kors (KORS) set to expire in 2015. But with the rising popularity of the Kors brand, PVH might not be able to renegotiate a contract.
Kors shares rose 0.2% to 75.87.

Vera Bradley (VRA) is slated to report quarterly results Wednesday, but analysts aren't so bullish on the handbag maker. On Monday Lazard Capital said it expects Vera to miss expectations and reiterated a sell rating on the stock. Lazard also expects a weak outlook from the company on more promotions.
Shares fell 1.7% to 18.81.
Lululemon Athletica (LULU), the high-end yoga apparel maker and retailer, is seen recovering strongly from its quality issues earlier this year when it reports results Thursday.
On Monday Citi initiated coverage of Lululemon with a buy rating and a price target of $90.
Citi believes that Lulu is still "warming up" and has significant growth opportunities in the men's apparel category, swim, and dance apparel for teens.
Shares jumped 2.5% to 71.24.

Lazard also expects a weak outlook from the company on more promotions.Shares fell 1.7% to 18.81.Lululemon Athletica (LULU), the high-end yoga apparel maker and retailer, is seen recovering strongly from its quality issues earlier this year when it reports results Thursday.On Monday Citi initiated coverage of Lululemon with a buy rating and a price target of $90.Citi believes that Lulu is still "warming up" and has significant growth opportunities in the men's apparel category, swim, and dance apparel for teens.Shares jumped 2.5% to 71.24.The Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group is ranked No. 59 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.
For frequent flyers and road warriors, two wheels may not be enough.

The latest luggage being hauled behind weary business travelers in Heathrow, LaGuardia or LAX is perched up on four wheels. And those bags, of course, are constructed of ballistic-grade nylon, able to stop just about anything a baggage handler could throw at it.
Tumi (TUMI) is bringing high-tech engineering and product innovation to the staid world of luggage.

But just because its bags are as sturdy as a bulletproof vest, they don't have to look like one. Tumi is now adding splashes of color to some of its bags and rolling out new fashionable accessories to both ride the rebound in global corporate travel, and lure more women and other new customers.
"One of the keys to their success has been their ability to broaden their product line and customer base without alienating their core customers," said Amy Noblin, an analyst with William Blair & Co.

Tumi was founded in 1975 by a former Peace Corps volunteer, Charlie Clifford, and named after a ceremonial knife used by the Incas and early culture in pre-colonial Peru. His company originally imported rough leather bags from Latin America. In the early 1980s it developed its signature product lines of black ballistic nylon bags for business travelers and other frequent flyers willing to pay more for high-quality, rugged gear.
Loyal Following
It built a loyal following from customers who liked the sturdy designs, and the company's repair work when a zipper or wheel didn't hold up.
"When something is 'design fixed,' it means that it's ready for production. Our products were never completely design fixed," Clifford said in a 2011 interview with Inc. magazine.

"We'd constantly make changes and tweaks: better handles, more pockets, stronger screws to hold the piece together. We never copied other companies, but we were never afraid to borrow good concepts and then interpret them as our own."
London private equity firm Doughty Hanson & Co. bought Tumi for $276 million in 2004. Clifford left the company shortly after.

Sales have grown at a compounded annual rate of 13% between 2005 and the end of last year. Tumi's bags and other products were on shelves at 1,700 retail locations at the end of last year, up 40% since 2006.

"They are one of the strongest brands in the global luggage space, which is a market that's growing at a healthy clip and looks to be consolidating," said Christian Buss, an analyst with Credit Suisse, which was one of the underwriters of Tumi's April 2012 IPO.
But investors have given Tumi mixed reviews. Shares surged 47% on its first day, but tumbled soon after.

Shares have taken several whacks, too, as Doughty Hanson continues to sell its stake with large follow-on offerings in November and in March. The private equity fund still holds 25% of the shares, so more large offerings are possible.

The risk from secondary offerings isn't unique to Tumi. Fellow high-flying lifestyle brand IPO Michael Kors (KORS) has issued three secondary offerings in the past 16 months, dampening investor enthusiasm.
But an expanding product line and growing net sales could help the market digest more Tumi offerings.
The company's travel bags, mostly those wheeled carry-on-sized luggage and soft-sided totes, made up 45% of sales last year. Brief-cases, messenger bags and other business items made up 41%.
The rest of sales came from its accessories line, launched in 2008. Sales of those wallets, business card holders, sunglasses and other goods were up 46% in the most recent first quarter.
Now, the company is focusing more on the form of its highly functional bags, in a bid to attract more women. Slightly more than half of its customers are men, it said.

"The brand heritage is outstanding, and our customers are highly loyal," CEO Jerome Griffith said in a May conference call with analysts. "We believe that these two factors will be crucial in enabling us to successfully expand into new categories while also continuing to create high-quality innovative travel goods for our existing consumers."
Hard-Shell Bags

The company added new colors last quarter to its Tegra-Lite line of lightweight, hard-shell wheeled bags that retail for about $800. It's Ticon line of leather satchels and bags, which sell for up to $1,500, have a pocket with a special lining that shields credit cards, ID cards and other data-chip devices from scanners that crooks can use to steel information.
Faye Landes, an analyst with Cowen & Co., credits the management team for delivering innovative products.

"Their level of understanding of their consumer and the analysis that goes into it, and their level of understanding on the product is just terrific," Landes said. "That's what makes this tick. A great management team makes it look easy."

But its latest guidance is modest compared with the Street's expectations. The company guided sales growth of 18% to 20%, with diluted earnings per share of between 82 to 86 cents. Analysts collectively expect sales to climb 19.9% to $477.7 million this year, with EPS at 87 cents.
Travel Industry

And Tumi's hit turbulence in the past. Sales plummeted after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, which devastated the travel industry. The SARS outbreak a few years later also sent ripples through the industry again.
While Tumi is diversifying with its accessories, the company remains susceptible to travel disruptions.

There's also strong competition in each of the markets it serves. In its core luggage market, it goes up against well-established brands, including Samsonite International (which reportedly made a bid for Tumi before it came public) and German luggage maker Rimowa. Its expanding accessories business brings it up against leather goods maker Coach (COH), Michael Kors and others.
Tumi will need to keep an eye on quality control as it expands.

High-end yoga clothier Lululemon Athletica (LULU) in March spent millions recalling a batch of its stretchy pants, and slashed guidance after noticing the sheer fabric was just a little too revealing.
But William Blair's Noblin says Tumi hasn't fallen into that trap.

"They're not trying to do this radically overnight. It's a very controlled evolution of the brand, and I think that has led to their success," she said. "Oftentime retailers move too fast."For frequent flyers and road warriors, two wheels may not be enough.The latest luggage being hauled behind weary business travelers in Heathrow, LaGuardia or LAX is perched up on four wheels. New highs can provide an important clue on the health of the stock market. During a confirmed uptrend, the new-highs tally expands. For example, in the 18 sessions beginning with the July 11 follow-through day, combined new highs reached 400 or more in 13 sessions. The last day for 400 or more new highs was Aug. 5, a day before…

Chinese stocks are making a comeback in the IBD 50, particularly some of the better-known Internet companies in that country.In Monday's IBD 50, NetEase (NTES) was at No. 44, as the stock hit 52-week highs.The operator of multiplayer online games had not been in the IBD 50 since last summer but came back starting in June.The stock has cleared the 65.18 buy point of a large cup with handle. Another interpretation is that it formed a long double bottom, breaking out in May.Earnings rose 18% and 16% the past two quarters as sales increased 9% and 11%. Those are weaker numbers than most other IBD 50 companies own and well below the median 40% EPS rise for the IBD 50. The blockbuster "World of Warcraft" game, which NetEase licenses from Activision Blizzard (ATVI), has seen softer demand.Profit margins and return on equity have been solid, though.In Wednesday's IBD 50, New Oriental Education & Technology Group (EDU) also reappeared on the screen after a long absence. The stock is making a second pullback to the 50-day moving average. A rebound could put shares in a follow-on buy area.New Oriental's earnings have been wildly uneven, going from a loss of 6 cents a share in the November-ended quarter to a year-over-year profit increase of 22% in the February quarter. But sales growth has ranged from 26% to 41% the past seven quarters.The test preparation and language school reports results of its May-ended quarter on Tuesday before the U.S. market opens. Analysts expect profit of 16 cents a share, up 7% from a year ago.YY Inc. (YY), which took a spot in Wednesday's IBD 50, is near new highs. The stock has become extended after a strong rally following a sharp pullback to the 50-day line.The provider of an online social platform in China went public on the Nasdaq Nov. 21 and its shares have more than tripled since then. YY reports quarterly earnings on Aug. 1. Analysts estimate a 62% rise in EPS, to 21 cents.Hong Kong-based Michael Kors (KORS) has been a more regular member of the IBD 50. No wonder: Its sales and earnings growth is some of the strongest, not just among Chinese stocks but for all IBD 50 companies as well.Chinese stocks had faded from the IBD 50 amid weak Chinese markets. Accounting fraud dogged some companies and hurt the credibility for others.

Consumers will spend more on gifts this holiday season, giving retailers a nice lift in November-December sales, the National Retail Federation projected Thursday. But the U.S. budget impasse could curb shoppers' holiday cheer.

The NRF expects the industry's November-December sales to rise 3.9% to $602.1 billion, compared with a 3.5% gain in 2012. The forecast is higher than the 10-year average holiday sales growth of 3.3%, however.

"Our forecast is a realistic look at where we are right now in this economy, balancing continued uncertainty in Washington and an economy that has been teetering on incremental growth for years," said NRF President and CEO Matthew Shay. "Overall, retailers are optimistic for the 2013 holiday season, hoping political debates over government spending and the debt ceiling do not erase any economic progress we've already made."

Still, the forecast is "somewhat hinging" on actions by the administration and Congress over the next 45 days relating to the government shutdown, he adds. "Without action on the government's part, we face the potential of a decrease in consumer confidence."

Positive forces, including growth in the housing market and a strong consumer appetite for buying big-ticket items, give retailers reason to be "cautiously optimistic for solid holiday season gains," according to the NRF.
But a lot remains "up in the air" as other factors such as fiscal concerns over the debt ceiling and government funding and income growth could hamper holiday sales.
The NRF defines holiday sales as November-December retail industry sales for most traditional retail categories such as department stores, accessories and specialty stores.
Those retailers that report monthly sales at stores open at least a year will report September results next Thursday.

Analysts are expecting the month's same-store sales to rise 4.3% vs. a year earlier, says Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The forecast factors in stronger-than-expect same-store sales in September from drugstore chains Walgreen  (WAG), which saw a 7.4% rise, and Rite Aid  (RAD), which posted a 1.9% gain.
Victoria's Secret's parent L Brands (LTD) is expected to see a 2.2% rise in September comps.
Long-running top performer Costco (COST) is forecast to see a 3.6% gain. Apparel giant Gap is forecast to show a 2% increase.

Some retailers such as department stores Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) and high-end fashion house Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) don't report monthly sales. Analysts expected Michael Kors to rock with a 20.5% rise in comps vs. a year earlier in Q3, says Perkins. They see Macy's posting a 2.9% gain for the quarter and Nordstrom showing a 0.3% rise.
Separately, Shop.org released its online holiday sales forecast Thursday, forecasting November-December sales to grow 13% to 15% over last year to as much as $82 billion.

Shop.org measures electronic sales as a component of the Commerce Department's "non-store" category.Consumers will spend more on gifts this holiday season, giving retailers a nice lift in November-December sales, the National Retail Federation projected Thursday. For most, trading was roughly half the average. Yet three of the leading stocks made noteworthy moves — all of them foreign stocks. SouFun Holdings (SFUN) reversed lower, dropping 1.18 to…

Another day of gains for the major averages Tuesday resulted in a fresh all-time high for the S&P 500, but another sluggish quarter from Apple (AAPL) weighed on the Nasdaq. Since reclaiming its 50-day moving average on Oct. 10, the S&P 500 continues to show signs of accumulation, with six higher-volume gains in the past 13 sessions. At the close,…

Another day of gains for the major averages Tuesday resulted in a fresh all-time high for the S&P 500, but another sluggish quarter from Apple (AAPL) weighed on the Nasdaq. Since reclaiming its 50-day moving average on Oct. 10, the S&P 500 continues to show signs of accumulation, with six higher-volume gains in the past 13 sessions. At the close,…
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 may have avoided another distribution day Tuesday but both indexes finished in the bottom half of their trading ranges and leading stocks took hits again.
The breakout of FleetCor Technologies (FLT) from a follow-on, four-weeks-tight pattern hasn't made much headway. Shares fell 0.81, or 1%, to 85.33. It's now slightly below a buy point of 85.66.
The company is a provider of fuel cards and workforce payment products to businesses.

Keep in mind that the best time to buy a growth stock is when it's breaking out of an early-stage base in the beginning stages of a new market uptrend. FleetCor isn't exactly in the early stages of a run at this point. Tight trading after a breakout can offer alternate entry points, but base breakouts are the best time to buy.
Priceline.com (PCLN) continues to hold near highs after a recent technical breakout. But the breakout was from a fourth-stage base, meaning it was a late-stage breakout, not an early-stage one.

To its credit, Priceline's weekly chart shows some tight closes which means another breakout isn't out of the question. The problem is the broad market, which isn't all that healthy at the moment. Shares of Priceline lost 3.93, or 0.5% to 798.69 in quiet trade.

Michael Kors (KORS) lost ground for the third straight session, falling 0.67, or 1%, to 61.57 in slow trade. Breakouts have a hard time making headway when distribution is making its presence felt in the market, and that's certainly been the case with Kors.

Shares jumped 3% in strong volume May 29 as investors cheered a strong earnings report, but the enthusiasm was short-lived. Interest in outlet centers has heated the last couple of years as real estate investment trusts and developers look to expansion opportunities, at a time when the major markets are saturated with regional malls. "Affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) started the day by breaking out with wicked volume. But the effort couldn't stick.Michael Kors had built a cup that runs 12 weeks long and 20% deep.The stock triggered its 58.72 buy point right on the opening with a gap-up move. But the stock — a member of the IBD 50 — quickly ducked back under its pivot, and ended the session with a small loss.You must raise your guard when a stock ends below its trigger on its breakout day — and you should be doubly dubious if the stock actually posts a loss, as Michael Kors did.But remember, though many failures look just like this, so too do many ultimately successful breakouts. Maybe the stock is dead. Maybe we're looking at the start of yet another base-building phase. Or maybe Michael Kors will regain the buy point and resume its rally.Sometimes it pays to look at a great stock as a wild bronco trying to throw you off its back.Look at how 3D Systems (DDD) started its torrid run. That stock broke out Nov. 1 at 44.90. It failed by sinking at least 8% from the buy point — twice! You really had to think fast to buy 3D as a rebound from its 10-week line.More about this base: This cup is a base-on-base structure. Michael Kors had burst from a 22-week cup in mid-August, and rose just 16% before falling into the current pattern.As such, the new cup is a first-stage base, just like the prior cup.Michael Kors came public in December 2011 at 20. Many of the market's greatest winners put in their best performances within 15 years of their debut.The tighter, shallower cup is a hint that institutions are still building positions in Michael Kors. Another clue is its up-down volume ratio, which has climbed to 1.9, its highest in months.Michael Kors seems to be striking a niche with its approach to fashion and accessories: Offer a sense of luxury without charging absurd prices.True, Michael Kors' lines include some out-of-this-world prices ($2,500 handbags, $6,000 dresses). But you'll also find a great selection of items without the sticker shock (many dresses and handbags for less than $200).Michael Kors has upped its EPS in the past four quarters by 87%, 133%, 162% and 96%. The consensus looks for a 46% gain in the December-ending period, which will be announced Feb. 12.Sales improved between 58% and 74% in the past four quarters, with acceleration seen in the past two reports.The 74% sales gain in the September-ending quarter was the company's best in years.

It's been a long time since we've seen so many top-quality U.S.-listed foreign stocks at or near buy points. The menu is extensive, so let's look at a few. South Korean chipmaker MagnaChip Semiconductor (MX) is barely above its buy range, sitting 5.1% above its 18.35 buy point from a recent consolidation. MagnaChip broke out from its base in the…
One day after weak earnings from eBay (EBAY) and Intel (INTC) weighed on the Nasdaq, disappointing profit reports from Google (GOOG) and Microsoft (MSFT) fueled more selling in the tech index.
Microsoft gapped below its 50-day moving average, falling 11%, while Google lost nearly 2%. It fell below its 50-day line early but was back above it nearly four hours into the session.

The Nasdaq slumped 0.8%; the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2% and the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking higher than Thursday, skewed somewhat by options expiration. Still the Nasdaq was on pace for its third distribution day in four sessions, a yellow flag for the bulls.

In the stock market today, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) extended gains after a recent breakout from a huge yet flawed cup-with-handle pattern. Shares jumped 8% in about seven times average volume. It's now 7% past a buy point of 379.25, slightly extended. Earnings and sales topped views. What stood out most was that sales growth accelerated from the first quarter, rising 18% to $816.8 million compared to 13% growth in Q1.

Elsewhere, Kansas City Southern (KSU) rose fractionally despite a solid profit report before the open. The railroad operator is flirting with a potential breakout from a nine-week, cup-shaped base. The buy point right now is 118.98.

On the downside, online restaurant reservation firm OpenTable (OPEN) cratered 7% in big volume. On Thursday, Yelp (YELP) announced plans to acquire SeatMe, an online restaurant reservation service for $12.7 million. Yelp already has a partnership with OpenTable. Headed into Friday, OpenTable was working on a base-on-base pattern but its weak price action today calls the viability of the pattern into the question.
Inside The IBD 50, biotechs turned on another solid performance. Alkermes (ALKS), Biogen-Idec (BIIB), Celgene (CELG) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) all outperformed.

Michael Kors (KORS) also outperformed, rising 1%, but the stock has been lagging the S&P 500, basically since February. Still, it's working on a base-on-base pattern with a potential buy point of 65.21. Earnings are due Aug. 6 before the open and another strong quarter of growth is expected. Facebook (FB), LinkedIn (LNKD) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) are on a list of five big, well-capitalized companies, more stable than most companies, that are also young and nimble. Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, quality stocks with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion. A second sort shows the top five Big Caps that went…

With the market in correction, it's a good time to hone stock watch lists and find companies such as Forrest Laboratories (FRX) and New Oriental Education & Technology (EDU) that soundly top earnings estimates. Today's Screen Of The Day is Estimate Beaters, stocks that beat earnings-per-share estimates by the widest margin in the latest reported quarter, sorted by percentage change.…
Some stocks have strong technicals. Others have solid fundamentals. But savvy investors focus on those with superior technicals and fundamentals.

Today’s Screen Of The Day is Bolting RS Lines, stocks whose relative strength measured against the benchmark S&P 500 has been rising, a sign of market leadership. Stocks with RS lines hitting new highs before the actual stock is a bullish sign.This article will spotlight the five Bolting RS Lines stocks that have a best-possible 99 EPS Rating. IBD’s EPS Rating rates how well a company’s earnings did in recent quarters and long-term vs. all publicly traded stocks on a scale of 1 to 99.

Four of the five companies — Green Mountain Coffee Roasters  (GMCR), Jazz Pharmaceuticals  (JAZZ), LinkedIn (LNKD) and Michael Kors  (KORS) hit all-time or multi-year highs intraday on Monday. The fifth, Yandex (YNDX), is close to a 2-year best.Green Mountain, maker of single-cup coffee brewing machines and coffee pods, has seen shares soar 405% from July 23, 2012. It rose about 1% to 86.44 on the stock market Monday.
One reason it’s stayed piping hot is, after establishing itself in the gourmet coffee market, it’s now eyeing the markets for carbonated soft drinks, juices, sports drinks and even soups.

One possible concern: Green Mountain’s sales growth has slowed from 33% to 11% over the past three quarters.Starbucks (SBUX), the world’s biggest coffeehouse chain, isn’t on the list but is trading just below its all-time high set on Aug. 2. Shares edged down a bit Monday. Starbucks makes a rival brewing machine, Verismo, but also has a licensing deal with Green Mountain for Starbucks-branded K-cups.)

Jazz Pharmaceuticals hit a fresh high Monday on continued healthy sales of its specialty drugs including narcolepsy treatment Xyrem, expected to generate more than a half billion dollars in sales this year.

Social network for professionals LinkedIn  (LNKD) has been rising since the beginning of the recession. With unemployment still high it’s seen as a good way for companies and professionals to connect. And for those whose careers are rolling, it’s a way to exchange ideas and build contacts. Its shares have climbed 439% since it went public in May 2001 at 45. On Monday it closed up 1% at 242.39.

Yandex  (YNDX), though officially Netherlands-based, is the top search engine in Russia and other parts of Eastern Europe. Sometimes called the “Russian Google (GOOG),” Yandex went public in May 2011 at 25 and immediately jumped to an all-time high above 42. It dipped as low as 16.60 at the end of 2011 and then turned up.This year, its stock has risen 67% since April 13, and it edged down fractionally Monday to 33.24.
Michael Kors  (KORS), the luxury apparel and accessories maker, continues to dazzle the market. On Monday, it ended unchanged at its all-time closing high of 72.57. Kors rose to 73.59 intraday.

Sector Leaders were remarkably quiet Friday despite a slide in the Nasdaq and options expirations.Most of the price changes were minor but were nonetheless significant in a few cases.LinkedIn (LNKD) closed below the 203.01 buy point it had cleared just one day earlier. Shares fell 4.87, or 2%, to 199.29 in average volume, so it was not a worrisome decline.Three Sector Leaders showed support in their muted price movements Friday.3D Systems (DDD) is holding above the 50-day moving average. Shares edged up 46 cents to 47.33. Its 1-1/2-week decline has resulted in a handle with a buy point at 49.85.However, the maker of three-dimensional printers is forming a risky late-stage pattern. It is a Sector Leader thanks largely to solid earnings and sales growth and profit margins.Michael Kors (KORS) and  Proto Labs (PRLB) showed signs of support as well.After a volatile Thursday, Kors moved up a little more from its 50-day line. It also has formed a handle, this one with a buy point at 65.21. The luxury apparel and accessories company rose 43 cents to 62.12.Proto Labs sank as much as 4.5% at the open, but the stock erased nearly its entire loss, closing down 43 cents at 64.13. Volume was about half its average. Shares are holding above a 59.94 buy point.HCI Group (HCI) is within 2% of a new high as it closes in on a potential buy point at 36.14. But the base is another late-stage pattern. Shares rose 37 cents to 35.21.The Florida-based real estate insurance, information and investment company posted earnings increases of 92% and 106% the past two quarters, as revenue rose 40% and 48%.
Stocks logged decent gains Thursday, as disappointing economic data seemed to argue against any slowing of the Fed's aggressive $85 billion-per-month bond-buying program.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.7%, the S&P 500 rose 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged ahead 0.1%. The Nasdaq had been up as much as 1% before paring gains.
Volume failed to tag along, with both major exchanges showing small declines in turnover, according to preliminary data.
The major indexes finished just fractionally below their recent highs. But the Philadelphia semiconductor index surged 1.5% to end at its highest since October 2007.

Initial jobless claims rose last week to 354,000 — up from the prior week's 340,000 and more than the Econoday consensus estimate, also 340,000. GDP rose an annualized 2.4% in the first quarter, less than the 2.5% initially reported by the Commerce Department and a tick below expectations.

Why would stocks rise on bad economic news? It's all about the Fed, and if, when and how Ben Bernanke pulls back on the pace of quantitative easing. Recently, just talking about what the Fed needs to see to take such a step rattled the stock market. So rising rolls for jobless benefits bodes ill for the labor market — but bodes well for quantitative easing.
Chinese social media website YY (YY) surged 4% in triple-paced volume, putting it 36% above a 20.99 buy point from a cup-without-handle base that the stock cleared in huge trade on May 6.

The company, which went public in November, operates a social platform that lets users communicate through voice, text and video. It's posted triple-digit sales growth in each of the past 13 quarters. Also, profit has grown rapidly in the past two quarters. But it's a Chinese microcap, an especially risky segment these days.

3D Systems (DDD) retook its 48.11 cup-base buy point in moderately above-average volume. The stock last Thursday plunged as much as 11% below the buy point, triggering a key IBD sell rule, before reversing higher.

Regaining a buy point is always a positive step. But bear in mind that the cup base was flawed: It was deep (42%) and was a late-stage base. 3D's price swings since this base began in early February are visually wider than those seen during the stock's long, successful run-up. These are all warning signs.

"Affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) shot up 3% in fast trade. It was the stock's fourth straight gain — three of them with heavy volume — and puts it 5% above its 62.35 cup-with-handle buy point.

Michael Kors' big push appeared Wednesday (up 3% in 3-1/2 times its average volume). Older companies may have a prestigious history, but younger companies are blazing their own trail in new and innovative industries.

With earnings season around the corner, here are the top five companies on IBD's Young Guns Screen Of The Day. Young Guns are top-rated companies that have come public in the last 15 years. Big market winners usually come from relatively recent public firms.

Hertz Global (HTZ) tops the list. The rental car giant has expanded via acquisitions, including Dollar Thrifty last year, to increase its fleets. Last quarter Hertz said EPS quadrupled to 21 cents, beating views by 4 cents. Revenue rose 24% to $24.4 billion, also beating estimates.
For the latest quarter, analysts see Hertz's EPS jumping 29% to 45 cents and revenue climbing 22% to $2.7 billion.
Shares fell 11 cents to 26.30 on the stock market Tuesday, after hitting a record high intraday.

LinkedIn (LNKD) comes in at No.2. The social networking site allows users to upload resumes and helps job seekers find employment. Last quarter, LinkedIn posted its third straight quarter of triple-digit EPS gains. Revenue rose 72% to $324.7 million, beating views. But the company issued weak quarterly guidance for the current quarter.
Analysts now expect LinkedIn to post an 87% jump in earnings to 30 cents per share and a 55% rise in revenue to $353.8 million.

Shares fell 1.6% to 189.34 on Tuesday. The stock is trying to form the right side of a base that started with a sell-off from its May 2 profit warning. But the advance has mostly come on lighter volume. The Accumulation-Distribution Rating has fallen to a C-, suggesting big institutions are selling some LinkedIn shares.

Overstock.com (OSTK) sells unsold electronics, furniture, apparel and household goods from retailers' inventories on its website. In April, the company reported a 166% jump in quarterly EPS to 32 cents. Revenue rose 19% to $312 million — the fifth straight quarter of accelerating growth. That report sent shares nearly tripling over the next several weeks.
For this quarter, the online retailer is expected to swing to a profit of 8 cents.
Shares rose 2% to 27.34. Overstock hit a 5-1/2-year high of 30.81 on July 2.

Michael Kors (KORS) is the youngest company in the top five debuting in December 2011. But lead designer Michael Kors has been making a splash at runway shows for years. The upscale apparel maker and retailer has been one of the most successful IPOs in the past two years, beating out tech giants like Facebook (FB).
Last quarter Michael Kors reported its fifth straight quarter of triple-digit earnings growth. The fashion house said Q4 EPS soared 138% to 50 cents. Sales climbed 57% to $597.1 million.
For the current quarter, analysts don't expect yet another triple-digit surge in earnings. But the forecast 44% EPS gain to 49 cents would still be hot, along with a 37% sales gain to $570 million.
Shares rose 1% to 64.28.

InvenSense (INVN), a motion sensor chipmaker used for many video game console devices, rounds out the top five Young Guns. In the fourth quarter the company reported a 133% rise in EPS to 7 cents, meeting analyst expectations. Revenue climbed 39% to $33.1 million, above estimates.
For this quarter, analysts are expecting a 33% jump in earnings to 12 cents per share. Revenue is seen rising 39% to $54.43 million.
Shares dipped 3 cents to 15.55 after hitting a 52-week high intraday. The stock has been very volatile, but has risen sharply since the last earnings report.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) stock continued climbing Wednesday, up more than 7% after the company's Tuesday announcement that it had tapped a top Google executive in China to help monetize search in its battle against Baidu (BIDU). Qihoo stock, which peaked at 96.74 in October, was trading near 87.30 in midday trading in the stock market today. Qihoo stock rose…
Coach (COH) earnings and sales fell more than expected in the critical holiday quarter as the luxury handbag and accessories maker lost further ground in North America to rivals such as Michael Kors.
Fiscal second-quarter earnings slid 14% to $1.06 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected $1.11. Earnings came in flat the prior quarter, after years of increases.
Coach's revenue fell 5.6% to $1.42 billion, short of views for $1.48 billion. It was the second straight quarter of lower sales.
North American sales fell 9% to $983 million. North American direct sales sank 8% while same-store store skidded 13.6%.
Shares sank 6% to 49.38, falling to the lowest levels since just after its prior earnings report.

When it came to buying handbags over the holiday season, women in key consumer segments showed an increased preference for Michael Kors (KORS) products vs. a year earlier, while the preference for Coach products declined, according to a report by Cowen analyst Faye Landes.
Michael Kors' shares rose 3% to 79.77 on Wednesday, as investors saw Coach's bad news as good news for Kors. Hong Kong-based Kors should report quarterly earnings in February.
But Coach's China results remained "resilient," with total sales up about 25% and same-store sales rising at a double-digit rate, CEO Victor Luis said.

"We continued to be disappointed by our performance in North America, which was impacted by substantially lower traffic in our stores and by our decision to limit access to our e-factory flash sales site," he noted in a press release.

Most luxury and accessible-luxury handbag rivals to Kors and Coach are privately held, such as Hermes and Louis Vuitton.Coach (COH) earnings and sales fell more than expected in the critical holiday quarter as the luxury handbag and accessories maker lost further ground in North America to rivals such as Michael Kors.Fiscal second-quarter earnings slid 14% to $1.06 a share. With the market trying to emerge from a correction, investors who want safety and stability will look at well capitalized large company stocks. But that doesn't have to mean sacrificing growth. Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, top-rated large-cap stocks priced above 15. Here are the top five Big Cap Leaders: Hertz Global Holdings (HTZ), LinkedIn (LNKD),…
Stocks staged a harsh downside reversal Wednesday after remarks from Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke and minutes from the recent policymakers meeting sparked fears of less easing in the near future.

The Nasdaq slid 1.1%, the S&P 500 lost 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.5%. Those indexes had been up as much as 0.9%, 1.1% and 1.1%, respectively — new highs for all — before reversing.
Volume swelled 25% on the Nasdaq and 34% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Bernanke's initial remarks were market-friendly. He said that an early end to quantitative easing — the $85 billion-per-month securities-buying program — would imperil the economic recovery. But he later said that the Fed could slow the pace of quantitative easing this year if the labor market showed sustainable improvement.
Plenty of market leaders staged their own downside reversals.

One of the bigger disappointments was registered by fashion house Michael Kors (KORS), which not only reversed lower (turning a 3% gain into a 1% loss) but saw its breakout from a cup-with-handle sour. The stock ended 3% below its 62.35 buy point.

Biotech Celgene (CELG) surrendered all of its 4% gain in moderately above-average volume. The stock's early gain came with solid volume, painting the picture of a healthy rebound from the 10-week line. But the afternoon fizzle made the picture less attractive, although the line held.

Mortgage-services provider Ocwen Financial (OCN) edged up a fraction in the morning, then did an about-face and slid 4% in moderately above-average volume. The stock ended 1% below its 42.17 buy point from a shallow cup.
Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM), another mortgage servicer, swooned 5% in fast trade, ending barely above its 41.86 buy point from a cup base.
Stratasys (SSYS) slid 7% in fast trade, ending 4% below its 87.07 cup-with-handle buy point.
Chip designer Ambarella (AMBA) reversed lower and dived 7% in nearly three times its usual volume. The stock ended 2% below its 16.10 entry from a cup-shaped base.

United Rentals (URI) had no gain to reverse from on Wednesday. Shares of the industrial-equipment renting company sank 3% in about average volume, ending fractionally below its 56.09 buy point from a flat base.

ARM Holdings (ARMH), which fell 5% Tuesday, further sank 3%. Both sessions saw fast action. The stock is now slightly above its 44.57 buy point from a flat base. But that gain had been as much as 13% before this two-day rout. While the stock is back within buying range, you may be better off focusing on not letting shares you already may own turn from profit to loss.Stocks staged a harsh downside reversal Wednesday after remarks from Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke and minutes from the recent policymakers meeting sparked fears of less easing in the near future. Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) makes no secret of its desire to become a much bigger player in the global market for high-end fashion items.
The company designs, sells and distributes accessories, footwear and apparel. It is named after founder Michael Kors, a designer perhaps best known as a judge on "Project Runway."
Most of its business comes from accessories such as handbags, small leather goods, eyewear, jewelry, watches and footwear.
Michael Kors Holdings operates through a multichannel distribution model that includes its own chain of retail stores as well as wholesale and licensing segments.

These channels have produced robust financial gains over the years, helping the company grow from roughly $500 million in annual revenue in fiscal year 2010 to around $2 billion in fiscal 2013, which ended in March.
Now Michael Kors has its sights set on $4 billion in annual sales over the next few years. Many analysts reckon the company has the brand strength, growth strategy and financial might to pull it off.
Market Share Gains

"Doubling sales doesn't sound that hard," JPMorgan analyst Brian Tunick noted in a report last month. "Management suggested that the path to about $4 billion in revenue over the next few years would come through a combination of market share gains, retail expansion and growth internationally."

During a recent meeting with Michael Kors CEO John Idol and CFO Joe Parsons, Tunick found that management sounds particularly upbeat over the company's growth potential in Europe, which it sees as a $500 million-or-greater opportunity.

"Michael Kors' strength in Europe is currently driven by only about 35% brand awareness," Tunick noted. "They believe 50% (brand recognition) represents a true inflection point for the business to take off, suggesting meaningful room ahead."

On a fiscal third-quarter conference call with analysts, CEO Idol said the company was "very pleased" with the growing acceptance of the Michael Kors brand in Europe despite a weak overall economy there.
"We continue to benefit from increasing brand awareness in this region as our strong product portfolio resonates well with the European consumer," Idol said.
During fiscal year 2012, Europe accounted for about 8% of overall revenue. North America contributed 91% and Japan 1%.

As of April 10, Michael Kors had 228 retail stores in North America, 43 in Europe and 26 in Japan. Longer term, the company sees those numbers growing to 400 North American retail locations, 100 European locations and 100 Japanese locations.
One potential growth area in Europe is Michael Kors' partnership with Fossil (FOSL). Under terms of that deal, Fossil makes watches that Michael Kors sells under its own brand.
Citigroup analyst Oliver Chen notes that the watch brand "resonates strongly" with customers and retailers in the UK, Germany and Switzerland.
The brand is also beginning to take hold in France despite heavy competition from Louis Vuitton, Longchamp and other European watch brands.
Chen cites a number of reasons the Fossil-Kors watches are showing strength across the Atlantic.
"We believe customers are responding to color, the fashion point of view, the synthesis of ideas from multiple high-end brands and the price points," Chen noted.
Michael Kors competes in the luxury end of the fashion and retail sector, along with companies such as Coach (COH), Ralph Lauren (RL) and Donna Karan International.
The closest rival in terms of the business model is Ralph Lauren, which also has a multichannel distribution platform that includes a near-equal amount of sales from retail and wholesale.

During fiscal year 2012, Ralph Lauren got 50% of its revenue from retail, 47% from wholesale and 3% from licensing agreements. That same year, Michael Kors got 48% of its sales from retail, 47% from wholesale and 3% from licensing.
Recent IPO
Michael Kors had its IPO in December 2011 at an opening price of $20. Shares peaked at 65.10 this February and now trade near 61.
During its first four full quarters as a publicly traded company, Michael Kors grew year-over-year earnings at least 96% and sales at least 58%.

It is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results on May 29. Analysts expect earnings to come in at 39 cents a share, up from 22 cents the previous year. Revenue should be in the neighborhood of $515 million to $525 million vs. $380 million a year earlier.

During its fiscal third quarter the company's earnings more than doubled from the prior year to 64 cents a share, comfortably ahead of views. Sales gained 70% to $636.8 million, also well above estimates. Same-store sales in North America climbed 41%.

Online sales represent only a tiny percentage of Michael Kors' overall business, at less than 2% of sales. JPMorgan's Tunick says the company can grow that figure to around 10% of retail sales, which would represent about a $100 million opportunity.

"At this point, we believe online traffic is driven off of Google searches and email blasts, and we would expect the company to raise their online marketing spend," Tunick noted.Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) makes no secret of its desire to become a much bigger player in the global market for high-end fashion items.The company designs, sells and distributes accessories, footwear and apparel. It is named after founder Michael Kors, a designer perhaps best known as a judge on "Project Runway."Most of its business comes from accessories such as handbags, small leather goods, eyewear, jewelry, watches and footwear.Michael Kors Holdings operates through a multichannel distribution model that includes its own chain of retail stores as well as wholesale and licensing segments.These channels have produced robust financial gains over the years, helping the company grow from roughly $500 million in annual revenue in fiscal year 2010 to around $2 billion in fiscal 2013, which ended in March.Now Michael Kors has its sights set on $4 billion in annual sales over the next few years. Many analysts reckon the company has the brand strength, growth strategy and financial might to pull it off.Market Share Gains"Doubling sales doesn't sound that hard," JPMorgan analyst Brian Tunick noted in a report last month. "Management suggested that the path to about $4 billion in revenue over the next few years would come through a combination of market share gains, retail expansion and growth internationally."During a recent meeting with Michael Kors CEO John Idol and CFO Joe Parsons, Tunick found that management sounds particularly upbeat over the company's growth potential in Europe, which it sees as a $500 million-or-greater opportunity."Michael Kors' strength in Europe is currently driven by only about 35% brand awareness," Tunick noted. "They believe 50% (brand recognition) represents a true inflection point for the business to take off, suggesting meaningful room ahead."On a fiscal third-quarter conference call with analysts, CEO Idol said the company was "very pleased" with the growing acceptance of the Michael Kors brand in Europe despite a weak overall economy there."We continue to benefit from increasing brand awareness in this region as our strong product portfolio resonates well with the European consumer," Idol said.During fiscal year 2012, Europe accounted for about 8% of overall revenue. North America contributed 91% and Japan 1%.As of April 10, Michael Kors had 228 retail stores in North America, 43 in Europe and 26 in Japan. Longer term, the company sees those numbers growing to 400 North American retail locations, 100 European locations and 100 Japanese locations.One potential growth area in Europe is Michael Kors' partnership with Fossil (FOSL). Under terms of that deal, Fossil makes watches that Michael Kors sells under its own brand.Citigroup analyst Oliver Chen notes that the watch brand "resonates strongly" with customers and retailers in the UK, Germany and Switzerland.The brand is also beginning to take hold in France despite heavy competition from Louis Vuitton, Longchamp and other European watch brands.Chen cites a number of reasons the Fossil-Kors watches are showing strength across the Atlantic."We believe customers are responding to color, the fashion point of view, the synthesis of ideas from multiple high-end brands and the price points," Chen noted.Michael Kors competes in the luxury end of the fashion and retail sector, along with companies such as Coach (COH), Ralph Lauren (RL) and Donna Karan International.The closest rival in terms of the business model is Ralph Lauren, which also has a multichannel distribution platform that includes a near-equal amount of sales from retail and wholesale.During fiscal year 2012, Ralph Lauren got 50% of its revenue from retail, 47% from wholesale and 3% from licensing agreements. That same year, Michael Kors got 48% of its sales from retail, 47% from wholesale and 3% from licensing.Recent IPOMichael Kors had its IPO in December 2011 at an opening price of $20. Shares peaked at 65.10 this February and now trade near 61.During its first four full quarters as a publicly traded company, Michael Kors grew year-over-year earnings at least 96% and sales at least 58%.It is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results on May 29. Analysts expect earnings to come in at 39 cents a share, up from 22 cents the previous year. Revenue should be in the neighborhood of $515 million to $525 million vs. $380 million a year earlier.During its fiscal third quarter the company's earnings more than doubled from the prior year to 64 cents a share, comfortably ahead of views. Sales gained 70% to $636.8 million, also well above estimates. Same-store sales in North America climbed 41%.Online sales represent only a tiny percentage of Michael Kors' overall business, at less than 2% of sales. JPMorgan's Tunick says the company can grow that figure to around 10% of retail sales, which would represent about a $100 million opportunity."At this point, we believe online traffic is driven off of Google searches and email blasts, and we would expect the company to raise their online marketing spend," Tunick noted.
Stock futures were positive, but not by much, ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures held 2.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were ahead 4.2 points. S&P 500 futures clung to a 0.2% advance. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 index down 4.1 points.

The stock market today will be all ears as the Federal Open Market Committee wraps up its two-day meeting with a policy announcement this afternoon. The consensus appears to expect further tapering, but no change to the target interest rate.

The day's other economic news was relatively thin. The current account deficit expanded to $111.2 billion in the first quarter, vs. a revised $87.3 billion deficit for the fourth quarter. The balance, a measure of transactions between the U.S. and all other countries, rose to 2.6% of GDP, vs. 2% in Q4.
Some heavyweight headlines did little to stir stocks in premarket trade.

Amazon.com (AMZN) rose less than 1% ahead of a press event scheduled in Seattle today, during which the company is expected to introduce a smartphone, in a partnership with AT&T (T). AT&T shares were up a fraction before the open. Amazon has been scooping through a 30% deep consolidation since January.

German chemicals and pharmaceutical giant Bayer (BAYRY) was flat after reports that it had signed a $14.2 billion loan to acquire the consumer care business of New Jersey-based Merck (MRK). Merck shares were also unmoved.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) bolted 9% higher after a surprise increase in its fiscal second quarter earnings. The maker of software programs including Photoshop, Acrobat and Reader ended Tuesday 5% below the 71.21 buy point of a four-month cup base.

Furniture maker La-Z-Boy (LZB) dropped 9% after narrowly topping fiscal fourth-quarter earnings expectations but stopping short of estimates on the revenue line. The stock has been unable to climb above key levels of support to start the right side of a five-month base.

Overseas, China's markets finished lower for a second day. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained, still working to take back ground lost during Monday's session, despite data showing a sharp drop in exports in May. In Europe, stocks were narrowly higher at midday.

The dollar eased against the euro, strengthened vs. the yen. Oil continued to bob between $106 and $107 a barrel. Natural gas was firm at $4.75 per million British thermal units. While J.C. Penney's (JCP) largest shareholder, hedge fund manager William Ackman, is demanding a new CEO as soon as possible, a quick change at the top won't stop the overall decline of department stores.
Since peaking in 2001, retail sales at department stores have fallen steadily and in June were at the lowest level since 1992, according to Commerce Department data.

Meanwhile, nonstore sales, which include online retailers like Amazon (AMZN), took off with the shift to ecommerce and overtook department store sales in 2003. In June, nonstore sales totaled $37.9 billion vs. $14.5 billion at department stores.
The Retail-Department Store group is ranked No. 152 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.
Saks (SKS) tops the group with Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillards (DDS) rounding out the top four.

Despite the sector's declining sales, upscale chains are outperforming downscale peers as high-income shoppers haven't felt the squeeze from the recession and favor the perks of shopping at high-end retailers such as personal shoppers.

Other stores like Macy's have been more successful by focusing on localization and investing in their stores. Some stores also have higher selections of luxury merchandise like Michael Kors (KORS), Chanel and Dior than online retailers do.
But Mary Ross Gilbert, managing director at Imperial Capital, believes that Penney's problems are unique to the chain.

"J.C. Penney displaced its historical core customer and it's going to take some time to bring them back while also trying to attract younger customers. The store made dramatic changes without testing their concepts," she said.

Macy's is slated to kick off department store earnings next week. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are expecting the company to report an 18% jump in earnings to 79 cents per share when it reports results Wednesday. Sales are seen rising 2.6% to $6.28 billion.

Nordstrom is expected to report Thursday. Analysts see earnings rising 17% to 88 cents per share and sales jumping 9.5% to $3.3 billion.While J.C. Chinese social platform YY (YY) spurted ahead 7% in above-average volume. Monday's action gives credibility to YY's rebound from its 10-week line. That move started June 24 when the…
Fossil (FOSL) shares fell after the accessory company reported a drop in third-quarter jewelry sales in Europe on Tuesday.
Fossil reported a 17% rise in third-quarter earnings to $1.28 per share, topping analyst estimates by 12 cents.

"Double-digit growth in our direct to consumer business and Asia Pacific region, coupled with expense management and improved gross margin resulted in third-quarter earnings surpassing our initial guidance," said CFO Mike Kovar.
While sales climbed 6% to $684.2 million, they missed estimates of $713 million.
Shares of Fossil tumbled 11% in Tuesday afternoon trading.
Europe wholesale sales were nearly flat due to a 25% decline in Fossil's jewelry business. Wholesale sales in the Asia Pacific region rose 26.6% on increased watch sales.
"We are not expecting improvements in our performance in Europe wholesale for the fourth quarter," CEO Kosta Kartsotis said on the post-earnings conference call.
Fossil makes watches and jewelry for Diesel, DKNY and Emporio Armani fashion houses.

High-end retailers have been preforming well during the economic downturn in the U.S. as wealthy consumers haven't had to curb spending. But economic uncertainty in Europe and slowing growth in China have affected even upper class spending in those regions.

North America was a bright spot for the company. Wholesale sales rose 5.9% on a 14.6% jump in the jewelry business. North American jewelry sales were helped by the continued popularity of the Michael Kors (KORS) jewelry line. Fossil also makes Kors-branded watches.
Michael Kors is slated to report earnings before the market opens on Nov. 13. Analysts see earnings of 40 cents per share and sales of $519.3 million in the company's first Q2 since going public.
Kors shares were down 1% in midday trading Tuesday.
Fossil sees Q4 EPS of $2.26 to $2.29. Analysts are expecting $2.27.

China search leader Baidu (BIDU), as well as video website Qvod Technology, were fined Monday for copyright infringement, with authorities saying the two companies' media player software provided access to pirated videos.
The companies were each fined about $41,240 by the National Copyright Administration of China, according to a representative of China online video company Youku Tudou (YOKU).

Youku this year brought copyright infringement complaints against Baidu and Qvod, as part of an alliance that included online video providers Sohu.com (SOHU), Tencent and the Motion Picture Association of America.
Baidu stock, though, was up a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, while Youku stock was down 1%.
The NCAC fines are being marked as a victory by Youku and its alliance, which says it's seeking better controls over online piracy in China.

"The alliance welcomes NCAC's findings and decisions, which clearly demonstrate the government's determination to protect online video copyrights," a Youku representative said in an emailed statement. "The alliance also calls on Baidu and Qvod to stop all pirating actions in order to help build a positive online and mobile video ecosystem."
The coalition is seeking up to $49 million in damages for alleged copyright violations. They say the companies make it easy for users to find and play pirated movies and TV shows.
Baidu didn't immediately return emails seeking comment.

Youku Won't Gain Much From China's 4G Rollout In 2014

Fashion designer Michael Kors (KORS) is near a buy point as it sketches a cup-with-handle base.The stock is about 4% below the 65.21 entry as it gets support at its 50-day moving average. The pattern formed next to a previous base and is first-stage, which has a better chance of success than those farther up the scale.Kors, which makes luxury apparel and accessories, possesses almost flawless fundamentals. But the stock has had difficulty making headway after clearing a series of bases formed after its December 2011 initial public offering. It's tripled since then, but most of the gains came in the first three months of trading.Kors said Tuesday that it will announce fiscal Q1 earnings before the market opens on Aug. 6.Wall Street analysts expect a 44% gain from a year earlier to 49 cents a share. That would mark a sharp slowdown from a string of mostly triple-digit gains over the past eight quarters. But it would still be strong growth.Sales are seen rising 38% to $571 million, continuing a long record of solid quarterly revenue growth. It's no surprise, then, that Kors boasts a best-possible 99 Earnings Per Share Rating, tops in the 29-member Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing industry group, which includes fellow IBD 50 stocks Iconix Brand Group (ICON) and PVH (PVH).Yet the stock has barely outperformed the S&P 500 since early 2012. The stock's most recent breakout, over a 62.35 buy point, failed despite strong breakout volume. Kors must overcome some head winds before it can clear the current buy point: The stock has met resistance at 65 since February and its Relative Strength line is lagging, a sign of weakness.Still, Kors is worth keeping an eye on. Institutional sponsorship has increased six straight quarters as Fidelity Magellan and other leading funds increased their holdings. That's backed up by Kors' Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B, which indicates growing demand for the shares.
LinkedIn (LNKD) looks to join a group of young, fast-growing companies such as Facebook (FB) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) that have seen their stocks vault higher on standout quarterly results.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Young Guns, top-rated companies that have gone public in the last 15 years.
The list includes four Young Guns that recently beat analysts' estimates: Facebook, Under Armour (UA), Wynn and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).
LinkedIn may be added to the list when it reports late Thursday.

Facebook went public in May 2012 at $45 a share and promptly went into the tank, losing more than half its value in six months. It clawed its way back and last September crossed above its IPO price for the first time.
Last Wednesday, the world's largest online social network gapped up more than 15%, as gains in mobile users and mobile ad revenue lifted fourth-quarter results.
Revenue surged 63% to $2.59 billion, and earnings per share popped 82% to 31 cents, with both well above views.
Facebook, which is on the proprietary IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, rose 2% in Tuesday stock market trading to a fresh all-time high of 62.75.
Athletic gear maker Under Armour soared 23% last Thursday after its EPS rose 26% to 59 cents, beating by 6 cents, and sales grew 35% to $683 million, besting estimates for $620 million.
The gains came after the company last year made its first acquisition, health website and app MapMyFitness, and made key investments in its women's, footwear and international businesses.
Shares fell 1% Tuesday.

Wynn Resorts is one of the world's hottest casino companies. Although smaller than Las Vegas Sands, Wynn continues to outperform the market. In the last three quarters, Wynn's EPS growth rose from 9% to 24% to a whopping 94% last quarter as it expands in Chinese hot spot Macau.
Wynn's Q4 EPS of $2.27 trounced forecasts for $1.73. Revenue grew 18% to $1.52 billion, trumping estimates of $1.44 billion.

Chipotle, which offers healthy casual Mexican fare, last Thursday reported such strong Q4 results and guidance that Morgan Stanley, Piper Jaffray and other analysts almost immediately lifted their future sales estimates even higher.
Chipotle expects 2014 same-restaurant sales to grow in the low- to mid-single digit range, up from its prior guidance of low single-digit growth.
LinkedIn, the online network for professionals, looks to emulate its four Young Gun peers by beating estimates when it reports Q4 earnings this Thursday after the market closes.
Analysts expect mild 9% EPS growth to 38 cents, but they look for revenue to surge 44% to $437.8 million.
The website has more than 260 million members and continues to grow at a brisk rate. Like other tech companies, it's also expanding into the hot mobile market, via apps for smartphones and tablets.
Related:
Meet 2 Estimate Beaters That've Reported, 2 That Will
Green Mtn., Michael Kors Lead IBD 50's Top 5 Earnings

There are two keys to Frank Caruso's investment strategy.
First, the lead manager of $2 billion AllianceBernstein Large Cap Growth directs his team to seek what he calls dynamic gaps.
Those gaps are big differences between how fast Caruso's team expects a stock's earnings to grow and Wall Street's consensus expectation.
The second key is where Caruso has his team look for that gap: four to five years out.
Caruso is adamant about avoiding a focus on the near term.
This approach had the fund up 32.46% this year through Nov. 30. That topped 78% of its large-cap growth peers, which averaged 29.96%. The S&P 500 was up 29.12%.
Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain is 18.14% vs. 15.70% for its peer group and 17.73% for the big-cap bogey.
Caruso, age 57, discussed his investment process with IBD from his office in Manhattan.
IBD: How does your search for leading stocks differ from other growth investors'?

Caruso: We think of equities generally (in terms of) a combination of growth and capital returns in the form of dividends and share buybacks, which support the valuations of equities over a long period.

And we take a long-duration approach to investment opportunities. But most growth investors are dangerously focused on the moment, growth in the short term. We try to exploit this phenomenon where not a lot of analytical work is being done four to five years out.
IBD: Give me some examples that show how your tack works, please.

Caruso: In the spring of 2012, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) missed a couple of months of sales estimates and the stock was crushed. It went from about 440 to 230 a share. But our research let us be marginal buyers in that lurch. We were confident in the caliber of management. We bought a distressed stock in a great long-term franchise (between May and July 2012 between 380 and 400). Later, they began to execute and sales improved. (We added to our position) through the beginning of October 2012 at prices between 284 and 330.
IBD: Is Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) another example? You added a big chunk to your stake a few quarters ago.

Caruso: They have a great core competency in technologies that are increasingly desired by clients: in the cloud and in mobility. It's been growing in the high teens and low 20s for years. It has no debt, and it has excess cash.
After putting up a strong quarter, they got caught up in the immigration debate. They rely on a lot of foreign visas to conduct their business. The stock went down about 25% in a heartbeat.

That was an opportunity for us to reload. In the spring of 2012 we started initiating. The stock broke down into the high 50s (from 78). We met with Cognizant managers for three or four hours, and we left convinced they still had a great business and plan. The stock moved higher. The immigration debate percolated, and we bought in the 60s. Now it's in the 90s.
IBD: Are you looking for investment opportunities created by the prospect of the Federal Reserve tapering its bond buys?
Caruso: We don't try to overthink the macro environment. So our marching orders to our analysts are to focus on company fundamentals.

But when (Fed Chairman Ben) Bernanke started the tapering discussion, after having underperformed the broad market and value in particular the prior 12 to 15 months, growth securities started to do well. So the market response to tapering seems to have catalyzed a shift on the margin to growth stocks.
IBD: Is that because growth stocks tend to have more foreign exposure?

Caruso: Yes, growth stocks generally have a little more exposure to foreign earnings growth. And U.S. value stocks have more exposure to, let's say, earnings that are fueled by Federal Reserve stimulus steps. This is speculation on my part, but the discussion regarding tapering might auger well for future growth stock performance.
IBD: Computer services, software and systems are your largest category of holdings at 12.36% of assets. Why do you expect good things from them?

Caruso: Cognizant is one, with close to a 4% weighting. The portfolio is built around companies like that and Google (GOOG). We think of Priceline (PCLN) as a service company. Some people think of it as a technology company.
Ansys (ANSS) is an engineering simulation software company. People think of this as a company that benefits from innovation.

In the old days, you had a team of engineers design a new product, build mockups, then software would run calculations that tested stress characteristics. It was on the tail end of the innovation. And it might take weeks to run those simulations.
Today you can run millions of simulations before you even get to the real engineering side of things.
IBD: Biotech is your second-largest industry group, with 5.45% of assets. Why are you focused there?

Caruso: Biotech came out of a very long, severe stock price underperformance. Now we're seeing far greater pipeline productivity emerging from a couple of leaders. We've centered our investments on Celgene (CELG), Biogen (BIIB) and Gilead (GILD). Each is in a different area of disease management.

Biogen has been mostly a multiple sclerosis story. They've come to market with a new oral medicine called Tecfidera, which has experienced one of the most unbelievably successful product launches in pharmacology history. But (investors) have been so focused on MS that they haven't paid attention to some of the products that are in development.

There is a hemophilia product (Eloctate) that we expect to launch in mid-next year. It has the opportunity to take share from Baxter (BAX) and drive growth. And there's upside left for Tecfidera for a long time to come.

Gilead is basically an HIV and hepatitis C story. It has new product launches on the horizon. We expect Gilead to remain dominant in HIV in the near- to midterm. Their hepatitis C portfolio is starting to contribute meaningfully to corporate growth.
Celgene is a multiple myeloma story, a cancer story. We see expanding use of the marketplace.
All of these companies were coming off of pretty conservative valuations for the kind of growth we envision them experiencing for the next couple of years.
IBD: Why did you trim your Facebook (FB) stake recently? You could not have foreseen the pullback that began in mid-October.
Caruso: The stock had an amazing run after reporting Q2 earnings. They demonstrated great acceleration in their mobility business, which people got excited about. The stock doubled in a short time.
We made a meaningful reduction in exposure in that euphoria. It had become close to 3% of the portfolio. So we cut our position roughly in half. It is roughly 1.5% today.

Their 20% fall? The stock had gone up the day they reported earnings. Then management talked about the need to spend more on investing in people and their product. A lot of highly valued, high-growth companies have seen similar price corrections.
I'm comfortable owning the stock. At the right price, we're getting back in.
IBD: Michael Kors (KORS) is relatively new for you. Are you concerned that earnings-per-share growth has sharply decelerated in recent quarters?

Caruso: We're always concerned about decelerating growth rates. But Kors' decline is to a less-than-extraordinary level. That's still better than a lot of companies. The stock is reasonably valued for the kind of growth we envision. They have opportunities in Europe and elsewhere overseas. Kors is seen as differentiated here and overseas.
IBD: Any surprise to Starbucks' (SBUX) accelerating EPS growth?

Caruso: No. They're just an unbelievable company. They're one of the few that has been able to consistently reinvent themselves. They've done a brilliant job of expanding their product offerings in small footprint stores, in being first to market in using new technologies to connect to their customers and their rewards programs are best in their class.
IBD: Precision Castparts (PCP) is up this year, but you've done some trimming. What are your concerns?

Caruso: They are persistent in acquiring businesses that let them leverage their own infrastructure. And they're an important supplier to Boeing (BA) on the 787. They generate about $10 million of content on every 787 that Boeing ships. Part of our reduction is that we own both companies. If we sell, it probably will be out of Boeing. Precision has lagged Boeing, so Precision has more upside.
IBD: Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) is way down this year. Yet you've added to your position in some recent quarters. Are you still optimistic?

Caruso: This has been the most disappointing stock in the portfolio in 2013. The interest we had was centered on the uniqueness of their business. There are no competitors at their scale. Robotic surgery is here to stay and will continue to grow.
Procedure growth continues to expand at a midteen clip year over year. The issue with execution relates to installation sales, which has slowed, especially in the U.S.

We expect a couple more tough quarters. Procedure growth will continue in the 16% area. There's no competition. Unbelievably high margins, big share buyback, no debt. Hopefully, it will be a contrary growth stock that recovers.
IBD: Are you concerned that LinkedIn's (LNKD) EPS growth has slowed for two quarters?

Caruso: They've brought a new (advertising product for mobile devices) to market. It will help their growth rate re-accelerate into next year. Like we did with Facebook, we made decent sales in the summer on the market euphoria around this stock. We're more interested in finding a price to re-engage LinkedIn than Facebook.

We think of it as a core holding, a business that's tough to replicate due to their network effect and LinkedIn managers who think of this as a business and want it to be profitable. It's a good business that is richly valued. It will grow into that. So getting the entry and trim points right is important.

IBD: Noble Energy's (NBL) EPS growth has soared the past two quarters. But tumbling crude oil prices have doused energy producer stocks' spark lately. This stock has pulled back about 10% since Oct. 30. Why stick with it?

Caruso: Noble is one of the best-positioned energy companies by way of its fracking inventory. Overseas — in Israel and Africa — they have unbelievable reserves. And they are really good operators, really focused on creating value.
Energy firms are more volatile than what we typically engage, but this company's assets are special.

We've seen a reduction in underlying commodity prices, so we would welcome an opportunity to buy some of this back, make it larger in the portfolio. It's not quite at a point where we would start buying it back.
IBD: What's the biggest change you've made since taking this fund's helm in February 2012?

Caruso: Basically, our perception of growth is linked to a company's ability to create long-term value. So our focus is further forward than many other investors' focus is. It's more on the economics of business and profitability than on the hunt for earnings growth, which is sometimes very episodic. We're still looking for opportunities in large-cap growth. But we're focused on the longer term.
IBD: What was the fund's prior time horizon?

Caruso: I can't say, but it was probably more consistent with most growth managers'. Annual turnover in growth portfolios is often 100% to 150%. We're trying to do closer to 50%. We want great franchises that have the ability to win over a very long time. I tell my analysts I want them to understand how companies are competitively differentiated. I don't want them spending their time trying to anticipate when a bad business is a good stock.There are two keys to Frank Caruso's investment strategy.First, the lead manager of $2 billion AllianceBernstein Large Cap Growth directs his team to seek what he calls dynamic gaps.Those gaps are big differences between how fast Caruso's team expects a stock's earnings to grow and Wall Street's consensus expectation.The second key is where Caruso has his team look for that gap: four to five years out.Caruso is adamant about avoiding a focus on the near term.This approach had the fund up 32.46% this year through Nov. 30. That topped 78% of its large-cap growth peers, which averaged 29.96%. The S&P 500 was up 29.12%.Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain is 18.14% vs. 15.70% for its peer group and 17.73% for the big-cap bogey.Caruso, age 57, discussed his investment process with IBD from his office in Manhattan.IBD: How does your search for leading stocks differ from other growth investors'?Caruso: We think of equities generally (in terms of) a combination of growth and capital returns in the form of dividends and share buybacks, which support the valuations of equities over a long period.And we take a long-duration approach to investment opportunities.
