The major averages remained higher early Tuesday afternoon, led by the tech-heavy Nasdaq, as the Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting. The Nasdaq rallied 0.7% to its best level since October 2000, as Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG) rose. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. Volume was tracking sharply higher on both…
3D Systems (DDD) and MasterCard (MA) head the list of five leading big-cap stocks that ended 2013 at all-time highs, making them worth looking at for 2014.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, institutional-quality stocks that are highly liquid and have excellent fundamentals.
Five of them ended the year on a high note: 3D Systems, MasterCard, Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), Mohawk Industries (MHK) and Alliance Data Systems (ADS).
3D Systems makes 3D printers, devices that use software blueprints to make a widening array of goods ranging from toys and appliance replacement parts to walls for homes.
The company along with rival Stratasys (SSYS) pioneered the hot category, which is growing rapidly as businesses adopt them for manufacturing and consumers start snatching them up too.

In early December, an analyst with Canaccord Genuity raised his price target on 3D Systems, saying "revenue growth is being driven by strong organic demand, a continuing expansion of new products, looming consumables growth acceleration, and an expanding consumer channel."
Shares of 3D Systems, which have nearly doubled since early October, rose 1% Tuesday to 92.93.
MasterCard had an outstanding year, as did larger rival Visa (V), which isn't on the Big Cap Leaders list.

MasterCard's global credit card transactions climbed to 10 billion last quarter amid a more positive economic climate. If its earnings per share growth hits Wall Street's 23% target this quarter, it will have had at least four years of double-digit profit growth.
MasterCard sports a best-possible 99 Composite Rating. Shares rose less than 1% to an 835.46 close in Tuesday trading on the stock market today.

Francisco D'Souza helped spin off Cognizant Technology Solutions, a tech consulting and outsourcing company, from Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) in the late 1990s and was named Cognizant's CEO in January 2007.

Despite the Great Recession, he's overseen its growth from $1.4 billion in revenue that year to a projected $8.4 billion in 2013. D'Souza told IBD in a recent interview, "I think the key to success in the business world today is to learn how to adapt quickly."
BNP Paribas forecasts that Cognizant's revenue will hit $10.3 billion in 2014.

Flooring and rugmaker Mohawk Industries has been growing in sync with the housing recovery. Credit Suisse was among a group of analysts that raised their ratings on Mohawk in December after the company posted accelerating EPS growth of 50%, 61% and 94% in the first three quarters of 2013.

Private-label credit card issuer Alliance Data Systems provides card services to chains such as Hilton Worldwide (HLT), which began trading as a public company again in December, Williams-Sonoma's (WSM) Pottery Barn and L Brands (LB), parent to Victoria's Secret. Consensus is for EPS to climb 27% this quarter.
In December, Alliance Data Systems and Mohawk got a further lift when they were included in the widely followed S&P 500, triggering more accumulation by index funds that track the S&P.
Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Related:Ambarella, Jazz Among Stocks Outpacing Record Market.

The top stocks from IBD's 33 sector groups rose across the board Thursday, many in strong volume, as the major averages rebounded from the previous day's losses.
The biggest winner among sector-leading stocks was 3D Systems (DDD), a maker of printers that produce three-dimensional prototypes mainly for the computer, aerospace and medical industries.
It rose 2.51, or 5%, to 50.22, retaking its 48.11 buy point. Volume was 42% above normal. It's now 4% above the buy point.

3D's rebound comes after it sank 11% below the buy point last Thursday, triggering a key IBD sell rule. Though the stock quickly rebounded, the decline was worrisome, especially since the pattern is late stage, making it more prone to failure. Buying it now would be risky.

Ocwen Financial (OCN) also reclaimed its buy point Thursday after rebounding from a recent pullback. The buyer of distressed mortgage loans climbed 1.82 — 4% — to 43.35. It's now 3% above its 42.17 buy point. Like 3D Systems, however, its base is late stage.

Meanwhile, Irish drugmaker Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) continues to behave well, rising 2.10 to a new high of 68.44 in volume that was 47% above normal. It ended near the top of its intraday range, a bullish sign. The stock has risen for nine of the past 10 sessions.

Fashion designer Michael Kors (KORS) also hit a new high after tacking on 1.73 to 65.68. It was the third straight high-volume gain for the stock, which on Wednesday cleared a 62.35 buy point in a cup-with-handle base following a strong quarterly earnings report. Kors is 5% above the buy point.

Priceline.com (PCLN) also performed well, rising 15.27 to 807.54 in strong volume. Companies cashing out through follow-on stock offerings can use the money for future growth or to profit insiders. But these transactions also can slap current investors when an otherwise bullish stock gets pummeled by the influx of new shares.
Pandora Media (P), Shutterstock (SSTK) and Textura (TXTR) are among the many companies with follow-on offerings this month.
In addition, LinkedIn (LNKD) this month unveiled a follow-on offering worth at least $1.2 billion to fund its expansion.

"The appetite for equities has increased dramatically from institutions," said Kieran McDonough, a Boston-based financial adviser. "Companies come to market when they can, not necessarily when they want to."
In some cases, stock offerings have a short-lived impact.
LinkedIn shares fell nearly 3% on Sept. 4, the day after disclosing its offering plan. But the next day the stock rose nearly 4% to a new high.

Pandora announced a big share offering after the market close on Sept. 16. The stock sold off at the next day's opening bell but quickly rebounded to end 7% higher. Its shares hit an all-time high of 27.35 last week.
But — as with any investment — there are risks involved.
Mark Mulholland, portfolio manager for Matthew 25 Fund, said follow-ons tend to be a negative sign in most cases.
"If they're selling stock and it's not for a concrete purpose then they're probably telling you the stock is selling above its intrinsic value," he said.

Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) has announced three follow-on offerings since the upscale fashion house's IPO in December 2011, each time shortly after reporting strong earnings that sent the stock to new highs. But shares reversed each time on the news that Mr. Michael Kors and other insiders were cashing out big portions of their holdings. Investors who bought at new highs after earnings quickly found themselves sitting on losses. Shares trended down for several weeks in each case.
Kors finally broke this cycle after its latest earnings report Aug. 6. The company did not announce another offering, and shares have rallied since then.

Investors also risk being shaken out from the initial negative reaction from offering announcements. Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) on Aug. 27 announced plans to sell $500 million in convertible debt. The Chinese Web security and search firm fell nearly 8% intraday on Aug. 28, wiping out virtually all the gains from its strong earnings results earlier in the week. But the stock closed down less than 2%. Qihoo recouped that modest loss the following day, and was setting 52-week highs the next week.

Two 3D printing companies, Stratasys (SSYS) and ExOne (XONE), this month also announced offerings, which didn't lead to instant success as their shares dropped by 6% and 11%, respectively, the day after each announcement. Stratasys has bounced back somewhat, but ExOne has continued sliding to a three-month low this week.Companies cashing out through follow-on stock offerings can use the money for future growth or to profit insiders. The high-fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) pierced its 50-day moving average with a heavy volume decline early Monday, as chatter on Twitter indicated that OTR Global sees decelerating sales.
Kors shares were trading down 4.3% intraday at 55.71 on the stock market today. It's 2% below that 50-day line.
It's down 14% from its highest close of 64.84 reached on Feb. 19.

But after that record close, the seller of watches, handbags and expensive clothing announced the 25 million share sale, including 3 million shares from the company's namesake designer. That brings his holdings in the company named after him down to 2.4%. Sportswear Holdings Limited, the private equity firm that is Kors' largest owner, unloaded 19.7 million shares, almost 63% of its holdings. CEO John Idol sold 2 million shares from trusts established for his family.
The insider sales sparked a sell-off.

Kors has been a top performer since its IPO and has consistently posted blistering sales growth. In its blowout fiscal Q3 report last month, the company said sales at stores open at least a year had climbed 41% from a year ago.
On Monday, the independent research firm OTR Global didn't immediately confirm whether it thinks sales are decelerating, but the prospects of that apparently spooked investors further.
Other upscale brands appeared untarnished.
Shares of Fossil (FOSL), which supplies Kors with branded watches and jewelry, climbed 0.2% to 103.61 intraday Monday.

Handbags and other leather goods maker Coach (COH) was up 0.9% intraday to 49.35.The high-fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) pierced its 50-day moving average with a heavy volume decline early Monday, as chatter on Twitter indicated that OTR Global sees decelerating sales.Kors shares were trading down 4.3% intraday at 55.71 on the stock market today. Stocks rebounded Tuesday, taking back a small portion of the past week's punishing slide, but volume was lower.

Worries about the Federal Reserve's tapering of its monthly bond buys and a credit crunch in China faded, at least for a day. Positive sentiment was helped by comments from two Fed officials Monday that downplayed the impact of scaling back the Fed's monthly bond-buying program.
Positive news on durable goods orders, the housing market and consumer confidence also encouraged the bulls.

The S&P 500 rose 0.9% and finished near its session high. The Nasdaq ended a four-session losing streak, up 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.7%. Top-performing industry groups included solar, cement, rail transport, super regional banks and oil refining.
There wasn't much conviction behind the buying Tuesday as preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in much lower than Monday.

In the stock market today, homebuilders outperformed early, but reversed early gains. Home prices rose 2.5% in April, more than double expectations, according to the S&P/Case Shiller composite index of 20 cities. Meanwhile, May new-home sales rose 2.1% to 476,000 units, the highest level since mid-2008 and slightly above the consensus estimate of 460,000.
Lennar (LEN) squandered most of a solid gain after it reported another quarter of strong top- and bottom-line growth. The stock, up as much as 5%, finished the day ahead only 0.7%.
Since hitting a high of 44.40 on May 20, Lennar has lost 23%. It's trading below its 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Big Cap 20 component Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) kept pace with the market, rising 1%. It's still stuck underneath its 10-week moving average as it consolidates recent gains. The drugmaker cleared a late-stage base in April. If market conditions continue to improve, it's best to focus on early-stage bases rather than late-stage ones.
The Big Cap 20 is published every Tuesday.

Elsewhere, HomeAway (AWAY) soared 6%. The stock is back above its 10-week moving average after spending a lengthy amount of time below the line. On a daily chart, the stock cleared a descending trend line today, found by connecting the recent highs of the stock. The company operates an online marketplace for vacation rentals. Recent earnings and sales growth has been solid, and growth prospects look good, with full-year profit expected to rise 27% this year and 26% in 2014.

Michael Kors (KORS) recovered a bit, but still closed below its 50-day moving average. Shares rose 3%. The stock's recent breakout over 62.35 looked good for a while, but eventually succumbed to selling pressure. It's still 5% below the buy point.
Here's a look at some upcoming earnings reports for the rest of the week:
Wednesday: Monsanto (MON), Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY).

The maker of home carbonation machines broke out of a first-stage base in December and is 22% past its 43.10 buy point.…
The rallying stock market played favorites with retail-stock purchases made by top-performing funds in recent months, which included Lumber Liquidators (LL), Cabela's (CAB) and Brown Shoe Co. (BWS).
Financials also were among recent winners. Several financial stocks made the latest list of New Buys Of Top-Performing Funds, but only one is focused on mortgages: Ocwen Financial (OCN).
When this column last visited Ocwen in the Jan. 4 edition, the mortgage lender was working through a shallow consolidation, which four weeks later resolved into breakout from a cup-with-handle base.
Ocwen last week cleared the base's 39.35 buy point. It eased Monday but remained within 1% of that mark.
Institutional Support

In recent weeks, institutional support for the stock has grown. The number of top-rated funds buying Ocwen grew from 10 funds investing an estimated $24 million in their latest reporting periods frame to 38 funds plopping down $176 million.
That's an increase that can spark further research by successful investors.
The total number of funds owning the company has risen to 377 from 330 in June.

Ocwen has an IBD Composite Rating of 99. Its Relative Strength Rating has been 98-99 for nine weeks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating tipped up to B+ from B. Its up/down volume ratio has slipped a tad to 0.9 from 1 two weeks ago.
Among big funds that have had significant stakes recently is $21.3 billion Fidelity Balanced . Oppenheimer Small & Mid Cap Growth, with $359 million in assets, also has taken on some shares.
IBD Leaderboard stocks that have found favor among top-rated funds include Grand Canyon Education (LOPE), Lumber Liquidators, and Michael Kors (KORS).
Sell Side
Top funds found disfavor with several medical stocks, including Pfizer (PFE), Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Viropharma (VPHM) in their latest reporting periods.

These stocks have enjoyed their day in the sun, riding along their 52-week highs. Stocks slunk lower as the dollar rose vs. the euro and global markets digested weak February export data from China.
Dow futures dropped 30 points after trading nearly flat in earlier action. Nasdaq 100 futures dipped 7.25 points and S&P 500 futures dipped 4.4 points.

Stocks in Europe showed moderate losses as the euro slumped vs. the dollar. Oil prices eased 1% to just above $106 a barrel. Natural gas slumped back to its 10-year low at $2.26 per thousand cubic feet. Gold slipped 1% to $1,694.90 an ounce.

Markets across Asia closed narrowly mixed after China posted its largest monthly trade deficit in 12 years, $31.48 billion in February, up from January's $27.28 billion tally. The slowing in export traffic, combined with a squall of weak data last week, raised concerns the economy could be cooling much more quickly than expected.

In stocks, Zoll Medical (ZOLL) spiked 23% ahead of the opening after Japan-based Asahi Kasei agreed to buy the maker of cardiac resuscitation gear for $2.2 billion. Asahi, a chemical and synthetic fiber maker, is using the acquisitions to expand into medical markets in Japan and Asia.
Zoll carries a 98 Composite Rating from IBD. It had just rebounded from 10-week support after clearing a deep, five-month correction.

Michael Kors (KORS) backed off 4% in premarket activity. The luxury fashion house jumped 3% in powerful trade Friday, then announced, after the close, plans for a 25 million share follow-on offering by certain shareholders.
The stock is up 148% since its public offering Dec. 15.

Coach (COH), the luxury handbag and accessory maker, reported first-quarter earnings and sales above low analyst expectations as sales in China remained strong.

The brand known for its iconic "C" design said first-quarter earnings rose 10% to 84 cents per share, beating analyst estimates by 4 cents. Sales climbed 7% to $1.19 billion, above estimates of $1.18 billion.
Shares jumped 10.6% to 55.97 in the stock market today. Michael Kors (KORS) rose 3.2% to 54.03. Ralph Lauren (RL) rose 2.5% to 170.07.
Coach sales in North America rose 7% to $792 million and international sales jumped 6% to $382 million. Total sales in China rose 40%.

"Internationally, our business is growing rapidly, with China in particular continuing to post excellent gains, and is now on course to generate about $425 million in sales this year," Chief Commercial Officer Victor Luis said in a statement.
Coach's men's business is also doing well and the company is expanding its brand. Revenue from the division is expected to double to more than $600 million in 2013.
Coach raised its annual dividend 15 cents to $1.35 per share.
The Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group is ranked No. 149 out IBD's 197 industry groups.

G-III Apparel (GIII) leads the group with a 91 Composite Rating. IBD's Composite Rating rates stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength. Gildan Activewear (GIL) is second with an 89 rating. Stocks fell hard, but ended off their worst levels Friday after a setback in the fiscal cliff saga. The market also digested a round of mostly better-than-expected economic data.

The Nasdaq trimmed a 1.8% loss to 1% and closed above the psychological 3000 level. It breached 3000 intraday. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 lost 0.9% each. Volume surged across the board due to the quadruple witching expirations of options and futures.
Equities also finished higher on the week. The Nasdaq rallied 1.7%, and the S&P 500 advanced 1.2%. The Dow lagged with a 0.4% gain.

Late Thursday's news that House Speaker John Boehner's "Plan B" didn't even get to a vote put equities on the defensive. On the economic front, personal income and spending came in above expectations, as did durable orders. But the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index unexpectedly dipped.

Panera Bread (PNRA) gapped down, dropped 4% and sliced its 50-day moving average. Although there was no specific news, the stock broke the key support in more than twice its average trade. It had just acted better earlier in the week and regained the 50-day line Tuesday. Panera closed slightly above its 200-day moving average.

SolarWinds (SWI) fell 3% and closed slightly below its 50-day line in heavy trade. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a 57.24 buy point, but it's a late-stage pattern. Late-stage bases tend to have higher failure rates.

Michael Kors (KORS) cut a 6% loss to 3% and finished above its 50-day line. But the stock snapped a five-session win streak. Michael Kors showed improved action this week, rising 7% in heavy volume. The stock is forming a base-on-base pattern.

On the upside, Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) bucked the negative trend, rising 4% in heavy turnover to an all-time high. The stock is now 8% past a 26.70 buy point from a cup base cleared Tuesday. It has a strong Composite Rating of 97.

Shares of Urban Outfitters (URBN) were up 5% at mid-day after the retailer disclosed in a regulatory filing late yesterday that same-store retail sales in Q4 are trending in the high single digits.
The quarter-to-date results were for all retail segments, including direct-to-consumer sales, and were above analysts' forecasts.
Besides its namesake 209-unit Urban Outfitters' chain, the company operates 177 Anthropologie stores and 77 Free People units.

Stifel Nicolaus analyst Richard Jaffe wrote in a client note that results were particularly strong given that December sales "were off to a slow start" for many retailers following a robust Thanksgiving weekend.
He estimated Q4 sales are so far up around 8% at Urban Outfitters, 5% at Anthropologie, 12% at Free People and 35% in the direct-to-consumer division.

"Urban's previous merchandise problems were driven by a lack of differentiation from other retailers," he wrote, noting it didn't have its typical ironic, irreverent merchandise. "We believe merchandise at this division has improved and customers are responding favorably to the new assortment."
Anthropologie has been the "most challenged" of Urban's brands, he added, but said an expanded assortment is helping.
Janney Capital Markets Adrienne Tennant wrote in a morning note that the "most pronounced margin recovery" appears to be coming from the Anthropologie division.
"We believe that Anthropologie stores look the best we have seen them all year," she wrote.

She said there could be upside to analysts' Q4 consensus estimate of 52 cents a share if current trends continue. That estimate is already 93% higher than last year's Q4 results. That would continue a trend of accelerating sales growth over the last three quarters.
Urban has posted two straight quarters of double-digit earnings growth.
Tennant said she expects acceleration in sales for the remainder of December.
Following last year's 26% earnings slide, analysts expected Urban's full-year earnings this year to rise 33% to $1.58 a share.

The Nasdaq composite dropped 1.1% as volume rose, marking a second day of distribution in as many sessions. On Tuesday, the tech-rich index made little price progress upward as volume increased. Such stalling action indicated that…
Earnings and revenue growth are key metrics for investors looking for top stocks to invest in.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Leaders with Rising Estimates: top-rated companies that analysts are raising earnings estimates on.
Here are the top six Rising Estimates equities ranked by expected EPS growth in the stock market today.
Topping the list is Evercore Partners (EVR), which provides advisory services on mergers, acquisitions, divestitures and the like. Consensus is that its EPS will spike 440% this quarter.
Evercore is a boutique investment bank that's filling a void left when many of the largest banks focused on mortgages and other services, leaving investment advice to companies like Evercore.
Its stock consolidated in the first half of 2012, bottomed at 20.57 intraday on July 27 and then began rising. It's since climbed 98% to 40.70 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day, at an all-time high.

LinkedIn (LNKD), the social network site for professionals, is projected to record 100% higher EPS for the quarter as it expands by providing career advice and bringing employees and employers together in an era of lingering high unemployment.
LinkedIn began trading on May 20, 2011 at 45 a share and closed Thursday at 168.18, up 274% since its IPO and down 0.2% for the day.

Michael Kors (KORS), which began trading in December 2011 at 20 a share, has met with tremendous acceptance. The luxury apparel, accessories and footwear retailer is forecast to report an 86% jump in EPS this quarter.
Kors turned heads when it reported a blowout holiday quarter on Feb. 12, which caused shares to gap up 8.8% for the day. Shares hit an all-time high 64.84 on Feb. 19, but have retreated a bit since.
Its share price has nearly tripled from its IPO to a 59.28 close Thursday, down 0.3% for the day.

Soufun Holdings (SFUN), a Chinese real estate marketing and listings company, is forecast for 53% higher EPS. It sports a hefty 7.1% dividend yield, which may or may not be attractive to investors, depending on investing strategy.
Like many U.S. counterparts, it's seen profit and sales grow at double- and triple-digit rates lately amid a hot real estate market.
After consolidating in early 2012, it stock began rising again on Aug. 1 and has since soared 145% to close at 26.85 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) provides specialized payment services to companies that operate commercial fleets, and is forecast to post a 37% EPS increase in EPS this quarter.
It's also No. 1 on the elite IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. Earlier this month, it cruised past estimates, fueled by global expansion.

It's benefited from an improving economy as companies shipped more goods of all sorts. Shares more than doubled from a midsummer low 34.82 on July 23 to close at an all-time high 69.81 Thursday, up 2.3% for the day. It's trading well above its 50-day and 200-day averages.

TripAdvisor (TRIP), the travel information provider spun off of web travel site Expedia (EXPE) in December 2011, is also on the Leaders with Rising Estimates list. TripAdvisor is expected to report a 21% EPS rise this quarter.
After a post-IPO surge, shares began consolidating last July. It's formed a long cup or saucer-type base and closed up 0.6% Thursday, 7% off its all-time high 49.35, reached on Feb. 6.
Related:
LinkedIn, Celgene, ARM Among Top 5 Big Cap Leaders

Stocks touched fresh session lows around midafternoon Wednesday, as investors digested the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's last policy meeting and President Obama's news conference.

The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%, the S&P 500 fell 0.7% and the Nasdaq dropped 0.6%. Each index has touched a fresh low for the current market correction and slumped further under its 200-day moving average. Volume was tracking ahead of Tuesday's level across the board.

The Fed minutes indicated some officials see the need for additional quantitative easing next year. The minutes also suggested the central bank is moving closer to providing better guidance on when it might make its first rate hike.

Meanwhile, the president called for Congress to extend middle-class tax breaks, saying: "We should at least do what we can agree on." He said Washington could then move to negotiating how to handle taxes on the wealthy as it works to avoid the fiscal cliff. Still, the market's sell-off has picked up through midafternoon.

IBD 50 stocks were mostly lower, with Catamaran (CTRX) sliding 7% in strong volume. The pharmacy benefits manager and IT services provider, No. 8 in Wednesday's IBD 50, sliced through its 50-day moving average after consolidating near that level in the last few weeks. Rival pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) is also down in heavy volume, sliding 1%.
Michael Kors (KORS), No. 3 in Wednesday's IBD 50, fell 5% in active turnover. The clothing and accessories maker, a December 2011 IPO, has undercut support at 50 and a prior buy point at 49.60.

On the upside, Cisco Systems (CSCO) jumped 5% in strong turnover, powered by its better-than-expected earnings report late Tuesday. The stock remains below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, as well as about 15% off its April high. Cisco has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 42, but it remains a tech sector bellwether.

Facebook (FB) gained 12% in big volume on a big lock-up expiration day for the May IPO. Stock futures fell hard ahead of Tuesday's open, tracking overseas losses and following a sudden transition in Microsoft's top management.
Dow futures were down 63 points and pointed lower. Nasdaq 100 futures fell 18.25 points and S&P 500 futures were 7.8 points lower.

Microsoft (MSFT) traded down 3% in premarket action, following the sudden resignation of Steven Sinofsky, head of the company's Windows division. Several news sources said Sinofsky had been a top candidate for the company's chief executive post.
Microsoft appointed company veteran Julie Larson-Green to lead all Windows software and hardware engineering.

Michael Kors (KORS) dumped 5% ahead of the open, despite reporting fiscal Q2 EPS up 113% and a 74% jump in sales. Analyst consensus called for a 74% earnings gain and 70% sales increase. Third-quarter revenue guidance was in line with projections, but earnings guidance was at the low end of expectations.
The stock stabbed through its 10-week line of support in heavy trade last week.

On the upside, Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) bounced 4% higher after reporting third-quarter earnings up 25%, topping analyst expectations for a 16% gain. Revenue growth of 11% was also better than expected, and management reported a 47% increase in e-commerce sales.
The stock has pulled back 11% since mid-September, closing below its 10-week moving average for the past six weeks.

Overseas, European markets stumbled lower through midday trade as Eurozone leaders and the International Monetary Fund locked horns over how best to deal with Greece, delaying further aid disbursements to the country and raising the risk of a default.

China's markets booked brisk losses overnight. The Shanghai Composite dropped 1.5%, as investors reacted to tightening regulations in the country's real estate markets. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 shed 0.2%.
The euro etched out a two-month low, down for a fifth straight session against the dollar. Commodities were mixed across the board and trading in a very tight range.

On the economic calendar, October budget data are due out from the Treasury Department at 10 a.m. EST.Stock futures fell hard ahead of Tuesday's open, tracking overseas losses and following a sudden transition in Microsoft's top management.Dow futures were down 63 points and pointed lower. Nasdaq 100 futures fell 18.25 points and S&P 500 futures were 7.8 points lower.Microsoft (MSFT) traded down 3% in premarket action, following the sudden resignation of Steven Sinofsky, head of the company's Windows division. Several news sources said Sinofsky had been a top candidate for the company's chief executive post.Microsoft appointed company veteran Julie Larson-Green to lead all Windows software and hardware engineering.Michael Kors (KORS) dumped 5% ahead of the open, despite reporting fiscal Q2 EPS up 113% and a 74% jump in sales. Analyst consensus called for a 74% earnings gain and 70% sales increase. Third-quarter revenue guidance was in line with projections, but earnings guidance was at the low end of expectations.The stock stabbed through its 10-week line of support in heavy trade last week.On the upside, Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) bounced 4% higher after reporting third-quarter earnings up 25%, topping analyst expectations for a 16% gain. Revenue growth of 11% was also better than expected, and management reported a 47% increase in e-commerce sales.The stock has pulled back 11% since mid-September, closing below its 10-week moving average for the past six weeks.Overseas, European markets stumbled lower through midday trade as Eurozone leaders and the International Monetary Fund locked horns over how best to deal with Greece, delaying further aid disbursements to the country and raising the risk of a default.China's markets booked brisk losses overnight. The Shanghai Composite dropped 1.5%, as investors reacted to tightening regulations in the country's real estate markets. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 shed 0.2%.The euro etched out a two-month low, down for a fifth straight session against the dollar. Commodities were mixed across the board and trading in a very tight range.On the economic calendar, October budget data are due out from the Treasury Department at 10 a.m. EST.

Sector Leaders gave a mixed showing Friday, but a few scored big weekly gains. Web.com Group (WWWW) rose for the fourth straight session, scoring an all-time high. It added 0.59, or 2%, to 25.60 in more than four times average trade. The stock closed 12% past a 22.94 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared June 19. For the week,…
Stock futures trimmed their early gains rapidly Friday as the market approached the opening bell.
Dow futures were up 34 points, well below their early 84 point advance. Nasdaq 100 futures trimmed a 17-point gain to 8.75 points. S&P 500 futures were up 5.75 and well off early highs.

The stock market today appears to be leaning toward a rebound after Thursday's sell off triggered a status shift to "market in correction." The two-day sell off left the Nasdaq down 1.7%, the S&P 500 off 2.4% and the Dow with a 2.1% loss so far for the week. All three indexes start Friday below their 50-day moving averages, and face potential resistance at that level.

China-based chip designer Spreadtrum Communications (SPRD) bolted 24% higher after a $1.38 billion buyout bid from a unit of government-owned Tsinghua Holdings. Spreadtrum raised its Q2 revenue estimates last week by $50 million to between $270 million and $278 million, citing higher demand from low-cost smartphone makers.
The stock had gained 15% so far this month, through Thursday, but was meeting resistance near its November high.
Leading stocks were generally tightly mixed ahead of the open, with a couple key exceptions on the IBD 50 list.

Michael Kors (KORS) traded up nearly 5% in premarket action. The Hong Kong-based fashion house slipped 3% in weak trade Thursday, ending just above its 50-day line and 4% below a 62.35 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Dunkin' Brands Doughnuts (DNKN) banged out a 4% gain ahead of the bell. The coffee shop chain, now rebranding itself as a beverage company and pursuing expansion into West Coast markets, booked a mild 2% loss Thursday in very weak trade. It ended in buying range on a rebound from 10-week support.

Overseas in Asia, China's markets closed out the week with thin losses Friday after the country's central bank relented, putting pressure on rising interest rates by pumping more than $8 billion into the banking system. For the week, the Shanghai Composite fell 4.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 3.3%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 climbed 1.7% Friday, leaving the index up 4.2% for the week.
Stocks in Europe carted mild gains through midday as the major indexes tracked toward hefty losses for the week. Frankfurt's DAX was hardest hit, looking at a loss for the week of 2.3%.

The dollar eased from Thursday's highs against the euro, but was still on track for its best gain in 12 months. The buck gained vs. the yen. In commodities, gold limped along near $1,291 an ounce, tracking toward a 7% loss for the week, after tanking more than 6% on Thursday. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) is No. 1 on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks and is among a group of six elite companies that will report earnings this week.The IBD 50 showcases companies with proven earnings and revenue growth records as well as strong Relative Strength.Green Mountain is showing unusual strength and is No. 1. The coffee and tea company continues to rack up strong profits with sales of its proprietary Keurig single-cup brewing systems and coffee/tea pods to supermarkets and partner Starbucks (SBUX).Green Mountain reports fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday. It's expected to see a 48% jump in earnings per share to 77 cents, and 13% higher revenue at $981.9 million.Shares dipped 0.5% Friday.Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), No. 20 on the IBD 50, develops specialty drugs to treat a variety of ailments including narcolepsy, chronic pain and psychiatric illnesses.Jazz is slated to announce Q2 earnings results Tuesday. Consensus is for EPS to rise 39% to $1.52, and revenue to accelerate 68% to $208.7 million.Shares slipped 0.1% Friday.Priceline.com (PCLN), No. 28 on the list, is cashing in on the travel boom as the globe emerges from a deep recession. Shares jumped 37% from a late April low to an all-time high 926.40 on July 15 before consolidating.The forecast is for the name-your-price hotel and airline site to announce a 20% Q2 profit gain to $9.38 per share late Thursday. Sales are projected to rise 25% to $1.66 billion. Shares edged up slightly Friday.No. 36 Tangoe (TNGO) sells on-demand software to companies to help them keep track of assets and services. Analysts project a 60% rise in EPS to 16 cents, and a 27% hike in revenue to $45.9 million when it reports Q2 results late Wednesday.Its stock price has popped 60% since late April.Luxury apparel and accessories maker Michael Kors (KORS), No. 29 on the list, has taken the fashion world by storm. Its stock has kept pace, climbing 244% from its $20 initial public offering in mid-December 2011 to a 68.80 close Friday.Analysts look for 44% higher EPS at 49 cents. Sales are seen rising 38% to $570.5 million when it announces fiscal Q1 earnings early Tuesday.No. 49 Regeneron Pharmaceutical (REGN) has a strong market niche selling drugs to treat eye diseases such as age-related macular degeneration. The outlook is for Q2 earnings to climb 24% to 87 cents and revenue to grow 56% when it reports early Tuesday.Related:IBD 50: Market Strikes New Highs, And Leaders Lead The Way
Questcor Leads Top 5 Small-Cap, Medical Stocks
Stocks further weakened near Tuesday's midpoint. Some leaders have also come under fire.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 lost 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.7%, with nearly all 30 issues lower. Turnover was again tracking sharply higher in the stock market today.

Web.com Group (WWWW) dropped 5%, erasing Monday's work and then some. The stock looked to be on pace for its first loss in four sessions. Yet it remains more than 20% past a 22.94 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared June 19. On Friday, the website designer hit a new high in reaction to better-than-expected quarterly results.

Celgene (CELG) fell 3% and was on pace for its third straight loss. Unlike the low-volume losses in the past two sessions, turnover was tracking vastly above average Tuesday. Celgene gapped above a 131.92 buy point from a cup base June 11.
Elsewhere, IBD 50 stocks YY (YY) and Proto Labs (PRLB) each shed 5% in heavy volume.

New issue LightInTheBox (LITB) rallied 5% on a gap up. It cleared an 18.34 buy point from a handle in an IPO base in big volume. But shares were up as much as 10% intraday. LightInTheBox is a Chinese retailer of clothing, electronics, sporting goods and numerous other items. The company lost money in the past few years, but is expected to turn a profit of 36 cents a share this year.

Michael Kors (KORS) was up just over 2% after early optimism faded. Shares of the fashion house rallied as much as 5% following its blowout fiscal Q1 results. The fashion house's earnings climbed 79% to 61 cents a share. Sales surged 54% to $640.9 million. Analysts had expected 49 cents a share on revenue of $570.5 million.Stocks further weakened near Tuesday's midpoint. Blue chips were in the driver's seat with about one hour left to go in Wednesday's session. The Dow Jones industrial average outperformed, rising 0.7%, partly due to strength in IBM (IBM). Shares rose 2% after the company agreed to sell its customer-care outsourcing business to Synnex (SNX) for $505 million. Shares of Synnex surged 21%. The Nasdaq, meanwhile, was…

Stocks held on to strong gains Thursday with little over one hour remaining in the session, helped by a bullish earnings report from Facebook (FB) and better-than-expected economic growth.The Nasdaq rose 1.9%, the S&P 500 climbed 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%. Volume was tracking lower in the stock market today, more so on the New York Stock Exchange.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and Under Armour (UA) paced the IBD 50 as each rocketed 22% and 21% respectively following blowout earnings reports.Facebook jumped 14% to a new high after mobile ad revenue fueled better-than-expected Q4 results. Google (GOOG), meanwhile, gained 4% after getting support at its 10-week line for the first time since its October breakout. Earlier today, Google sold its Motorola Mobility hardware business to Lenova for $2.9 billion. Two years ago, Google paid just over $12 billion for the business.On the downside, Celgene (CELG) was among the few losers in the IBD 50. It was down 2% in heavy volume after the biotech company reported that Q4 profit rose 14% to $1.51 a share, below analysts' expectations. Celgene is below its 50-day line. On Monday it fell 8% below a 173.90 flat-base entry, triggering a sell rule.Earlier Thursday, the government reported that the U.S. economy grew at a 3.2% annual rate in the final quarter of 2013 on strong gains in consumer spending. Wall Street analysts had forecast a smaller 3% increase.

IBD 50 stocks mostly dropped last week, with some tumbling as the market endured a couple of days of selling in rising volume.The IBD 50 index shed 1.1% for the week. The index is up for the year, but its Relative Strength line continues to trend lower — a worrisome sign.Meanwhile, the Nasdaq lost 1%, the NYSE composite 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.3%. For the S&P 500, it was its first down week of 2013.Fed minutes out Wednesday hinted at an earlier-than-expected slowdown in the central bank's bond buying program. Market observers generally blamed the sell-off on those minutes, although some also said the market rally was due for a setback.IBD's market outlook has downshifted to "uptrend under pressure" from "confirmed uptrend." Investors should be thinking about locking in some profits. You also want to become more cautious about buying stocks.In addition, watch out for sell signals from leading stocks.Yandex (YNDX) was among the IBD 50 stocks that flashed a sell sign last week. The Russian search engine tripped IBD's 7% to 8% sell rule for investors who bought at its recent handle buy point at 23.99. It's now fallen out of the IBD 50.On the plus side, Yandex erased some losses and finished the week near its 10-week moving average.Generac Holdings (GNRC) also triggered the 7% to 8% sell rule, and the generators maker closed below its 10-week line amid heavy trade. Generac dropped as it made a secondary share offering.Another IBD 50 name that had a secondary offering, Michael Kors (KORS), has shown weakness but hasn't flashed a clear sell signal.Still, in the past week, the fashion house did erase most of its 11% gain from the week before last.Among the week's advancers, Celgene (CELG) continued to hold up well, finishing the week just a little below an all-time high. The biotech tripped IBD's eight-week hold rule at the start of the year, and it's now been eight weeks.So Celgene holders now have a decision to make. This hold rule is meant to help investors hang on to a potential big winner. It says that if a stock advances 20% from a buy area in three weeks or less, you should hold it for at least eight weeks.Medicines Co. (MDCO), featured in today's Stock Spotlight also behaved well. The biotech drew strong upside volume as it moved past a recent four-weeks-tight pattern.

Volume in the stock market today is tracking up slightly from Monday's levels on the NYSE and roughly flat on the Nasdaq. Michael Kors (KORS) was recovering a little…

The S&P 500 dipped 0.1% and the Dow was flat, caught between a rising Home Depot (HD) and Microsoft's (MSFT) 3% slide. Volume was uneven, up 20% on the Nasdaq and effectively flat on the NYSE compared…

The stocks in IBD's Sector Leaders screen delivered a mixed performance Monday, as the main indexes finished little changed. It's executing its first rebound off its 10-week moving average since an August breakout. The stock now…
Michael Kors (KORS) shares plunged 3.9% to 53.83 Monday after the luxury apparel and accessory maker announced a secondary offering by certain stockholders.
Kors announced the 20 million share secondary offering Friday afternoon and would give underwriters a 30-day option to buy up to 15% of additional shares.
Other luxury brands, Coach (COH) rose 1.7% to 62.74 and Ralph Lauren (RL) fell 0.1% to 161.
The company has been one of the most successful IPOs in the last year and is currently ranked No. 2 on the IBD 50 list.
Since its debut in December 2011 at 20 the stock had risen to a high of 56.03 on Sept. 7 before falling Monday.
Kors reported triple-digit earnings growth the last two quarters and luxury spending has rebounded quicker than midmarket apparel retailers.

"Right now luxury is the first to recover (from the recession) because it has the greatest level of longevity of growth," according to Marshal Cohen, chief retail analyst asked NPD group. "Also luxury consumers are the last to go into a spending cocoon and the first to come out if they even go in at all."

The Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group is ranked No. 53 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.Michael Kors (KORS) shares plunged 3.9% to 53.83 Monday after the luxury apparel and accessory maker announced a secondary offering by certain stockholders.Kors announced the 20 million share secondary offering Friday afternoon and would give underwriters a 30-day option to buy up to 15% of additional shares.Other luxury brands, Coach (COH) rose 1.7% to 62.74 and Ralph Lauren (RL) fell 0.1% to 161.The company has been one of the most successful IPOs in the last year and is currently ranked No. 2 on the IBD 50 list.Since its debut in December 2011 at 20 the stock had risen to a high of 56.03 on Sept. 7 before falling Monday.Kors reported triple-digit earnings growth the last two quarters and luxury spending has rebounded quicker than midmarket apparel retailers."Right now luxury is the first to recover (from the recession) because it has the greatest level of longevity of growth," according to Marshal Cohen, chief retail analyst asked NPD group. Major averages were near session lows Tuesday with a little more than an hour remaining in the session. Sellers were in control after Charles Evans, president of the Chicago Federal Reserve, said the Fed is "quite likely" to slow its monthly bond purchases before the end of the year. The Nasdaq lost 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average and…
Stocks can react violently to Fed policy announcements, like the one coming Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET. A slew of U.S.-traded quality foreign stocks and ADRs are near buy points. Let's look at a few.

Michael Kors (KORS) isn't making it easy. The stock's breakout from its 62.35 cup-with-handle on May 22 failed, falling 7% before finding its legs. By then, one assumes that prudent longs from that breakout unloaded under the 7%-8% sell rule.
But Michael Kors found support at its 10-week moving average — twice, with a push to a new high and a retreat in between.

One could see Michael Kors as a rebound from the 10-week line, but the stock has shown no upside volume since its most recent test, June 13. (Although that session saw a high-volume upside reversal, Michael Kors didn't make it into positive territory.)
What to look for? A high-volume reclaiming of the original 62.35 buy point, although with the stock so near that spot, it likely will look the same as a high-volume rebound.
We note that Michael Kors' executive brain trust has issued three secondary offerings since March 2012. It seems every time the stock gets going, the company issues a new supply.

Taiwanese chip designer ChipMos Technologies (IMOS) on June 11 looked like it was breaking out of a four-weeks-tight add-on point. But the stock reversed lower wildly from a 6% gain, turning that into a loss of as much as 4% before ending the day off a few pennies.
By ending within the parameters of the four-weeks-tight, ChipMos kept that pattern alive.
The stock has climbed as much as 3% from its 18.91 buy point, but so far volume has been a no-show. That could change quickly.
The four-weeks-tight appears after a long, too-deep cup that showed a breakout above 16.30. That flawed structure offered a high-risk entry, but the four-weeks-tight is far more attractive.
Yandex (YNDX), Russia's dominant Web search engine, stands 6% above its 26.07 entry from an awkward and asymmetrical cup.

But Yandex is now in its fifth week of a base-on-base effort, which would be a first-stage structure. And if that doesn't pan out, the stock also offers an entry as a rebound from its 10-week line. Either development would be more attractive than the flawed cup.

Chinese online "flash sale" retailer Vipshop (VIPS), trading at about 33, has regained its 10-week line with fast volume. This is the second test of the line since Vipshop broke out from an initial base at a low price of 6.48 in September. Normally, institutional investors focus on stocks trading at least at 10 a share. As of Q1, 52 funds held shares in Vipshop, up from 8 in the year-ago period.Stocks can react violently to Fed policy announcements, like the one coming Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET. Stocks ended modestly higher Wednesday, with the S&P 500 hitting another all-time high, amid data suggesting that the U.S. economy was picking up.

The S&P 500 rose 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each rose 0.2%. Volume was mixed, with NYSE volume tracking 6% lower than Tuesday and Nasdaq volume rising 6%, according to preliminary data.

Private employers added 191,000 jobs in March, according to ADP, pretty much in line with the consensus estimate of 193,000. Figures from the prior month were revised sharply higher. The data came ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to increase by 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%.
Orders for manufactured goods rose a better-than-expected 1.6% in February, the biggest increase in five months.

In the stock market today, office supply retailer Staples (SPLS) led the S&P 500 in terms of percentage gain, jumping 5% in heavy volume. However, the stock remains depressed well below its key support lines and 30% below its 52-week high.

Meanwhile, Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) continued to rebound sharply after announcing Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its next-generation da Vinci robotic surgical system. The stock jumped 5% to a 52-week high in more than double its average daily volume. It's up 20% for the week.

On the downside, Apollo Education (APOL) slumped 9%, slicing through its 50-day moving average, after the operator of the for-profit University of Phoenix reported that revenue for the latest quarter fell a greater-than-expected 19%.

The company also said it had received a subpoena from the Education Department seeking information about the University of Phoenix's operations in the Northeast.Stocks ended modestly higher Wednesday, with the S&P 500 hitting another all-time high, amid data suggesting that the U.S. economy was picking up.The S&P 500 rose 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average kept to a 0.1% loss. Volume dipped 30% on the NYSE and was 11% lower on the Nasdaq compared with the same time…

Fossil (FOSL), Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) are all expected to report a rise in revenue when they announce earnings this week. Overall October retail sales beat estimates as the back-to-school shopping momentum continued.

Fossil makes watches and accessories and is the licensed producer of Michael Kors (KORS)-brand watches. Analysts are expecting it to report a 6% rise in third-quarter earnings to $1.16 per share, when it announces earnings Tuesday. Sales are seen climbing 11% to $713.1 million.

Department store giant Macy's is slated to report third-quarter earnings Wednesday. Wall Street analysts are expecting a 9.4% drop in EPS to 29 cents per share, but revenue is seen rising 3.5% to $6.06 billion.

Nordstrom released preliminary results Nov. 1 but is slated to release official numbers Thursday. The high-end department store said Q3 sales jumped 13.8% to $2.7 billion. Analysts were expecting $2.8 billion. Nordstrom said same-store sales rose 10.7%.
Analysts are expecting earnings to rise 20% to 71 cents per share.

Retail continues to be a bright spot for the economy. October sales at stores open at least a year rose 5% vs. a year ago, according to Ken Perkins, president of industry analyst group Retail Metrics. Analyst were expecting a 4.6% jump. Nordstrom's October same-store sales jumped nearly 10% and Macy's rose 4%.
High-end retailers like Fossil, Kors and Nordstrom have done well during the economic downturn as wealthy customers never had to curb spending and are less price conscious than other shoppers.

Sometimes, stocks show up in the Stock Spotlight in clusters, and clothing manufacturers form one such cluster today. Three leaders from that industry have recently bounced back above the 50-day moving average, although they are in different stages of their chart development. Michael Kors (KORS) has bounced from a pullback to the 50-day line last week. However, the stock broke…

Despite three distribution days for the Nasdaq in less than two weeks, it's hard to get too down on this market when the tech-laden index sits just 1% off its recent high.Some market leaders are facing selling pressure, but a quick scan of the IBD 50 shows just a handful of names below their 10-week moving averages — not indicative of a market that's in trouble.Still, some leaders are showing chinks in their armor. Recent IBD 50 names like Ocwen Financial (OCN), Celgene (CELG) and Herbalife (HLF) have fallen below their 10-week lines. Other big leaders like LinkedIn (LNKD) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) are in the same boat.There are times when the IBD 50 is fertile ground for buying opportunities. It's not the case now, but that doesn't mean you should stop paying attention to the list. In fact, its makeup should be monitored closely in coming weeks. If the market uptrend stays on course, alternate entry points could be seen in names holding gains after recent breakouts. If the market weakens from here, the list will reveal stocks showing resilience — good watch-list candidates for down the line.It's not easy finding buying opportunities if you've got money to put to work. The market landscape is filled with extended stocks and base breakouts remain few and far between. The problem with buying base breakouts now, infrequent as they are, is that there's always the risk you're buying a laggard breakout that could end up rolling over in no time.Spirit Airlines (SAVE) is one of the exceptions. Despite a volatile day of price action on Oct. 30, the discount airline continues to hold up well after a recent base breakout. The stock gapped up out of a cup-with-handle base on Oct. 11.Other IBD 50 names still in buying range include TripAdvisor (TRIP). The online travel firm recently cleared a 79.99 entry. As of Friday's close, it was 4% above the buy point. TripAdvisor recently reported a 2% decline in quarterly earning per share, but did report its fourth straight quarter of 20%-plus year-over-year sales growth.Meanwhile, Stratasys (SSYS) extended gains for the fourth straight session Friday. It's now 4% above a buy point of 113.04, but it's a low-volume breakout so far from a late-stage base. Stratasys, a maker of three-dimensional prototyping systems, reports earnings on Thursday. Michael Kors (KORS), MercadoLibre (MELI) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) all report on Tuesday.

Stocks pared their losses to end little changed and near multi-year highs Monday.
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq finished flat while the Dow Jones industrial average ended down 0.1%. Volume was lower across the board, according to preliminary figures.
Even though the stock market today rebounded from early losses, Novo Nordisk (NVO) didn't fare so well.

The Danish drugmaker gapped down and plunged 14% in huge turnover after the FDA requested additional cardiovascular information regarding a trial of Tresiba, Novo's long-acting insulin drug. Novo Nordisk said in a statement on its website Sunday that it likely won't be able to furnish the additional data this year.
The stock had broken out of a cup-with-handle base at 164.01 on Jan. 2, but has given back almost all of its 19% gain.
Gun maker Sturm Ruger (RGR) sank 3% in volume that was modestly above normal. It had been down as much as 7% intraday, sinking below its 53.22 buy point in a cup-with-handle base before recovering.
On the upside, Ruckus Wireless (RKUS), which went public in November, climbed 3% in strong volume to a new high, building on Friday's 17% jump.
The company is expected to report that profit soared 683% in 2012 to 47 cents a share.

Stocks continued to hold near their sessions lows late Thursday. Mixed economic data and continued worries over the Fed taking away the punchbowl put equities on defense for a second straight session.

The Nasdaq slumped 1.2% and neared its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 fell 0.8% and was hovering near the psychological 1500 level. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell a milder 0.5%, thanks to a jump in Wal-Mart (WMT). Volume was tracking sharply higher in the stock market today.
A number of leaders suffered heavy losses.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) gapped below its 50-day line and dumped 6% to a two-month low. The generator maker priced a secondary offering of 10 million shares at 35 or a nearly 3% discount to Wednesday's close. The shares are being sold by affiliates of CCMP Capital and not the company. Intraday, the stock fell almost 11% below a 37.22 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) was off its session low, but still down 8% in huge turnover. The flooring retailer has slumped to its 10-week moving average and erased essentially all of its gains from a breakout past a 58.90 buy point in late January.

Alkermes (ALKS) staged a big downside reversal, shed 4% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The stock also wiped out gains from its Jan. 7 breakout past a 20.79 early buy point in a flat base. Shares rose as much as 12% past that buy point.

Give us your poor, your tired, your huddled masses, yearning to develop the hottest fashions or the sleekest new microprocessor.Young companies often have innovative products and nimble management, which can fuel some major stock runs. Today's Screen Of The Day looks at Young Guns — a collection of stocks that went public in the last 15 years, with excellent fundamentals and IBD Composite Ratings.This batch also has some notable foreign-born stocks that are burning up U.S. markets, including the fashion house giant Michael Kors (KORS) and chip giant ARM Holdings (ARMH).But first up among the imports is SodaStream International (SODA), the Israeli company that makes a kitchen countertop appliance to make sodas and other carbonated beverages at home. The company, with a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99, made a splash during Sunday's Super Bowl with a commercial touting the wasted plastic soda bottles that its system could replace.SodaStream shares had a strong run from mid-November to late January. But since then the stock has fallen 10.5%, suffering several high-volume selling days. Shares were up fractionally Tuesday to 48.34.Kors, which reports its fiscal Q2 on Feb. 12, has a 98 Composite Rating.The Hong Kong-based fashion house hit a new high on Jan. 28, but reversed, beginning a six-session string of losses. The stock tested its 50-day line on Tuesday, but rebounded to close up almost 1% at 55.38.ARM, with a 97 Composite Rating, designs high-performance, low-power chips used in Apple's (AAPL) iPad and iPhones — but in most other advanced mobile devices, too. And it's moving into PC and server fields, taking on long-dominant Intel (INTC).So even though Apple shares have plunged over the last several months, ARM has muscled higher.The U.K.-based stock rose 4% Tuesday to its best level since March 2000 after the company reported better-than-expected Q4 earnings and sales and offered strong guidance for the current quarter.New Jersey, where Cognizant Technologies Solutions (CTSH) calls home, isn't foreign land. But the IT outsourcing firm does much of its work in India — where skilled software developers and engineers can do coding and testing for U.S. customers at about half the cost of America-based teams.Cognizant jumped 5% on Jan. 11 to a 52-week high after rival outsourcer Infosys (INFY) posted better-than-expected earnings and offered an upbeat sales forecast. Cognizant shares have mostly moved sideways since.Cognizant shares climbed 0.7% Tuesday to 78.34. It reports Q4 results on Thursday.Related:Netflix Leads Top 5 Techs Smashing Profit ForecastsIBD 50: Michael Kors, ARM Lead Top 5 Big-Cap StocksOracle Leads 4 Top Tech Stocks With Bolting RS Lines

Ralph Lauren (RL) announced second-quarter earnings and sales above analyst expectations Friday. But the apparel maker lowered its full year sales outlook on weak demand.

The fashion house known for its preppy styles said second-quarter earnings were nearly flat at $2.45 per share, topping analyst expectations of $2.15. Sales fell 2% to $1.86 billion, as Ralph Lauren has closed partner owned stores and boutiques in China. Sales nevertheless beat views of $1.84 billion. Ralph Lauren will replace the shuttered stores with company-run shopping in better locations.
Shares rose 2.7% to 163.34.
Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 5%. Same-stores sales are an important figure because they don't include stores that opened or closed during the year.

Retail sales jumped 5% to $901 million. Wholesale sales dipped 8% to $915 million as the company shipped fewer goods to European stores. Gross profit margin widened 220 basis points to 58.8% on lower input costs.
Ralph Lauren's chief financial officer said 12 stores were still closed due to Hurricane Sandy, yet expects the storm to have only a "modest" impact on third-quarter results.
The company does expect uncertainty in the market to affect sales and lowered its sales outlook for the rest of the year.

"While we expect continued margin improvement in the back half of the year, macroeconomic conditions lead us to be incrementally more cautious on near-term customer demand trends worldwide," said COO Roger Farah. "Notwithstanding these macroeconomic challenges, the desirability of the Ralph Lauren brand is undeniable and we are well positioned for the upcoming holiday season."
The company sees a 2%-3% sales gain for the year vs. an earlier estimate for midsingle-digit percentage growth.

High-end retailers like Ralph Lauren have done well during the economic downturn as wealthy customers never had to curb spending. Brands like Michael Kors (KORS), Coach (COH) and Ralph Lauren entice customers by offering high-quality products and services.
Kors is ranked No. 2 on the IBD 50 list, which ranks companies based on superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.

Stocks shifted lower near Wednesday's midpoint, with about eight in 10 IBD industry groups losing ground through morning trade. The Nasdaq dug in 0.7%. The S&P 500 dropped 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average held to a 0.3% decline. Turnover remained down from Tuesday's levels and largely quiet across both the Nasdaq and the NYSE in the stock market…
The IBD 50 lists top-rated stocks and is a good place to search for watch-list candidates.
It's earnings season and companies are showing their true colors in quarterly reports. Here are the top 5 companies in the elite IBD 50 on tap to report earnings the coming week.
Fashion house and retailer Michael Kors (KORS) is No. 8 on the IBD 50, and will announce fiscal third quarter earnings Tuesday before the market opens.
Analysts expect Kors to report an 86% surge in earnings per share, to 41 cents. Revenue is forecast to climb 45% to $540.3 million.
Shares of premium lifestyle apparel, accessories and fragrance maker Ralph Lauren (RL), which is not an IBD 50 stock, jumped 5.9% Wednesday after it solidly beat targets on strong holiday sales.
Kors went public in December 2011 at 20 and grew rapidly. Shares are trading above 50-day and 200-day averages, about 4% off the 52-week high.

It hit an all-time high of 60 on Jan. 28, but closed down that day and slid for several sessions before finding support at its 50-day line last week and rebounding. Shares rose 0.8% in Friday's stock market.
Kors sells watches made by Fossil (FOSL), which is not on the latest IBD 50. But Fossil reports earnings Tuesday as well.

Generator maker Generac (GNRC) is No. 17 on the IBD 50. Its products were in hot demand last week amid preparations for a major storm along the Eastern seaboard, dubbed Nemo. Generac gapped up 20% on Oct. 31 during Superstorm Sandy, then consolidated until it got another boost from Nemo.
When Generac reports Q4 results early Thursday, consensus is for EPS to fall 9% to 69 cents, and for sales to grow 16% to $309.4 million. Its stock ended the week at an all-time high 40.54.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) is No. 31 on the list. It's a spin-off from online travel company Expedia.com (EXPE). The stock fell 2% Wednesday after reporting earnings that badly missed estimates despite Expedia's record hotel bookings.
TripAdvisor lets travelers share trip reviews. like Kors, it's a December 2011 IPO that's done well since.

Shares turned up on Nov. 2 after its Q3 earnings report and have climbed 64%, to a 47.02 close Friday. The stock spiked Wednesday early on Expedia's results, but closed little changed that day. Wall Street is looking for Q4 EPS of 26 cents, up 3 cents from last year. Sales are forecast to rise 21% to $167.1 million.

Discovery (DISCA) is No. 36 on the IBD 50 and the world's No. 1 nonfiction media company with networks such as Discovery Channel, TLC and Animal Planet. It announces Q4 results early Thursday. Also reporting Feb. 14: CBS (CBS), which is trading at a 52-week high, and DirecTV (DTV), just 3% off its high.

Analysts expect DirecTV to report an 11% earnings per share decline to 76 cents, and for revenue to grow a modest 7% to $1.2 billion. From its October 2008 bottom in the Great Recession, shares have shot up 613%, closing at 71.47 Friday.

Jarden (JAH) is a diversified manufacturer that makes Sunbeam kitchen mixers, Coleman camping tents, First Alert smoke detectors, Bicycle playing cards and and many other well-known consumer and outdoor products.

The No. 36 company on the list is forecast to report a 31% gain in EPS to $1.26, and a 4% advance in revenue to $1.81 billion. Since Dec. 31, Jarden's stock has risen in all but five days. Friday it closed at a fresh all-time high of 60.82.
Bonus: IPG Photonics (IPGP) reports on Friday. The maker of optical fiber-based lasers for materials processing and other applications is No. 50 on the IBD 50.

Michael Kors (KORS) wowed Wall Street Tuesday with blowout earnings on huge holiday sales, sending the fashion house's stock to a new high.

The luxury lifestyle brand said earnings for the fiscal third quarter ended in December surged 129% to 64 cents a share, sailing past views for 41 cents a share. Revenue leapt 70% to $636.8 million, well above the Street's forecast for $540.3 million.
Michael Kors, a longtime member of the IBD 50 list of top stocks, has consistently topped sales and earnings forecasts since its December 2011 IPO.
Holiday Sales Boom

Same-store sales for stores in North America shot up 41% vs. a year earlier amid strong demand over the holiday season. Despite Europe's weak economy, comps in that region surged 58%, reflecting growing acceptance of the brand and continued expansion at retail and wholesale.

"Overall, the report was fantastic," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy. "The beat in terms of the bottom line was driven by very solid top-line growth as it continued to see strong wholesale gains and very strong retail comp growth. It speaks to the aspirational nature of this growing global lifestyle brand."
Kors retail sales surged 67% to $332.6 million. Wholesale sales popped 77.4% to $274.3 million.

"It saw tremendous acceleration in the third quarter in its wholesale business, including watches, giftable items and accessories in addition to handbags," said Citi Research analyst Oliver Chen. "That's a good sign because the momentum is likely to continue in the new year."
Shares rose nearly 9% to 62.01 in the stock market Tuesday, but closed in the lower half of its trading range after reaching a record 64.80 intraday.
Another hot accessories brand, Fossil (FOSL), also delivered a solid report for its holiday fourth quarter Tuesday. The IBD 50 stock rose 3% to 110.65. It hit a nine-month peak of 115.19 intraday.

The watch and accessory designer and retailer saw earnings rise 21% to $2.27 a share, 1 cent ahead of views and the third straight quarter of accelerating growth. Sales rose 14% to $947.7 million, which topped forecasts for $930.43 million.
Michael Kors stores sell Fossil watches.
"It was a very good beat on revenue because this is a growth story," said Chen.
He said expectations for Fossil were "cautious" coming into the quarter because the company had a "volatile" 2012.
The profit growth it did achieve was very impressive, he adds. Chen says Fossil is one of his top stock picks for 2013.
Fossil, he says, benefits from a leading market share in $200 to $300 watches.

The company enjoyed growing demand for its watches across the globe in Q4. Proprietary watch brands include Fossil, Relic and MW Michele. It also has licensing pacts with many premium brands, including Michael Kors.
It got a nice lift from last year's acquisition of Skagen Designs, a maker of contemporary Danish-design watches and other accessories.

Separately Tuesday, Fossil said it signed a licensing pact with designer Tory Burch. The companies will design Tory Burch watches. The Tory Burch timepiece collection's global launch is scheduled for late 2014.

"I'm pretty excited they're adding Tory Burch to their licensed watch portfolio," said Chen. "It's an outstanding license and a great brand."Michael Kors (KORS) wowed Wall Street Tuesday with blowout earnings on huge holiday sales, sending the fashion house's stock to a new high.The luxury lifestyle brand said earnings for the fiscal third quarter ended in December surged 129% to 64 cents a share, sailing past views for 41 cents a share. Sellers came into the market Friday. The silver lining was that volume fell from Thursday's level and most Sector Leaders held up well. Six names in the screen bucked the trend, rising 1% or more. LinkedIn (LNKD) jumped 6.22, or nearly 4%, to 178.24 in above-average turnover after ITG Research raised its second-quarter revenue estimate, citing increased pricing and other…

Most Spotlight stocks are holding up well despite the overall market's correction, though one — Michael Kors (KORS) — has slipped below its buy point.A correction is a time for investors to be especially vigilant in order to protect gains and avoid big losses. Watch lists of promising stocks should also be updated. New buys should be kept to a minimum and restricted to only the highest-rated stocks breaking out of sound bases in strong volume.Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) has bucked the market's downdraft, rising to a new high Thursday. The Mexican and Tex-Mex-style restaurant chain recently cleared a 35.08 buy point in a seven-week consolidation, but volume was weak and hasn't picked up. It's 8% past the buy point, putting it beyond the 5% limit that defines a buy area.Chuy's has posted strong sales and profit growth over the past four quarters. Profit for the June-ended quarter is expected to jump 91%.Meanwhile, Cabela's (CAB) has pulled back since hitting a record high of 72.54 on May 17. But volume has been weak and the stock is still extended from a 62.32 buy point from a third-stage flat base. Later-stage bases tend to hold higher risk, so shareholders should keep a close eye on the stock as it approaches its 10-week line.Soufun Holdings (SFUN), a Chinese provider of online real estate listings, has climbed back above its 10-week line as it works on a new base. Trading has tightened up somewhat in recent weeks, but the overall pattern shows wide swings and accumulation is lacking. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is D-, below the neutral C and an indication that institutional investors are net sellers of the shares.Michael Kors has fallen below its 62.35 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Yet so far, the fashion designer's decline has been fairly modest, coming in weak volume. The stock is also getting support at its 10-week line and hasn't yet triggered IBD's 8% sell rule, which would kick in at 57.36.

A number of Sector Leaders cleared buy points Friday, but also showed questionable action. Actavis (ACT) rallied 3.86, or 3%, to 132.71. The stock hit a new high and cleared a 133.10 buy point from a flat base. Volume surged more than 100% above average. But the stock closed below the 133.10 trigger, which can in some cases be an…

Foreign stocks are moving fast, with lots of quality names breaking out and running up.Chinese online-gaming issue NetEase (NTES) on Thursday pared what was a 3% gain to just 19 cents. At its intraday high, NetEase had poked beyond the 5% reach from its 65.18 cup-with-handle buy point.That long base held some serious flaws, including some weeks of sloppy action, a handle drooping as much as 16% and a correction that runs 44% deep.Grifols (GRFS), a Spanish maker of plasma derivatives and diagnostics systems, shows a much more attractive cup-with-handle base. The cup corrected just 21%, the handle a scant 4%.Volume dried up as the stock built its right side. A little more action during this period would have made for a nicer picture. Watch for volume to surge as the stock triggers its 31.21 buy point, which sits just 20 cents above Thursday's close.Most interestingly, this cup undercut the previous flat base, resetting the base count.Michael Kors (KORS) also shows a remarkably shallow cup with handle, running just 15% deep. This buy point appears at 65.21. The structure is the latest in a base-on-base series.We'd note that the fashion house's prior breakouts didn't go very far, which is how it made a base on base on base on base.Most troubling, the company has issued three secondary stock offerings in the past 16 months. Nothing chills a rally like a wave of new supply.Perion Networks (PERI), the Israeli company that offers customized email apps for the mobile and home user, shows a 10-week consolidation running 28% deep.Perion's earnings and sales growth are stellar, but the stock is cheap and trades a low $4.8 million on average per day.On the downside, South Korean chipmaker MagnaChip Semiconductor (MX) gapped lower Thursday and dived 7% in heavy volume. The stock sliced through its 10-week line and ended 5% below its 18.35 buy point from its most recent base, a second-stage consolidation.Citibank cut its rating on MagnaChip to neutral from buy.The downgrade overshadowed the announcements of two new MagnaChip chips.The MXG1300 is an e-Compass sensor product for smartphones and tablets.Then there's a sensor product line designed for consumer, industrial and medical markets.
Qihoo 360 Technology, Baidu, Las Vegas Sands and Michael Kors are among the leading China-focused stocks with top fundamentals that point to significant potential upsides.

Past big market winners showed robust earnings and sales increases before big price moves, and Baidu's (BIDU) Q2 results Wednesday showed China's search leader is thriving even amid competition from Qihoo (QIHU) and Sohu (SOHU).
Las Vegas Sands (LVS) results were less encouraging overall but still showed its Macau operations are on a hot streak.
The IBD Screen Of The Day is Top Fundamentals, highly rated stocks with three-year earnings per share and sales growth rates above 25%.
Today's screen features a group of companies based or focused in China that are benefiting as the world's largest consumer market transitions to even more consumption-led growth.

Qihoo is a leader in the hot online software distribution market, which quickly loads software via the Internet onto companies' systems. Its EPS grew at a 302% annual rate the last three years. Sales growth ranged from 79% to 191%.

Shares climbed 2.6% in Thursday afternoon trading to a new all-time high on the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/, partly in sync with Baidu, which soared on strong Q2 results.

Las Vegas Sands, parent of Sands China Ltd., gets most of its growth from its casinos in Macau, the former Portuguese colony on China's southern coast and the globe's largest and fastest-growing casino gaming region.
Sands EPS has grown at a 116% annual rate for three years, and revenue growth ranged from 18% to 50%. Shares fell 1%.

Luxury apparel and accessories maker Michael Kors (KORS) is based in Hong Kong but sells about 90% in North America. Its three-year EPS growth rate is 111%, and over the last three years, sales grew at a 58%-68% rate. Kors was up about 1%.

In the last three years, Baidu's EPS has grown 88% annually. Sales growth ranged from 57% to 92%. Baidu late Wednesday said Q2 EPS fell 2 cents to $1.22, beating estimates by a penny. But sales jumped 44% to $1.23 billion, also topping views, and it gave upbeat Q3 revenue guidance. Baidu gapped up 11% to 125.49 Thursday.
While 3D Systems (DDD) isn't based in China, it is on the Top Fundamentals screen and generates 16% of its revenue from the Asia-Pacific region.

As China moves into more value-added manufacturing, 3D Systems could see increased demand from the world's No. 2 economy. The three-year EPS growth rate is 109%, and sales growth ranged from 160% to 354%.
