The right mix of accessories and international sales growth helped Steven Madden (SHOO) step over foul weather and budget-conscious consumers. The footwear designer and seller said first-quarter earnings per share climbed 4% to 52 cents, in line with forecasts of analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Net sales climbed 4.9% to $278.9 million, just shy of forecasts for $280.9 million. Accessories…
Stocks rebounded Tuesday, taking back a small portion of the past week's punishing slide, but volume was lower.

Worries about the Federal Reserve's tapering of its monthly bond buys and a credit crunch in China faded, at least for a day. Positive sentiment was helped by comments from two Fed officials Monday that downplayed the impact of scaling back the Fed's monthly bond-buying program.
Positive news on durable goods orders, the housing market and consumer confidence also encouraged the bulls.

The S&P 500 rose 0.9% and finished near its session high. The Nasdaq ended a four-session losing streak, up 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.7%. Top-performing industry groups included solar, cement, rail transport, super regional banks and oil refining.
There wasn't much conviction behind the buying Tuesday as preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in much lower than Monday.

In the stock market today, homebuilders outperformed early, but reversed early gains. Home prices rose 2.5% in April, more than double expectations, according to the S&P/Case Shiller composite index of 20 cities. Meanwhile, May new-home sales rose 2.1% to 476,000 units, the highest level since mid-2008 and slightly above the consensus estimate of 460,000.
Lennar (LEN) squandered most of a solid gain after it reported another quarter of strong top- and bottom-line growth. The stock, up as much as 5%, finished the day ahead only 0.7%.
Since hitting a high of 44.40 on May 20, Lennar has lost 23%. It's trading below its 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Big Cap 20 component Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) kept pace with the market, rising 1%. It's still stuck underneath its 10-week moving average as it consolidates recent gains. The drugmaker cleared a late-stage base in April. If market conditions continue to improve, it's best to focus on early-stage bases rather than late-stage ones.
The Big Cap 20 is published every Tuesday.

Elsewhere, HomeAway (AWAY) soared 6%. The stock is back above its 10-week moving average after spending a lengthy amount of time below the line. On a daily chart, the stock cleared a descending trend line today, found by connecting the recent highs of the stock. The company operates an online marketplace for vacation rentals. Recent earnings and sales growth has been solid, and growth prospects look good, with full-year profit expected to rise 27% this year and 26% in 2014.

Michael Kors (KORS) recovered a bit, but still closed below its 50-day moving average. Shares rose 3%. The stock's recent breakout over 62.35 looked good for a while, but eventually succumbed to selling pressure. It's still 5% below the buy point.
Here's a look at some upcoming earnings reports for the rest of the week:
Wednesday: Monsanto (MON), Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY).

Stocks set sail with mild gains in massive trade early Friday as the market tried to gather its wits after Thursday's sell-off.
The S&P 500 bobbed 0.5% higher. The Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 0.3% while the Nasdaq inched up a fraction.
Quadruple witching options expirations amplified volume in the stock market today, with trade soaring 470% on the NYSE and up more than 300% on the Nasdaq compared with Thursday morning's activity.

In stocks, auto dealership chain CarMax (KMX) popped 5% at the open after reporting stronger-than-expected first-quarter results. Earnings and revenue topped analyst expectations, and the company repurchased 2.9 million shares during the quarter. The stock pulled back from a May 16 high for a quiet test of the 50-day moving average, then fell through that line in heavy trade Thursday. Friday's move lifted shares back above the 50-day moving average, at least temporarily as the stock gave back some ground.

Oracle (ORCL) swooned 9% at the open, diving through its 200-day moving average in heavy trade. The enterprise software maker reported late Thursday its fiscal Q4 earnings met views, but revenue stopped short of analysts' forecasts. It was the second straight quarterly sales miss.

The stock had crept higher after selling off on its Q3 sales and earnings miss. It fell through the 50-day average in heavy trade Thursday. Friday's slip drove shares to their lowest mark since November.
Among leaders, drugmakers led a mild rebound among IBD 50 stocks. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) gained 2%.
Both Michael Kors (KORS) and Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) gave up pre-market gains of more than 4% and posted fractional losses in opening trade.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) dropped 2% in a second day of heavy trade. There is usually a trade-off between speed and size. Large companies with institutional ownership offer stability and investors are unlikely to see a catastrophic loss. But they often suffer from sluggish earnings — and stock growth.
But some big-cap stocks also boast impressive profit and sales gains.
IBD's daily screen is Big Cap Leaders, focusing on large capitalization stocks with superior fundamentals and other factors.
Here are the top five stocks from the Screen Of The Day:

Michael Kors (KORS) is one of the most successful recent IPOs. The maker of affordable high-end handbags, accessories and apparel reported a 96% jump in last quarter's EPS as issues in Europe failed to slow the fashion house's well-planned expansion plans in the region. Sales last quarter climbed 74%. Kors did offer some caution on the current, holiday quarter.
Kors shares hit an intraday high on Nov. 2, then sold off before finding support above the 200-day moving average. The stock remains below the 50-day line.
During Q3 Comcast (CMCSA) reported a 39% rise in EPS. The cable television and Internet provider said company revenue rose 15%, boosted by the London Olympic coverage.

Analysts at UBS and Oppenheimer expect Comcast (CMCSK) to add net video customers in Q4, for the first time since 2007. Users have been canceling their television subscriptions in favor of streaming shows on the Internet. But live TV and sporting events lured back viewers. Time Warner Cable (TWC) also makes the Big Cap Leaders list.
Comcast shares have risen the past three sessions, moving back off their 50-day moving average.

Deere & Co. (DE), the maker of farm equipment, reported a 17% rise in last quarter's EPS and a 15% rise in sales. Deere reports Q4 earnings Wednesday. Analysts expect the maker of tractors, combines and large commercial mowers to report a 16% rise in EPS to $1.88 and revenue is seen climbing 12% to $8.82 billion.
The company faced issues with sluggishness in China, India and Europe, as well as manufacturing problems that delayed domestic shipments during Q3. They were expected to resolve in the just-ended Q4.
Deere shares have been moving sideways for several weeks, near the top of a consolidation that goes back to mid-February.
Novo Nordisk (NVO) is a Danish drugmaker that makes insulin and other diabetes treatments. The company reported a 34% rise in EPS last quarter and a 15% rise in revenue.
Novo shares found support around the 200-day line earlier this month, but like Kors is still below the 50-day benchmark.
ARM Holdings (ARMH) designs chips for smartphones and other mobile devices. It reported a 29% jump in earnings last quarter. Revenue rose 24%.

Apple (AAPL) uses ARM technology to design its own chips for the iPhone and iPad. Rumors circulated earlier this month that the tech giant might switch from Intel (INTC) chips to its own chips for future Mac computers.

ARM shares fell nearly 4% on Tuesday after spiking to a 12-year high Monday. That's a lot better than Intel, which sank 4% to a 14-month low, a day after CEO Paul Otellini's surprise announcement that he will step down soon.

Many great stocks represent companies that spend heavily on research and development.
A company with a consistent commitment to R&D will often outperform rivals that lack commitment — especially over the long haul.
The right innovation can lead to market domination and creative destruction of rivals in the stock market today.

Yet before we go further, let's recognize the exceptions. R&D isn't critical for every great stock. For some industry groups, R&D is not a factor at all. A screen of IBD's 197 industry groups found that 40% of the groups involve companies that spend either nothing or less than 1% of sales on R&D.
For example, restaurants and apparel retailers don't face the same pressures to reinvent themselves that technology companies do.
Restaurants and retailers do have to keep up with changes in style and taste, but they don't need a small army of techies with high IQs to stay ahead of the curve.

And if you've seen how techies dress and what they eat, then you know their advice on taste and fashion trends wouldn't put companies such as Michael Kors (KORS), Urban Outfitters (URBN) or even upscale restaurateur Ruth's Hospitality Group (RUTH) ahead of the curve.
The R&D types, however, are indispensable to semiconductor designers, biomedical companies, software, aerospace and other high-tech companies.
R&D is all about the new factor. It gives a company a chance to invent new products and improve established products.
Even some of the blue chips in the Dow Jones industrial average continue to spend aggressively on research and development.
Six of the 30 stocks in the Dow had R&D budgets in 2012 that involved spending a double-digit percentage of sales.
Intel (INTC) spent 19% of sales on research and development; Merck (MRK) 17.3%; Microsoft (MSFT) and Pfizer (PFE), 13.3% each; Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), 13.1%; and Cisco Systems (CSCO) 11.9%.
Here are some interesting facts. So far this year, Microsoft stock is up 31%; Cisco, 22%; Intel and Johnson & Johnson, 19% each; Merck, 15%; and Pfizer, 13%.

The Dow is up 14% this year, and part of that is because of the above stocks. With the exception of Pfizer, the Dow's top spenders in R&D are outperforming the Dow. Granted, that's thin evidence for a grand conclusion. However, if any established company is going to break out of a rut, innovation is the surest path.

IBD ran a screen for stocks trading above $15 a share, a Composite Rating of 90 or better, and R&D spending in 2012 of at least 20% of sales. Relative strength is a good thing to consider in any market.The RS line shows how a stock is doing vs. the S&P 500. A rising line means a stock is either gaining more or losing less than the index.One group showing strength is apparel manufacturers. Six stocks in the Apparel-Clothing Manufacturers group have Composite Ratings of 93 or better.RS lines are at or near 52-week highs for five of the six stocks. Two appeared in Thursday's Stock Spotlight screen — Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and G-III Apparel (GIII).Why should apparel stocks be doing well in this sluggish economy? Last year, U.S. apparel consumption by volume fell 5.3%, according to the American Apparel & Footwear Association.Despite the drop in volume, value of sales grew 4.9% at the retail level. Part of that was because of price increases. However, the ApparelStats 2012 report also pointed out that consumers are "returning to purchases of apparel at higher price-points."That's good news for Michael Kors, a luxury play with the highest pretax margin (21%) among the top-rated apparel stocks. The others have margins that range from 6% to 13%.A December IPO, Michael Kors also has the best return on equity. ROE is 56%, despite a debt-to-equity ratio of 0%. (Debt can inflate the ROE number.)The stock is working on a flat base with a 57.45 buy point.G-III Apparel has brands that include Levi's, Guess and Kenneth Cole. The stock recently bounced off its 50-day moving average, but earnings have been erratic.In August, the company bought Vilebrequin, a maker of luxury swimwear and resort wear with 185 retail stores. This represents a change for G-III, which has outlet stores but has not previously operated a luxury, full-price retail chain.
Fashion retailer Michael Kors (KORS) has pulled back after rising as much as 16% above its buy point from a cup-without-handle base.
The stock is still 6% above the 49.60 entry, so it's a bit extended. Buying now could leave investors vulnerable to a routine pullback.

Volume on the downside has been heavy, and Kors' Relative Strength line has come off its highs. However, the stock has shown signs of getting support in the past few sessions. The stock remains above its 10-week line and is getting support around the 51 price level.
A big chunk of the stock's losses came on Tuesday, when it sank 4% in huge trade after the company priced a secondary offering of 23 million shares at 53, a 3% discount to Monday's closing price.

Hong Kong-based Michael Kors sells luxury clothing, footwear and accessories at prices within reach of many. The company, founded by the "Project Runway" judge of the same name, competes against Coach (COH) and earns most of its revenue in the U.S. and Canada.

Kors' fundamentals remain strong . The stock has best-possible 99 Composite and Relative Strength ratings, and its Earnings Per Share Rating is 98. That puts it at the top of the 32-member Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing industry group.
Also, the stock's Accumulation-Distribution Rating has remained relatively steady at B-, indicating modest demand for the shares.
Profit for Kors' fiscal second quarter that ends this month is seen rising 65% from a year ago, a solid gain that nevertheless would mark the slowest pace in six quarters.
Sales growth has also been strong, with gains of at least 50% in each of the past 10 quarters.

Hong Kong-based fashion retailer Michael Kors (KORS) hit a new high Wednesday, a day after it broke out of a base following a strong earnings report.The stock edged up 0.06 to 49.39 in heavy volume Wednesday, after giving up a larger gain. For the second straight day, it cleared a 49.60 buy point from a cup without handle, only to close below it.On Tuesday, Kors soared more than 16% in huge turnover on strong fiscal Q1 profit and sales.The buy range goes to 52.08, or 5% above the trigger.The base is Michael Kors' first since it went went public last December at 20 a share. In addition to the 49.60 buy point, the chart shows an alternate entry at 50.79.The pattern was 30% deep, which is within a normal range. Volume in the base was about even in terms of weeks of distribution and accumulation. The largest volume was the week of June 15, when the stock came off its low in the base after another strong quarterly report.Some weeks of tight price closes also were positive for the base.The stock's Accumulation-Distribution Rating has risen to B from D+ in the past few weeks, indicating growing demand for the shares.Michael Kors sells luxury handbags, shoes and other accessories at prices within reach for many.Though based in Hong Kong, more than 90% of the company's revenue comes from the U.S. and Canada, whose economies continue to chug along at a slow but steady pace.Michael Kors reported Tuesday that profit for the June-ended quarter jumped 162% from a year ago to 34 cents a share. Revenue rose 71% to $414.9 million, the biggest increase in at least four years.Sales at stores open at least a year soared 38.4% in North America and 24.2% in Europe despite the eurozone's recession.Michael Kors "has the best momentum in retail," according to a report Wednesday by Nomura Equity Research. "As they build their share in the U.S., they are planting the seeds for international growth, which sets them up to become one of the next great global brands."Nomura added that Kors is taking market share from main rival Coach (COH) as the global market for luxury handbags and other high-end goods continues to grow despite economic turmoil. Coach shares are trading about 30% below their March peak.
Shares of fashion and accessories brand Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) moved higher on the stock market today after Morgan Stanley maintained its rating and target price on the stock.
Michael Kors' stock price rose more than 1% to 61.26 in early trading Monday after Morgan Stanley added the stock to its "Best Ideas" list and maintained an "overweight" rating and 71 price target.
Shares of the designer of luxury apparel, footwear and accessories are up 17% since April 22.
Michael Kors operates through a multi-channel distribution model that includes its own chain of retail stores as well as wholesale and licensing segments.
The success of these channels have helped the company grow from roughly $500 million in annual revenue in fiscal year 2010 to more than $2 billion in fiscal 2013, which ended in March.
Michael Kors now has its sights set on $4 billion in annual sales over the next few years, which means it would have to roughly double its current business.
The company is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 earnings May 29. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 39 cents, up from 22 cents the prior year.
Meanwhile, apparel stocks as a whole continue to move higher. IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group, which set a record high on Friday, is up 18% since the beginning of the year.

Stocks that have hit new highs in recent weeks include the two biggest companies by market cap: VF Corp. The more characteristics of high quality a stock has, the better its chance of being a market winner.Of course, the more you demand from a stock, the fewer that may be suitable for purchase.We recently ran a screen of stocks that match IBD's 20 Rules For Your Investment Success. The results were more than limited: Not one stock met the grade.That doesn't mean you should forget about stock investing and seek returns elsewhere.The truth is, stocks can fall short in one or two areas but still become successful investments. They must be purchased and sold properly and when the market is strong.The key point: It's the degree of drawbacks that come up in a stock's analysis that has to be weighed. While there may be no such thing as a perfect stock, investors are always better off going with the stocks with the fewest blemishes.Suppose you scan through the IBD 50 for stock ideas. The first layer of the selection process might be those companies with the best profit and sales growth, leaving aside those with lesser numbers. The next layer could be the chart, focusing on those leaders forming smooth bases.As the research process goes deeper, more imperfections come up. Ultimately, an investor must decide which flaws are acceptable.Research into the company's markets and financial outlook can help make those final decisions. For example, a trend of single-digit sales gains could be normal for the company's industry. A slow economic recovery may be depressing sales growth.Don't expect a computer screen to make all those decisions for you. Critical thinking, knowledge and experience are key.Here are three case studies of successful stocks and their flaws:Stratasys (SSYS). An investor studying the stock in April 2012 would have noticed the company's annual return on equity was 13%, below the 17% minimum for winning stocks. It was thinly traded — just 201,000 shares a day on average.But Stratasys' sales, earnings and margins were superb. The stock broke out April 16 and soared 120% to its January peak of 92.30.Michael Kors (KORS). The luxury clothing and accessories house went public in December 2011 boasting excellent financials.A two-week correction was too short to be considered a proper base, even as an IPO base. But the light-volume decline marked reluctance by shareholders to sell. Kors crossed 27.68 and nearly doubled in a seven-week run.Lumber Liquidators (LL). In April 2012, the flooring products chain had some solid earnings gains but sales growth increased no more than 18% for several quarters. Return on equity and margins weren't so great, either.But the company was benefiting from the housing market's recovery. A breakout April 26 led to a 130% gain until an October top.

For many fashion brands, it's hard enough establishing success in one distribution channel, be it retail, wholesale or licensing.
Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) is out to prove it can find success in all three at the same time.

Michael Kors is a global accessories, footwear and apparel company. Most of its business, about 75%, comes from accessories such as handbags, small leather goods, eyewear, jewelry, watches and footwear.

At the close of its fiscal first quarter, which ended in June, the company operated 253 of its own retail stores and licensed another 68 stores to partners. It also operates wholesale and licensing segments.
All of these channels have produced robust growth in recent quarters, no mean feat, analysts say, considering the volatile nature of the fashion industry as well as the sluggish economy.

"Among a specialty retail landscape that is desperate for growth, Michael Kors represents a highly compelling longer-term footage growth story," JPMorgan analyst Brian Tunick said in a report earlier this month. "The company is in the enviable position of being able to drive growth across all of its distribution channels and geographic regions for the foreseeable future."
Kors operates in the luxury end of the fashion and retail sector, along with companies such as Coach (COH), Ralph Lauren (RL) and Donna Karan International.
Its founder, Michael Kors, has built a reputation for fashion-forward designs, though he's probably best known to most folks as a judge on the "Project Runway" television series.

The company's products feature "innovative designs, materials and craftsmanship with a jet-set aesthetic that aims to combine stylish elegance and a sporty attitude," said Citigroup analyst Oliver Chen.
Fashionistas aren't the only ones who've taken a liking to Michael Kors Holdings. It also has earned high marks from Wall Street.
Financially, Michael Kors has consistently topped analyst expectations since going public last December.
During its first three quarters as a publicly traded company, Michael Kors has grown earnings at least 87% and sales at least 58%.
Chen reckons Michael Kors can grow its annual sales in Europe to $550 million, up from $109 million in fiscal 2012. The company also targets bigger sales in Japan.
"Michael Kors has accelerating awareness in targeted international markets," Chen noted. "(The company) has a long growth runway given its low saturation."
He projects 25% annual growth in the number of Michael Kors stores over the next few years, with a potential for 600 stores.

Meanwhile, the company's long-term wholesale revenue growth should exceed 20% a year based on new or enlarged shop-in-shops in the U.S. and Europe. "Shop-in-shop" refers to areas within department stores that are devoted to Michael Kors products.
Business has been so brisk at Michael Kors that the company recently raised its guidance for its fiscal second quarter, which ended in September.

Management now expects earnings in the range of 38 cents to 40 cents a share vs. earlier guidance of 33 cents to 35 cents. It expects sales of $510 million to $520 million, up from previous guidance of $490 million to $500 million. The company raised its retail same-store sales growth to 45% vs. prior guidance for a 30% increase.
It is due to report Q2 earnings on Nov. 13.

"Following its updated outlook, Michael Kors has now posted 26 straight quarters of positive comps and 10 straight quarters of 35%-plus comps, some of the most robust and consistent comp gains in the space," Tunick noted.

The company logged fiscal first-quarter earnings of 34 cents a share, up from 13 cents the prior year and 14 cents above Wall Street views. Revenue gained 17% to $414.9 million, well above estimates for $368.3 million.
Retail sales during the quarter climbed 76% to $215 million. Same-store sales increased 37%.
Wholesale revenue rose 66% to $182.4 million. Licensing revenue gained 61% to $17.5 million, driven by strong demand for watches.
Kors' growth strategy includes targeting a younger, affluent demographic that is often overlooked by luxury brands.
JPMorgan's Tunick points out that the company's current target customer is 25 to 54 years old, with annual income above $50,000 a year.

"The growth going forward is targeting the more aspirational luxury customer," Tunick noted. "Brand awareness is trending younger; the 18- to 24-year-old demographic is now the highest awareness group. This positions them well for future growth."For many fashion brands, it's hard enough establishing success in one distribution channel, be it retail, wholesale or licensing.Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) is out to prove it can find success in all three at the same time.Michael Kors is a global accessories, footwear and apparel company. Most of its business, about 75%, comes from accessories such as handbags, small leather goods, eyewear, jewelry, watches and footwear.At the close of its fiscal first quarter, which ended in June, the company operated 253 of its own retail stores and licensed another 68 stores to partners. It also operates wholesale and licensing segments.All of these channels have produced robust growth in recent quarters, no mean feat, analysts say, considering the volatile nature of the fashion industry as well as the sluggish economy."Among a specialty retail landscape that is desperate for growth, Michael Kors represents a highly compelling longer-term footage growth story," JPMorgan analyst Brian Tunick said in a report earlier this month. For yet another week, the current stock market uptrend stayed intact and produced more bullish moves by highly rated stocks.A few IBD 50 names took it on the chin, however. It's important in IBD-style investing to watch for possible breakdowns among leading stocks, since that can serve as a caution flag. So far, though, struggles among the leaders haven't been that widespread.3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS) were among the week's big losers.3D Systems slumped to its 10-week moving average in big volume. It had dropped that key support level in the week ended Feb. 1, then tried to rally. Meanwhile, rival 3D printer maker Stratasys undercut its 10-week line.Generac Holdings (GNRC) also lost considerable ground, though it erased some losses after touching its 10-week line. The power generator maker reported Q4 results that crushed forecasts, but its outlook disappointed the market.Among the week's big winners, Michael Kors (KORS) made a gap-up move on its strong earnings report. The fashion house jumped back above its recent 58.72 buy point after running into resistance at that level in late January.Other IBD 50 stocks have continued to climb to fresh highs, becoming even more extended from their last buying ranges. ARM Holdings (ARMH), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Marathon Petroleum (MPC) and Waddell & Reed Financial (WDR) match this description.You also can still find some stocks that aren't that far extended from their recent buy zones. Ocwen Financial (OCN) cleared a 39.35 trigger from a cup-with-handle base a couple of weeks ago, but it's still not that far past that level.Note that the mortgage servicer's latest base was a third-stage pattern — riskier and not as fresh as a first- or second-stage structure.In addition, there are IBD 50 names that have offered secondary buying opportunities via 10-week rebounds.Consider fracking play U.S. Silica (SLCA) and South Korean chipmaker MagnaChip Semiconductor (MX). Keep in mind that MagnaChip's action also could be viewed as a base-building effort.For the week, the IBD 50 index fell 0.6%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq and NYSE composite both edged down less than 0.1% for the week. The Nasdaq bid farewell to a six-week winning streak.The S&P 500 edged up a little more than 0.1%, extending its winning streak to seven weeks.
Stocks edged higher in lower volume Monday as Wall Street readied for Twitter's IPO later in the week.

Earlier today, the online social network said it plans to raise $1.75 billion by offering 70 million shares at a price range of $23 to $25, up from a prior range of $17 to $20. The company will trade under the ticker TWTR.
At the close, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in lower than Friday's levels.

Major averages continue to trade tightly and hold near highs. Distribution days remain well-contained in the major averages. A small number of leaders look a bit worse for the wear, but many others are holding gains bullishly. The bottom line is that major averages and leading stocks aren't flashing meaningful sell signals yet.

IBD's Oil & Gas — U.S. Exploration & Production group was one of the day's top performers, rising about 3%. Leadership was widespread in the group. Continental Resources (CLR), EOG Resources (EOG) and Noble Energy (NBL), members of last week's IBD Big Cap 20 list of leading large-cap growth stocks, all outperformed Monday.

After the close, Houston-based oil and gas producer Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) earned 72 cents share, 2 cents above the consensus estimate. Sales were a tad light at just over $145 million, up 37% from a year ago. Shares fell 1% in early after-hours trading.
Group peer and market leader Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) was also scheduled to report but hadn't reported at publishing time.

In the stock market today, oil and gas producer Berry Petroleum (BRY) gapped out of a long consolidation. Shares jumped 6% in heavy volume after Linn Energy (LINE) raised its stock-for-stock offer for Berry by $600 million. The deal was first announced in February. Linn's revised offer now values the deal at $4.9 billion, including debt.
Elsewhere, China-based wealth manager Noah Holdings (NOAH) extended gains after recently finding support at its 50-day moving average. Shares rallied 6%. Earnings are due Nov. 18 after the close.

On the downside, BlackBerry (BBRY) slumped 16% after Fairfax Financial, the company's largest shareholder, walked away from a deal to buy the company. BlackBerry also said CEO Thorsten Heins is stepping down.
Tomorrow before the open, watch for earnings from AOL (AOL), Michael Kors (KORS) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN).

Things that look similar are often very different.

Take the luxury retailer Burberry. The British company's shares in London tumbled 20% on Tuesday's report of disappointing earnings on stalling sales. Shares of Michael Kors (KORS) and other luxury purveyors slumped slightly on the news.

But the upscale fashion house and retailer Kors in its last quarter said luxury demand globally is still growing. It beat views and raised guidance. It also tops the Screen Of The Day for Big Cap Leaders.
These large-cap leaders have the liquidity and top-tier fundamentals institutional investors want.

Also on the list is LinkedIn (LNKD). The professional networking site is similar to the social media giant Facebook (FB). But LinkedIn has soared, and is up 165% since its successful May 2011 initial public offering. By contrast, Facebook has tumbled 46% since its botched May 2012 offering.
It was rallying Wednesday after CEO Mark Zuckerberg's public statements about the promise it sees in monetizing its growing base of mobile users.
Three biotech firms round out the top five of the daily screen.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) has reported growing sales of its lone commercialized drug, Soliris, which treats rare blood disorders.

Generic-drug maker Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) has climbed on the announced acquisition of Swiss partner Actavis. The deal should form the third-largest generics company, with about $8 billion in combined 2012 revenue.

Amgen (AMGN), a maker of cancer and anemia treatments, has climbed steadily this year on strong quarterly earnings. But on Wednesday a Robert Baird analyst lowered his rating to neutral, from outperform. He also lowered his price target by 1 to 83, suggesting little near-term upside from its Wednesday afternoon price of 83.72.Things that look similar are often very different.Take the luxury retailer Burberry. Movado (MOV) shares jumped 10% to 37.41 Friday after Citi upgraded the stock while acknowleding the watchmaker's diversified business model.
Oliver Chen of Citi Investment Research raised Movado to buy from neutral. He upped the price target on the stock from 38 to 40.
Chen was impressed with Movado's wholesale line, which makes up 42% of its sales.
"Wholesale reduces Movado's exposure to volatile consumer spending habits and decreased margins from markdowns," he wrote in a client note.
Movado makes watches for high-end brands like Coach (COH), Juicy Couture, Tommy Hilfiger and Hugo Boss.

Luxury brands have done well in recent months as economic uncertainties didn't stop upper-class customer spending and middle-class customers splurging on high-end accessories like handbags and watches.
Michael Kors (KORS) designs women's clothing but has focused on high-margin accessories. A handbag can retail for more than $300, three times what it costs to make. Shares rose 2.9% to 54.60.
Fossil (FOSL) makes the watches for Kors and its shares have been lifted by Kors' high-flying success. Shares rose 2.9% to 54.61%. The Kors watches retail between $250 and $300

Michael Kors  (KORS) rode its deftly managed expansion in Europe to better-than-expected earnings and sales in its latest quarter, but cautious holiday guidance gave some investors pause Tuesday.
Kors shares fell 5% in premarket trading but rebounded to close up 0.9%.

The fashion house said earnings in its second quarter ended Sept. 29 vaulted 123% to 49 cents a share. Analysts expected 40 cents. Sales jumped 74% to $532.9 million, above forecasts for $519 million.
Sales growth was the best since Kors' Dec. 15 IPO. Kors has been a leader among apparel manufacturing stocks, a leading group.
Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 45%. North American same-store sales also climbed 45%. European sales surged 97% as Kors expanded its brand in the region.
'Excited' About Europe

"We are excited about what is happening in Europe. Our numbers are outstanding," CEO John Idol said in a conference call. "By this time next year, we anticipate to be the most accessible handbag luxury brand in Europe."

Europe's economic problems haven't affected Kors as much as some high-end retailers. Kors, which is based in Hong Kong but generates most of its sales in the U.S., only does 10% of its business in Europe. Its European sales also rely less on Asian tourist money than other brands like the U.K.'s Burberry. The flow of tourists from Asia has slowed as the Chinese and South Korean economies have cooled.
Kors' well-planned entry into Europe boosted sales.

"They understand the distribution model in Europe. They started as a wholesale brand and are now rounding out into retail," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy . "They also took a country-specific approach to expansion to address each country's unique distribution structure. This strategy has helped it develop into a pan-European brand."
Kors' "accessible luxury" price point helped it penetrate Europe and maintain strong U.S. sales.
Its handbags range from under $200 to $500 or more. Fossil (FOSL) has a licensing deal to make watches under the Kors brand name that can sell for over $200.
Kors aims to build its high-margin accessories business to bring in 85% of sales, vs. 79% now.
Ready For The Holidays
Murphy believes Kors is well-positioned to gain market share in the crucial holiday season.
Kors sees Q3 earnings of 37-39 cents a share, putting the midpoint below analyst expectations of 39 cents. It remains cautious on consumer sentiment after Hurricane Sandy.

"It's too early to tell about the hurricane affecting stores," Idol said. "New York City seems to be rebounding quickly, but our concerns are not just free-standing stores but department stores" in New Jersey and Long Island.

Saks (SKS), the upscale department store, did not fare as well as Kors in its latest quarter. It said Tuesday that third-quarter EPS rose 9% to 12 cents, in line with forecasts. But sales rose just 3% to $713 million, under forecasts of $726 million.
Saks sees flat same-store sales in the current quarter.

"As the overall macroeconomic environment remains very uncertain, we continue to approach the future cautiously," said CEO Stephen Sadove. "Sales trends have been soft for the first two weeks of November in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy."Michael Kors  (KORS) rode its deftly managed expansion in Europe to better-than-expected earnings and sales in its latest quarter, but cautious holiday guidance gave some investors pause Tuesday.Kors shares fell 5% in premarket trading but rebounded to close up 0.9%.The fashion house said earnings in its second quarter ended Sept. 29 vaulted 123% to 49 cents a share. Analysts expected 40 cents. Sales jumped 74% to $532.9 million, above forecasts for $519 million.Sales growth was the best since Kors' Dec. 15 IPO. Kors has been a leader among apparel manufacturing stocks, a leading group.Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 45%. North American same-store sales also climbed 45%. European sales surged 97% as Kors expanded its brand in the region.'Excited' About Europe"We are excited about what is happening in Europe. Our numbers are outstanding," CEO John Idol said in a conference call. "By this time next year, we anticipate to be the most accessible handbag luxury brand in Europe."Europe's economic problems haven't affected Kors as much as some high-end retailers. Kors, which is based in Hong Kong but generates most of its sales in the U.S., only does 10% of its business in Europe. Its European sales also rely less on Asian tourist money than other brands like the U.K.'s Burberry. The flow of tourists from Asia has slowed as the Chinese and South Korean economies have cooled.Kors' well-planned entry into Europe boosted sales."They understand the distribution model in Europe. They started as a wholesale brand and are now rounding out into retail," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy . "They also took a country-specific approach to expansion to address each country's unique distribution structure. This strategy has helped it develop into a pan-European brand."Kors' "accessible luxury" price point helped it penetrate Europe and maintain strong U.S. sales.Its handbags range from under $200 to $500 or more. Fossil (FOSL) has a licensing deal to make watches under the Kors brand name that can sell for over $200.Kors aims to build its high-margin accessories business to bring in 85% of sales, vs. 79% now.Ready For The HolidaysMurphy believes Kors is well-positioned to gain market share in the crucial holiday season.Kors sees Q3 earnings of 37-39 cents a share, putting the midpoint below analyst expectations of 39 cents. It remains cautious on consumer sentiment after Hurricane Sandy."It's too early to tell about the hurricane affecting stores," Idol said. "New York City seems to be rebounding quickly, but our concerns are not just free-standing stores but department stores" in New Jersey and Long Island.Saks (SKS), the upscale department store, did not fare as well as Kors in its latest quarter. "Sales trends have been soft for the first two weeks of November in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy."

Luxury brands have been falling and department stores have been warning, so all eyes will be on Michael Kors (KORS) when it reports second-quarter earnings on Tuesday.Analysts are expecting earnings of 40 cents per share and sales of $519.3 million in the company's first Q2 since going public last December. The company has reported double- or triple-digit EPS and earnings gains since its debut.Kors has been one of the biggest IPO successes of the past year. It went public for 20 per share but now is trading well above 50.The brand isn't new, though. Its lead designer and namesake, Michael Kors, has been in the fashion industry for years but is perhaps best known as a judge on the hit reality show "Project Runway."But luxury brands, which have done well during the economic downturn, have taken some hits the past month.Fossil (FOSL), who makes Kors licensed watches and jewelry, reported weak European sales last week.Ralph Lauren (RL), the fashion house known for its preppy styles, reported flat Q2 earnings on Nov. 2. Wholesale revenue dipped 8% as the company shipped fewer goods to European stores and the company lowered its outlook.Macy's (M) third-quarter earnings beat estimates last week, but the department store operator issued weak guidance for its important holiday season in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.Kohl's (KSS) also announced quarterly earnings that beat analyst estimates but said it expects holiday sales growth will miss Wall Street targets.Michael Kors shares broke below their 50-day moving average last week. Even so, it is No. 2 in the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. RELATED: IBD 50: 3D, Qihoo 360 Lead Top 5 Techs Not Crumbling
Stocks turned modestly lower near Thursday's halfway point as early comeback efforts faded. The action extended Wednesday's massive sell-off.
The Nasdaq dropped 0.5% to a fresh three-month low. The S&P 500 lost 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.3%. Turnover was tracking sharply lower across the board.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) dropped 4% as it further pulled back from recent stellar gains. The maker of backup generators bolted 21% last week as it stands to benefit from Superstorm Sandy. Generac is still 33% past a 26.95 three-weeks-tight buy point.

Michael Kors (KORS) lost 4% and sliced its 50-day moving average in fast trade. Intraday, it fell more than 9% below a 57.45 buy point in a flat base. On Tuesday, Michael Kors closed above its 50-day line after breaching it intraday. The high-end fashion apparel firm will report Q3 results Nov. 13. Analysts see profit rising 74% to 40 cents a share. Sales are slated to surge 70% to $519.31 million.

Whole Foods Market (WFMI) gapped down and slumped 4% in huge trade despite delivering fiscal Q4 results that met views late Wednesday. The organic grocer's earnings climbed 43% to 60 cents a share — the biggest gain in seven quarters. Sales rose 24%, the biggest gain in years. Whole Foods also guided full-year fiscal 2013 profit well ahead of views.

On the upside, Sturm Ruger (RGR) was off its session high, but still up 5% in active trading. Earlier, the stock was up as much as 10%, and it cleared a 52.13 buy point from a flat base within a larger pattern.

Gun makers are rising on fears of tougher regulation after President Obama's re-election. A backspread looks to position with net long contracts using all calls for bullish opinions and all puts for those carrying a bearish axe. With the former, a greater number of a higher up, same month strike call is purchased relative to a lower call strike. This forms a ratio spread with common configurations being (-1) x 2, (-1) x 3 and (-2) x 3.

Lower implieds helps this spread as the trader is a net buyer of premium, thus the reduced contract cost will allow for a potential small credit or tinier debit to enter into the position. Ultimately, the initiation cost will also rest with the ratio one uses, as well as the strike price distance between the sold and purchased contracts. Where shares are in relation to the backspread and the amount of time until expiration for the position will also affect costs.

As for the risk / reward profile, the max risk of the backspread is going to be at the purchased strike at expiration. At that point, the long contracts would be worthless and the trader would be facing an in-the-money short. Thus, the dollar amount at stake is the difference between strikes minus any credit received or if a debit was involved; adding that amount to the total bill of sale.

On the upside, which if we're looking at a call backspread, the trader begins to reduce his or her loss upon shares passing through the purchased strike at expiration. Prior to that time, the value of the spread can potentially increase in value and see profits if shares begin to move in that direction quickly and / or enjoy an increase in implied volatility, which would stand to benefit the net long contract backspread position.

The other upside to this particular kind of backspread is the downside, if the undesired move in shares is significant enough. The reason being, if the stock is below the lower sold call, both calls would expire worthless and allow the trader to keep the credit or have a much smaller loss on their hands than other bullish strategies less flexible when dead wrong on direction.

One name this type strategy might look suitable on is men's and women's designer label Michael Kors  (KORS). To illustrate, above we're looking at a (-1) x 3 October 44 / 55 call backspread which looks to take advantage of reasonable implieds which have fallen to multi-month lows and are probably more likely to stabilize or rebound than continue lower.

Technically, the IBD 50 constituent and recent IPO is attempting to breakout from a corrective weekly cup-shaped base after posting all-around better-than-forecast earnings results this week. However, if ever-fashionable and sometimes fickle investors have a change of heart, the backspread largely guards against the legacy of all gaps, even bullish ones, getting filled, especially if the other guy or gal's potential double top has any say in matters.

What do you think? Feel free to share your opinion in the comments section below.A backspread looks to position with net long contracts using all calls for bullish opinions and all puts for those carrying a bearish axe. IBD Special Report: Mutual Fund Monthly
The $15 billion T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth Fund is in the top tier of large-cap growth portfolios over several recent time periods.
Portfolio manager Larry Puglia has done that with a focus on stocks capable of sustainable growth.
Many of the fund's large-cap durable growers also happen to pay dividends that increase each year.
The fund was up 17.80% this year going into Tuesday. That put it into the top 14% of its peer group, which averaged a 14.17% gain, according to Morningstar Inc. The S&P 500 was up 14.41%.
Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain is 12.76% vs. 9.90% for its direct rivals and 10.92% for the big-cap bogey.
Puglia, who is 52 years old, talked with IBD from his office in Baltimore.
IBD: You seek companies that can sustain high growth for three to five years. What sort of companies do that?

Puglia: Companies need several things. We use (Harvard Business School professor) Michael Porter's analysis that it takes companies with competitive advantages. Warren Buffett talks about franchise companies. And Morningstar talks about moats. We want to see stable to improving margins. We want to see companies taking market share. We ask if the total addressable market for a company's products is growing quite large over time.
The final piece is management. All of the other things are not that important if management does not know how to reinvest free cash flow.

The analogy is that a company that generates superior return and has strong free cash flow but does not have strong management is like a fast ship without a rudder. Sooner or later, it will run aground.
IBD: How many of your holdings pay a dividend?
Puglia: Eighty-eight out of 132. Exactly two-thirds.
IBD: Have you tried to tweak your portfolio this year to cope with volatility?

Puglia: If you could anticipate market changes so you could transition from more growth to more defensive names — but that's impossible to do. And we don't want to. That's why we look for durable growth.
IBD: Does that mean there's nothing you can do to position the fund for next year, when we don't know yet what the tax background will be?

Puglia: The longer it takes (for the political parties) to come to an agreement and the less confident investors are that agreement on the budget at least partially addresses entitlement reform, then the more concerned investors will be about riskiness of investing in growth.

Obviously, the more significant the tax increases — and everyone knows there will be tax increases — the more that investors will be concerned about growth. If the tax increases are well above what was discussed in the debt-ceiling negotiations (in the summer of 2011), that could damage growth.
IBD: So the longer it takes Washington to reach an agreement and the higher the taxes, what will you do with your portfolio?

Puglia: The longer it takes or the higher the taxes, the more that's going to lead you away from companies that are economically sensitive. And the more that will cause us to want companies that would do fairly well even in a lackluster growth environment. We will emphasize to even a greater extent companies that have durable, sustainable growth.

Will we continue to own companies in the technology area? Sure. But if the prospects for slower growth or even a double-dip recession increase, we will be even more reluctant to own industrial or more cyclical companies.
IBD: I imagine that Sherwin-Williams (SHW) is one of your dividend names. They recently bought Mexico's Comex. What else do you like?
Puglia: They've increased dividends 34 or 35 years. And it is important that we're having a housing recovery. New buyers paint their homes. People paint when they remodel homes.
I just hope the housing recovery is not dampened by the budget negotiations.

Also, Sherwin-Williams has increased their prices several times, showing pricing power. And a lot of raw materials have dropped in price. Oil is down. Titanium oxide is moderating. Still, someone downgraded it. That's why it dropped recently. It's still attractive. It's done well, though, so we're not buying aggressively at current prices.
They have a chance to earn $10 a share in 2014, so they're trading around 15 times 2014 earnings, which is reasonable. We would consider buying on any correction.
IBD: Why reference 2014 earnings rather than 2013's?

Puglia: We are less than a month away from 2013. And we generally price stocks using earnings estimates for the next calendar year. Consequently, we are starting to price stocks using calendar 2014 estimates.
IBD: Is Apple (AAPL) a dividend stock for you?
Puglia: They recently started one and they have the ability to pay a growing dividend. We think it's unwise to eliminate a company like that from a potential buying pool.
IBD: Is Apple's recent pullback a long-term concern for you?

Puglia: It is under pressure. Some concerns are real. The iPad's 55% market share is not sustainable. And they've had supply constraints with the iPad mini and iPhone 5. Supply is catching up, though. Still, there's more competition coming. Samsung is a good company, and its products (like the Galaxy smartphone) are selling well.
(Amazon's) Kindle, which is not directly comparable to Apple's tablet, is selling briskly.

And while the iPad is on a closed system, Android is more of an open system. That means that if customers see Android products and features as equivalent to the iPad, they may be less willing to pay a premium for the iPad.
And demand for Mac computers is not so strong. But no one's desktops and computers are selling as well as handhelds.

But Apple's positives are there. They feel good about demand for the holidays. They have a share buyback in place. They've instituted dividends. We think the stock is mispriced. They'll have over $200 a share in cash on their balance sheet in the next 18 to 24 months, closer to $250 really. They'll earn $50 a share in 2013 and $60.70 in calendar 2014. That means the stock is trading at less than 10 times 2014 earnings before you consider the cash. Once you take the cash out, it's more like seven times earnings. That's cheap in our view.
IBD: Do dividends help the fund weather volatile markets?

Puglia: Dividend growth helps some stocks perform better in volatile markets. But dividend growth is essentially a byproduct of durable growth, which we pursue. There are durable earnings growers that do not have significant dividend yield, which we think should also perform well in volatile markets.
IBD: Michael Kors (KORS) is one of your nondividend plays.
Puglia: It is.
IBD: Is its recent pullback a long-term concern for you?

Puglia: We're always concerned about companies that have fashion risk. They have more fashion risk than we would typically find in the sector. But they're becoming a more accepted brand name across a variety of products — wrist watches, handbags. They're competing with Coach (COH), which we still own and has less fashion risk.

The overarching point about Kors is that they are becoming a sought-after brand, and will have longevity. They have a variety of products, garments, handbags. Growth will be stronger than people realize and more durable.
IBD: Visa (V) just keeps trending higher. Can it keep it up?
Puglia: We have meaningful positions in Visa and MasterCard (MA). Some new technologies threaten them. Others could augment their growth.

MasterCard has partnered with some companies working in the area of near-field communications and outfitting phones with gear to enable swipes and make payments. They have a partnership with Google Wallet. Visa has introduced "V.me" mobile wallet.

EBay (EBAY) just reported Black Friday results. PayPal (eBay's online payment system) numbers are up close to 200%. So electronic wallets, new payment technologies are enjoying robust growth. And the bread-and-butter credit card payment business continues to show steady growth.
Visa does not own a European operation. So because that market is weaker, it has been better for Visa.
IBD: Speaking of eBay, how is its Marketplaces (e-commerce) unit doing?

Puglia: Both PayPal and Marketplaces are doing well. PayPal is growing more rapidly. But it was a lot more important for management to fix the (bigger) Marketplaces business. And they've done that. They fixed the website. They brought in third-party sales, similar to what Amazon (AMZN) has done.
We think they could earn over $3 a share in calendar 2014. Maybe $3.25 to $3.40. So they're trading at just 15 times what they could earn in 2014.
IBD: What will it take for Priceline (PCLN) to recover from its exposure to Europe? Does Europe have to get better?

Puglia: To a degree. It's reassuring to us that after a quarter or two of earnings disappointments, they have shown improving growth. Business reaccelerated for Bookings.com, their European engine. Agoda, which is prevalent in Asia, continues to do well. Priceline was already reasonably priced when it stumbled, its stock corrected, and that made it even more reasonably priced.
IBD: Amgen (AMGN) is helped by sales of Enbrel. What else do you like?

Puglia: Amgen is a company that has struggled a little. Reimbursement (from Medicare, Medicaid and other sources) concerns surround a number of their products like Epogen, which is essentially a red blood cell stimulating factor. Then they have Neupogen, which stimulates white blood cells.

Both are big products. Another, Aranesp, has been hurt. It is used by kidney dialysis patients. There's been a big debate about how much of it should be consumed. That's resulted in a dramatic slowing of that product.

Other products, like Prolia, have all kinds of derivatives. Some are used to rebuild bone mass by women with osteoporosis. Others can control lesions that prostate cancer patients might suffer. Prolia has shown dramatic growth.
In their pipeline are a series of compounds that lower bad cholesterol or high-density lipid cholesterol.
Amgen is not our favorite biotech. But the company has cut expenses. It is probably going to grow its dividend. And its valuation is still interesting.
IBD: PVH (PVH) gapped up Oct. 31 after news of the Warnaco acquisition.

Puglia: Right. That buy was postulated for some time. PVH owns (the Calvin Klein brand) and Warnaco licenses (Calvin Klein underwear) from PVH. The deal lets PVH unify the brand. And it gives them control over valuable licenses in Europe and various markets. And it will let them save a lot of expenses by taking out redundant functions.
PVH has other brands like Tommy Hilfiger (and Van Heusen, Izod and Speedo).
IBD: American Tower (AMT) benefits from carriers upgrading their networks to 4G. What are the risks?

Puglia: Technological threats. There are some approaches to wireless data and voice that don't require big towers. Some only require small transponders. We've been watching that trend for three to four years. We're comfortable nothing will happen soon, but it's out there.IBD Special Report: Mutual Fund MonthlyThe $15 billion T. We think it's unwise to eliminate a company like that from a potential buying pool.IBD: Is Apple's recent pullback a long-term concern for you?Puglia: It is under pressure. Some concerns are real. The iPad's 55% market share is not sustainable. And they've had supply constraints with the iPad mini and iPhone 5. Supply is catching up, though. Still, there's more competition coming. Samsung is a good company, and its products (like the Galaxy smartphone) are selling well.(Amazon's) Kindle, which is not directly comparable to Apple's tablet, is selling briskly.And while the iPad is on a closed system, Android is more of an open system. That means that if customers see Android products and features as equivalent to the iPad, they may be less willing to pay a premium for the iPad.And demand for Mac computers is not so strong. But no one's desktops and computers are selling as well as handhelds.But Apple's positives are there. They feel good about demand for the holidays. They have a share buyback in place. They've instituted dividends. We think the stock is mispriced. They'll have over $200 a share in cash on their balance sheet in the next 18 to 24 months, closer to $250 really. They'll earn $50 a share in 2013 and $60.70 in calendar 2014. That means the stock is trading at less than 10 times 2014 earnings before you consider the cash. Once you take the cash out, it's more like seven times earnings. That's cheap in our view.IBD: Do dividends help the fund weather volatile markets?Puglia: Dividend growth helps some stocks perform better in volatile markets. But dividend growth is essentially a byproduct of durable growth, which we pursue. There are durable earnings growers that do not have significant dividend yield, which we think should also perform well in volatile markets.IBD: Michael Kors (KORS) is one of your nondividend plays.Puglia: It is.IBD: Is its recent pullback a long-term concern for you?Puglia: We're always concerned about companies that have fashion risk. They have more fashion risk than we would typically find in the sector. But they're becoming a more accepted brand name across a variety of products — wrist watches, handbags. They're competing with Coach (COH), which we still own and has less fashion risk.The overarching point about Kors is that they are becoming a sought-after brand, and will have longevity. They have a variety of products, garments, handbags. Growth will be stronger than people realize and more durable.IBD: Visa (V) just keeps trending higher. Can it keep it up?Puglia: We have meaningful positions in Visa and MasterCard (MA). Some new technologies threaten them. Others could augment their growth.MasterCard has partnered with some companies working in the area of near-field communications and outfitting phones with gear to enable swipes and make payments. They have a partnership with Google Wallet. Visa has introduced "V.me" mobile wallet.EBay (EBAY) just reported Black Friday results. PayPal (eBay's online payment system) numbers are up close to 200%. So electronic wallets, new payment technologies are enjoying robust growth. And the bread-and-butter credit card payment business continues to show steady growth.Visa does not own a European operation. So because that market is weaker, it has been better for Visa.IBD: Speaking of eBay, how is its Marketplaces (e-commerce) unit doing?Puglia: Both PayPal and Marketplaces are doing well. PayPal is growing more rapidly. But it was a lot more important for management to fix the (bigger) Marketplaces business. And they've done that. They fixed the website. They brought in third-party sales, similar to what Amazon (AMZN) has done.We think they could earn over $3 a share in calendar 2014. Maybe $3.25 to $3.40. So they're trading at just 15 times what they could earn in 2014.IBD: What will it take for Priceline (PCLN) to recover from its exposure to Europe? Does Europe have to get better?Puglia: To a degree. It's reassuring to us that after a quarter or two of earnings disappointments, they have shown improving growth. Business reaccelerated for Bookings.com, their European engine. Agoda, which is prevalent in Asia, continues to do well. Priceline was already reasonably priced when it stumbled, its stock corrected, and that made it even more reasonably priced.IBD: Amgen (AMGN) is helped by sales of Enbrel. What else do you like?Puglia: Amgen is a company that has struggled a little. Reimbursement (from Medicare, Medicaid and other sources) concerns surround a number of their products like Epogen, which is essentially a red blood cell stimulating factor. Then they have Neupogen, which stimulates white blood cells.Both are big products. Another, Aranesp, has been hurt. It is used by kidney dialysis patients. There's been a big debate about how much of it should be consumed. That's resulted in a dramatic slowing of that product.Other products, like Prolia, have all kinds of derivatives. Some are used to rebuild bone mass by women with osteoporosis. Others can control lesions that prostate cancer patients might suffer. Prolia has shown dramatic growth.In their pipeline are a series of compounds that lower bad cholesterol or high-density lipid cholesterol.Amgen is not our favorite biotech. But the company has cut expenses. It is probably going to grow its dividend. And its valuation is still interesting.IBD: PVH (PVH) gapped up Oct. 31 after news of the Warnaco acquisition.Puglia: Right. That buy was postulated for some time. PVH owns (the Calvin Klein brand) and Warnaco licenses (Calvin Klein underwear) from PVH. The deal lets PVH unify the brand. And it gives them control over valuable licenses in Europe and various markets. And it will let them save a lot of expenses by taking out redundant functions.PVH has other brands like Tommy Hilfiger (and Van Heusen, Izod and Speedo).IBD: American Tower (AMT) benefits from carriers upgrading their networks to 4G. What are the risks?Puglia: Technological threats. There are some approaches to wireless data and voice that don't require big towers. Some only require small transponders. We've been watching that trend for three to four years. We're comfortable nothing will happen soon, but it's out there.

Stocks rose Friday, but closed off their session highs. The market got a lift from a solid jobs report and relief over Greece's bond swap, but pulled back in the wake of news that the swap counts as a "credit event," or basically a default.The Nasdaq tacked on 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.1%. Volume declined from Thursday's levels on both main exchanges, taking some punch out of the move higher.After the close, shares of Michael Kors (KORS) plunged. The company announced a secondary stock offering. The luxury apparel company had just hit a new high in regular trading as it continued a heated advance.For the week, the Nasdaq rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. Each index advanced for a fourth straight week, fighting back from sizable losses suffered earlier in the week. The Dow lost 0.4% for the week.Economic news mostly was positive Friday. The government jobs report for February showed better-than-expected growth, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 227,000 and the unemployment rate staying at 8.3%. On the downside, payrolls are still 5.3 million below the January 2008 peak and the U.S. trade deficit widened for a third straight month.In the late afternoon Friday, the International Swaps and Derivatives Association said Greece's bond swap counts as a "credit event," meaning holders of credit default swaps likely will be entitled to compensation estimated at $3.2 billion. Analysts have said the ISDA's announcement was expected and the amount is less than feared.Among IBD 50 stocks on Friday, Sourcefire (FIRE) gained 5% in above-average volume and touched a new all-time high. The maker of security software and hardware climbed back above a 46.39 buy point from a short-stroke pattern that it first cleared Monday. It closed 4% beyond 46.39, leaving it near the upper limit of a possible buy zone.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), another IBD 50 name, reversed from a high and finished about flat Friday. The stock was up as much as 3% in reaction to its better-than-expected Q4 results, out late Thursday. Ulta's earnings and sales grew 52% and 23%, respectively. Despite the reversal, it's still well extended past a 75.80 buy point from a cup-shaped consolidation.Starbucks (SBUX) jumped 3% in big turnover, helped by the company's plans to sell single-serve coffee makers. The company, which announced the plan late Thursday, has hit an all-time high and is now well extended past a buying range after lifting off support at its 10-week moving average. Starbucks sports an IBD Composite Rating of 96, near the best-possible grade of 99.  Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which makes the Keurig single-serve brewers, plunged 16% Friday on the news.On Monday, Clean Energy Fuels (CLNE) is among the companies expected to report quarterly earnings. The day's economic news will include the Treasury's monthly account of the surplus or deficit for the federal government.

Companies with a proven track record show the ability to come to market time and again with innovative products. All are institutional-quality stocks with excellent fundamentals.…
Stocks were near session lows late Thursday and on pace for their biggest losses of the week.

The Nasdaq fell 1%, on pace to end a four-session win streak. The S&P 500 fell 0.7% and was a hair above the 1400 level. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was also down 0.7%, with 28 of 30 issues losing ground.
Turnover was tracking lower across the board.

Seagate Technology (STX) extended its pullback from a recent multiyear high, dropping 5% in heavy trading. The stock is now 2% below a 32.65 buy point from a cup base. It had been up as much as 9% past that trigger.

Fresh Market (TFM) shaved a 5% loss to less than 2%. But it's still 1% below a 57.96 buy point from a double-bottom base. The high-end grocer staged a huge downside reversal Wednesday following weak same-store sales guidance.

Michael Kors (KORS) turned tail from a near-record high and slipped 1% in fast trade. The stock has either reversed lower or closed near its intraday lows in recent sessions. Michael Kors is still 7% past a 49.60 buy point from a cup base.

Zumiez (ZUMZ) trimmed a 6% gain to 2% as the action sports and accessories retailer gets set to report Q2 results after the close. Analysts see earnings rising 62% to 13 cents a share. Sales are expected at $135.52 million, up 21% from a year ago. Stocks struggled for direction at the open Tuesday, but found some buyers after better-than-expected factory data.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 climbed 0.4% each while the Dow Jones industrial average ticked up 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.In economic news, the ISM manufacturing index rose to 54.8 in April. That's the highest since June 2011. Economists expected a dip to 53 from 53.4 in March. Construction spending edged up 0.1% in March vs. expectations for a 0.5% gain.Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) rallied 3% in fast trade ahead of its fiscal Q3 results after the market's close. Analysts see the networking gear maker's earnings rising 80% to 27 cents a share. Sales are slated to climb 77% to $90.5 million. The new issue is near a record high after bouncing off its 10-week line in March.Michael Kors (KORS) keeps rebounding off its 50-day line and rose 3%. The stock is working on its first base since coming public in December. Michael Kors is a luxury goods retailer. Analysts see its profit jumping 79% this year.Expedia (EXPE) was off its session low, but still down 1% after being cut to underweight from equal weight at Barclays. It's on pace to end a five-session run. Last week, Expedia surged after crushing views with a 62% jump in Q1 earnings. The online travel firm noted a surge in hotel bookings.TripAdvisor (TRIP) shed 3% ahead of its Q1 results after the close. The Expedia spinoff is expected to earn 33 cents a share on sales of $174.41 million. The stock found support at its 50-day line Thursday.

Shares of children's clothing maker Carter's (CRI) surged 10% to 48 in intraday trading after it beat analysts' fourth-quarter estimates, and issued guidance for the current year well above Wall Street estimates.

Earnings per share rose 5% to 63 cents, trouncing views of 44 cents a share, on strong holiday sales of its namesake Carter's and OshKosh B'gosh brands. Revenue climbed 22% to $606.6 million. Analysts expected $572.8 million.

Carter's, the largest U.S. branded marketer for baby and infant clothing, operates more than 500 stores in its Carter's and OshKosh chains, and sells through retail channels like department stores and specialty chains.

For the current quarter, Carter's expects EPS of 38-43 cents, below its 57-cent profit in the same quarter last year. For the full year, it sees EPS of $2.40-$2.50, well above analysts' consensus of $2.32 a share. The company sees sales rising 8%-10% over the prior year's $2.1 billion, a weaker advance than in 2011, when sales jumped 21% over the prior year.
Since hitting a low of 27.44 on Aug. 22, shares have shot up about 75%.

Elsewhere in the apparel group, luxury apparel and footwear maker Michael Kors' (KORS) shares edged up 1% to 42.97. Ralph Lauren (RL) was also up less than 1% at 175.13, and underwear and sportswear maker Under Armour (UA) lifted more than 2% to 89.64.

Carter's, the largest U.S. branded marketer for baby and infant clothing, operates more than 500 stores in its Carter's and OshKosh chains, and sells through retail channels like department stores and specialty chains.

Carter's Chief Executive Michael Casey said sales grew in every business segment, and he attributed the gains to strong brand recognition and compelling prices. He said profit was hurt, though, by high commodity costs.

"For the year, we achieved a record level of sales by extending the reach of our brands in the United States and international markets," Casey said. "Earnings continue to be impacted by abnormally high cotton prices. We expect to see the benefit of lower cotton prices in the second half of 2012, and we are forecasting good growth in sales and profitability this year."

Carter's said that product costs for its spring line will rise about 15% compared to spring 2011, because of continued high cotton, labor and other product-related costs. But by the time it rolls out its fall line, it sees product costs falling about 10% vs. costs for fall 2011.Shares of children's clothing maker Carter's (CRI) surged 10% to 48 in intraday trading after it beat analysts' fourth-quarter estimates, and issued guidance for the current year well above Wall Street estimates.Earnings per share rose 5% to 63 cents, trouncing views of 44 cents a share, on strong holiday sales of its namesake Carter's and OshKosh B'gosh brands. Stocks touched fresh session lows around midafternoon Wednesday, as investors digested the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's last policy meeting and President Obama's news conference.

The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%, the S&P 500 fell 0.7% and the Nasdaq dropped 0.6%. Each index has touched a fresh low for the current market correction and slumped further under its 200-day moving average. Volume was tracking ahead of Tuesday's level across the board.

The Fed minutes indicated some officials see the need for additional quantitative easing next year. The minutes also suggested the central bank is moving closer to providing better guidance on when it might make its first rate hike.

Meanwhile, the president called for Congress to extend middle-class tax breaks, saying: "We should at least do what we can agree on." He said Washington could then move to negotiating how to handle taxes on the wealthy as it works to avoid the fiscal cliff. Still, the market's sell-off has picked up through midafternoon.

IBD 50 stocks were mostly lower, with Catamaran (CTRX) sliding 7% in strong volume. The pharmacy benefits manager and IT services provider, No. 8 in Wednesday's IBD 50, sliced through its 50-day moving average after consolidating near that level in the last few weeks. Rival pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) is also down in heavy volume, sliding 1%.
Michael Kors (KORS), No. 3 in Wednesday's IBD 50, fell 5% in active turnover. The clothing and accessories maker, a December 2011 IPO, has undercut support at 50 and a prior buy point at 49.60.

On the upside, Cisco Systems (CSCO) jumped 5% in strong turnover, powered by its better-than-expected earnings report late Tuesday. The stock remains below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, as well as about 15% off its April high. Cisco has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 42, but it remains a tech sector bellwether.

Facebook (FB) gained 12% in big volume on a big lock-up expiration day for the May IPO. Stocks continued to trade in modestly positive territory at midafternoon Monday.
The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were both up 0.3%, as each index worked to extend its winning streak to seven straight sessions. The Nasdaq was up 0.2%.
Volume in the stock market today has turned mixed. It's down from Friday's pace for the NYSE, but up slightly for the Nasdaq.

Among IBD 50 stocks, MagnaChip Semiconductor (MX) was performing best, gaining 5% in above-average volume. The Korean chipmaker is lifting off its 50-day moving average. Early Monday, it announced a new product for smartphone power amplifier applications.

Tupperware Brands (TUP) remained the worst performer among IBD 50 stocks, losing 4% in fast trade. It's dropping from an all-time high toward its 10-week moving average, hit by a downgrade to "equal weight" by Morgan Stanley analysts.

Former IBD 50 stock Michael Kors (KORS) lost 5% in heavy turnover, slicing through its 50-day moving average and putting it 6% below its recent buy point at 58.72. The fashion house has been a regular in the IBD 50, but wasn't in the most recent lineup.

On the earnings front, Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) was down 10% in giant volume after its fourth-quarter earnings missed forecasts, and its Q1 guidance also disappointed. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 71 out of a best-possible grade of 99. Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 16% on the NYSE and falling 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary figures.
European Central Bank head Mario Draghi suggested that the ECB will introduce new stimulus measures at its Dec. 3 meeting.
Retailers, medical and apparel stocks led the upside, while data storage, energy and steel stocks underperformed.

Nike (NKE) led the Dow and the IBD 50, jumping 5% in heavy volume after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split, share buyback and a dividend increase late Thursday. The stock is well extended past a 117.82 buy point but has found support at the 50-day moving average.

Alaska Air (ALK) was also among the best-performing IBD 50 stocks. The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.

On the downside, Mentor Graphics (MENT) plunged 35% to a 52-week low after Mentor, a developer of software used to test electronic systems, issued a disappointing quarterly earnings report.Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Spending from wealthier consumers drove strong Ralph Lauren (RL) fourth-quarter results. But ongoing economic malaise in Europe threatens growth in the coming quarters, the upscale fashion and home goods brand said. Stocks pushed ahead Friday afternoon. The major indexes have now recouped more than half of Thursday's losses.

The Nasdaq rallied 1% and the S&P 500 0.8%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, despite a 5% drop in Walt Disney (DIS). Volume continued to track slightly higher across the board compared with the same time Thursday.
Top-rated stocks up in volume were few, despite the market's bounce.

3D Systems (DDD) bounced back from earlier losses and climbed 3% to a second straight record high. It's now 4% past a 44.90 buy point. The company makes 3D printers, which are used to make parts for the aerospace, health care, military and transportation markets. In late October, 3D Systems beat views with Q3 earnings and sales that surged 78% and 57%, respectively.
Rival Stratasys (SSYS) reversed higher and also climbed 3%.

Steven Madden (SHOO) erased earlier losses after finding support near its 200-day line and climbed 3%. The upside reversal wiped out Thursday's fall and then some. On Thursday, the stock fell more than 8% below a 45.65 buy point in a flat base.

Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2% as it rebounded from Thursday's 7% dive below its 50-day line. The stock also fell more than 8% below a 57.45 buy point from a flat base Thursday. Michael Kors will unveil its Q3 results Tuesday before the market's open. The luxury apparel market is expected to earn 40 cents a share, up 74%.
