Fashion designer Michael Kors was in New York, showing off his latest designs on the catwalk for New York's fashion week.
But investors will get a peak at how well his designs are selling Tuesday morning, when the fashion and design house named after him reports fiscal third-quarter results.

Analysts think Michael Kors (KORS) — the Hong Kong-based firm — will report earnings of 41 cents per share, more than double last year's 20 cents per share. The consensus estimate calls for Kors' revenue to be up 44% in the December-ending quarter, to $540.3 million.
Kors was up 0.7% intraday on the stock market today.

Accessories such as watches and jewelry have been big sellers for Kors, which is good news for another firm reporting Tuesday, Fossil (FOSL). It has been Kors exclusive supplier of watches since 2004 and of its jewelry since December 2010.
Analysts think it will report fourth-quarter earnings of $2.26 per share, up 21% from $1.87 a year ago. The consensus estimate calls for revenue to be up 12% to $930.43 million.
Fossil shares were down 1.8% intraday.
Both names cater to relatively well-heeled clientele. That segment has held up, even as the broader cross-section of consumers gets squeezed by still high unemployment, and stagnant wage growth.

On Friday morning, more clues to those consumers' health comes with VF Corp. (VFC). The company's brands include wintery weather clothier The North Face, and jeans brands including Wrangler and Lee. Analysts think it will report a 31% increase in EPS to $3.03.
Estimates call for revenue to climb 5.5% to $3.07 billion.
Its shares slipped 0.8% intraday.

Also on deck is the youth clothier Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF), which reports on Feb. 22. Analysts expect earnings to climb 74% to $1.95 per share. Revenue is forecasted to climb 11.6% to $1.48 billion.

Oil and gas stocks were strong in the stock market today as crude added 3%. Giants Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) led on the Dow with 2% gains.
The tech sector lagged, with Cisco (CSCO), Intel (INTC) and Microsoft (MSFT) the weakest Dow components.

Leaders up in volume were limited, but J.B. Hunt Transport Services (JBHT) climbed 4% in huge trade to a record high. The trucking and logistics firm announced Q1 earnings before the open that topped expectations.

Warehouse grocery chain Smart & Final Stores (SFS) hit a new high in heavy trade before surrendering the majority of gains. The stock is extended since gapping past a 16.95 cup-base entry on strong fourth-quarter results.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Chinese car website Autohome (ATHM) outperformed with a 4% gain. Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. Michael Kors (KORS) reported earnings above estimates on Tuesday but the holiday season might not be so cheery for luxury wholesalers and retailers as its outlook for the important holiday quarter was below analyst expectations. Saks (SKS) expects Q4 sales at stores open at least a year to be flat in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.

Michael Kors said second-quarter earnings more than doubled to 49 cents per share in its first Q2 report since going public Dec. 15. Analysts were expecting 40 cents. The fashion house said sales jumped 74.4% to $532.9 million, beating views of $519 million.

Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 45.2%. Same-store sales are an important metric because it does not include stores that have opened or closed in the past year. North American same-store sales climbed 45%. European sales surged 97% as the company continues to expand its brand in the region.
Shares fell as much as 5% in pre-market trading, but were up 1% to 51.08 in late-morning trading Tuesday.
Kors sees Q3 earnings of 37-39 cents per share, the midpoint below analyst expectations of 39 cents per share.

Despite the weak guidance, Kors continues to be one of the biggest IPO successes of the past year. The fashion house is used to being in the spotlight as its lead designer and namesake, Michael Kors, has been in the fashion industry for years but is perhaps best known as a judge on the hit reality show "Project Runway."

Luxury overall has struggled in the past month. Fossil (FOSL), who makes Kors licensed watches and jewelry, reported weak European sales last week. Preppy fashion house Ralph Lauren (RL) reported flat Q2 earnings on Nov. 2 and lowered its outlook.
Saks, the upscale department store, continued luxury's disappointing earnings on Tuesday.
The company said third-quarter EPS rose 9% to 12 cents, in line with estimates. Sales climbed 3% to $713 million, under expectations of $726 million.

"As the overall macroeconomic environment remains very uncertain, we continue to approach the future cautiously," said CEO Stephen Sadove. "Sales trends have been soft for the first two weeks of November in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. Many of our stores, representing about 40% of our total company revenues, were directly impacted by the storm, and we have experienced a decline in saks.com sales generated from our customers in the Northeast."
It expects flat same-stores sales during the quarter due to the storm.

The operator of Saks Fifth Avenue and Off Fifth department stores said it expects sales at stores open at least a year to be flat during the current holiday quarter because of a slow start to November due to Superstorm Sandy.

Last week, competitor Macy's (M) also issued weak guidance for its holiday quarter in the wake of the storm.Michael Kors (KORS) reported earnings above estimates on Tuesday but the holiday season might not be so cheery for luxury wholesalers and retailers as its outlook for the important holiday quarter was below analyst expectations. Among apparel stocks, most don't pay a dividend.Of those that do, the top-rated stock is VF Corp. (VFC)The North Carolina-based company, which is No. 18 in the Big Cap 20, holds a slew of well-known brand names, including Wrangler, Lee, JanSport, The North Face and Timberland.Over the years, VF has grown through acquisitions. For example, Lee was acquired in 1969, JanSport and Wrangler in 1986, The North Face in 2000 and Timberland in 2011.Last year's $2.3 billion buyout of Timberland was VF's largest ever, and expanded VF's footprint in the outdoor clothing space.In a New America article in March, Cowen & Co. analyst John Kernan told IBD that VF "could be poised to make another acquisition in the back half of this year."The analyst believes the acquisition "will be focused in outdoor active sports, and we think it will be a major international brand, probably in Europe."VF derives about two-thirds of its revenue from the U.S. The balance is from Europe, Canada, Asia, Mexico and Latin America.The company said in its latest 10-K report that it is focusing more on outdoor attire, because profit margins and growth rates are higher in that space than in VF's other businesses.In 2011, VF's pretax margin was 12.7%, the best in the past five years.Annual earnings dropped 8% on a revenue decline of 6% in recessionary 2009. Since then, EPS rebounded 25% each in 2010-11 as revenue rose 7% and 23%.The Street expects earnings to rise 17% this year on 17% sales growth.The three-year earnings stability rating is 4, and the five-year rating is 9. The gauge runs from 0 (calm) to 99 (wild). The current annual yield is 1.9%.One angle to consider is VF's No. 2 status in its industry group in Stock Checkup at Investors.com. The No. 1 stock is Michael Kors (KORS), an upscale apparel marketer with much stronger fundamentals, though it pays no dividend. Buying the best on a breakout and taking income out of capital appreciation might be the best strategy.

Stock futures pointed sharply lower ahead of Monday's open, as markets responded to Friday's jobs data for March.
Dow futures traded down 116 points. Nasdaq 100 futures were off 27.25 points and S&P 500 futures slipped 14.9 points.

Friday's disappointing jobs data showed the economy added 120,000 jobs in March, half of January's rate and well below the 200,000 number forecast by analysts. The numbers included 34,000 jobs lost in retail trades, the second month of sharp decline in that industry. Hourly earnings and the average work week slipped a notch. So did the unemployment rate, to 8.2%.

In stocks, AOL (AOL) shares swept up 34% after the company announced it would sell more than 800 patents and related applications to Microsoft . The deal, valued at $1.06 billion, involves a subsidiary upon which AOL expects to report a capital loss, for tax purposes, the company said in a statement. Management said it planned to return proceeds to shareholders, and expected the deal to close before the end of the year. Microsoft shares slipped a fraction.

Sony (SNE) traded up nearly 2% after news reports said the company would pare an estimated 10,000 employees from its global workforce. New chief executive Kazuo Hirai reportedly plans to restructure the Japan-based electronics brand in two years, through 2014. Most of the cuts are expected in the company's chemicals and liquid crystal display businesses. Details are expected to be announced on Thursday.
Leading stocks were under sharp selling pressure ahead of the open. About 20% of the IBD 50 stocks were down 2% or more.

Among the hardest hit, InvenSense carved a 4% loss ahead of the opening bell. The motion-processing chip and applications maker has toppled 29% in the past two weeks, cutting its 10-week line of support last week in heavy trade. The stock ended Thursday 112% above its November IPO price.

Another new issue, Michael Kors (KORS) pared losses but remained 2% lower ahead of the open. This left the stock well above its 10-week moving average and still possibly building a flat base. The luxury fashion house closed Thursday 137% above its December IPO price.

Overseas, markets in Europe remained closed for the spring holiday. The Shanghai Composite dropped 0.9%, reacting to Friday's job numbers from the U.S. and to accelerating consumer price inflation in March. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slumped 1.5% — its fifth, straight loss — as the yen climbed vs. the dollar and the euro.

Weakish data from the U.S. and signs of trouble in the EU knocked stocks modestly Tuesday until a late burst of buying helped indexes to a mixed close.
Higher volume on both exchanges would have made for a distribution day if not for that last surge to break-even.
The S&P 500 dipped 0.1%, while the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each added a hair.
Volume increased 35% on the Nasdaq and 7% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Retail sales came in weaker than expected, adding a trace of doubt to the U.S. economic recovery. And EU finance ministers canceled a Greek-rescue meeting, slated for Wednesday, which added more than a trace of doubt over Europe's confidence in Athens' efforts.
Recent IPO Zynga (ZNGA), a game developer, shot up 7% in double-paced trade. The company is slated to release its first-ever earnings report since its December debut.

Cloud-computing firm Rackspace Hosting (RAX) gapped up and leapt 13%, fueled by a knockout Q4 report. Rackspace netted 18 cents in the period, 3 cents more than expected. And the 80% profit advance was the company's best showing since Q4 of 2008.

Rackspace Hosting had already busted out from a cup-with-handle Feb. 2, rising past the 45.55 buy point in triple-paced action. The stock finished Tuesday 23% above that trigger. Such a big move in so short a time suggests that longs hold on for a total of eight weeks.
Luxury clothing maker and retailer Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), another recent IPO, soared 27% in its highest volume since its first trading session, Dec. 15.

Upscale footwear retailer Steven Madden (SHOO) jumped 7% in four times its normal volume, putting the stock 10% above a 39.52 buy point from a cup within a larger base. Steven Madden last month agreed to buy its privately held Canadian licensee, SM Canada, to step up its expansion there.Weakish data from the U.S. and signs of trouble in the EU knocked stocks modestly Tuesday until a late burst of buying helped indexes to a mixed close.Higher volume on both exchanges would have made for a distribution day if not for that last surge to break-even.The S&P 500 dipped 0.1%, while the Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each added a hair.Volume increased 35% on the Nasdaq and 7% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.Retail sales came in weaker than expected, adding a trace of doubt to the U.S. economic recovery. The watch, wallet and handbag accessory retailer said profit rose 28% to $1.87 per share, compared to a year ago, beating estimates by 10 cents. Revenue increased 18% to $830 million, shy of the $841 million analysts' had expected. Despite the mixed…

Stock futures surrendered early gains and dived into the red Tuesday after disappointing January retail sales numbers. Dow futures reversed and fell 12 points. Nasdaq 100 futures slipped 3.75 points and S&P 500 futures gave up 2.6 points. Retail sales rose less than expected in January, up 0.4% vs. expectations for a 0.8% gain. Sales were flat in December. Minus…
Restoration Hardware (RH) popped 28% in early trading Friday, after pricing atop its expected range late Thursday.
The home-furnishings retail chain priced at 24, the high end of the range it set last week. With the sale of 5.2 million shares it raised $124 million, which will go toward paying down debt.

As IBD reported earlier this week, Restoration Hardware returns to the market a rather different company from when it last traded in 2008. The management has repositioned it as a luxury brand appealing to the same clientele who shop at Saks (SKS) and Michael Kors (KORS) outlets, with retail stores rebranded "galleries" to show off a wider variety of big-ticket merchandise. It has also turned profitable, with EBITDA running at about 7% of revenue.

Two energy IPOs, Delek Logistics (DKL) and Southcross Energy (SXE), also priced well and rose more than 10% in early trading Friday, suggesting continued demand for new-issues despite the storm-shortened week.Restoration Hardware (RH) popped 28% in early trading Friday, after pricing atop its expected range late Thursday.The home-furnishings retail chain priced at 24, the high end of the range it set last week. Small caps did best as the S&P 600 popped 1%. Volume fell across the board. Economic news was sparse. New-home sales for February were weaker…
Stocks flirted with a down day in higher volume Wednesday, but the losses and the volume shrank by session's end.
The NYSE composite fell 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.1%. The Nasdaq rose fractionally while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%.
Volume was lower on both major exchanges, according to preliminary calculations.
Among blue chips, IBM (IBM) poked to a new high in roughly average volume. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base Feb. 23 and is now 5% above its 194.91 buy point.
Top-rated stocks were mostly down Wednesday as four stocks fell for every one that rose on the IBD 50.
Apple (AAPL) was one of the rare gainers, jumping almost 4% in close to triple its usual volume. The stock is now 38% above a 427.85 buy point.
Upscale apparel marketer Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) slipped 2% but volume was 4% quieter than usual.

Among IBD's 197 industry groups, most were down. The biggest loser was the gold-mining group, which fell almost 4%. Gold futures fell 3%, while silver lopped off 4%. Copper futures slid 2%. Stock futures steered sharply lower ahead of Tuesday's open, tracking losses in overseas markets.
Dow futures snapped down 102 points. Nasdaq 100 futures traded 22.5 points lower and S&P 500 futures fell 11.7 points.

China's markets took their heaviest loss in three months, with the Shanghai Composite ending down 1.4%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 2.2%, led by an 8% tumble by insurer AIA Group, as American International Group (AIG) sold 1.72 billion shares, about 14% of its ownership stake in the company, raising $6 billion and leaving AIG with a 19% interest in AIA.
Europe's markets were down hard heading into afternoon trade. The CAC-40 in Paris showed a 1.5% loss and the DAX in Frankfurt was off 1.6%.
Oil held steady above $106 a barrel. Natural gas hovered after dropping to $2.36 per thousand cubic feet on Monday. Gold slipped 1% to near $1,690 an ounce.

IBD 50 stocks took generally mild losses in premarket trade. One exception, Lululemon Athletica (LULU), backed off 2% ahead of the open. The women's fitness wear maker surged 5% to a new high Thursday. The move cleared a 67.32 buy point in a three-week tight pattern. The stock ended Monday 2% above that buy point.

Michael Kors (KORS) dropped more than 2% in premarket action. The luxury fashion house posted four days of strong gains through Monday, rattling off consecutive new highs. All three indexes rallied into the close, another encouraging sign. The…

Stock futures traded lower, but steady ahead of Monday's open as oil prices and the Federal Reserve tested investor confidence. Dow futures traded 40.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures hung 5.5 points below the line. Nasdaq 100 futures were off a mild 7.6 points. Small caps were under disproportionate pressure, with Russell 2000 futures falling 8.2 points.The stock market today opens under a clear caution flag ahead of Wednesday's policy decision from the Federal Reserve. The Nasdaq dropped 4.1% last week, slicing below support at both its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The S&P 500 crumpled 3.8%, also violating both levels of support. That means all bets are off on the market's direction for the next two days.Within that uncertainty, oil prices continued diving early Monday, with West Texas Intermediate down more than 2% to below 35% a barrel, its lowest mark in more than a decade. Brent crude dropped nearly 3%, below $37, to its weakest level since 2008. Both benchmarks have logged steady losses since the Dec. 4 Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting, in which the group failed to agree on a production quota, permitting member countries to continue current production levels.Despite the oil price slump, it was DuPont (DD) and Apple (AAPL) that dragged down the Dow before the open. DuPont dipped more than 1%.Apple trimmed its premarket loss to 1%, up from a 3% dive, after Morgan Stanley cut its price target to 143 from 162, citing pressure on international iPhone prices due to oversupply outside China. Apple ended Friday well off an August low, but struggling to retake its 10-week moving average within a five-month consolidation.Jarden (JAH) jumped 5%, Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) slipped more than 2% after Newell said it would pay $13.2 billion in a cash/stock deal to acquire the Boca Raton, Fla.-based maker of Sunbeam irons, Marmot outdoor gear and Crock-Pot cookware.Newell management said the combination is targeting $500 million in annualized cost savings, would be immediately positive for earnings, and should close in Q2 of 2016. Jarden rose 9% last week on merger speculation, moving the stock up the right side of a five-month consolidation.China-based maker of solar electrical components Trina Solar (TSL) spiked 9% on news reports that the company had received an offer to be taken private at $11.60 per share by Shanghai Xingsheng Equity Investment & Management. The offer was 321% above Friday's closing price.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) was confusing brokerage data collection systems in premarket trade, as it prepared to go live with its 2-for-1 stock split at today's open. It is the company's first stock split since May 2010.Overseas, Europe's stocks came off their lows near midday. London's FTSE 100 reversed early losses and wrestled into narrowly positive territory. Frankfurt's DAX was down 0.8%, up from a 1.2% loss. The Cac-40 in Paris eased to a 0.4% loss, from 0.6%.Asia's markets were widely mixed: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dipped 0.7%, the Shanghai Composite jumped 2.5% and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo stumbled to a 1.8% loss.

The day's biggest economic news, from the housing sector, was disappointing. Pending home sales slipped…

Stocks held modest gains and remained at their best levels near lunchtime Tuesday. Earlier, the market received better-than-expected housing and consumer sentiment data. Stocks continued to march ahead in afternoon action Tuesday, reaching new session highs and then holding near them.
The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Volume was tracking up from Monday's level across the board.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) climbed 3% in fast trade, hitting a fresh all-time high. The stock is now about 7% beyond a 66.72 three-weeks-tight entry, meaning it's extended past a proper buying range. CommVault, a maker of database software, was No. 2 in Monday's IBD 50.

Rackspace Hosting (RAX) jumped 6% in big turnover, clearing a 70.10 buy point from a handle. A Bloomberg report late Monday said the cloud computing company and related firms might become acquisition targets. Rackspace has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a best-possible 99.

Apple (AAPL) rose 2% in above-average volume, as the stock continued to rally after finding support around 500 on Monday. But it remains about 24% off its September high. The Apple news on Tuesday included a report suggesting the company's new TV device will use gesture recognition technology, and both a setback and a victory in its legal battle with Samsung.

Among the big losers Tuesday, IBD 50 stock Sturm Ruger (RGR) and rival Smith & Wesson (SWHC) continued their recent slide, falling 9% and 11%, respectively. The two gun makers both recently formed later-stage bases, broke out and then triggered IBD's 8% sell rule. Each stock is now below its 50-day moving average and its 200-day line, dropping amid expectations of stricter gun laws following Friday's mass shooting in Newtown, Conn.
In economic news, the National Association of Home Builders said its housing market index rose to 47 in December, matching expectations and providing the best reading since April 2006.

On the fiscal-cliff front, negotiations were continuing. House Speaker John Boehner has offered a fallback plan that would prevent tax hikes for households earning $1 million or less a year, but the White House has rejected it, saying that plan won't pass the Senate.Stocks continued to march ahead in afternoon action Tuesday, reaching new session highs and then holding near them.The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Stocks hovered near session lows midday Friday and have erased about half of the prior session's gains. Spanish bank stress test results and Moody's decision on whether to downgrade Spain's government debt are still on tap. The Dow Jones industrial average, Nasdaq and S&P 500 were each down 0.7%. Turnover was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.…
Stocks extended losses Wednesday, but ended off their session lows.
Worries over the eurozone put investors on edge. Spain's economy slowed sharply in the third quarter and Spanish bond yields topped 6%. An unexpected drop in U.S. new-home sales didn't help, either.

The Nasdaq again suffered the hardest hit, falling 0.8%. But it was off by 1.2% at Wednesday's low. The S&P 500 fell 0.6% for its fifth straight loss. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3%. According to preliminary data, NYSE volume rose and Nasdaq trade fell.

Web.com Group (WWWW) trimmed an 8% loss to 4%. Intraday, the stock fell more than 8% below an 18.40 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared Tuesday. Although volume was heavy on the breakout, the stock closed under the buy point, which is usually not a good sign.

Stratasys (SSYS) slumped 4% to a two-month low. The stock closed near a 54.47 trigger from a cup-with-handle base cleared July 18. Stratasys has now erased the 35% gain from that breakout. The maker of 3D printers was recently cut from the small-cap S&P 600 index, as its pending merger with peer Objet violates certain index criteria.

Elsewhere, homebuilders fell hard one news that new-home sales eased 0.3% in August to an annual rate of 373,000 units. Economists expected a slight rise to 380,000 units. Meritage Homes (MTH) swooned 7% and Ryland Group (RYL) lost 6%.

Leaders up in volume were few, but Michael Kors (KORS) gained nearly 1% as it bounced back from two days of heavy selling. On Tuesday, the company priced a secondary offering by existing holders of 23 million shares at a discount to Monday's close. Selling shareholders include founder Michael Kors and CEO John Idol.

Data on the third-quarter GDP, initial jobless claims, durable goods and pending-home sales will be out Thursday.Stocks extended losses Wednesday, but ended off their session lows.Worries over the eurozone put investors on edge. Spain's economy slowed sharply in the third quarter and Spanish bond yields topped 6%. An unexpected drop in U.S. new-home sales didn't help, either.The Nasdaq again suffered the hardest hit, falling 0.8%. But it was off by 1.2% at Wednesday's low. The S&P 500 fell 0.6% for its fifth straight loss. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3%. According to preliminary data, NYSE volume rose and Nasdaq trade fell.Web.com Group (WWWW) trimmed an 8% loss to 4%. Intraday, the stock fell more than 8% below an 18.40 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared Tuesday. Although volume was heavy on the breakout, the stock closed under the buy point, which is usually not a good sign.Stratasys (SSYS) slumped 4% to a two-month low. The stock closed near a 54.47 trigger from a cup-with-handle base cleared July 18. Stratasys has now erased the 35% gain from that breakout. The maker of 3D printers was recently cut from the small-cap S&P 600 index, as its pending merger with peer Objet violates certain index criteria.Elsewhere, homebuilders fell hard one news that new-home sales eased 0.3% in August to an annual rate of 373,000 units. Economists expected a slight rise to 380,000 units. Meritage Homes (MTH) swooned 7% and Ryland Group (RYL) lost 6%.Leaders up in volume were few, but Michael Kors (KORS) gained nearly 1% as it bounced back from two days of heavy selling. On Tuesday, the company priced a secondary offering by existing holders of 23 million shares at a discount to Monday's close. Selling shareholders include founder Michael Kors and CEO John Idol.Data on the third-quarter GDP, initial jobless claims, durable goods and pending-home sales will be out Thursday.
Retailers posted soft March sales gains Thursday as abnormally cold weather and an early Easter dampened spending, leaving shelves bulging with spring merchandise.

March sales at stores open at least a year rose 1.4% vs. a year ago, says Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The results were roughly in line with analysts' already lowered expectations. Only 43% of retailers beat views, while 57% missed.
"But the numbers could have been worse, given the head winds some of the retailers were facing," Perkins said.
Easter holiday store closures on March 31 hurt many retailers, especially apparel chains, as they lost a weekend day of sales vs. March of last year, he says.

Retailers faced difficult weather comparisons with March 2012, when above-normal temperatures led to strong spring apparel sales. This March, abnormally cold weather and above-normal snowfalls in parts of the U.S. hurt spring clothing sales and chilled sales of lawn products and outdoor furniture.
Zumiez Zooms

But the month saw some winners. Shares of Zumiez (ZUMZ) rocketed 15.66% in midday trading as the action sports retailer posted the biggest upside surprise of the group, with a 2.1% gain in March comps vs. a year ago, ahead of forecasts for an 8% decline.

Other chains — including Victoria's Secret's parent L Brands (LTD) and off-price retail operator Ross Stores (ROST) — also saw strong stock-price gains after reporting same-store sales ahead of views. Shares of warehouse club giant Costco Wholesale (COST) and off-price retail operator TJX Cos. (TJX)also saw a nice uptick.
But overall the showing was a mixed bag.

Costco led the pack in March with a 4% rise in same-store sales, below forecasts for a 5.6% rise, as it got stung by lower fuel prices and a strong dollar. But when you look at its core business, excluding the impact of gas and international weakness on its sales, comps were roughly in line with views, Perkins says.
L Brands was among the handful of chains that beat views. It posted a 3% rise in same-store sales vs. a year ago, compared with forecasts for roughly flat sales.
Ross saw a 2% increase in March comps vs. a year earlier, besting forecasts for a 1.3% decline. CEO Michael Balmuth expects a 5% to 6% rise in April comps.
After Thursday's bell, apparel giant Gap (GPS)saw comps slip 1% from a year earlier, slightly ahead of forecasts for a 1.9% decline.

TJX saw same-store sales slip 2% in March, below forecasts for a 1.4% decline. But April is looking better. "April is off to a good start, our inventories are in great shape, and we are seeing an enormous amount of desirable product in the marketplace," said TJX CEO Carol Meyrowitz in a statement.
The specialty apparel group was the month's weakest performer, with a 0.2% decline in same-store sales.
In addition to the weather drag, retailers faced other head winds in March. Macroeconomic data softened during the month as both weekly jobless claims and non-farm payrolls weakened.
Still, Perkins isn't putting too much weight on the March results.
"The hope is it doesn't say much about consumer spending," he said. "There were some one-time mitigating circumstances taking place in March."
He says you have to look at same-store sales for March and April in tandem to determine any kind of a spending trend.

Perkins expects a sequential improvement in April from sluggish March results as consumers continue to benefit from delayed tax refunds playing catch-up, falling gas prices and an extra selling day relative to last year due to the Easter holiday calendar shift.
L Brands, Ross Stores and TJX are among those retailers expected to see April comps up in the mid-single-digit range, Perkins says.
"Hopefully, the rise in the stock market and continued uptick in home prices will lead to consumers feeling better about their net worth and spending," Perkins said.
Michael Niemira, chief economist at the International Council of Shopping Centers, also calculates that March same-store sales rose 1.4% vs. a year ago.

The cold weather blast was a drag on retailers' comps in February and March, he says. But that means some pent-up demand has been built up that could be helpful to sales of items like apparel in April.
"I am optimistic that April's numbers will have a more positive outlook, as warmer temperatures should drive demand for seasonal apparel," Niemira said.
Niemira expects April same-store sales to increase in the range of 2% to 3% vs. a year ago.
Fat Inventories

Given how slow sales have been, retail inventories should be in relatively good shape, adds Perkins. But retailers will still have to discount to clear out spring merchandise this month, which "certainly" will erode margins a bit, he says.
Overall, the environment for retailers is lukewarm.
"The hourglass/barbell situation continues onward," said Perkins.

High-end retailers — such as Michael Kors (KORS), Nordstrom  (JWN), Tiffany  (TIF)and Coach (COH) — should fare better than the rest of the group, Perkins says. He expects the lower end of the barbell — including discount chains like Costco, dollar stores and off-price retailers like TJX and Ross — to also fare better than other segments of retail.
But he sees the midtier department stores and specialty apparel chains having a little tougher time in this retail environment.

Retailers continue to face head winds. A low savings rate and slow employment growth are among them, Niemira says. And he sees a relatively "sluggish" rate of economic growth in the second, third and fourth quarters.

"As long as we're in a sluggish economic growth pattern, we can't expect a lot of growth from the retail sector," Niemira said.Retailers posted soft March sales gains Thursday as abnormally cold weather and an early Easter dampened spending, leaving shelves bulging with spring merchandise.March sales at stores open at least a year rose 1.4% vs. a year ago, says Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The makers, designers and retailers of apparel have provided one of the brighter patches in a gradually mending U.S. economy. Consumers flocked to uber-trendy clothing such as brightly colored skinny jeans and printed tops over the spring and summer, according to Retail Metrics, an industry analyst. The group reported overall apparel same-store sales in August grew 7.8% vs. 2011, beating…

Michael Kors (KORS) shares jumped 5.5% to 55.35 in early afternoon trading Friday after the fashion house increased its second-quarter and full-year profit outlook. Kors now expects profit of 38-40 cents per share in Q2, up from an earlier guidance of 33-35 cents. Analysts are expecting 36 cents. For the year the clothing maker and retailer sees EPS of $1.39-$1.41…
Stocks traded moderately higher around midday Friday, after pulling back from their session highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.2%. Volume surged across the board from Thursday's levels, boosted by quadruple witching for options and futures contracts.

Expedia (EXPE) jumped 5% in huge volume, hitting a new multiyear high and clearing a 59.60 buy point from a cup-shaped base. The online travel broker got a lift from Cantor Fitzgerald starting coverage with a buy rating, as well as Deutsche Bank upgrading the stock to a buy. Cantor Fitzgerald said Expedia was in the early stages of a turnaround and had prospects for further margin expansion. Expedia sports an IBD Composite Rating of 92 out of a best-possible 99.

Apple (AAPL) added nearly 1% in big trade, as iPhone 5 sales began and fans flocked to Apple stores around the world. The tech giant has hit a fresh all-time high and moved back above 700, after closing below that level Thursday. The stock, No. 5 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, is well extended from a 619.97 handle buy point.

Michael Kors (KORS) leapt 6% in strong turnover, nearing its all-time high. Late Thursday, the luxury accessories and clothing maker hiked its EPS target range to 38 to 40 cents, up from 33 to 35 cents and above Wall Street's expectations. It sees Q1 revenue of $510 million to $520 million, also above forecasts. Michael Kors, a December IPO that's No. 4 in Wednesday's IBD 50, is well extended past its recent entry at 49.60.

On the downside, IHS (IHS) tumbled 5% in heavy trade, sliding further below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. It plunged 18% on Thursday as its quarterly earnings missed views and its lowered outlook disappointed investors. Robert W. Baird has downgraded the research company to neutral from outperform. IHS' Composite Rating has slumped to a mediocre 73.

In economic news, Spain appeared to be making progress toward achieving reforms and gaining an EU bailout. Reuters, quoting unnamed sources, reported that Spain is considering freezing pensions and speeding up a planned rise in the retirement age to 67 from 65. A decision could be announced as early as next week.

Facebook (FB), Actavis (ACT), LinkedIn (LNKD) are atop a list of big cap companies with soaring sales growth amid a Q3 earnings season that has pointed to weak demand elsewhere, as seen in the 3.3% revenue growth among S&P 500 companies. Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, companies with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion.…
Stocks opened modestly higher in weak trade Friday after a round of lukewarm economic data.

The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial average all held 0.3% gains in early trade. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were tracking toward modest gains for the week. The Dow remained below last week's close.

Nasdaq volume slumped 25% while NYSE was down 14% compared with the the same time Thursday. First Solar (FSLR) led the Nasdaq 100 with a 6% gain. Merck (MRK) and Alcoa (AA)rose more than 1% each, leading the Dow.

Wholesale inventories expanded 0.4% in January, less than the 0.6% growth economists expected. The Census Bureau revised December's growth up slightly to 1.1%, from 1%. The February employment report showed a gain of 227,000 jobs. That was above forecasts and kept the jobless rate at 8.3%
Gold dropped 1%, to below $1,681 an ounce, following the morning's payroll report. Oil dipped a fraction, holding just below $107 a barrel.
In stocks, Sourcefire (FIRE) snapped up 3%, taking a new high in solid trade. The network security software and gear maker's gain since a breakout in February has been more than 20%.
Luxury fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) stepped up 3% and was just below its March 5 high. The December new issue has not yet paused to offer a valid buy point.

On the downside, Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) tumbled 7%, cutting its 10-week line in heavy trade. Stocks opened modestly lower Monday as they took a breather. The Nasdaq fell 0.4% and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. They had been up for five and six weeks in a row, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1%. Volume was tracking drastically lower on both major exchanges. Lowe's (LOW) was off its session low, but still down 3%.…
Stocks continued to march ahead in afternoon action Tuesday, reaching new session highs and then holding near them.
The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Volume was tracking up from Monday's level across the board.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) climbed 3% in fast trade, hitting a fresh all-time high. The stock is now about 7% beyond a 66.72 three-weeks-tight entry, meaning it's extended past a proper buying range. CommVault, a maker of database software, was No. 2 in Monday's IBD 50.

Rackspace Hosting (RAX) jumped 6% in big turnover, clearing a 70.10 buy point from a handle. A Bloomberg report late Monday said the cloud computing company and related firms might become acquisition targets. Rackspace has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a best-possible 99.

Apple (AAPL) rose 2% in above-average volume, as the stock continued to rally after finding support around 500 on Monday. But it remains about 24% off its September high. The Apple news on Tuesday included a report suggesting the company's new TV device will use gesture recognition technology, and both a setback and a victory in its legal battle with Samsung.

Among the big losers Tuesday, IBD 50 stock Sturm Ruger (RGR) and rival Smith & Wesson (SWHC) continued their recent slide, falling 9% and 11%, respectively. The two gun makers both recently formed later-stage bases, broke out and then triggered IBD's 8% sell rule. Each stock is now below its 50-day moving average and its 200-day line, dropping amid expectations of stricter gun laws following Friday's mass shooting in Newtown, Conn.
In economic news, the National Association of Home Builders said its housing market index rose to 47 in December, matching expectations and providing the best reading since April 2006.

On the fiscal-cliff front, negotiations were continuing. House Speaker John Boehner has offered a fallback plan that would prevent tax hikes for households earning $1 million or less a year, but the White House has rejected it, saying that plan won't pass the Senate.Stocks continued to march ahead in afternoon action Tuesday, reaching new session highs and then holding near them.The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. The market stumbled Thursday after three days of little movement, taking down nearly all Sector Leaders. Web.com Group (WWWW) bucked the sell-off, gaining 0.19 to 16.44. The stock has now risen for three straight sessions, but volume has been light the entire time. Generally, stocks that rise in a down market should be given attention as they're showing uncanny strength.…

The best companies reward investors' confidence, and their cash, with strong profits. Return on equity — the amount of net income they're producing as a percentage of shareholders' equity — is a key measure of financial efficiency. The higher, the better.
Specialty chemical firm W.R. Grace (GRA) tops today's financial efficiency Screen of the Day list at No. 38.

Chinese search giant Baidu (BIDU) follows at 57.3% ROE. The Google (GOOG)-like company dominates in its home country. But it's branching out, developing technology and services for Southeast Asian languages.
Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), No. 7 on the IBD 50 list, has an ROE of 56.2%. Barclays Capital on Monday initiated coverage of the fashion house with an overweight rating.
The Fresh Market (TFM) shows an ROE of 52.8%. The upscale, small-format grocery chain is No. 11 on the IBD 50 list.

Discount flier Spirit Airlines (SAVE) also sports a 52.8% ROE. The firm was the topic of a New America profile last week.The best companies reward investors' confidence, and their cash, with strong profits. Shares of fashion watch retailer Movado Group (MOV) jumped 19% in early trading, touching a new high, after the watch retailer reported profit results that topped analyst expectations, and raised its full-year sales outlook.
But Brown Shoe's (BWS) shares slid after the trendy footwear maker reported disappointing results.
In midday trading, Movado shares were up about 17.5% to 35.41, while Brown Shoe's stock had fallen 9% to 14.05.

Shares of PVH (PVH), which sells fashionable apparel under Tommy Hilfiger and other brands, on Monday beat profit and sales views, as EPS climbed 17% to 1.25. Shares were up 5% to 93.04 Tuesday afternoon.

Elsewhere in the luxury goods market, women's apparel boutique operator Francesca's (FRAN), ranked No. 1 on the IBD 50 list of top stocks, was up 0.6% and luxury clothing and shoe chain Michael Kors (KORS) advanced 1% to 54.10. Kors has soared since it went public at 25 a share in December.
Movado markets watches ranging from $59 to more than $1,000, including high-end Movado, mid-range Hugo Boss and fashion brand Tommy Hilfiger.
The company said customers trended toward its fashion and luxury brands, as EPS jumped 100% to 32 cents, well ahead of consensus for 18-cents-a-share profit.
Sales edged up 4% to $118 million, falling shy of analysts' projections of $122 million.
Brown Shoe reported EPS of 16 cents, vs. a 6-cent-a-share loss in the same quarter last year, topping views for a 3-cent profit.
Consumers have continued to trend to high-quality items despite global economic uncertainty and continuing high unemployment in the U.S.
Brown Shoe sells footwear targeted largely to fashion-conscious women at more than 1,300 stores, including its Famous Footwear and Naturalizer chains.
But revenue slid 4.5% to $599.8 million, below analysts' forecast of $606.3 million.

Brown Shoe forecast full-year earnings of 85-95 cents a share. The midpoint is roughly in line with views of 89 cents.

Earnings reports from Ralph Lauren (RL) and Hanesbrands (HBI) on Wednesday will give investors a clearer picture of how premium apparel retailers fared during the holiday selling season.
Ralph Lauren is expected to report a 17% jump in EPS as sales edged up 2.2% to $2.45 billion when it reports fiscal third-quarter earnings before the market opens.
Leather goods maker Coach (COH) and Tiffany & Co. (TIF) earlier reported wary consumers, with both reporting that sales rose just 4% year over year last quarter.

Wall Street's outlook for Hanesbrands, a maker of underwear, T-shirts and casual wear, is for earnings to soar 146% to $1.01 per share when it reports late Wednesday. The company earlier said it expects $1 to $1.06 per share. Revenue, however, is forecast to grow a mild 0.6% to $1.152 billion from $1.145 billion.

In December, Hanes used cash to buy back $250 million in bonds to reduce debt, and it plans to cut interest expense further this year by repaying half of its remaining $500 million of 8% senior notes due in 2016, a year earlier than expected. The clothier is trading just 2% off its all-time intraday high of 38.80 set on Jan. 28.
Hanes sees EPS of $3 to $3.25 for the full year 2013. That's below analyst guidance of $3.33 EPS this year, although Hanes may lift its guidance when it reports.
Some luxury and trendy clothing and accessories makers have performed well over the holidays. Michael Kors (KORS) is ranked No. 18 among the IBD Top 50 list of best-performing stocks.
Kors went public in December 2011 at 20 a share. Its stock has climbed 175% since then on steadily rising sales and profits.

PVH (PVH), which sells under Van Heusen, Izod and other brands, is trading just 3% off its 52-week high and sports an IBD Composite Rating of 92, meaning it's outperformed 92 % of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. IBD recommends stocks with an IBD rating of 95 or higher for investor stock-watch lists.

Carter's (CRI), a maker of babies' and children's clothing under the Carter's and Oshkosh brands, hit an all-time high Friday and also has a 92 Composite Rating. Two words are key when considering initial public offerings.
Calm down.

When a new IPO hits the market, the investor is often anxious to buy. The fear is that the stock will soar before the investor can grab shares. So, why not buy immediately? Isn't IBD's advice to wait for an IPO base too conservative?
The short answer: No. Occasionally, the "buy now and ask questions later" approach will work. But that's relying on luck, not a probabilities-driven strategy.

The questions you should ask first, not later, are: Is the company making money? If not, why would you buy it? If it is profitable, is it a turnaround story or a proven winner quarter after quarter, year after year? Is it thinly traded? Do institutions want this stock? Has it formed an IPO base?

When Google (GOOG) debuted on the Nasdaq in August 2004, it was already growing earnings and sales fast. Daily trade was in the millions. Funds were piling in. And the stock formed and broke out of an IPO base about four weeks after its issue.

The IPO base wouldn't be considered long enough in a more mature stock. As "How to Make Money in Stocks" points out, what you're looking for in the IPO is "the breakout from its first correction and base-building area."
Two IPOs recently appeared in the Spotlight screen.

Laredo Petroleum Holdings (LPI) turned profitable in 2010 after four years of net losses. Return on equity was 25% last year. But Laredo is thinly traded, moving less than 200,000 shares most days since its mid-December debut. No IPO base has emerged.

Apparel maker Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) grew earnings 200% and 81% in the past two fiscal years ended in March. Daily trade has been above 400,000 most days since its mid-December debut. No IPO base has yet formed.Two words are key when considering initial public offerings.Calm down.When a new IPO hits the market, the investor is often anxious to buy. Stocks rose for the fourth time in the past five sessions as volume picked up on both major exchanges Wednesday.
The Nasdaq and the NYSE composite each tacked on 0.3%, while the S&P 500 added 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume was up about 6% on the Nasdaq and NYSE, according to preliminary data.
The indexes gapped up at the open on news from Europe. Germany's high court ruled that Berlin's approval of a bailout fund for debt-ridden European Union nations was not unconstitutional.

This news, however, was expected, and the indexes hit their highs for the day in the first 10 to 20 minutes of trade. The rest of the session involved action within a fairly tight range and closes in the mid to upper half.
Among top-rated stocks, three stocks rose for every two that fell.
Apple (AAPL) gained 1% in volume that was 77% above average. The company unveiled a thinner and faster iPhone 5.
Visa (V) cleared a 132.68 buy point in a base-on-base pattern, but volume was only 23% above average. The stock added 1.5%. Generally, a breakout should have volume at least 40% above average.
On the downside, upscale apparel marketer Michael Kors (KORS) slipped for a third straight session. The stock is now 6% off a high it notched Friday.

Among IBD's 197 industry groups, laggards showed the best gains. Cement, office supplies and solar stocks notched good gains. The day's biggest losers were mostly defensive groups — tobacco, soft-drink beverages and dairy products.
Brent crude oil inched up 0.1% while West Texas Intermediate oil fell 0.3%. Copper and gold were flat, but silver stepped back 0.6%.

On Thursday, the Federal Reserve will wrap up its two-day meeting. British fashion brand Burberry warned on its earnings for the year, and some analysts are worried that the luxury spending boom could be over.
The fashion house best known for its raincoats featuring a camel, red and black check pattern said it sees full-year profit at the low end of its guidance of $652 million-$722 million.
The news rattled luxury brands in the U.S., with Ralph Lauren (RL) falling 3% to 155.54 intraday and Tiffany & Co. (TIF) dipping 1% to 62.35
Coach (COH) slid 2% to 61.21 after Brean Murray downgraded it to hold from buy.

Luxury was the first retail group to rebound from the recession as the upper class in the U.S. emerged from the recession relatively unscathed. High-end brands turned to emerging markets like China to make up for any lag in U.S. and European sales.
But now, growth in China is slowing and analysts are worried Burberry and others will see a large drop in sales.
Hong Kong-based Michael Kors (KORS) was down about 2% to 52.65.
Burberry said same-store sales, or sales in stores open for over a year, were flat, after a 6% rise in the previous quarter.

But Burberry's gloomy outlook is not shared by all luxury shops. Stocks swept lower early Friday in reaction to a setback on the fiscal cliff and the increased odds for an economic downturn after Jan. 1.
The Nasdaq slumped 1.4%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.9% each.
Volume exploded on quadruple witching expirations of options and futures.

Worries that spending cuts and higher taxes may go into effect increased after House Speaker John Boehner suffered a setback late Thursday. His plan for taxes on those earning more than $1 million a year did not even get to a vote, as Republicans rebelled against any tax increases.

The University of Michigan said consumer sentiment shifted lower in December, as it revised its Consumer Sentiment Index down to 72.9. It was the lowest in at least five months, and well short of analyst forecasts for 75.

Among stocks on the Dow, only Bank of America (BAC) slipped more than 2%, while about 20% of Nasdaq 100 stocks fell 2% or more. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 remained up more than 1%, so far, for the week.

On the IBD 50, 3D Systems (DDD) and Michael Kors (KORS) dropped more than 4% each in opening trade. SodaStream (SODA) was the only other IBD 50 stock to drop more than 3%. Most quickly began trimming their initial losses.

Michael Kors remained down 4% in heavy trade. The Hong Kong-based fashion designer has been trading sideways since late September, attempting to hold support at its 10-week line as it builds the right side of a base.

Open source software maker Red Hat (RHT) jumped 5% after meeting analyst expectations for Q4 earnings, and easily topping views for revenue growth. The gap-up lifted shares back above their inverted 40-week moving average. Not all large companies are lumbering investments. They tend to be less volatile than smaller companies, and some big caps can offer the liquidity for investors to easily get in and out while still offering robust profit growth and stock gains.IBD's Big Cap Leaders Screen of the Day features companies that are large enough to offer liquidity but still poised for growth.The elite IBD 50 list ranks companies based on superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.Here are the top 5 IBD 50 stocks featured on the Big Cap screen.The biotech Celgene (CELG) is ranked No. 7 on the IBD 50 list. Last week the company reported a 26% jump in EPS to $1.32, in line with recently raised expectations. Sales rose 14% to $1.42 bil, just shy of views.Shares jumped 16% from Jan. 7-15 after the company gave upbeat 2013 guidance and a bullish outlook to 2017. It also announced positive results of late-stage trials for their drug to treat the skin disease psoriasis.Michael Kors (KORS), the affordable-luxury fashion house, is ranked No. 8 on the IBD 50. The company was one of the most successful IPOs in recent years, but the namesake designer, Michael Kors, has been a leading figure in the fashion world for decades.On Friday, Kors reached a new closing high. On Monday, the stock tried to break out but then fizzled to end lower. Shares dipped Tuesday.ARM Holdings (ARMH) is ranked No. 15 on the IBD 50 list. The U.K.-based company licenses its microprocessor designs to chipmakers and other tech companies, mostly to run wireless devices. ARM chips are found in Apple (AAPL) products like the iPhone and iPad. But ARM is not completely tied to Apple's fortunes.Apple shares have fallen nearly 35% from their closing high of 702.10 on Sept. 19, last week reporting its first EPS decline in nearly a decade. ARM shares have soared 45% during the same time. The stock rose 1% Tuesday, consolidating slightly below its Jan. 14 peak.The world's largest payment processor, Visa (V), is ranked No. 22. The company has posted double-digit revenue and profit growth every year since going public in 2008 and its shares have more than doubled, hitting a new intraday high on Jan. 10. Visa shares edged higher Tuesday, not far off their peak.Visa reports earnings next week. Its rival MasterCard (MA) reports Thursday. Analysts expect MasterCard to report faster growth, ending a four-quarter string of slowing earnings and revenue growth.BlackRock (BLK) rounds out the top five at No. 26. On Jan. 17, the world's largest money manager reported a 24% jump in Q4 profit as consumer confidence on stocks rose. Total assets under management rose 8% to a record $3.8 trillion. Its iShares division is the leader in ETF assets.BlackRock hit a 3-year closing high Tuesday, very close to an all-time best.Related:Oracle Leads 4 Top Tech Stocks With Bolting RS LinesIBD 50 Earnings: Seagate, MasterCard Lead Elite 7

Jinko Solar (JKS) dropped 9%, slicing through its 200-day and 50-day lines. It reports earnings Nov. 19. SunPower (SPWR) fell 7%.NetEase (NTES), Avolon Holdings (AVOL), Tower Semiconductor (TSEM) and ADT (ADT) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Consumer spending rose in July despite high unemployment and economic uncertainty in Europe. U.S. shoppers are ready to open their wallets again to buy new clothing and beauty products, recent results suggest. Designer brand Michael Kors (KORS), big in handbags, posted strong Q1 earnings in mid-August, and the Gap (GPS) said August same-store sales rose 9%.

Francesca's (FRAN), No. 1 on the IBD 50 list, operates small boutique-style stores across the U.S. The apparel retailer stays up to the minute with fashion, and only buys merchandise for delivery no more than 90 days out to ensure the styles are fresh.
Analysts are expecting Francesca's to report a 60% jump in second-quarter earnings to 24 cents per share when it reports Tuesday. Sales are seen rising 38.8% to $71.09 million.
Francesca's debuted in July 2011. It closed at a new high of 36.28 on Aug. 29.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA), an operator of one-stop beauty supply shops, is ranked No. 19 on the IBD 50 list. Ulta offers both bargain items like Herbal Essences shampoo that can be found at local drugstores and high-end products — prestige brands like Redken hair care products — only offered at department stores and salons.
Ulta owes some of its success to the prestige-brand spending. According to the NPD group, high-end brand spending on beauty products rose 11% to $9.5 billion in 2011.
Analysts are expecting Ulta to report a 34% rise in EPS to 51 cents when it reports earnings on Thursday. Wall Street sees sales climbing 20% to $473.8 million.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) will report earnings on Friday. Shares of the Canadian yoga and athletic gear retailer fell sharply in late June on speculation that notorious short-seller David Einhorn had taken a short position on the company. The stock tumbled again in early August but has been on the uptick since, crossing its 50-day moving average in mid-August.
Analysts are expecting Lulu to report a 19% rise in EPS to 31 cents. Sales are seen rising 32.9% to $282.26 million.

Stocks closed high in the day's range Thursday but still lost ground. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. The S&P 500 inched down less than 0.1%. The IBD 50 eased 0.2%. Volume fell across the board. Lighter volume prevented the losses from becoming distribution days. The market remains with a tolerable amount of such higher-volume losses,…

Sector Leaders showed mixed results Tuesday, reflecting well the broad market's mixed close. Apple (AAPL) rose 1.92 to 661.31 as volume jumped 44% above its average pace. The stock opened firm and had climbed 1% in fast trade, then slid to loss territory in the afternoon. But some buying in the last 15 minutes pushed Apple back over Monday's close.…
Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq added less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 split the difference, up 0.2%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, up 5% on the Nasdaq and 8% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The top-line number in the Commerce Department's May durable goods report showed a 1.8% decline and a downward revision to April's number to minus 1.5%. Economists had forecast a more mild 0.6% slip. The bulk of the miss was apparently due to a sharp decline in aircraft orders during the month. Minus transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.5% — in line with expectations. So far this year, durable goods orders are running 2.2% below last year's January to May period.

Housing prices improved steadily in May, lifting the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index 0.3%. That increase was equal to March's increase but just below consensus forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Year over year, the index is up 5.3%.

New home sales popped in May to an annualized rate of 546,000, according to the Commerce Department. That was up from April's (upwardly revised) 534,000 pace, well above consensus expectations of 525,000 and the strongest number since Feb. 2008.

A bit less rosy was the preliminary June manufacturing estimate from researcher Markit. Its Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index was at 53.4, down from May's 53.8 number and below forecasts for an increase to 54.2. The number points to a third month of slowing activity and is the gauge's weakest gain in 18 months.
In stocks, it was a good morning for Florida-based companies.

Darden Restaurants (DRI) rose 3% to lead the S&P 500 by a wide margin. The Orlando-based owner of the Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains reported healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results and announced plans to slice off a portion of its real estate assets into a separate real estate investment trust. The stock popped to a new high, paring some gains but holding just above a cup-base buy point of 70.48.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) pecked out a 2% gain, the best increase among Nasdaq 100 stocks. The Fort Lauderdale-headquartered software developer is still in buying range, 4% above a 69.33 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Among leaders, most of the IBD 50 list posted modest gains and losses — with a couple of dramatic exceptions.

Ambarella (AMBA) led the list with a 9% rebound. The stock tumbled 21% Monday, following a short-seller's report on Friday that questioned the stock's valuation. The stock remains extended after a mid-May rebound from 10-week support and is well above its 10-week moving average.

At the bottom of the group, burger joint Sonic (SONC) dived 11% in massive trade. Fiscal third quarter sales and profits met consensus expectations, but full-year earnings guidance didn't. The sell-off stopped at a test of the stock's 10-week moving average, seriously damaging efforts to shape a three-month cup base.Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The market's bounce Friday spawned dozens of 52-week highs, including breakouts among two leading health care stocks. Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) surged 4.69 to 83.32 in heavy trading, clearing the 81.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. The company said the Food and Drug Administration has approved Watson's generic version of Endo's Lidoderm, a patch for relief of shingles-associated pain. In…

Youth isn't always wasted on the young. With earnings season about to kick off in full force, a slew of young, nimble firms are expected to show stellar earnings growth. IBD's Screen Of The Day — Young Guns — focuses on highly ranked firms that have come public within the last 15 years. Stocks often make their biggest prices moves…

Stocks traded in flat to slightly positive territory in early-afternoon action Friday, as they digested Thursday's solid advance. The Nasdaq added 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 was about flat. Options expirations boosted volume, which rose sharply from Thursday's level for the NYSE, but was down slightly for the Nasdaq. For…

Stocks continued to show sizable losses in early-afternoon action Friday, hurt by the House's failure late Thursday to pass Speaker John Boehner's Plan B for averting the fiscal cliff. The Nasdaq lost 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.3%. Volume surged across the board from Thursday's levels, boosted by quadruple witching expirations of options and…
Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. Strong sales of leather handbags, watches and jewelry propelled Michael Kors  (KORS) ahead of earnings estimates, with huge same-store sales growth in its first public earnings report Tuesday.

The luxury apparel and accessory retailer said its wholesale, retail and licensing divisions all saw growth, and it remains bullish going forward, on the spending strength of its more affluent clientele.
Michael Kors shares rocketed to fresh highs, rising 27.5% to 42.85. They debuted at 20 in December.

The fashion house reported earnings of 20 cents per share in its fiscal third quarter — 28 cents excluding one-time items. Analysts expected 9 cents. Revenue surged 68% to $373.6 million. Sales at stores open more than a year climbed 38% in North America and 34% in Europe.
Michael Kors sees fourth-quarter EPS of 10 to 12 cents on revenue of $350 million to $355 million. Analysts expect 11 cents per share on $347.4 million in sales.
The firm guided same-store sales growth of 25% to 30%. Margins would be slightly tighter due to markdowns, partially offset by a sales shift to higher-margin retail stores, the company said.

"The luxury segment continues to grow globally, and our positioning as an American lifestyle luxury brand will enable us to continue our global expansion," CEO John Idol said in a conference call with analysts.
Michael Kors is named after its founder — a fashion designer and "Project Runway" reality show judge. It sells $300 purses, $500 suede jumpsuits, and other must-haves for young aspirational buyers.
It ended the quarter with 231 retail stores, up from 156 a year ago. Retail sales climbed 83% to $199.4 million.
Michael Kors is headquartered in Hong Kong, but its products are sold in 2,300 department stores and other retailers in the U.S. and Europe. Wholesale division sales climbed 55% to $154.6 million.
Royalty revenue grew 44% to $19.6 million.
The quarter benefited from a slight shift to higher-margin retail and European sales.
Europe's economic woes have not hurt, the company said. And rising commodity costs had a minimal impact

The brand is still building awareness and cache, said Robert W. Baird analyst Erika Maschmeyer. And new products keep existing customers coming back. "They're finding incremental ways to get women to open their pocketbooks," she said.
Also Tuesday, watch and accessory retailer Fossil (FOSL) beat earnings forecasts and rocketed 15% to 119.82, a six-month high.
Fossil supplies Michael Kors with its branded watches that retail for $150 to $500. Fossil also supplies necklaces, bracelets and other jewelry that Michael Kors sells for $45 to $400.
Kors said jewelry sales are on track to reach the targeted 5% of sales at its free-standing stores.
"We don't know how high is high because we ran out of product, quite frankly," Idol said in the conference call.

Luxury handbag and accessories maker and retailer Coach (COH) rose fractionally to a fresh high. Stocks pushed into new high ground with modest gains Friday on news that the economy added a good deal more nonfarm jobs than had been expected.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each added 0.4%. But volume on the stock market today declined slightly on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.

The economy added 236,000 nonfarm jobs last month, the Department of Labor said in its much-awaited report. That was a 98% increase from January's downwardly revised report and 31% higher than the 180,000 new jobs forecast by analysts.

Investors had already seen positive omens for this report the past few days. The ADP report Wednesday and the weekly report on jobless claims Thursday both showed signs that the U.S. labor market is on the mend.
The job gains pushed the unemployment rate to 7.7% from 7.9%, also better than expected.
Average hourly earnings ticked up 0.2%, in line with expectations. And the average workweek inched up to 34.5 hours, topping expectations for no change from January's 34.4 hours.

U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA), which has been on a tear, shot up 3% in almost twice its usual volume. The stock is now extended 22% above its 21.60 buy point from a cup with handle. It's also extended from a rebound off its 10-week moving average. The company makes the glass, fillers, ceramics and chemicals that frackers use to extract oil and natural gas.

Contact lens maker Cooper (COO) jumped 3% to a new high in heavy volume on a well-received quarterly report. The stock is extended 7% from a 101.02 buy point from a saucer base-on-base pattern. But Cooper's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is a neutral C, indicating a standoff between buyers and sellers.

"Affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) reversed higher from its early 2% loss to end the day nearly flat. The session's low was met by the stock's uptrending 10-week moving average. This follows Thursday's session, which saw the stock fall 5% in fast trade. Friday's reversal sparked barely above-average action. Michael Kors is flirting with its 58.72 buy point from a cup.

Online bank BOFI Holding (BOFI) rose 2% in almost double-paced trade, scoring a new high. The thinly traded stock is extended from a 28.10 buy point. BOFI's Relative Strength line has risen sharply, indicating the stock is easily outperforming the S&P 500.

Tempur-Pedic International (TPX) gapped up and surged 6% in torrid action on news that the Federal Trade Commission gave its approval for the company's $229 million acquisition of Sealy (ZZ). Tempur-Pedic shares are up 118% from a June low, after correcting 76% from April to June.

Fashion retailer Ann (ANN) gapped up and jumped 8% in more than twice its average volume. The New York-based chain reported Q4 earnings well above views — but revenue barely missed. The move wedged the stock just above its 50-day line and just below its 200-day. Ann rose from near the bottom of a five-month correction.

Alaska Air Group (ALK) added 3% in barely above-average volume. Stocks continued to trade well off their worst levels late Wednesday. The Nasdaq was off by 0.5%. It has pared more than half of its intraday loss. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% and was on pace for its fifth straight loss. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2%. Turnover was tracking higher across the board, but only slightly higher…

The best foreign stocks are doing what any great stocks should be doing in a broad-market uptrend — they're rising, usually leading the way. Foreign banks put in stellar gains Monday, then cooled off Tuesday. Banco Santander Mexico (BSMX), which debuted four months ago at 12.18 per share, surged 4% Monday, then fell 2% Tuesday. Volume was a no-show both…

Retailers had a mixed holiday season, with standouts and washouts in terms of sales and stocks. Here are the top five holiday-related retailers from Nov. 16 — the Friday before the Thanksgiving week — through Jan. 14, according to an IBD analysis. (The list only focuses on stocks with a Composite Rating of at least 80 and a current price above 10.)

The top holiday-related stock in the IBD analysis was Vipshop Holdings (VIPS), a Chinese online retailer. The recent IPO has surged more than 206% since its March debut. Shares soared 73.6% in the Nov. 16 through Jan. 14 holiday span.
Vipshop's holiday season may just be getting started, with the upcoming Chinese New Year.
The rest of the list is made up of more traditional holiday plays.

Watch and accessories maker Fossil (FOSL) leapt 23.7% in that same holiday span. It rebounded from a sharp fall earlier in the year after missing first-quarter earnings and warning of sluggishness in Europe and elsewhere. Its shares still managed a 17.3% gain for 2012. Fossil, which has its own stores, also supplies the upscale fashion brand and retailer Michael Kors (KORS) with watches and jewelry. Kors offered up a more modest 8.2% gain during the Nov. 16-Jan. 14 period.

Shares of Urban Outfitters (URBN) climbed 20.5% over that same holiday window. Just last week, the hipster clothier said November-December sales were up 15%, thanks to strong online sales. The company's shares surged 42.8% last year and are up more than 8% so far this month.

The warehouse bulk retailer Costco Wholesale (COST) rose 20.2% during the holiday span measured by IBD. Costco was one of the leaders in a mixed pack of retailers who reported December same-store sales. Its shares have climbed 29.9% in 2012, and were up another 2% so far in January, near new highs.

Lithia Motors (LAD) sells new and used cars from 87 dealerships in 11 states. Its shares surged 18.4% during the holidays. Turn on a TV during the holidays, and it never takes long to see a slew of holiday-themed car commercials.

On Tuesday, the Commerce Department said auto sales rose 1.6% in December, as Detroit and foreign automakers closed out their best year since 2007. Overall December retail sales rose a solid 0.5% vs. November.
Lithia shares climbed 71% in 2012. They're up 2.6% so far this year, though the shares have come down from all-time highs reached earlier this month.

Stocks were again lower in afternoon trading Friday, with techs faring the worst.

Hurt by weakness in chip issues, the Nasdaq dropped 0.8%. The Philadelphia semiconductor fell 1.6%. Apple (AAPL), which accounts for 11.5% of the Nasdaq, swooned 2% on disappointing iPhone 5 sales. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 slipped 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.2%. Turnover continued to track vastly lower across the board.

Michael Kors (KORS) lost almost 4% and gave back a little less than half of its gain from the prior session. The stock jumped 9% to a new high Friday in reaction to late Thursday's raised outlook. Despite the pullback, Michael Kors is still 12% past a 49.60 buy point from a cup base.

Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) fell nearly 4% in heavy trading. The stock erased Friday's move and appeared headed for another test of its 50-day line, where it has found support in recent sessions. Mellanox has been bouncing back after falling on news that its chief financial officer would retire in early November.

Stratasys (SSYS) dropped 3% in brisk trading, extending last week's loss. The slide puts it just 4% past a 54.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared July 18. Stratasys' gain was as big as 35%. The stock was recently removed from the small cap S&P 600 index.

On the upside, Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) reversed earlier losses and climbed 2% to a brand new high. The upside reversal puts the November IPO 38% past a 28.91 in a cup-with-handle base cleared July 5. The fertilizer maker has posted three straight quarters of triple-digit profit growth. Analysts are expecting another in the current period.Stocks were again lower in afternoon trading Friday, with techs faring the worst.Hurt by weakness in chip issues, the Nasdaq dropped 0.8%.
