The Nasdaq added 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 was about flat. Options expirations boosted volume, which rose sharply from Thursday's level for the NYSE, but was down slightly for the Nasdaq. For…

High unemployment has kept consumers cautious overall at home and overseas. But a number of leading firms in the IBD 50 have remained trendy for shoppers and investors. Now with some hopeful economic news, these top stocks are well positioned for any uptick in spending. IBD 50 stocks Francesca's (FRAN), Ross Stores (ROST) and Apple (AAPL) have done well during…

Stocks continued to show mostly mild losses at midafternoon Monday, as turnover remained down sharply from Friday's levels. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped a fraction, the S&P 500 edged down 0.2% and the Nasdaq lost 0.6%. Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) lost 8% in huge turnover, but it had been down as much as 14.5%. It's finding support near its 50-day…
Stocks were still in the red, but have worked off some losses Monday afternoon.

The Nasdaq trimmed an earlier 0.5% loss to 0.2%. Apple (AAPL), which makes up about 11% of the index, was still up 2% in big volume. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Turnover continued to track sharply lower on both major exchanges.

Michael Kors (KORS) reversed from a new high and fell 2% in below-average volume. It's now 4% past a 49.60 trigger in a cup-without-handle base cleared Aug. 14 on stellar Q2 results. On that day, the luxury-goods maker and retailer smashed expectations with earnings that surged 162% and sales that climbed 71%.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) gave up early gains, lost 2% and breached its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is consolidating in a new base, but it's a late-stage pattern. Ulta Beauty reports Q2 results Sept. 6. Analysts see profit rising 34% to 51 cents a share, which would mark the third straight period of deceleration.

On the upside, Stratasys (SSYS) rallied nearly 3% to an all-time high in brisk trade. That puts it 29% past a 54.47 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. The stock broke out July 18 and climbed more than 20% in less than three weeks, triggering a key IBD rule. The rule states that stocks that gain 20% or more in three weeks or less should be held for at least eight weeks, unless sell signals appear.

Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) trimmed an earlier 5% gain to less than 1%. Despite this, it's still 5% past a 32.69 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Francesca's, which operates women's boutiques, has delivered accelerating earnings growth for three straight quarters. Analysts see its profit rising 60% for the year.

Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI) was also off its session peak, but still up 2% in fast trade. Earlier, the stock cleared a 44.70 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Texas Capital broke out from a flat base in June. Texas Capital provides financial services to businesses and private clients. It specializes in loans in the $10 million to $250 million range. Foreign stocks enjoyed the ride as well as U.S. names amid the relief felt by the fiscal deal reached in Washington. Today we'll revisit some of the U.S.-listed foreign stocks mentioned in this column in recent months.SodaStream International (SODA) gapped up 4% and stretched further from a 43.10 cup-with-handle entry.The Israel-based do-it-yourself soda machine maker has caused a sensation in the U.S. market; earnings grew 57%, 37% and 58% in the past three quarters, and double-digit growth is likely to continue in Q4.Oil & gas contract driller Ensco (ESV) gapped up and flew 4% in below-average action. Ensco's daily chart shows a breakout Dec. 18 from a cup with handle. But the 59.40 buy point triggered no special volume, and the stock has since moved above and below that buy point as if it had no significance. Maybe it doesn't.Ensco's weekly chart reveals a flat base with a buy point at 61.58. Will this base work? Let price-and-volume action be your guide.Banco Santander Mexico (BSMX) reversed lower in low volume, giving up its earlier 3% burst. Still, the September 2012 IPO stands 10% above its 14.87 flat-base buy point. Its solid Accumulation-Distribution Rating of A is a sign that institutions are still buying this stock.Toyota Motor (TM), the world's biggest carmaker, added 3% to its recent torrid gains. Toyota ended the session 11% above its 86.30 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern, and 15% above its 83.83 buy point from a flat base.In addition to relief from the U.S. fiscal crisis, Toyota was one of many Japanese manufacturers that lurched higher as the yen lurched lower. The dollar rose to 87.23 Japanese yen Wednesday, its highest since July 2010.Toyota's ADR pays a dividend that comes to an annual yield of 1.5% at current prices.Another dividend-paying stock, Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM), gapped up and surged 5% in average volume. The stock launched from a rebound off its 10-week moving average as well as from its 17.57 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Taiwan Semi has a dividend yield of 2.3%.Michael Kors (KORS) logged a small gain in rapid trade, and saw its stab at regaining its 50-day line come up short. But the stock was trading off as much as 2% before clawing back. Michael Kors was mentioned in a Motley Fool piece that questions its ability to continue its stellar same-store sales growth and, by extension, its high price-earnings ratio.India's HDFC Bank (HDB) is trying to halt a recent slide since clearing its 39.42 flat-base entry Nov. 21. The stock rose 1% to 41.19 in above-average trade.

Visions of sugar plums, or perhaps big screen TVs, danced in consumers' heads, but credit cards remained in their wallets. Early reports suggest a lackluster holiday shopping season, without many of the big-ticket items and pricier splurges that made Christmas sales in recent years merry for retailers.

Same-store sales rose just 0.7% for the week that ended Dec. 22, the International Council of Shopping Centers said Wednesday. ICSC is still holding to its comparable sales forecast of 3% for the November-December holiday shopping season.

But a report from MasterCard Advisors pegged the sales bump for the eight weeks leading up to Christmas at just 0.7%, compared with a 2% bump that same period last year. It's the slowest growth since the 5.5% decline MasterCard's SpendingPulse noted in 2008, when the economy was mired in recession.
'No Real Joy'
With improvements in the housing market, and the economy seeming to improve, analysts expected busier cash registers.

"There seemed to be no real joy this holiday season or buzz out there in retail land," Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, told IBD. Perkins said he now expects "ho-hum" results, with maybe a 2% bump in sales at stores open at least a year.

Investors weren't in the buying mood either, especially for luxury goods. Fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) fell nearly 7% in heavy volume Wednesday. Leather handbags, accessories maker and retailer Coach (COH) slid 6%. Ralph Lauren (RL) lost about 4%.
Shares of discount giants Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Target (TGT) dipped about 1%.
"I was wandering around on the 24th and there weren't a lot of people in the stores. Parking lots weren't overly full," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors.

There were many contributing factors. Unemployment has edged lower, but remains high. Superstorm Sandy devastated parts of the Northeast at the end of October. Unseasonably warm weather in parts of the U.S. hurt outerwear sales, while heavy snows right before Christmas socked in many in the Midwest.
Then there was the tragic Newtown school shooting, which shattered the holiday spirit of many.
Pull It Forward

Naroff thinks retailers' earlier start to the holiday also pulled sales forward. Many retailers opened on Thanksgiving, rather than waiting until the traditional Black Friday. Christmas decorations and music in stores started even earlier.

Shoppers who waited until the last minute may have been spooked by the fiscal deadlock in Washington. Taxes will go up, and some have forecast another recession, if President Obama and GOP lawmakers can't settle on a deal before the new year.
Online retailers felt the slowdown too.
MasterCard data showed online spending up 8.4%, a more muted pace than the double-digit growth of recent years.
Amazon.com (AMZN) shares slid 4% Wednesday. EBay (EBAY) fell 2%.
The iPad Mini was seen as a rare "must have" item, but Apple (AAPL) shares fell more than 1%, back near recent 10-month lows.

The holiday season isn't over yet. Retailers typically get an echo as consumers cash in gift cards and trade in items. But the slower pre-holiday traffic could signal larger margin-eroding inventory clearance sales.Visions of sugar plums, or perhaps big screen TVs, danced in consumers' heads, but credit cards remained in their wallets. Stocks turned mixed at midafternoon Monday, with the Nasdaq showing a fractional gain after being down as much as 0.5% in the morning. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average remained in the red but off their session lows, with the Dow down 0.6% and the S&P 500 off 0.5%. Volume has been tracking up from Friday's levels, but…
Prognosticators think retail sales grew modestly in September, though some IBD 50 stocks likely outpaced the pack.

Retail Metrics predicts sales at major chain stores open at least a year climbed 1.4% in September. Factoring out the expected drag from drugstores, the data-tracking firm predicts 3.5% growth when the data are reported Thursday.
Luxury brand Michael Kors (KORS), No. 3 on the IBD 50, doesn't report out monthly same-store figures. But it's seen posting a 37.1% gain for the second quarter when it reports on Nov. 13.
It tops Retail Metrics' ranking of firms with expected biggest September or current-quarter bumps.
Yoga clothier Lululemon Athletica (LULU) is expected to show a 14.3% gain in its Q2. Lulu is No. 13 on the IBD 50.
Women's boutique chain Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), No. 19 on the IBD 50, is expected to report strong 12% growth for its Q3.

Discounter TJX Cos. (TJX), which operates the T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods chains, is seen posting a 4% sales gain for September. The nation's largest off-price retailer is No. 43 on the IBD 50 list.
Fellow discounter Ross Stores (ROST), No. 46 on the IBD 50, is also seen coming in with 4% growth.

If retailers hit those expectations, overall retailer sales would be down from August's 3.3% gain including drugstores, and 5.9% without. Drugstores have been walloped by a slew of issues, including new, cheaper generic competition on some key drugs.
Retail Metrics said back-to-school shopping was strong in August, and continued into the first half of September, before tapering off.
Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), the world's largest retailer, doesn't report monthly figures, but analysts think its Q3 same-store sales will be up 1.9%.
But rival Target (TGT) could post a 1.9% same-store boost for September.
Kohl's (KSS) is seen reporting a 0.2% September hike.

Struggling department store J.C. Doing well is important. Beating expectations can be even more so. Companies that deliver strong earnings growth far above Wall Street forecasts are likely to see big stock gains. Financial, tech and health-related stocks lead today's IBD Estimate Beaters Screen Of The Day based on actual EPS percentage gains in the latest quarter. Private equity firm Apollo Global Management (APO)…

In the worst of the Great Depression, an old lady is selling apples from a cart. Her sign says "Apples: $10,000." A man walks up and says "Lady, who's gonna buy your apples for $10,000?" She replies, "I only have to sell one!"If you can sell apples — or dresses and handbags — for $10,000 each, you'll have no trouble racking up fantastic profits. Michael Kors (KORS) is thriving with a different approach.Michael Kors wholesales and retails its own line of what some analysts call "affordable luxury," attractive, jet-set fashion at mostly competitive prices. There's plenty to be had by the value-conscious shopper, and a few selections for those with money to burn.A walk through the Kors line shows many dresses priced between $100 and $300, and handbags priced similarly (although some run as high as $2,600).Most men's jackets run a few hundred dollars, with at least one at $1,295. Men's watches are priced from $180 to $395.Michael Kors came public in December at 20 per share. (It's since more than doubled.) But the company was incorporated in 1981, and the fashion world is familiar with the Kors name.Wholesale deals accounted for 51% of last year's sales, retail 43% and licensing 6%.Michael Kors ran up as high as 50.69 on March 9 — a 153% surge from its IPO listing price in less than three months.The stock has been consolidating for seven weeks, correcting as much as 22%. The stock regained its 50-day moving average Friday, and remains around that level. With shares about 10% from a new high, the stock still needs some time to complete its base.Kors shows clues that another surge is not imminent. Its Relative Price Strength Rating is a stellar 98, but its Relative Strength line has chopped lower, reflecting the price. It's nowhere near its recent high.Its up-down volume ratio, at 0.9, is another clue that the stock lacks the sort of pent-up steam that makes for a dramatic push higher.But the broader picture shows a healthy company, with many fundamentals well in place.Earnings gains have been hot since an 18% tumble in the quarter ending in March 2011, Kors' fiscal fourth. Succeeding reports showed gains of 200%, 125% and 87%.Analysts' consensus for the recently ended fiscal Q4 profit runs at 56% growth.Sales in the past four quarters ranged from 45% to 81%.Kors upped its EPS 81% in fiscal 2011, and is expected to post a 79% improvement in the just-ended fiscal 2012 and 41% this current year.Its three- and five-year EPS growth rates shine at 114% and 41%, respectively. But its three-year Earnings Stability Factor is 28, and its five-year rate is 73 (on a scale from one to 100, where the lower the factor the more stable the earnings).Where's the glitch here? A nasty 78% EPS dive in 2009.Pretax margins last year came in at 16.6% — the highest since at least 2007. It was also fourth best of 34 companies in the industry group.After-tax margin in the past three reports came in at 7.3%, 12.4%, 12.4% and 14.3%. Each is an improvement over its year-earlier reading.

Stocks started weakly but ended strongly Monday, with most of the major indexes logging multiyear highs or better. The Nasdaq climbed 0.3% to its best levels in more than 12 years, while the S&P 500 rose 0.3% to a fresh five-year high. The benchmark S&P index is now a little more than 1% from its Oct. 11, 2007 record high.…

With the market in a confirmed rally, investors should be looking at stocks that are setting up and breaking out of bullish patterns. But you've got to look at your fundamentals.Today's IBD Screen Of The Day is Top Fundamentals, companies with a long track record of success. The screen sorts stocks with three-year EPS and sales growth rates of 25% or higher.A secondary sort pegs companies that saw profits surge last quarter.Here are five companies with the biggest EPS gains in the latest quarter on IBD's Top Fundamentals screen.Ellie Mae (ELLI)Electronic mortgage originator Ellie Mae tops the list. Reports indicate growing strength in housing, including Thursday's National Association of Realtors' index showing pending sales of existing homes in October jumped to the highest level in more than five years.Ellie Mae's EPS soared 280% last quarter to 35 cents. The prior quarter, EPS rose an astounding 1,200% to 27 cents. Over the past three years, the company's EPS growth rate was 144%.Shares rose nearly 3% Thursday afternoon, finding resistance near its 50-day average.LinkedIn (LNKD)The social network for professionals to build contacts and post and find jobs reported a 267% EPS gain last quarter, its fourth quarter in a row of double- or triple-digit profit hikes. Over the last three years, LinkedIn's EPS growth rate was 200%. Revenue grew from $140 million in the third quarter of 2011 to $252 million last quarter.Shares edged lower Thursday afternoon. The stock is sandwiched between its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. It peaked on Sept. 14.Top overall social network Facebook (FB) isn't on the list. Its stock plunged after its May 18 IPO, falling from a day-one intraday high of 45 to a low of 17.55 on Sept. 4. In recent weeks it's rebounded, rising to a four-month high Thursday.Michael Kors (KORS)The popular luxury apparel and accessories retailer, No. 3 on the list, last quarter managed to expand in Europe even though that region is still working through its debt crisis.Kors' EPS climbed 96% last quarter, the lowest rate in five quarters. Kors, which went public last December, has a long-term growth rate of 125%. Its stock sports a 99 Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 99% of all stocks.Kors shares hit a record high intraday on Nov. 2, then sold off before finding support near the 200-day line on Nov. 15. The stock moved back above the 50-day average Wednesday, but edged lower Thursday afternoon.Three D Systems (DDD)This company makes 3D printers that use software "blueprints" to make prototypes of a host of things, ranging from toys and jewelry to manufacturing gear. It's growing fast, as personal 3D printers priced under $500 hit the market. 3D and archrival Stratasys (SSYS), a bit lower on the Top Fundamentals list, are leaders in this emerging market.Last quarter, 3D's EPS hiked 78% to 32 cents, its strongest rate in five quarters. Long term, it's grown at a 180% clip.3D shares fell 3% Thursday afternoon after hitting a new high Wednesday. Stratasys slid 1.5% intraday after Wednesday's record high.Air Lease (AL)The aircraft leasing and fleet management company founded by Los Angeles billionaire Steven Udvar-Hazy went public in April 2011. It provides services to some 55 airlines in 33 countries and has grown in sync with the travel market's recovery. Last quarter, EPS swelled 64% to 41 cents, the lowest in five quarters. Over a three-year period, EPS popped 616%, mainly on a one-time spike in Q3 2011 after the company went public.Air Lease shares were little changed Thursday near a 6-month high, still well off their February highs.

Same-store retail sales are estimated to have grown just 1.9% in December, down from the 2.5% forecast at the beginning of the month, a report out Monday said. The Retail Metrics December same-store sales index was hurt by continuing weak drugstore sales. Factoring out drugstores, December comparable stores sales were 3.7%, also below the market tracker's earlier estimate of 4.2%…

Stocks added some gains and were near session highs late Friday. But the major averages were still on pace to end a multiweek win streak. The major averages had previously strengthened following a report that the European Central Bank is thinking about a new bond-buying program. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained…
Stocks continued to march ahead in afternoon action Tuesday, reaching new session highs and then holding near them.
The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Volume was tracking up from Monday's level across the board.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) climbed 3% in fast trade, hitting a fresh all-time high. The stock is now about 7% beyond a 66.72 three-weeks-tight entry, meaning it's extended past a proper buying range. CommVault, a maker of database software, was No. 2 in Monday's IBD 50.

Rackspace Hosting (RAX) jumped 6% in big turnover, clearing a 70.10 buy point from a handle. A Bloomberg report late Monday said the cloud computing company and related firms might become acquisition targets. Rackspace has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a best-possible 99.

Apple (AAPL) rose 2% in above-average volume, as the stock continued to rally after finding support around 500 on Monday. But it remains about 24% off its September high. The Apple news on Tuesday included a report suggesting the company's new TV device will use gesture recognition technology, and both a setback and a victory in its legal battle with Samsung.

Among the big losers Tuesday, IBD 50 stock Sturm Ruger (RGR) and rival Smith & Wesson (SWHC) continued their recent slide, falling 9% and 11%, respectively. The two gun makers both recently formed later-stage bases, broke out and then triggered IBD's 8% sell rule. Each stock is now below its 50-day moving average and its 200-day line, dropping amid expectations of stricter gun laws following Friday's mass shooting in Newtown, Conn.
In economic news, the National Association of Home Builders said its housing market index rose to 47 in December, matching expectations and providing the best reading since April 2006.

On the fiscal-cliff front, negotiations were continuing. Stocks erased most of their losses to finish mixed Monday. The Nasdaq rose less than 0.1%, but it had been down as much as 0.7%. The S&P 500 fell 0.1%, ending a six-session winning streak. The Dow Jones industrial average fared worst, losing 0.3%, but it also had been down as much as 0.7%. Volume decreased from Friday's levels across…

Stocks put in a session of low-volume gains Monday, as new optimism for Europe combined with some holdover bullishness after last week's better-than-expected U.S. jobs report. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%. The major indexes backed off from headier gains, but still managed to score their highest closing prices…
Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were each up 0.9% while the Nasdaq climbed 0.5%, building on smaller gains at the open. Volume was up 10% on the NYSE and down 1% on…

Upscale fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) shrugged off sluggishness at home and dismal economies in Europe to strut past earnings and sales forecasts on Tuesday. Tony cosmetics brand Estee Lauder (EL) also beat estimates. Both noted a still-growing global luxury market. But both also appeared to be taking share from rivals.
High-end department store operator Saks (SKS) reported a smaller-than-expected loss on continued modest sales growth.
"Macro weakness had seemingly no impact," Morgan Stanley analyst Kimberly Greenberger wrote in a note on Kors.
Kors shares surged 16.5% to 49.33, just shy of a closing high set in March. The stock came public at 20 last December.
Estee Lauder leapt 10% to 60.13. Saks climbed 6.2% to 11.52.

That peak at the high end of the retail world came as government data showed July U.S. retail sales overall climbing slightly after three months of decline, driven by spending on autos, furniture and clothing.
Kors, founded by "Project Runway" judge and designer Michael Kors, reported fiscal Q1 earnings of 34 cents per share, up 161.5% from a year ago, and 14 cents better than the consensus.
Sales Growth Accelerating
Revenue rose 70.6% to $414.9 million, well ahead of the $367.96 million expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. It was the best gain in at least four years.
Kors reported double-digit gains in retail, wholesale and licensing divisions. It boosted margins on fewer markdowns.
Sales at stores open at least a year surged 38.4% in North America and 24.2% in Europe, despite sluggish U.S. growth and recession in much of the eurozone.
It guided for 30% same-store-sales growth in the current quarter and mid- to high-20% range same-store growth for the full year.
Kors sees EPS of 33 to 35 cents in Q2 and $1.32 to $1.34 for the year, vs. analysts' forecasts for 28 cents and $1.12, respectively.

"We think that the luxury market continues to expand on a global basis," CEO John Idol said during the conference call with analysts. "The U.S. handbag market continues to expand. Then, of course, we believe that we have the opportu nity to take market share as well."

Kors' gain may have come at the expense of Coach (COH), which on July 31 reported weak North American sales. The "affordable luxury" handbag maker and retailer had to discount many of its wares. The stock fell nearly 19% that day. It retreated 2.9% on Tuesday.
But consumers appeared to embrace Kors' less-pricey luxury, with purses, shoes, eyewear and other accessories accounting for 79% of its product mix in the quarter.

Analysts saw little to quibble about. Several noted that inventory doubled vs. a year earlier, well beyond near-term projected sales growth. But Kors said it needs to stock its growing base of stores — it opened 16 in its Q1 and expects to open 65 to 75 this year. And it said its inventories were still too lean in Europe.

"Momentum continues in all aspects of the business and F13 is off to a strong start," Nomura analyst Paul Lejuez wrote. "Longer term, Kors is a proven brand that is in the early stages of expansion and is taking share."
Estee Lauder cited momentum in the U.S. and China, and tourists at its airport stores, for fiscal Q4 EPS growth of 31% to 17 cents excluding one-time items. That was a penny over analysts' estimates.
Revenue climbed 9.2% to $2.25 billion, slightly over estimates.
Estee Lauder, which often gives cautious guidance, forecast fiscal Q1 EPS of 71 to 77 cents, under views for 78 cents. It expects full-year EPS of $2.44 to $2.56, vs. views for $2.57.

"Despite pockets of economic uncertainty around the globe, our sales growth was broad-based, with strong gains in every geographic region and product category and many distribution channels," Estee Lauder CEO Fabrizio Freda said in a statement.
Saks reported an adjusted per-share loss of 5 cents in Q2 vs. analyst forecasts for a 9-cent loss.

Meanwhile Fossil (FOSL), which provides Kors with watches and jewelry, slipped 1.1%. Its shares shot up 31.5% on Aug. 7, thanks to better-than-expected quarterly results, but the stock is still nearly 39% below its May 3 peak.

Ralph Lauren (RL) fell 0.5%. Last week, the upscale brand reported its fourth straight quarter of decelerating sales growth, from 32% to 4%. It boosted margins on fewer markdowns.Sales at stores open at least a year surged 38.4% in North America and 24.2% in Europe, despite sluggish U.S. growth and recession in much of the eurozone.It guided for 30% same-store-sales growth in the current quarter and mid- to high-20% range same-store growth for the full year.Kors sees EPS of 33 to 35 cents in Q2 and $1.32 to $1.34 for the year, vs. analysts' forecasts for 28 cents and $1.12, respectively."We think that the luxury market continues to expand on a global basis," CEO John Idol said during the conference call with analysts. "The U.S. handbag market continues to expand. Then, of course, we believe that we have the opportu nity to take market share as well."Kors' gain may have come at the expense of Coach (COH), which on July 31 reported weak North American sales. The "affordable luxury" handbag maker and retailer had to discount many of its wares. The stock fell nearly 19% that day. It retreated 2.9% on Tuesday.But consumers appeared to embrace Kors' less-pricey luxury, with purses, shoes, eyewear and other accessories accounting for 79% of its product mix in the quarter.Analysts saw little to quibble about. Several noted that inventory doubled vs. a year earlier, well beyond near-term projected sales growth. But Kors said it needs to stock its growing base of stores — it opened 16 in its Q1 and expects to open 65 to 75 this year. And it said its inventories were still too lean in Europe."Momentum continues in all aspects of the business and F13 is off to a strong start," Nomura analyst Paul Lejuez wrote. "Longer term, Kors is a proven brand that is in the early stages of expansion and is taking share."Estee Lauder cited momentum in the U.S. and China, and tourists at its airport stores, for fiscal Q4 EPS growth of 31% to 17 cents excluding one-time items. That was a penny over analysts' estimates.Revenue climbed 9.2% to $2.25 billion, slightly over estimates.Estee Lauder, which often gives cautious guidance, forecast fiscal Q1 EPS of 71 to 77 cents, under views for 78 cents. It expects full-year EPS of $2.44 to $2.56, vs. views for $2.57."Despite pockets of economic uncertainty around the globe, our sales growth was broad-based, with strong gains in every geographic region and product category and many distribution channels," Estee Lauder CEO Fabrizio Freda said in a statement.Saks reported an adjusted per-share loss of 5 cents in Q2 vs. analyst forecasts for a 9-cent loss.Meanwhile Fossil (FOSL), which provides Kors with watches and jewelry, slipped 1.1%. Its shares shot up 31.5% on Aug. 7, thanks to better-than-expected quarterly results, but the stock is still nearly 39% below its May 3 peak.Ralph Lauren (RL) fell 0.5%. Last week, the upscale brand reported its fourth straight quarter of decelerating sales growth, from 32% to 4%. And it warned of a mid-single-digit sales decline in the current quarter.

"In fashion, one day you're in and the next you're out," Heidi Klum always reminds contestants on Project Runway. And Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), founded by Project Runway judge Michael Kors, is most definitely in fashion as its fourth-quarter earnings beat Street estimates.
The fashion house reported a 120% rise in fourth-quarter earnings to 22 cents per share vs. 10 cents in '11, and topping analysts estimates by 6 cents. Revenue increased 58.3% to $380 million.
It sees Q1 EPS of 18-20 cents, above analyst estimates of 17 cents.
Shares rose2.7% to 39.19.
Many high-end retailers like Tiffany (TIF) and Ralph Lauren (RL) have struggled recently from economic turmoil in Europe and rising unemployment in the U.S.
But Michael Kors saw a 122.6% jump in revenue from its Europe sector as same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 13.6%.
North American same-store sales increased 37.2% and overall same store sales climbed 36.1%.
Kors sells high-end women's apparel as well as accessories. Kors has a licensing agreement with Fossil (FOSL) to sell Kors branded watches and jewelry made by the accessory company.
"Total licensing revenue grew 26.9% in the quarter due to strong sales of our licensed products led by the Michael Kors watch and eyewear lines," CEO John Idol said.
While Kors watches performed well, Fossil's Q1 sales missed expectations and it lowered guidance in early May. Its shares fell 3%.
For the year, Kors' revenue increased 62.1% to $1.3 billion as the company opened 71 new stores. Gross profit widened from 55.5% to 57.8%.
Unlike other recent high-profile IPOs like Facebook (FB) and Groupon (GRPN), Kors continues to outperform expectations since its debut in December.

Apparel IPOs have been outperforming their tech counterparts. Earlier this month apparel boutique operator Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), who debuted last July, said Q1 EPS doubled to 20 cents, and its sales also topped views. Its shares fell 1.8%.

The Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group is ranked 79 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups."In fashion, one day you're in and the next you're out," Heidi Klum always reminds contestants on Project Runway. Luxury brands Michael Kors (KORS), Tiffany & Co. (TIF), Ralph Lauren (RL), Coach (COH) and True Religion (TRLG) dropped in the stock market Wednesday after Burberry Group reported a decline in first-quarter sales growth tied to its performance in China.

High-end denim brand True Religion fell the most of brands traded on U.S. stock exchanges, 6.5%. IBD 50 stock Michael Kors Holdings, a maker of handbags and clothing, dropped 4.5%. Ralph Lauren declined 3.4%, bag brand Coach lost 1.9% and jeweler Tiffany 0.4%.

Worries about China's economic slowdown were already hitting stocks when the British luxury handbag and apparel maker cited weak demand in China as a reason it only reported an 11% rise in revenue. Analysts were expecting 13%.

Burberry has 63 stores in China and wants to build 100 more. But in June, China's imports only rose at half the expected rate. Burberry CEO Angela Ahrendts called Burberry's performance "robust" but warned of "a more challenging external environment."
Burberry stock fell 8.5% Wednesday on the London exchange.
Luxury firms had been turning to China and other developing markets in an effort to offset a slowdown in spending in the U.S. and Europe — and Burberry isn't the only brand hurting.
In May, CLSA analyst Barbara Wyckoff said jewelry maker Tiffany could struggle over the next couple of quarters on a decline of sales in China and South Korea.

In April, Michael Kors opened its fifth and largest store in China and is expected to open 15 stores in the greater China area in 2012. The company operates 10 stores in Southeast Asia and thinks Japan could eventually be a top market.

Meanwhile, short sellers are interested in luxury jean maker True Religion Apparel, according to a blog at SeekingAlpha.com. The blog is also concerned that the company's pricey jeans could become unpopular. But it remained bullish on the stock on falling cotton prices and increased distribution outside of boutique stores. True Religion had been a top stock, but took a huge hit after it reported negative EPS growth in February and has been moving sideways since.

Many apparel stocks have lagged the market so far this year. For example, the 29-stock apparel manufacturing group has fallen to No. 155 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD from 11 three months ago.
Still, many apparel stocks still have high ratings and are flirting with all-time highs. Among them are Michael Kors (KORS), Gildan Activewear (GIL) and PVH (PVH) in the stockmarkettoday.

Three apparel companies, Ann Inc. (ANN), Foot Locker (FL) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO), will report fourth-quarter results this coming week. Wall Street expects American Eagle and Foot Locker to show strong profit growth for the holiday quarter, while they forecast a steep decline for Ann.

Teen clothing retailer American Eagle will be the first of the group to report Wednesday. American Eagle has logged three straight quarters of of double digit sales and earnings growth. Wall Street doesn't see that scenario changing. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect American Eagle's fourth-quarter earnings to soar 60% to 56 cents a share. They see sales climbing 22% to $1.12 billion.

American Eagle offers trendy clothes and accessories at affordable prices under its American Eagle Outfitters and Aerie brands. It operates more than 1,000 stores in North America and ships to 77 countries through its websites.

"American Eagle had one of the best holiday quarters in teen apparel," said Brian Sozzi, chief equities analyst at research firm NBG. "It had the most interesting products in the teen space, their promotions were compelling and drove traffic into stores pretty consistently, and their inventory was lean."

Athletic footwear retailer Foot Locker will report Friday before the bell. It's been on a roll the past nine quarters with profits up by at least 30%. Analysts see a strong fourth-quarter showing with earnings up 31% to 72 cents a share. They see sales rising 12% to $1.68 billion.
As of Feb, 2, Foot Locker operated 3,335 stores in 23 countries in North America, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand.
The company enjoyed a cheery holiday quarter as it lured consumers with innovative products from brands like Nike (NKE).

Specialty women's clothing retailer Ann has had a nice run the past few quarters, with solid sales and profit growth. But the company has already told shareholders its fourth quarter won't be up to par when it updated its outlook Feb. 7. It now says sales will come in at $608 million, reflecting a 1% decline in same-store sales vs. a year earlier. That's well below its earlier forecast of $625 million in sales and same-store sales growth in the mid-single digits. Analysts expect earnings to plunge 90% to 1 cent a share.

Sozzi says Ann has been losing business to department stores like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), which are offering "better bang for the buck." Also, Ann didn't offer a wide enough assortment in the fourth quarter, he adds, and it was more aggressive than it would have liked with promotions, which hurt margins.

As of Oct. 27, Ann operated 981 Ann Taylor, Ann Taylor Factory, LOFT and LOFT Outlet stores in 47 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and Canada.Many apparel stocks have lagged the market so far this year. Tiffany & Co. (TIF) lowered its outlook after reporting its fourth straight quarter of declining earnings Thursday as the slowdown in China affected consumer spending in the region.

The jeweler said third-quarter EPS plummeted 30% to 49 cents per share, missing Wall Street expectations by 14 cents. Earnings had declined 3%, 4%, and 16% in the last three quarters. Sales for the quarter rose 4% to $852.7 million, below estimates of $859.2 million.
Shares were down in heavy volume.

"Three months ago, we had anticipated that third-quarter results would be affected by continued economic weakness in many markets as well as by challenging comparisons to last year," said CEO Michael Kowalski. "Gross margin was weaker than we expected and Tiffany's effective tax rate was higher than we expected. As a result, net earnings were below our expectations."
Sales in the Americas region rose 3% to $400 million and same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, were up 1%. Sales in the New York flagship store rose 5% in the quarter.
Revenue from Europe climbed 6% to $98 million as sales in continental Europe rose, offsetting a decline in U.K. sales.
In the Asia-Pacific region, total sales increased 2% to $188 million, but comparable-store sales declined 4%.
Tiffany has been focused on expanding its presence in Asia, especially China, to offset declines in developed markets. But consumers have been curbing spending during the economic slowdown in China.

Tiffany lowered its outlook for the third straight quarter. It now expects full-year EPS of $3.20-$3.40 vs. a previous forecast of $3.55-$3.70. Implied Q4 guidance is $1.35- $1.55, below analysts' expectations of $1.60.
"We continue to maintain a cautious near-term outlook about global economic conditions. However, we expect to see improving results in this holiday season," Kowalski said.

Last week, Signet (SIG), the operator of Kay Jewelers and Jared, said Q3 sales jumped 43%, beating views, but reported flat sales. The jeweler said November was "challenging" because of Hurricane Sandy.
Shares were slightly lower Thursday.
The Retail/Wholesale Jewelry group is highly ranked at No. 19 out of the 197 industry groups Investor's Business Daily tracks.

On Wednesday, watchmaker Movado (MOV) reported a 12% jump in revenue to $160 million, beating views due to increased sales in the accessible luxury and licensed brand categories. It joined Costco (COST) and other retailers in approving a special dividend over fiscal cliff concerns.
Movado shares were also down.

Things haven't been looking so cheery for luxury brands heading into the important holiday season. Michael Kors (KORS) reported earnings above estimates earlier this month, but issued weak guidance. Fossil (FOSL), which makes Kors-licensed watches and jewelry, reported weak European sales.

Saks (SKS) CEO Stephen Sadove said "the overall macroeconomic environment remains very uncertain. We continue to approach the future cautiously" after the upscale department store reported weak Q3 results in early November. It expects sales at stores open at least a year to be flat during the current holiday quarter because of a slow start to November due to Sandy.Tiffany & Co. Stocks remained sharply lower Wednesday afternoon as worries over the fiscal cliff and the eurozone's economy put investors on edge.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were down 2.5% and 2.2%, respectively. Both were off by as much as 2.8% earlier. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.2%. All 30 Dow stocks were lower. Volume was still tracking vastly higher across the board.

Rackspace Hosting (RAX) shed 6% and sliced its 50-day line heavy trading. The provider of website hosting services reported Q3 results that met views late Tuesday. Rackspace's earnings rose 36%, while sales grew 27%. Both marked a slowdown from recent quarters.

Beacon Roofing Supply (BECN) shaved 5% and erased the gains from the past two sessions. The pullback puts it 2% past a 30.90 buy point in a rare ascending base. Beacon broke out Oct. 18 in heavy trading.

Apple (AAPL) was off its session low, but still down 3% in active trading. The stock, which touched a five-month low earlier Wednesday, is in its deepest correction in years. Apple is now 20% off its Sept. 21 record high.

Michael Kors (KORS) was off by 2% after rebounding from a dip below its 50-day moving average, which as acted as support in recent sessions. Shares were off by as much as 4% at Wednesday's low. Still, the stock fell nearly 7% below a 57.45 buy point from a flat base. The luxury apparel firm reports Q3 results Tuesday.

On the upside, gun makers Smith & Wesson (SWHC) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) gapped rallied 8% and 6%, respectively on fears of tougher regulation after President Obama's re-election. Wealthy tourists splurged during the holidays, and on Tuesday, high-end jeweler Tiffany & Co. (TIF) will show whether that buying continued into this year.Analysts expect the jeweler to post fourth-quarter earnings of $1.42 per share, down slightly from last year's $1.44 per share. Revenue is seen climbing 7.6% to $1.19 billion for the January-ending quarter.The company has previously announced holiday sales for the two months ending Dec. 31 of $952 million, up 7% from the same period a year ago. It credited double-digit gains in Asia, and smaller increases in Europe and the Americas.Sales at its flagship New York City store decreased 1%.The company said free-spending tourists visiting the U.S. made up for sluggish spending from American shoppers. European sales edged up 1% to $117 million, with a slight increase on the continent and a decrease in the United Kingdom.On Thursday, U.K.-based jewelry retailer Signet Jewelers (SIG) posts fourth-quarter results. The operator of Kay Jewelers, Jared The Galleria Of Jewelry, and other stores, also pre-announced holiday sales. It saw a 7.8% hike in stores open more than a year over the nine-week period ending Dec. 31, with its U.S. division up 9.2% and its U.K. store sales up 1.8%.Its shares edged slightly higher midday to 49.52.Shares of the accessories retailer Fossil (FOSL) have been surging since last month's earnings beat, in part on strong sales of its watches and jewelry supplied to high-end fashion house Michael Kors (KORS).On Monday, Fossil shares surged 3.8% to 130.43. Michael Kors shares climbed 1.75% to 47.09.Swiss upscale watchmaker Movado Group (MOV) reports on April 2. Its shares climbed 2.3% to 22.14.Related StoryLululemon, Michael Kors Lead IBD 50's Top 5 Retailers

Two days of rough going on the NYSE and the Nasdaq have taken their toll on many ADRs.Even as some leaders have suffered big hits, others have shown impressive resilience.MercadoLibre (MELI), Latin America's answer to eBay, fell 1% for the day and 2% for the week.MercadoLibre is barely above its 91.55 buy point from a cup with handle.The stock also is nine weeks into a double-bottom base with a 103.08 trigger. The top of the double bottom is less than 20% above the cup with handle, making the entire structure a base on base.China-based NetEase (NTES) is holding up better than most. Its two straight losses have been minuscule. Shares of the online video-game star have climbed 17% from their 51.14 cup-with-handle buy point.The stock seems to have tried to break out from a square-box base that started in the March 30 week. But volume on the breakout was poor, and the action looks more like a test of the 10-week moving average.NetEase is slated to release its Q1 results May 16. Consensus runs at $1.01 EPS, which would be 17% more than its year-earlier profit. That would be NetEase's weakest gain in seven quarters.Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which had been rising from a rebound off its 10-week moving average, fell 3%. That loss broke a three-day winning streak.For the week, the Vancouver-based retailer of yoga-themed workout apparel and accessories climbed 4% and hit a new high.Lululemon shows all the signs of robust bidding. Its up-down volume ratio climbed to 1.5, and it hasn't been below 1.1 for months. An A- Accumulation-Distribution Rating is another clue that institutions are still buying.Affordable-luxury fashion designer, wholesaler and retailer  Michael Kors (KORS) fell 5% Friday, slicing through its 10-week moving average.Its two-day loss comes to 10%, and the weekly chart shows a downside reversal. Still, volume has been light during the retreat, and an eight-week consolidation is intact.Crude oil's two-day dive did its damage to two oil-sector names on the Top World Stocks list.Ecopetrol (EC), Colombia's oil-and-gas giant, fell 4% Friday. Three straight losses have pushed Ecopetrol 6% off its 52-week high. The stock had been rebounding nicely from its 10-week moving average.Netherlands-based oilfield service provider Core Laboratories (CLB) dipped just 1% Friday. But Thursday saw the stock reverse lower from a record high, falling 3% in double-paced trade.Like Ecopetrol, Core had been rebounding from its 10-week line. Core's weekly chart shows a downside reversal.

Don't mistake $1.2 billion Fidelity Trend's approach as a growth-at-a-reasonable-price fund.Manager Dan Kelley prefers to describe his fund as looking for companies whose growth is underestimated by Wall Street analysts.Kelley favors three types of growth stocks:Stable earnings growers.Companies on a hot streak, with high sustainable growth for many years.Opportunistic growers, which have low valuations but are near a point when a catalyst sparks a growth spurt.Google (GOOG), Monsanto (MON) and Visa (V) are examples of stable growers. Michael Kors (KORS) is in his high sustainable growth bucket, as he puts it.  Manitowoc (MTW), new to the fund as of its latest disclosure, and United Technologies (UTX) are opportunistic growers.Those latter two stocks benefit from the rally in nonresidential construction, Kelley says. Manitowoc sells cranes and lifting equipment. United sells elevators and heating systems.Other holdings also sell into the construction space.  Ingersoll-Rand (IR) makes climate control systems. Wesco (WCC) distributes industrial and electrical construction, maintenance, repair and operating supplies. Vulcan Materials (VMC) makes construction aggregates."Nonresidential construction tends to lag residential by 12 to 18 months, so this space is right in a sweet spot," Kelley said.The ongoing rebound in residential housing benefits materials and tools sellers. The fund held Lowes (LOW) and Home Depot (HD) as of its latest disclosure."As home sales improve, people feel more comfortable adding or refurbishing rooms or taking care of deferred repairs in existing homes too," Kelley said.Kelley's CredentialsThose areas are familiar to Kelley. Before taking the reins of Trend in January last year, at various times he has served as research analyst covering REITs and homebuilder stocks as well as manager of Select Construction & Housing along with other duties. He now runs four portfolios in all.Another trend Kelley has played is refurbished auto parts. He owned LKQ (LKQ) as of his latest disclosure."Insurers are looking to lower auto claims expenses, so they're utilizing more refurbished parts. LKQ owns junk and scrap yards, where they get parts refurbished and recertified," Kelley said.Barriers To EntryThe field has grown fast and has barriers to entry. "They have a distribution network of hubs across the U.S. that can get parts to mechanics and repair shops," he said.The fund was up 6.86% this year going into Tuesday. Its large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. averaged 7.63%. The S&P 500 was up 10.24%.Over the past three years the fund's average annual return is 11.33% vs. 9.19% for its peers and 11.29% for the big-cap bogey.The fund's first-quarter relative performance trailed the S&P 500 as many investors shifted into defensive names and stronger yield payers. Rather than make such moves, Kelley continued to pursue growth. "I stuck to my philosophy and process," he said.Kelley trimmed Apple (AAPL) in recent months. Its margins have shrunk due to rivals offering similar products at lower prices, he notes.

Stocks were supported for a while Wednesday by positive economic data and market-friendly nuggets in the Fed policymakers' minutes, but succumbed late in the day to nervous investors.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was the star of Tuesday's session, fell 1.4%, as did the S&P 500. The Nasdaq slid 1.3%. Volume climbed on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data.

The minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's October meeting showed plenty of support for a continued easy posture. Several voting members of the Fed's policymaking board want to see an extension of action after the Dec. 31 expiration of Operation Twist, where the Fed has been selling short-term securities and buying longer dates. The aim was to push the liquidity additions further along the maturity range. That should lower mortgage rates, which would support the housing market.
Also discussed was the idea of linking the current super-easy policy to economic results — including unemployment and inflation rates — rather than setting an expiration date.

Meanwhile, President Obama called for Congress to extend middle-class tax breaks, saying: "We should at least do what we can agree on." He said Washington could then move to negotiating how to handle taxes on the wealthy as it works to avoid the fiscal cliff.

Economic data were mixed. The producer price index fell 0.2% in October from the prior month, a far cry from the 0.2% gain expected in a Bloomberg survey of economists. The rate rose 2.3% from a year earlier. But retail sales fell 0.3% last month, a bit worse than expected and a negative turnaround from September's 1.3% gain. Auto sales were a major culprit in that disappointment.
Some high-profile gains couldn't save the day.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) jumped 5% in strong turnover, powered by its better-than-expected earnings report late Tuesday. The stock remains below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, as well as about 15% off its April high. Cisco has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 42, but it remains a tech sector bellwether.
Facebook (FB) gained 13% in big volume on a big lock-up expiration day for the May IPO. The social network remains 50% off its peak and still has a poor IBD Composite Rating of 45.
But the market was dominated by sellers.

Catamaran (CTRX) slid 7% in strong volume. The pharmacy benefits manager and IT services provider, No. 8 in Wednesday's IBD 50, sliced through its 50-day moving average after consolidating near that level in the last few weeks. Rival pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) was also down in heavy volume, sliding 2%.
Michael Kors (KORS), No. 3 in Wednesday's IBD 50, fell 4% in active turnover. The clothing and accessories maker, a December 2011 IPO, has undercut support at 50 and a prior buy point at 49.60.

Chico's FAS (CHS) fell 3% in fast trade, dropping further below its 50-day line. The women's clothing retailer isn't in the IBD 50, but it has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, near the best-possible grade of 99.

Sandstorm (SAND) dived 9% in giant volume, slicing through its 50-day moving average. The gold play came public in August and sports a highest-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. Recent IPO, potential growth outfit and niche, luxury men's retail label Michael Kors (KORS) came in with all-around strong results this morning. But despite beating on both its top and bottom-lines and issuing upside, above-views FY13 guidance, investors saw fit to back away from an out-the-gate gap test of its 50-day simple moving average and move shares from a high near 42.75 to an intraday level of about 40 a share.

For longer-term investors seeing today's report as an opportunity to get long KORS with a good deal of company-specific uncertainty now removed, but respecting the inability of shares to get above their 50-day simple moving average within its weekly base; a collar using call and put options, might be a smart way to accessorize the position.

The collar strategy buys stock, sells an "at" or out-of-the-money call and purchases a put for downside protection on a one-to-one basis. While the position is generally considered a moderately bullish one, the placement of strikes is what ultimately determines the risk and reward involved and how much movement in the underlying shares will be required to realize either of those amounts.

To illustrate a collar and one which looks interesting given what's occurring in the stock today, we've set up a 3x collar using the July 37 put and July 42 call for a net cost of $40.29 per spread. The component prices used to establish the debit are $40.04 for long stock, $2.00 call sale and $1.75 purchase price for the put. Thus, the option "risk reversal" costs $0.25 per spread which is added to the price paid for shares.

This particular collar is uneven, meaning the sold call and protective put aren't equidistant to the share price and the position maintains a bit more downside exposure versus its potential upside gain. However, adjustments might be possible down the road, given the right opportunity. In the end, the collar is a limited risk and limited reward position. But prior to expiration it's best not to cling to the notion a collar is a static spread; rather, see it as being potentially electric or dynamic and open to new designs that better fit the times.

What do you think? Feel free to share your opinion in the comments section below.Recent IPO, potential growth outfit and niche, luxury men's retail label Michael Kors (KORS) came in with all-around strong results this morning. He said Washington could then move to negotiating how to handle taxes on the wealthy as it works to avoid the fiscal cliff.Economic data were mixed. The producer price index fell 0.2% in October from the prior month, a far cry from the 0.2% gain expected in a Bloomberg survey of economists. The rate rose 2.3% from a year earlier. But retail sales fell 0.3% last month, a bit worse than expected and a negative turnaround from September's 1.3% gain. Auto sales were a major culprit in that disappointment.Some high-profile gains couldn't save the day.Cisco Systems (CSCO) jumped 5% in strong turnover, powered by its better-than-expected earnings report late Tuesday. The stock remains below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, as well as about 15% off its April high. Cisco has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 42, but it remains a tech sector bellwether.Facebook (FB) gained 13% in big volume on a big lock-up expiration day for the May IPO. The social network remains 50% off its peak and still has a poor IBD Composite Rating of 45.But the market was dominated by sellers.Catamaran (CTRX) slid 7% in strong volume. The pharmacy benefits manager and IT services provider, No. 8 in Wednesday's IBD 50, sliced through its 50-day moving average after consolidating near that level in the last few weeks. Rival pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) was also down in heavy volume, sliding 2%.Michael Kors (KORS), No. 3 in Wednesday's IBD 50, fell 4% in active turnover. The clothing and accessories maker, a December 2011 IPO, has undercut support at 50 and a prior buy point at 49.60.Chico's FAS (CHS) fell 3% in fast trade, dropping further below its 50-day line. The women's clothing retailer isn't in the IBD 50, but it has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, near the best-possible grade of 99.Sandstorm (SAND) dived 9% in giant volume, slicing through its 50-day moving average. The gold play came public in August and sports a highest-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. Late Tuesday, CNBC's Jim Cramer indicated he was bearish on Sandstorm.

Recent IPO, potential growth outfit and niche, luxury men's retail label Michael Kors (KORS) came in with all-around strong results this morning. But despite beating on both its top and bottom-lines and issuing upside, above-views FY13 guidance, investors saw fit to back away from an out-the-gate gap test of its 50-day simple moving average and move shares from a high near 42.75 to an intraday level of about 40 a share.

For longer-term investors seeing today's report as an opportunity to get long KORS with a good deal of company-specific uncertainty now removed, but respecting the inability of shares to get above their 50-day simple moving average within its weekly base; a collar using call and put options, might be a smart way to accessorize the position.

The collar strategy buys stock, sells an "at" or out-of-the-money call and purchases a put for downside protection on a one-to-one basis. While the position is generally considered a moderately bullish one, the placement of strikes is what ultimately determines the risk and reward involved and how much movement in the underlying shares will be required to realize either of those amounts.

To illustrate a collar and one which looks interesting given what's occurring in the stock today, we've set up a 3x collar using the July 37 put and July 42 call for a net cost of $40.29 per spread. The component prices used to establish the debit are $40.04 for long stock, $2.00 call sale and $1.75 purchase price for the put. Thus, the option "risk reversal" costs $0.25 per spread which is added to the price paid for shares.

This particular collar is uneven, meaning the sold call and protective put aren't equidistant to the share price and the position maintains a bit more downside exposure versus its potential upside gain. However, adjustments might be possible down the road, given the right opportunity. In the end, the collar is a limited risk and limited reward position. But prior to expiration it's best not to cling to the notion a collar is a static spread; rather, see it as being potentially electric or dynamic and open to new designs that better fit the times.

What do you think? Shares of Coach (COH) jumped 7.5% to 69 at 11:45 a.m. ET on Tuesday after the luxury handbag designer's second-quarter earnings per share and revenue beat Wall Street estimates.
The maker of the famous handbags with an interlocking "C" design said Q2 EPS rose 18% to $1.18, beating views by three cents. Sales grew 15% to $1.45 billion.

Coach's sales were probably helped by mild winter weather and "the lack of a clear apparel fashion trend" for the Christmas season, which steered consumers toward classic-style handbags and accessories, according to a research note by Christian Buss, an analyst for Credit Suisse.
Gross margin narrowed slightly to 72.2% from 72.4% in the prior year. The operating margin was 36% vs. 35.9% in the prior year.
Same-store sales in North America increased 8.8%

The brand is also performing well internationally, especially in Asia. During the second quarter, the company opened nine new stores in China, including a flagship store in Hong Kong. The company expects China to generate at least $300 million in sales in fiscal 2012.

Coach's accessories aren't just for women. The company has recently entered the men's market, manufacturing high-end belts, wallets and computer bags. After a strong Q2, Coach expects the men's business to double to over $400 million in 2012.
Coach's earnings give a good indication of how luxury brands are faring during shaky economic times. The wealthy are still spending on pricey items as sales in other sectors have slowed.
The apparel-clothing group ranked 83 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.

Rival apparel and accessory designer Ralph Lauren (RL) will report third-quarter earnings Feb. 8. The tech-heavy index has met resistance…
Companies that have built a solid base with consistent profit and sales growth are among the most likely to continue to see gains.
IBD's Screen Of The Day is Top Fundamentals, which lists stocks with three-year EPS and sales growth of 25% or higher.

But it's important to track forward-looking indicators as well. A second sort of companies on the list spots those which are forecast to report highest earnings per share this quarter, making them watch-list prospects for successful investors.

3D Systems (DDD), along with Stratasys (SSYS), is a leader in the emerging 3D printing industry. 3D Systems' printers use software code to "print" actual objects, laying materials one on top of the other to make everything from household items to walls for buildings. Eight analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast 3D Systems' EPS will pop 138% this quarter.
Its stock has soared 80% since mid-November. Shares fell 2% Wednesday to 68.35, but from record highs.

HollyFrontier (HFC), a petroleum products refiner, has grown rapidly amid a broad advance in the oil sector. Its EPS has grown at double- or triple-digit levels for six quarters in a row, and sales have kept pace in all but one of those periods.
HollyFrontier is expected to see a 111% rise in EPS when it reports fourth-quarter earnings on Feb. 26. Shares jumped 3.6% to 45.90 Wednesday, just 4% off its 52-week high.

United Therapeutics (UTHR) is a biotech that develops products like monoclonal antibodies and cell-based therapies to treat heart and infectious diseases. It has six straight quarters of double-digit sales and profit gains. Consensus is a 64% jump in EPS this quarter. Shares, trading above both their 50-day and 200-day averages, slid 1.4% to 52.73. The stock has been consolidating since late November after recovering from a late October crash.

Ellie Mae's (ELLI) software helps more than 54,000 mortgage professionals and lenders process the reams of documents involved with loan applications. It's benefiting from the recent surge in home sales.

Ellie Mae's EPS soared 1,250% in Q2 of last year, to 27 cents. Comps got tougher in Q3, and profit growth slowed to 289%. It's projected to post a 62% rise in EPS this quarter. Shares crashed 8.7% Wednesday, though, after William Blair downgraded Ellie Mae to market perform from outperform.
LinkedIn's (LNKD) social website helps connect employers and employees and provides a platform for professionals to generally network.

It's grown at a rapid clip in recent years as unemployment, which topped 10% during the recession, remains stubbornly high, making LinkedIn a go-to job search and recruitment site. In its most recent two quarters, EPS advanced 300% and 1,200%. Wall Street expects a more moderate 58% rise in the current quarter. Shares rose 0.8% to 120.26 to their best level since early October. The stock peaked on Sept. 14.

Michael Kors (KORS), the fashion clothing and accessories maker, rounds out the list. The Hong Kong-based clothier has posted six quarters of double-digit sales and profit growth. Kors is expected to report a 46% EPS rise in the latest quarter.

Rival Coach (COH), which sells leather goods like handbags and accessories in the moderate price range, was crushed Wednesday, falling more than 16% after reporting weaker-than-expected holiday sales and EPS.
But Kors investors didn't flinch. Kors shares rose 1.2% Wednesday to 55.63, close to its record high set in early November.

Revenue jumped 21% to $122.4 million vs. $101 million last…

Stocks got off to a great start with solid volume Tuesday, thanks to a healthy manufacturing report, but a late retreat pared those gains. The S&P 500 led the major indexes with a 0.6% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.5% and the Nasdaq added a scant 0.1%. The S&P 500 was up as much as 1.2% earlier in…

Over three decades, designer Michael Kors has gone from rising star in the fashion world to mature talent and TV celebrity judge on "Project Runway."But his namesake public company, Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), is just getting started. It debuted on the Nasdaq only five months ago.But it's already a rising star on Wall Street despite being caught up in the stock market's latest dip.Having given investors a big Valentine's Day present in its first quarterly report as a public company, it has set a high bar for itself.Not only did the self-described "accessible luxury lifestyle company" beat analysts' estimates by more than double, but it also clocked same-store sales gains of 38% in North America and more than 34% in Europe.That good news was just on the fast-growing retail side, which closed the quarter with 231 stores, 75 of them having opened in the 12 months prior.Wholesale and licensing revenue, which included a double-digit gain in fashion watches, also shone.The company buys watches from partner Fossil (FOSL), which reports quarterly earnings on Tuesday.It also buys fragrances from Estee Lauder (EL) and eyewear from Marchon Eyewear, two other licensees it uses for their specialized expertise.Jobs ReportShares on Valentine's Day soared 27.5% to a new high. But mixed economic news on Thursday and a disappointing jobs report on Friday sent Kors' shares tumbling around 10% over the two days as the overall market fell.Shares are still more than double from December's IPO price of $20.The company will report its March-ended fiscal fourth-quarter results next month.Will the runway show for Wall Street thrill again?If Kors were a movie, it would be "Raging Bull," wrote JP Morgan analyst Brian Tunick on Friday."We think the outperformance will continue," said analyst Corinna Freedman of Wedbush Securities in a phone call, adding that it probably won't be as outsized as the last quarter."Our channel checks have shown stores across the nation are comping stronger than competitors," Freedman said. "Sales growth and traffic are being driven by handbags and accessories."Same-store sales for the 11 weeks ended March 17 grew 35.8%, the company said on March 19, when it raised its earnings forecast for the fourth quarter to 14 cents to 16 cents per share from 10 cents to 12 cents prior.For the full fiscal year, it expects to report 79 cents to 81 cents vs. 74 cents to 76 cents earlier. It sees revenue of up to $1.28 billion.The company later announced a secondary stock offering of 25 million shares at $47 a share, allowing insiders to sell shares to the public and take profits ahead of the IPO's six-month lockout period, which ends June 12.If the uncertain economy and high gas prices do hurt Michael Kors, the impact will be minor, says Craig Johnson, president of Customer Growth Partners."It will be more than offset by the organic growth in the store base and wholesale distribution expansion," he said.It doesn't hurt to be in the luxury arena, one of the strongest performing categories in retail."This is a very good time to be in luxury, and midluxury is the next growth area for the consumer," said Marshal Cohen, chief retail analyst at the NPD Group."(Michael Kors) is in a pretty good spot. If done right, they can grow their brand in several different directions," Cohen said, adding: "Right now, Michael Kors is for the lower-upper class and the upper-middle class, and they are aspiring to reach the middle class."Management believes it can open as many as 400 retail stores in North America, 100 locations in Europe and 100 in Japan.Plans are also under way to expand shop within shops in department stores in North America, Europe and Japan.Michael Kors' own branded retail stores are higher margin than wholesale sales. They emphasize hand bags, small leather goods and other accessories such as fashion watches and jewelry, a newer category that flew off shelves in the past quarter.Michael Kors' American-style luxury sportswear apparel is a small part of the store mix.Ready-to-wear apparel from Kors and his design team are mostly sold in department and specialty stores.The two primary collections include the Michael Kors luxury line and the lower-priced accessible luxury collection known as Michael, which was introduced in 2004.Cohen says such multitier branding strategies have worked for Ralph Lauren (RL), Donna Karan and other fashion houses as well as for Coach (COH), the handbag and accessories company.Michael Kors competes with the larger Coach in handbags and accessories. Should Coach be worried?Johnson of Customer Growth Partners thinks so."Coach is encountering more competition from Michael Kors and Tory Burch," he said. "They are more today and tomorrow brands than Coach, which is a today and yesterday brand.""We do store checks all over the country," Johnson went on, "and we are seeing a little more buzz at the Tory Burch and Michael Kors stores."Chief Creative OfficerKors is still active in the company. He's chief creative officer. And he has more than half a million Twitter followers, according to CEO John Idol, a veteran of apparel and fashion concerns Kasper, Donna Karan and Ralph Lauren.Idol has told analysts that the firm is increasing spending on social media and expects to have more than 1 million Facebook fans by this month or next.Michael Kors' target and core customer is a 35-year-old woman who aspires to a "jet-set lifestyle," the company says.After the 30-to-40-year-olds, the next biggest category is women 18 to 25. That younger group is the company's fastest growing demographic, Idol said in a February conference call."As this young woman grows with us, she is going to be a loyal customer in the future," he said.
Stocks showed modest losses Tuesday in the wake of minutes from the latest meeting of the Federal Reserve's policymakers. But many market leaders braved the storm by pushing higher.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. The final hour of trade saw the averages pare slightly deeper losses: 1% for the S&P 500 and the Dow, 0.7% for the Nasdaq.
Volume rose across the board, according to early readings.

Minutes from the March 13 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee show that policymakers want to see inflation dip below 2% before they add to accommodation measures. All in all, the sense of urgency among FOMC members to add liquidity seems to be fading.
Apple (AAPL) continued its steep climb with a 2% gain in above-average volume. That makes a new high for the market leader.

SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) bolted 6% in heavy volume, putting the pharmacy benefits manager 3% above a 76.52 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Analysts speculated that the Federal Trade Commission's approval Monday for a takeover of Medco Health Solutions by Express Scripts (ESRX) made SXC a leading takeover candidate.

Gun maker Sturm Ruger (RGR) climbed 1% to a new high in double its average daily trade. The thinly traded stock is 10% past a 46.78 buy point from a square-box base. The company said last week that it had received orders for 1 million guns in the first quarter, exceeding its production capacity. Analysts say the firearm business is booming amid fears that President Obama would restrict gun ownership if re-elected this fall.
GNC Holdings (GNC) lurched ahead 2% in fast trade, notching a new high. With that gain, GNC stands 6% above its 33.80 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
Recent IPO Michael Kors (KORS) climbed 2%. It's still trading in a relatively tight band after a three-month run-up that saw the stock more than double from its IPO price.

Name-your-price travel site Priceline.com (PCLN), which has been on a tear, added 3%, hitting new highs in fast trade. Stratasys (SSYS) carved a 3% loss. The 3D printer maker slumped 9% last week, ending 7% below its 10-week moving average.

Women bought colorful jewelry and other accessories to spruce up dated wardrobes, giving a second-quarter jolt to Francesca's Holdings (FRAN). The chain of trendy clothing boutiques gave stronger guidance for the current quarter.

But the news was partially overshadowed by the announcement that CEO John De Meritt would step down at the end of the year. Neill Davis, president, will take over. Davis was hired away from Men's Wearhouse (MW) in July.
Shares closed up 2% to 36.07, but were down 4.6% after hours.
The company posted earnings of 28 cents per share, up 87% from a year ago and 4 cents better than analysts' consensus estimate.
Revenue climbed 49% to $76.4 million, beating estimates of $71.19 million. Sales at stores open at least a year surged 20.7%, its 13th straight quarter of same-store gains.
"Increased transactions, that's really been the driver for us for the last few quarters," De Meritt said in a conference call with analysts.
Jewelry Strong
The company said jewelry was its strongest category, though it didn't break out sales figures for it.
"In a bad economy, people want to buy accessories because you can change the look of many outfits just by changing your necklace," Mark Montagna, an Avondale Partners analyst, told IBD.

Francesca's guided for adjusted Q3 EPS of 21 to 22 cents, with analysts forecasting 19 cents. For the full year it said to expect earnings of 96 to 98 cents vs. views for 91 cents. It guided for low-double-digit same-store sales growth.
The Houston-based chain operates about 350 Francesca's Collections boutiques in 44 states, selling somewhat affordable, fashionable clothing and accessories. Its core audience are women age 18 to 35.
It sells trendy items, at affordable prices: colorful dresses for $44, boots for $58 and bright necklaces for $24.
The strategy is to go broad and shallow. It offers a wide array of items but limited quantities of each, creating a sense of scarcity and newness that keeps customers returning often, Montagna said.

Davis answered "all of the above," when analysts asked whether he shared that vision for quick-turn merchandise and national expansion. He said the company could eventually reach 900 stores nationwide.
De Meritt, a co-founder who became CEO in 2007, said he was stepping down to pursue other interests, without elaborating.
"I've decided that the time is right for me to hand over the reins," he told analysts.
Montagna suggested the transition might have been in the works for months with the potential for the top job being what allowed Francesca's to win the "heavy hitter" away from Men's Wearhouse.
Davis had 15 years with the men's retailer, most recently as chief financial officer and executive vice president.
Seasoned Executive

"Neill is a highly qualified and seasoned retail executive," Greg Brenneman, nonexecutive chairman, said in a statement. "His experience in helping Men's Wearhouse realize double-digit compound annual growth rates in sales and profitability during his 15-year tenure will be invaluable in the coming years."

Francesca's competitors are the White House/Black Market chain, owned by Chico's FAS (CHS), Ann Taylor, owned by Ann (ANN), Charlotte Russe, Brighton Collectibles and Urban Outfitter's (URBN) Anthropologie chain.

It's also up against the independent boutiques. Its roughly 1,400-square-foot stores are often located in trendy areas, such as New Orleans' Magazine Street and Montana Avenue in Santa Monica, Calif. Over the last few years, the company has expanded into malls.
"What's winning today is fashion, freshness, inventory turn and all at a value price. They have all of that," Montagna said.
Retail has been one of the bright spots of an otherwise lackluster economy this past quarter.

Last month, Chico's reported better-than-expected earnings and said it didn't have to resort to margin-eroding discounts to clear shelf space for fall fashions. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) outperformed on early back-to-school spending. Both raised their outlooks for the year.

And upscale fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) also shrugged off the slow economy, beating last month and noting a still-growing luxury market globally.Women bought colorful jewelry and other accessories to spruce up dated wardrobes, giving a second-quarter jolt to Francesca's Holdings (FRAN).
