The maker of women's handbags and leather accessories disappointed the Street as its reported lower-than-expected quarterly sales after being hurt by discounts in its North American market.
Coach's (COH) fiscal fourth-quarter sales grew 12% vs. the same quarter last year, to $1.16 billion. Analysts expected $1.199 billion.
Earning per share rose 27% to 86 cents, a penny above estimates.
Shares of the quality leather goods maker plunged 15% early, to 51.28 in morning trading. Its stock price has fallen about 27% from its 2012 high of 79.70 on March 27.

Coach's report could lift True Religion (TRLG), which reports after the market closes Tuesday. Analysts had speculated that True Religion's EPS could come in below the Street's consensus due to slowing sales in China. But Coach said it's seeing strong sales overseas, particularly in China, which partially offset the decline in North America. True Religion slid 2.8% to 26.50 Tuesday morning.
Coach CEO Lew Frankfort said robust international sales were driven by both distribution and productivity increases.

"In North America, however, an increasingly promotional environment led to lower growth than expected in factory stores. As a result, we responded by reinstating our prior practice of in-store couponing in a cross section of factory location late in the period."

During the quarter, Coach opened four new North American retail stores and seven factory outlets, including five dedicated men's stores. This brought the total to 354 retail stores and 169 factory stores in North America, the company's biggest market, as of June 30.
In China, the company opened 11 stores, bringing the total to 96.
Frankfort said in a written statement that the company's target is double-digit top- and bottom-line growth.
Elsewhere in the clothing and accessories market, Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), the only luxury brand maker on the IBD 50 list of top stocks, dropped 2.3% to 40.52. Kors reports results on Aug. 14.

Midrange boutique operator Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), another IBD 50 stock, was unchanged. Also on the list are discount retailers Ross Stores (ROST) and T.J. Maxx parent TJX Cos. This brought the total to 354 retail stores and 169 factory stores in North America, the company's biggest market, as of June 30.In China, the company opened 11 stores, bringing the total to 96.Frankfort said in a written statement that the company's target is double-digit top- and bottom-line growth.Elsewhere in the clothing and accessories market, Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), the only luxury brand maker on the IBD 50 list of top stocks, dropped 2.3% to 40.52. Kors reports results on Aug. 14.Midrange boutique operator Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), another IBD 50 stock, was unchanged. Also on the list are discount retailers Ross Stores (ROST) and T.J. Maxx parent TJX Cos. (TJX), which were unchanged and down 0.7%, respectively.

Prestige brands Coach (COH) — the handbag maker — and True Religion (TRLG) — the denim designer — are expected to report quarterly sales above estimates on Tuesday. But economic troubles abroad could impact retail sales. Only one luxury clothing and bag brand makes the IBD 50 list of top stocks at the moment: Michael Kors Holdings (KORS), which reports…

The Nasdaq failed to halt its losing streak Wednesday, but a rebound in the final 90 minutes of the session helped shave the leading index's losses. The large-cap S&P 500 closed virtually flat. Strength among energy, paper and a few financial stocks offset poor action among consumer goods and cyclical issues. The NYSE composite, still the laggard index among the…

Stocks ended mixed Wednesday, thanks to a late-session comeback that shaved a good chunk of the day's losses. The Nasdaq fell 0.5% after having been down as much as 1.2%. It managed to close above its 50-day line. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.4%. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 ended flat and also closed above its 50-day moving average. NYSE…
Stocks wavered to a mildly higher close Wednesday amid much better-than-expected data on February retail sales. Overall sales jumped 1.1%, more than doubling expectations.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 rose 0.1% each. The Dow Jones industrial average scored its ninth straight gain, rising a fraction to a new closing high. Volume fell across the board in the stock market today.

Michael Kors (KORS) rallied 4% in brisk volume after being upgraded to market outperform from market perform at Avondale Partners. The stock went back above its 50-day line, which it sliced in heavy trading Monday. Michael Kors tumbled 5% Monday on rumors of a slowdown in sales.

EverBank (EVER) ended mostly flat after cutting losses. After sliding 7% Tuesday on a downgrade, it fell an additional 4% early Wednesday before rebounding. The stock again found support near its 50-day line. EverBank blew past a 15.93 buy point from a double-bottom base March 5, but fell 7% below that trigger Tuesday. Investors should always cut losses at 7% to 8% from their purchase price.

U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA) continued to weaken, tumbling 7% in heavy trading Wednesday. The producer of silica used in glass, chemicals and oil-shale fracking, had already slid 8% Tuesday in reaction to news of a secondary share offering. Despite the hard hits, the stock is still extended from a rebound off its 10-week moving average.

CVR Energy (CVI) tumbled 8% after Macquarie downgraded shares of the oil refiner to underperform from neutral. The stock erased all of Tuesday's gain and a lot more. CVR cleared a 56.73 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern Feb. 28, but closed nearly 4% below that trigger Wednesday. The stock is nearing potential support at its 50-day line.
Analysts at Macquarie also downgraded rivals HollyFrontier (HFC) and Valero Energy (VLO) .

Initial jobless claims and producer prices will be out Thursday. Under Armour (UA) shares hit a new high on Tuesday after the athletic clothing manufacturer reported second-quarter earnings above Street estimates and raised guidance. Shares spiked 11.5% to 53.93 in afternoon trading, rising to 55 intraday. Under Armour said Q2 earnings were flat at 6 cents, topping estimates by a penny. Sales jumped 27% to $369.47 million, above views of…

Under Armour (UA) is expected to report a decline in profit but an increase in sales when it reports second-quarter results on Tuesday. Wall Street analysts are expecting the sports apparel company to report a 17% decline in earnings to 5 cents per share. Sales are seen rising 23% to $358.5 million. During its Q1 report Under Armour updated its…
The technology sector led an early market sell-off Thursday as weak Q2 results trumped a surprise decline in weekly jobless claims.
The Nasdaq slumped 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Volume was higher compared with the same time Wednesday.
India-based software engineer Infosys (INFY) dropped 12%, the largest decline on the Nasdaq 100, after dropping its full-year revenue outlook. The stock is trading at the lowest level in three years.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) fell 3%, the Dow's biggest decline, a day after a report from researcher Gartner showed PC sales down 0.1% in Q2, a seventh straight quarter of flat-to-single-digit gains. HP maintained its leading market share, but saw shipments slump 12%. Its shares are near 52-week lows.

But Merck (MRK) jumped 4% to lead both the S&P 500 and the Dow after reporting positive results in a trial of its experimental osteoporosis drug, odanacatib. An independent committee recommended the trial be closed early due to robust results showing fracture reductions from use of the oral drug. Analysts have forecast annual sales of odanacatib at $402 million by 2016, according to Thomson Pharma.

Among leaders, Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) carved a 4% loss at the open. The maker of chips for high-speed networking equipment dropped in four straight sessions through Wednesday. But the stock found support at its 50-day moving average. It is 5% below a 67.30 buy point.

Hong Kong-based design house Michael Kors (KORS) slipped 5%, falling deeper below its 50-day line. The stock closed just below the 50-day line in weak trade Wednesday. It has been consolidating since a March 9 high.

Family Dollar Stores (FDO) slipped 3% after Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded it to underperform from neutral. The brokerage put a 60 price target on the stock. The loss drove the stock back below its 50-day moving average in heavy trade.

GNC Holdings (GNC) dumped 3% in active turnover, looking to stretch its losing streak to five days as it broke below its 50-day line. The stock on Wednesday set off a sell rule by dropping 9% below its 42.05 buy point.

In commodities, oil slipped nearly 2% to below $85 a barrel. Natural gas was steady at $2.82 per million British thermal units. Gold faltered 1% to below $1,558 an ounce. Major averages traded in a tight range Monday and didn't give up much ground with a little more than an hour left in the session.

The Dow Jones industrial average led the way, falling 0.4%. The S&P lost 0.2% and the Nasdaq dropped less than 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume tracking about 20% lower than Friday. Nasdaq volume fell 14%.

In the stock market today, China-based medical-device maker Mindray Medical (MR) continued work on the right side of a base, rising nearly 2% to 41.94, ahead of its earnings report after the close. Its Relative Strength line is rising, a sign of technical strength. The potential buy point is 42.50. Mindray has delivered double-digit earnings and sales growth for four straight quarters.

Meanwhile, SolarCity (SCTY) led IBD's Energy-Solar group to a 3.7% gain. SolarCity jumped 7% ahead of its earnings report Wednesday after the close. It's been firming up at its 50-day moving average in recent weeks.

Elsewhere, IBD 50 component AVG Technologies (AVG) continued to firm up at its 10-week moving average, rising 8.5%. Shares of the Internet security software firm slumped 7% last week after the company reported earnings but the stock managed to close above its 10-week moving average.

Also in the IBD 50, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) enjoyed a heavy-volume up day, rising 3%. It reports Q2 results Wednesday after the close. Concerns about mounting competition for Green Mountain in the single-serve coffee market seem to be in the rear-view mirror for now. Green Mountain is working on a seven-week base and is only 3% off its 52-week.

The Nasdaq fell 1.8%, while the S&P 500 lost 1.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.6%. Volume soared on the Nasdaq and the NYSE by more…

IBD50 constituent Michael Kors  (KORS) is seeing unusually heavy and lopsided option trading entering Thursday's final hour. Net volume of roughly 20,000 contracts is seeing more than 80% of the trading concentrated in the puts with two block prints behind the activity.

Specifically, 7,750 August 40 puts traded for $2.40 in the opening minutes. A bit more than three hours later, an identical 7,750 August 36 puts were put up for $1.15. If you're of the mind the two are related and set up a vertical spread, you're not alone. However, as specific as that might sound, what actually happened, without talking to the parties involved firsthand, is a tough one to crack, though we'll give it a shot with the imperfect information that is available.

One key factor complicating matters is whether the position is opening or closing. Not only does existing open interest nearly match today's volume, yesterday saw an identical size "spread" of 7,750 put up for $1.70 compared to today's "staggered" $1.25 net cost. The activity ultimately begs the question of whether a trader is doubling up a bearish or bullish bet, exiting for a loss or closing for a profit of $0.45 per spread.

Higher implieds today on top of yesterday's bid and a vertical sporting slightly more vega per point in the 40 strike put suggest the trader may have added to a bear put spread. Also, the fact today's volume was spread out with the 40s trading first during this morning's "EU" euphoria (helping gap shares higher) could point to a bear trying to fade the move and receive a better price for a second vertical by waiting to sell the 36 strike put on anticipated weakness later on.

On the other hand and a scenario we like slightly more, today's action might represent a trader exiting a bull put spread. A profit of $0.45 may not sound all that enticing compared to the full $1.70 potential, but a more detailed interpretation of "higher implieds", skew and the vertical's vega, could hint at just that sort of closing buyer.

Digging a bit deeper into the pricing of implieds the past couple days reveals that while premiums lifted Wednesday, the increase was actually much smaller than today's bid. In fact, it appears the 40s and a contract now sporting more vega relative to the 36 put, saw implieds push higher by a handful of points compared to the typically upwardly skewed, lower strike put which remained largely flat.

That's odd behavior. But if we reestablish the intentions of the early block print in the 40 put as a trader wanting to close long deltas in fear of the bullish opening gap faltering during the session and looking to leg the long 36 put for more opportune prices later on, it seems to make sense enough, even if $0.45 doesn't do it for you.

What do you think? Feel free to share your opinion in the comments section below.IBD50 constituent Michael Kors  (KORS) is seeing unusually heavy and lopsided option trading entering Thursday's final hour. Movado (MOV) shares were on the uptick early Wednesday afternoon after the watchmaker raised its full-year guidance and issued a special dividend. Movado, which produces a wide variety of watches from affordable to luxurious, said third-quarter earnings rose 3% to 67 cents per share. Analysts were expecting 61 cents. Revenue climbed 12% to $160 million, beating estimates of $155 million,…

Priceline (PCLN) tops the list of IBD 50 companies that are set to report earnings this week as investors look for some good news to rebound from disappointing economic data earlier.The other companies on deck include TransDigm (TDG), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and Fossil (FOSL). The IBD 50 is a list of top growth stocks with top fundamentals and strong relative price strength.TransDigm, an aircraft parts maker, reports Tuesday and has posted accelerating earnings growth for three straight quarters, with gains climbing from 24% to 38%, 42% and 65%.Analysts expect Q2 profit of $1.46 a share, up 50.5% from a year ago. Aerospace suppliers have benefited from growing demand for passenger aircraft, especially in emerging markets.Discovery Communications also reports Tuesday and has notched four consecutive quarters of accelerating profit growth, helped by a lineup of programming with broad appeal across markets.The top provider of "edu-tainment" content, including Animal Planet and Discovery Channel, is expected to earn 60 cents a share in Q2, a 22% increase from a year ago.Fossil is due on Tuesday as well, and analysts see the watchmaker reporting a Q1 profit of 92 cents a share, up 7%. The company has been helped by the renewed popularity of a fashion accessory that was feared would sink into obsolescence with the rise of mobile phones.It also licenses and markets models from Armani, Michael Kors (KORS), DKNY, Burberry and Adidas, and wealthier consumers in Asia have been eager to show off such brands.Priceline will report Wednesday, and expectations are high for another solid quarter of double-digit earnings and revenue growth. Analysts see profit jumping 48% to $3.94 a share.Last quarter, the online travel agency easily topped forecasts on global hotel bookings, especially in Asia and other new markets, which have made up for weakness in Europe.Late last month, rival Expedia (EXPE) reported better-than-expected quarterly results. Last week, Expedia spinoff TripAdvisor (TRIP), an ad-supported user reviews site, also trounced analyst forecasts.
Stocks opened higher in healthy trade Thursday, despite weaker than expected manufacturing and construction spending data.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%; the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 gained 0.4% each. Volume was up slightly on the Nasdaq and about 12% higher on the NYSE compared with the same time Wednesday.
The Institute for Supply Management's February index slipped to 52.4, down from a 54.1 reading in January, missing expectations for a gain to 54.7. The gauge had increased for four straight months.
Construction spending for January also disappointed, down 0.1% after a 1.4% increase in December. Analysts had forecast a 1% increase.

Bank Of America (BAC) led the Dow, up 2%, after news reports detailed company plans to institute fees for customers who don't bank online, and to nudge customers to buy more products and maintain prescribed minimum balances. JPMorgan (JPM) also gained 2%.
Apparel retailer Gap (GPS) popped 11% after reporting a 6% increase in February sales. The company's Banana Republic stores led with a 12% increase.
Among leaders, Polaris Industries (PII) throttled up 4% at the open, climbing 8% above a 63.16 buy point after clearing a double-bottom base Jan. 25.

Coinstar (CSTR) climbed 3% out of the gate, working to get above recent resistance near 60. The Redbox movie rental kiosk operator is featured in today's New America section. The stock recovered a portion of Wednesday's 6% decline, leaving shares 5% above a buy point of 57.17.

3D Systems (DDD) and shale boom-related stocks are among the companies with top fundamentals that are also changing the face of the U.S. industrial sector. The proliferation of 3D printers could revolutionize manufacturing, while a cheap, reliable source of domestic energy has lowered costs enough for U.S. plants to make them more competitive internationally. IBD's Top Fundamentals Screen Of The…

Losses were oddly distributed among leaders Friday as the market coped with bad news from the fiscal-cliff war. Some leaders got smacked, some held up with modest losses — and a few actually moved up.Fashion designer and retailer Michael Kors (KORS) fell 3% in modestly above-average volume. But the stock had sunk as much as 6% before clawing back enough to regain its 10-week line.U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA), a provider of silica to various industries — including fracking companies — dived 3%. Here, too, volume was muted. And the stock pared what was a 7% loss.But Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) shot up 4% to a new high. Volume surged to four times its norm. The oil and gas producer broke out Tuesday from a cup base. The 26.70 buy point sparked a volume surge that has yet to cool off. Bonanza ended the session 8% above that trigger.FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a provider of payment solutions to commercial fleets and oil companies, poked 1% higher in low volume. FleetCor has been riding higher for months along its uptrending 10-week moving average.Drugmaker Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) climbed 1% in fast trade. The stock scored a small upside reversal after dropping 1% at the open. Watson is pushing past resistance at 90, which looks like a breakout from a shallow base.Home-beverage-systems maker SodaStream (SODA) fell 3% in average turnover, but the stock recovered from an earlier 6% loss. SodaStream couldn't quite regain its 43.10 cup-with-handle buy point.3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS), two makers of 3D printers and prototype systems, each bucked the selling to log small gains in below-average trade.3D Systems ended 16% past its 44.90 buy point from a cup-shaped base. That breakout was treacherous. The stock fell 8% from its Nov. 1 breakout, then regained the trigger price, then fell 8% again — and then took off.Stratasys also has put in a choppy climb. The stock ended 15% above its 69.18 cup-with-handle entry.Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), a Chinese Web-based security software distributor and, more recently, the search engine that's challenging Baidu's (BIDU) dominance, pared its 3% loss to just 1%, and finished 9% above its 24.40 trigger from a cup-with-handle base.Cloud issue SolarWinds (SWI) fell 3% in fast trade. Online travel agent TripAdvisor (TRIP) fell 2%.

With many players absent from Friday's half-day session, most Sector Leaders performed like the broad market, moving up with much-decreased volume. Polaris Industries (PII) climbed above its 50-day line, adding 1.32, or 2%, to 84.02 in less than half its usual volume. The stock recorded its sixth-straight win, regaining a good chunk of ground lost in the prior six sessions,…

Stocks stumbled Monday amid troubling overseas news. The Nasdaq dropped to its lowest level in more than a month, but then bounced back somewhat to trim its loss. The Nasdaq finished with a 1% loss, after trading as much as 1.8% lower. The NYSE composite fared slightly worse, dropping 1.1% after also being down 1.8% intraday. The S&P 500 and…

Hurricane Sandy slowed consumer spending before the important holiday season, causing retail sales to dip in October for the first time in three months the Commerce Department, announced on Wednesday.
Retail sales fell 0.3%, ending three straight months of gains including a 1.3% increase in September. Analysts were only expecting a 0.2% dip.

As areas of New Jersey and Long Island remain without power, the full effect of Sandy won't be known for months. The storm is estimated to have caused $50 billion in damages on the East Coast and could reduce Q4 GDP by half a percentage point.
Auto sales fell 1.5% last month due to Sandy. Replacing vehicles ruined by Sandy could boost future auto sales.

Core retail sales, which does not include autos, gasoline and building materials, fell 0.1% after rising nearly 1% in September. Sales at apparel chains fell 0.1% after a 0.4% gain in September boosted by back-to-school shopping.

Luxury apparel brands like Ralph Lauren (RL) and Coach (COH) have struggled the past month on economic worries. Michael Kors (KORS) bucked the trend, reporting a triple-digit rise in EPS for the fourth straight quarter. But after rising modestly Tuesday, Kors shares fell Wednesday afternoon to their lowest level in nearly three months.
Department store sales fell 0.3% in October. Last week Nordstrom (JWN) reported EPS that missed estimates and Macy's (M)gave weak Q4 guidance due to Hurricane Sandy.
General merchandise, which includes Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), rose 0.2%. Both big-box retailers are slated to report earnings Thursday.
Building materials and garden equipment sales rose 2.1%. Home Depot (HD) raised guidance on Tuesday after reporting earnings above estimates.

Electronics sales fell 1% after Apple's (AAPL) much anticipated iPhone 5 release boosted sales in September.Hurricane Sandy slowed consumer spending before the important holiday season, causing retail sales to dip in October for the first time in three months the Commerce Department, announced on Wednesday.Retail sales fell 0.3%, ending three straight months of gains including a 1.3% increase in September. Analysts were only expecting a 0.2% dip.As areas of New Jersey and Long Island remain without power, the full effect of Sandy won't be known for months. China is so big and is growing so fast that it's becoming increasingly common for well-run companies to have significant Chinese connections. IBD's rotating Screen Center today focuses on Top Fundamentals, companies with a long run of strong fundamentals. Here are the five members with Greater China ties.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) (3-year EPS growth rate: 728%)Wynn Resorts (WYNN) (3-year EPS growth rate: 103%)These two U.S.-based casino giants are riding the wave of Macau, China's special zone that is the only part of the country where casinos are allowed. It's surpassed Las Vegas as the world's largest gaming market. Sands just opened its huge Cotai casino resort there and reportedly is close to picking between Madrid and Barcelona for a Spanish gaming mecca. Meanwhile, Wynn reportedly is in negotiations to build a new Macau casino of its own.Macau's gaming growth is slowing but remains solid.Las Vegas Sands reports earnings on April 25. Analysts expect a 58% EPS gain. That follows a 36% advance in the year-end quarter on a 26% revenue increase.Wynn should report results in early May. Wall Street sees just a 2% per-share profit rise. That follows a 70% bump on a modest 9% sales gain.Wynn shares shot up Wednesday to a new closing high on that new casino buzz. Sands shares hit a record high on April 10 and are trading modestly below that peak.Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) (3-year EPS growth rate: 114%)The company is technically based in Hong Kong, but most of its sales are in America and Europe. Still, with such strong growth, the fashion designer and retailer fits right in with the other companies listed here. Kors only came public in December, then followed up with an 83% profit gain as revenue soared 91%. Analysts see a 75% earnings gain next time.Kors' shares had a huge run initially, ultimately peaking in early March. Since late March, the stock has stumbled and is now trading below its 50-day line.Baidu.com (BIDU) (3-year EPS growth rate: 95%)There's no denying Baidu's inclusion here. Its long-term performance has been great. It's a mainland Chinese company, with nearly all of its operations and revenue there. Baidu is the dominant search engine in the world's largest, and still fast growing, Internet market. Global giant Google (GOOG) curbed its China operations a few years ago amid censorship and security issues there.Baidu reports earnings on April 24. Analysts expect earnings per share rose 75% vs. a year earlier. That follows a Q4 2011 EPS rise of 83% as revenue climbed 91%.Baidu shares are near the top of a consolidation that began in July.Apple (AAPL) (3-year EPS growth rate: 68%)The tech titan manufactures and assembles, via suppliers, most of its iPhones, iPads and other amazing gadgets in China. This includes the infamous Foxconn plant with its massive staff, tough working conditions and some headline-grabbing suicides.But China also is a big opportunity market for Apple sales, though it's probably only scratching the surface of its long-term potential there as millions of people join the country's middle class every year.Apple, like Baidu, reports on April 24. Analysts expect quarterly profit rose "only" 55%. That follows the eye-popping 116% gain last quarter on the back of a 73% sales rise.Apple shares peaked on April 10, when the stock briefly enjoyed a $600 billion market cap. The stock retreated for five straight sessions but found support above its 50-day line. Apple shares fell early Thursday as an analyst clipped 2012 EPS forecasts but raised the price target.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @EdCarson1.

Nasdaq 100 futures traded fractionally higher. The major indexes are tracking toward a mixed finish this week. The Nasdaq ended Thursday up 0.3% so far this…

Think of some of the themes you've found in leaders in the past few years: technology, retail and high-growth economies. A good number of winners thrived on the wave of at least one of these themes, some enjoyed two.MercadoLibre (MELI) sits in the nexus of all three.The Argentina-based company is a sort of Latin American  eBay (EBAY), operating platforms that allow for auction-style sales and virtual stores in a dozen Latin American and Caribbean countries.MercadoLibre facilitates payments in six of these markets with its MercadoPago system, which works a lot like PayPal.This column in Tuesday's edition noted the rash of retailers that led the market's recent uptrend. They included  Lululemon Athletica (LULU), GNC Holdings (GNC), Tractor Supply (TSCO) and Michael Kors (KORS).Each of these retail stars found a niche to help it stand out. After all, if there's one thing we have no shortage of, it's stores.For example, GNC grabs prime retail space to sell its line of high-priced nutrients to the health-conscious workout crowd. Michael Kors has targeted the concept of affordable luxury fashion. And Lululemon Athletica sells its own line of yoga-themed exercise apparel and accessories.These niches are unique.But MercadoLibre, or the vendors that operate on any of its platforms, can sell anything or everything, just like eBay. What's special about everything?We're really looking at the upside of tapping into a fast-growing emerging market.True, introducing an online business in a region where penetration is rising and has room to grow seems like a winning idea.But that seems a normal part of the bigger story. Latin America is largely a fast-growing region. A middle class is emerging in countries such as Brazil (the region's anchor economy, which accounted for 56% of sales last year). Wealth is being created and spent.Nearly 76 million Brazilians were Internet users as of June 2011, according to Internet World Stats. That's 37.4% of the population. The government says the number of Internet users will grow 13.9% this year.Urban unemployment fell to 4.7% in December, an all-time low.And, crucially, per-capita GDP rose to $11,600 in 2011. That's up 2.6% for the year — and 53% in the past decade.The World Bank says Brazil's economy rose 7.5% in 2010. Credit-rating agency Fitch Ratings said in December that Brazil's GDP likely rose 2.8% in 2011.Morgan Stanley thinks growth will rise to 3.5% this year. The central bank is easing after a series of rate hikes. The new posture should help restore consumption and growth, Morgan Stanley said in December.MercadoLibre earned 47 cents per share in Q4 on sales of $86.5 million. Both results missed estimates, which seems to be traced to currency movements.MercadoLibre's chart shows a flat base developing, and a recently formed handle points to a buy point at 103.08.Volume has been light during the five-week correction, which combines with the tight price action to form a sound pattern.

Stocks stayed in mildly positive territory with an hour left in Friday's trading session despite a rebound in oil prices and a decline in new-home sales for a second straight month.
The Nasdaq erased morning gains to rise 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 both rallied 0.4%, also reversing earlier losses. Volume was still running lower.

New-home sales dipped in February to 313,000 vs. 318,000 homes sold in January. Analysts had expected a rise to 323,000 homes. Sales had increased for three months through December. The Census Bureau revised January's number downward from an initial estimate of 321,000 sales.
Homebuilders and retailers suffered the biggest declines. Mining and metals stocks did best.

KB Home (KBH) was down 8% after plunging as much as 15% earlier in huge volume following the company's announcement that first-quarter orders fell sharply. The stock, which has fallen below its 50-day moving average, has a poor Earnings Per Share Rating of 14.
Lennar (LEN) (15 EPS Rating) and luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. (TOL) (12 EPS) posted smaller declines of 2% or less and managed to hold their 50-day lines.

Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) soared 8% to a new high in strong volume. The wide area networking gear maker has an average daily volume of just 298,000 shares, below the 400,000-share threshold desired. But 91 funds owned shares as of the December quarter, a sign of hearty institutional demand.

Ubiquiti cleared resistance at 23 in huge volume in the week ended Feb. 3 and has rallied 32%. The stock holds a 97 Composite Rating, highest within the 39-member Telecom-Infrastructure industry group. The group, which also includes Neustar (NSR), is ranked 63rd among 197 IBD industry groups for six-month performance.

Among retailers, Michael Kors (KORS) was down 2% after the luxury fashion house priced a secondary offering of 25 million shares at 47, a 3.5% discount to Thursday's closing price. The selling shareholders granted a 30-day option for underwriters to purchase up to 3.75 million additional shares.
The new issue is still on track for a weekly gain and is 138% above its December initial offering price.
Deep discount retailer Dollar General (DG) rose 3%, climbing to new highs in strong trade for the second straight day. The stock is 12% past a 42.20 buy point.
Meanwhile, metals processor Valmont Industries (VMI) was up 2% in average turnover. It's 5% past a 108.61 entry in a cup-with-handle base, putting the stock at the top end of its buying range.

Randgold Resources (GOLD) gained 1%, reversing an earlier 6% loss on the heels of Thursday's 12% gap down. The gold miner has toppled on events in Mali, where the military turned on the country's leadership, apparently seizing Bamako, the capital.

On Thursday, a company statement said Randgold's chief executive, Mark Bristow, was at the company's Loulo complex in west Mali, about 200 miles from the capital. He said the country was calm, although exact details were unclear, and that company operations were unaffected. A reported 60% to 70% of Randgold's assets are located in Mali.

In the tech sector, chipmaker InvenSense (INVN) jumped 7% in heavy trade, closing in on a new high as it continues a strong rebound from its 50-day line. The stock, which went public last November, is out of buying range.

Micron Technology (MU) dropped 4% after reporting lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings. Revenue slipped a less-than-expected 8%. The Boise, Idaho-based chipmaker lost its chief executive, Steve Appleton, in an aircraft accident in February. But they outperformed during last week's short trading week.Thanks to big gains in several top stocks, the IBD 50 climbed 0.6% for the week vs. a 0.2% gain for the S&P 500. The Nasdaq fell 0.2%.CommVault Systems (CVLT) blasted up 23% for week, putting it back above its 10-week line and a 53.90 buy point. The maker of storage software surged on better-than-expected fiscal Q2 2013 results. Its earnings jumped 58% to 38 cents a share. That was the biggest gain in five quarters. Helped by new enrollments, sales grew 23% to $133.6 million. That marked the fifth straight period of acceleration. Are retailers ready to store up? Decisions on whether to open new locations could be swayed by how much cheer consumers deliver during holiday 2012.

As Americans start their holiday shopping they'll have yet more online choices, more outlet stores filled with designer goods and the return of seasonal pop-up stores, at a time when retailers and mall owners are trying to squeeze more out of their space than in years past.

Predictions call for a solid showing, but not a stellar one. How high or low this year's holiday sales and profit numbers actually come in could steer store planning toward or away from expansion in 2013.

"Most prognosticators expect this holiday's retail sales to be better than last year and the trailing 10-year historical average — despite the economy," said Ryan Severino, senior economist at real estate research firm Reis (REIS).

"With little construction coming online in the fourth quarter, there's some hope that this could translate into at least slightly increased demand for retail space and buttress retail fundamentals," he said.

November-December brick-and-mortar retailer holiday sales should rise roughly 3% over last year, forecasts Michael Niemira, chief economist at the International Council of Shopping Centers. While that would be less than last year's 3.7% gain, it would still amount to a "relatively healthy" holiday season, Niemira says, and above the 2.1% 10-year average rise in holiday sales. The data exclude most brick-and-mortar retailers' online sales.
Profit Picture Perks Up

Analysts see U.S. retailer fourth-quarter profits rising 13.9% from a year ago, says Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. They were up only 2.5% year over year in 2011's fourth quarter as stores came under big margin pressures from major discounting, rising cotton prices and free shipping, Perkins says.

This time, retailers are heading into the holiday with well-managed and controlled inventories, he adds. With inventories in good shape and solid demand, Perkins does not expect to see any "fire sales."

Most retailers have kept expansion plans modest lately, Niemira notes. Some, though, are selectively growing their footprint. Department store chain Nordstrom (JWN), for example, is boosting its Nordstrom Rack discount locations as that business thrives. It sees opening 24 Racks in 2013 vs. 15 this year. Dollar stores have also expanded fast, but aren't so sensitive to holiday sales as others.
"The slow recovery of the last several years has put a damper on expansion in the industry," Niemira said of retail generally.
Store openings have also been limited because developers aren't building many shopping centers.
"Very few retailers are expanding right now outside of the restaurants," Severino said. "Most are holding off, and the ones who are expanding are keeping things quite modest."
Severino expects only about 11 million square feet of space to be absorbed in 2012, but about 21 million in 2013.

Through the third quarter of 2012, total U.S. retail space has inched up only 0.2% from a year earlier, following a rise of 0.3% for all of 2011 and 0.4% in 2010, Niemira says, citing data from CoStar Realty Information. It's far down from as recently as 2006-08, when yearly growth ranged from 1.8% to 2.2%.

"Clearly, the pace of expansion has virtually ground to a halt," Niemira said. "But existing holders of retail property find this a plus since less new supply will help to absorb the vacant space more effectively today and generate more rent."

Opinions vary on how much weight this holiday season's numbers will carry, in determining whether stores expand assertively or not much at all. But given forecasts for a healthy Christmas season, many analysts expect the numbers to favor expansion, though they don't see a boom in the cards.

Retailers won't make long-term moves based on a single holiday, Severino says. But if they see 2012 holiday sales are up from, say, 2011 and 2010, they may decide the time is right to capitalize on still-low rents and lease more space.
Money In The Stocking

If forecasts for a 3% to 3.3% rise in 2012 holiday sales are on target, and if retailers are able to hit or exceed expected profit margins on their sales gains, it should give them additional funds to invest in expansion, notes John Bemis, executive vice president at the retail arm of commercial real estate firm Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL).

"If sales and margins line up the way they are projected for the 2012 holiday, retailers should have a good profit picture at the end of the holiday and that in turn should drive additional store expansion in 2013," Bemis said.
If a retailer was planning to add perhaps 20 stores in 2013, and it does particularly well over the holiday, that may give it the added funds needed to open 25, he says.

Typically, a successful holiday season plays a large role in determining a retailer's growth plans for the following year, says Garrick Brown, director of research for retail real estate brokerage ChainLinks Retail Advisors.
Expanding Tradition

Take what happened in 2011, after holiday sales came in well above what was forecast. The surprising success of the season helped spur retailer expansion. By the spring, overall unit growth plans for 2012 were up 20% from before the holiday, Brown says.

This year, he predicts, the holiday won't be as much of a factor in expansion, though it should be a successful season. He says a lot of people are waiting to see what happens with the fiscal cliff. Brown expects holiday 2012 to lift unit growth plans for 2013 by 10% at most by the spring, vs. before the holiday season.

"When I speak to site selection guys they're all trying to figure out where the tax policy will be next year," Brown said. "Because of that they're postponing doing deals. A lot of people have deals near the finish line, but they're holding off to see what will happen."

Also, in the past, the big sales boost resulting from a successful holiday season had been strongest among midpriced mall apparel retailers. But they're not in growth mode because the typical middle-income consumer is still being frugal, Brown says.
But Bemis says the midpriced store segment is beginning to perform better and should see sales gains for the holidays.

He says midmarket retailers such as department store Macy's (M), Victoria's Secret's parent Limited Brands (LTD) and teen apparel chain American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) are at a price point that accounts for the majority of stores in shopping centers across the U.S.
Bright At Both Ends

The luxury goods segment is also performing extremely well, Bemis says. It includes store operators such as Saks (SKS), Nordstrom and Michael Kors Holdings (KORS). That booming handbag and fashion brand, No. 2 on the IBD 50 list of top companies, has stores on New York's Madison Avenue and in Beverly Hills, Calif., and in malls. It also runs popular discount outlets.
Value retailers are also still doing extremely well. Discounters Family Dollar Stores (FDO) and Dollar General (DG) will open more stores than other retailers, Bemis says.
Overall, retail chains — mostly conservative on expansion — are starting to loosen the reins, he says.

"I expect this slow, steady increase to continue through 2013 and most likely 2014," Bemis said. "But I don't think we will see a huge spike like we saw in 2001."Are retailers ready to store up? Decisions on whether to open new locations could be swayed by how much cheer consumers deliver during holiday 2012.As Americans start their holiday shopping they'll have yet more online choices, more outlet stores filled with designer goods and the return of seasonal pop-up stores, at a time when retailers and mall owners are trying to squeeze more out of their space than in years past.Predictions call for a solid showing, but not a stellar one. Dollar stores have also expanded fast, but aren't so sensitive to holiday sales as others."The slow recovery of the last several years has put a damper on expansion in the industry," Niemira said of retail generally.Store openings have also been limited because developers aren't building many shopping centers."Very few retailers are expanding right now outside of the restaurants," Severino said. "Most are holding off, and the ones who are expanding are keeping things quite modest."Severino expects only about 11 million square feet of space to be absorbed in 2012, but about 21 million in 2013.Through the third quarter of 2012, total U.S. retail space has inched up only 0.2% from a year earlier, following a rise of 0.3% for all of 2011 and 0.4% in 2010, Niemira says, citing data from CoStar Realty Information. It's far down from as recently as 2006-08, when yearly growth ranged from 1.8% to 2.2%."Clearly, the pace of expansion has virtually ground to a halt," Niemira said. "But existing holders of retail property find this a plus since less new supply will help to absorb the vacant space more effectively today and generate more rent."Opinions vary on how much weight this holiday season's numbers will carry, in determining whether stores expand assertively or not much at all. But given forecasts for a healthy Christmas season, many analysts expect the numbers to favor expansion, though they don't see a boom in the cards.Retailers won't make long-term moves based on a single holiday, Severino says. But if they see 2012 holiday sales are up from, say, 2011 and 2010, they may decide the time is right to capitalize on still-low rents and lease more space.Money In The Stocking If forecasts for a 3% to 3.3% rise in 2012 holiday sales are on target, and if retailers are able to hit or exceed expected profit margins on their sales gains, it should give them additional funds to invest in expansion, notes John Bemis, executive vice president at the retail arm of commercial real estate firm Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL)."If sales and margins line up the way they are projected for the 2012 holiday, retailers should have a good profit picture at the end of the holiday and that in turn should drive additional store expansion in 2013," Bemis said.If a retailer was planning to add perhaps 20 stores in 2013, and it does particularly well over the holiday, that may give it the added funds needed to open 25, he says.Typically, a successful holiday season plays a large role in determining a retailer's growth plans for the following year, says Garrick Brown, director of research for retail real estate brokerage ChainLinks Retail Advisors.Expanding TraditionTake what happened in 2011, after holiday sales came in well above what was forecast. The surprising success of the season helped spur retailer expansion. By the spring, overall unit growth plans for 2012 were up 20% from before the holiday, Brown says.This year, he predicts, the holiday won't be as much of a factor in expansion, though it should be a successful season. He says a lot of people are waiting to see what happens with the fiscal cliff. Brown expects holiday 2012 to lift unit growth plans for 2013 by 10% at most by the spring, vs. before the holiday season."When I speak to site selection guys they're all trying to figure out where the tax policy will be next year," Brown said. "Because of that they're postponing doing deals. A lot of people have deals near the finish line, but they're holding off to see what will happen."Also, in the past, the big sales boost resulting from a successful holiday season had been strongest among midpriced mall apparel retailers. But they're not in growth mode because the typical middle-income consumer is still being frugal, Brown says.But Bemis says the midpriced store segment is beginning to perform better and should see sales gains for the holidays.He says midmarket retailers such as department store Macy's (M), Victoria's Secret's parent Limited Brands (LTD) and teen apparel chain American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) are at a price point that accounts for the majority of stores in shopping centers across the U.S.Bright At Both EndsThe luxury goods segment is also performing extremely well, Bemis says. It includes store operators such as Saks (SKS), Nordstrom and Michael Kors Holdings (KORS). That booming handbag and fashion brand, No. 2 on the IBD 50 list of top companies, has stores on New York's Madison Avenue and in Beverly Hills, Calif., and in malls. It also runs popular discount outlets.Value retailers are also still doing extremely well. Discounters Family Dollar Stores (FDO) and Dollar General (DG) will open more stores than other retailers, Bemis says.Overall, retail chains — mostly conservative on expansion — are starting to loosen the reins, he says."I expect this slow, steady increase to continue through 2013 and most likely 2014," Bemis said. "But I don't think we will see a huge spike like we saw in 2001."

There's no substitute for the fundamentals of solid revenue and profit growth over time, and some companies in Thursday's IBD Stock Screen have more than doubled earnings in just the last few years.Past big market winners showed robust earnings and sales increases before big price moves. For some companies with top gains in the last three years, the stock price has already taken off.Triple-digit surges in quarterly earnings per share are common among the fundamental leaders. Long strings of quarterly double-digit revenue advances also are frequent.Here are the top five.Northern Oil & Gas (NOG)The energy company tops the list but doesn't do the actual drilling or other activities usually associated with oil exploration and production. Instead, it acts as a minority investor in wells, with an exclusive focus on the Williston Basin in North Dakota and Montana.That's part of the Bakken oil shale formation that has become one of the richest U.S. deposits in recent years, helped by newer but controversial extraction techniques like hydraulic fracturing.A “non-operator,” Northern Oil can avoid operating and overhead costs, allowing the Wayzata, Minn., company to call itself a low-cost producer. Its Q4 earnings report is due early next month, with per-share profit expected to nearly double to 25 cents on revenue of $55 million, up by five times from a year ago.Northern Oil has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 154%.Equinix (EQIX)The data center operator reported Q4 results last week that missed profit expectations. Earnings rose 21% to 35 cents a share, below views of 44 cents. Sales rose 25% to $431.3 million, beating views of $429.8 million.But the stock price barely had a hiccup and promptly continued a rapid climb. It has surged 33% since the start of the year and 60% since October. Demand for data centers has grown with the proliferation of cloud-based services and media-rich content for wireless devices. Equinix plans to expand its geographical reach and rentable space.Equinix has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 118%.Accretive Health (AH)The company provides software and services to help hospitals register patients, track their care, collect bills and verify insurance benefits.With hospitals looking to save money or cope with budget cuts, they have turned to IT tools to improve efficiency. That has meant more business for companies like Accretive. The last three quarters saw per-share earnings jumps of 83%, 71% and 100%. The next report due in early March is expected to show another surge of 78%.Accretive Health has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 116%.Baidu (BIDU)The Chinese search leader dominates the world's largest Internet market and doesn't look like it will lose its grip any time soon. Despite its excellent fundamentals, the stock price has been choppy, retreating since last week's report.It gets most of its revenue from ads placed with search results and expanded its market share after global search leader Google (GOOG) exited the China market over government censorship policies.Last week's Q4 report had profit and revenue that beat analysts' estimates, but Q1 outlook that disappointed. Earning growth has slowed from its triple-digit pace but is still in the 80s.Baidu has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 88%.Michael Kors Holdings (KORS)The luxury apparel and accessory retailer has only been public for a few months and has released only one quarterly report since its December IPO.It also appeared on Tuesday's Young Guns stock screen of leading newly public companies.Its Q3 report easily topped forecasts as the wholesale, retail and licensing divisions all saw growth. Kors guided Q4 profit in line with forecasts, on revenue ahead of predictions.Michael Kors has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 81%.Other companies making the fundamentals screen include megacap Apple (AAPL) and Latin American e-commerce firm MercadoLibre (MELI). Apple has a 3-year EPS growth rate of 62%, with a 122% profit gain in the latest quarter. MercadoLibre has a 3-year growth rate of 68%. It's expected to report a 42% EPS gain to 51 cents for the latest quarter after Thursday's market close.

Handbag and accessories stocks rose Tuesday as Fossil (FOSL) soared 31.4% in afternoon trading on its strong Q2 results and Tumi (TUMI) lifted 28.3% after an upgrade.
IBD 50 stock Michael Kors (KORS), getting to be a big name in handbags, rose 2.2%, and Coach (COH) the same.

Fossil, the handbag and watch maker, cited strength in key Asia markets where economic worries have been affecting some higher-end brands. Fossil makes watches for Armani Exchange, Marc by Marc Jacobs and Michael Kors as well as its namesake line.
Another watch maker, Movado (MOV), jumped 13.3%.

Fossil said before the stock market opened that second-quarter earnings were up 15% to 93 cents per share, beating views by 15 cents. Sales rose 14.3% to $636.1 million, above estimates of $634.9 million.

Fossil said its gross profit rose 14.2% to $356.4 million vs. $312.0 million last year. Revenue from the company's wholesale segment increased 14% to $481.9 million. Wholesale revenue in North America jumped 17% to $249.8 million on higher watch sales and its Skagen branded merchandise.

"Across each of our geographical segments we experienced acceleration in wholesale sales growth in comparison to our first quarter of 2012. Constant dollar sales of watches worldwide increased by 23.2% and included contributions from almost all major brands," said CFO Mike Kovar. "In Asia, we saw constant dollar sales grow by 27.2% demonstrating the success of our investments in this opportunity and the heightened consumer demand for FOSSIL and our multi-brand watch portfolio."
Fossil sees full year outlook of $5.29-$5.34 per share. Analysts are expecting $5.28.
The Retail/Wholesale-Jewelry group is ranked No. 188 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.
Luggage maker Tumi reported a second-quarter EPS of 13 cents, in line with views and sales of $95.93 million, topping views, on Monday after the market closed.

Credit Suisse analyst Christian Buss raised the recent IPO from neutral to outperform and lifted the price target from $23 to $25. He believes that Tumi has only reached 30% of its global penetration potential according to an investor's note in a Reuters article.
The Leisure-Products group is ranked No. 88.
Ralph Lauren (RL), slated to report earnings Wednesday, rose 2.3% in late afternoon trading.

Other retailers reporting this week include: Macy's (M) on Wednesday, Nordstrom (JWN) and Kohl's (KSS) on Thursday and J.C. Penney (JCP) on Friday. Ralph Lauren Corporation (RL  -  Free Report) is slated to release fourth-quarter fiscal 2018 results on May 23, before the market opens. The company posted positive earnings surprise of 8.6% in the last reported quarter.Moreover, the company delivered positive earnings surprises in the trailing four quarters, with an average beat of 10.4%. Let’s see how things are shaping up prior to this announcement.What to ExpectThe question lingering in investors’ minds is whether this designer, marketer and distributor of premium lifestyle products will be able to deliver a positive earnings surprise in the quarter to be reported. The company’s Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter under review is pegged at 86 cents, reflecting a year-over-year decline of 3.4%. We note that earnings estimates for the current quarter have been stable in the last 30 days. Moreover, analysts polled by Zacks expect revenues of $1.49 billion, down about 4.7% from the year-ago quarter.Ralph Lauren Corporation Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise Ralph Lauren Corporation Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise | Ralph Lauren Corporation QuoteRalph Lauren has outperformed the industry in the past year, driven by its positive earnings trend. The company’s shares have surged 53.2%, compared with industry’s gain of 39.1%.Factors at PlayRalph Lauren has a robust surprise trend with positive earnings surprises delivered in 12 straight quarters. The company has been gaining from favorable geographic and channel-mix shifts along with lower promotions and reduced product costs. Additionally, results in the recent quarters have been gaining from foreign currency tailwinds.The company adjusted fiscal 2018 outlook to account positive currency rates, which are likely to aid revenues and operating margins. Further, the outlook for fiscal fourth-quarter reflects optimism. The company expects fiscal fourth-quarter reported revenues to be down 8-10%, excluding currency impact. The company anticipates foreign currency to aid revenue growth by nearly 330 basis points (bps). Though it expects operating margin to decline 240-260 bps on a currency-neutral basis, foreign currency is likely to boost operating margin by about 90 bps in the fiscal fourth quarter.Including ASU 2016-09, the tax rate is expected to be nearly 3% in the quarter under review, driven by lower U.S. federal statutory income tax, owing to the new tax reform.Furthermore, Ralph Lauren remains focused to deliver goals under its Way Forward Plan while bolstering digital and international presence. Additionally, it is well on track with its restructuring plan, which is likely to generate savings of roughly $140 million by the end of fiscal 2019. These restructuring activities include rightsizing the portfolio and cost-structure alongside streamlining the organizational structure. All these factors make us optimistic about Ralph Lauren’s upcoming results.However, the company’s North America business continues to suffer due to distribution and brand exits, a planned reduction in shipments and promotions to enhance the quality of sales, and lower customer demand.What the Zacks Model UnveilsOur proven model does not conclusively show that Ralph Lauren is likely to beat earnings estimates this quarter. This is because a stock needs to have both a positive Earnings ESP and a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold) for this to happen. You can uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they’re reported with our Earnings ESP Filter.Ralph Lauren currently has a Zacks Rank #2 and an Earnings ESP of 0.00%. The combination of the company’s Zacks Rank and Earnings ESP makes surprise prediction difficult.Stocks With Favorable CombinationHere are some companies that you may want to consider as our model shows that these have the right combination of elements to post an earnings beat:Michael Kors Holdings Limited (KORS  -  Free Report) has an Earnings ESP of +6.82% and a Zacks Rank #2. (PVH  -  Free Report) has an Earnings ESP of +1.22% and a Zacks Rank #3.Today's Stocks from Zacks' Hottest StrategiesIt's hard to believe, even for us at Zacks. After reporting a positive earnings surprise of 14.3% in the final quarter of 2017, Office Depot, Inc. (ODP  -  Free Report) delivered in line earnings in the first quarter of 2018. Meanwhile, the top line came ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the third straight quarter.Favorable results and strategic initiatives, including strengthening of core businesses and expansion of service and subscription offerings, prompted management to provide an encouraging outlook for 2018. This led the stock to rise as much as 9% during pre-market trading hours.Moreover, improvement in Business Solutions and CompuCom divisions is also likely to benefit the company going forward. The company has undertaken a strategic review of business operating model, growth prospects and cost structure and concentrating on e-commerce platforms. Management is also making incremental investments to catapult it into a product and services-driven enterprise. Service revenue now represents approximately 14% of the total sales.The company is trying all means to give itself a complete makeover. This seems evident as demand for office products (paper-based) has been decreasing due to technological advancements. Smartphones, tablets and laptops are fast emerging as viable substitutes for paper-based office supplies. Further, stiff competition from online retailers such as Amazon (AMZN  -  Free Report) and lower traffic count in retail stores have been playing spoilsport.The reflection of the same is quite visible from this Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock’s performance in the bourses. In the past three months, shares of the company have nosedived 20.4%, wider than the industry’s decline of 1.1%.Office Depot, Inc. Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise  Office Depot, Inc. Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise | Office Depot, Inc. QuoteQuarterly ResultsThis office supplies retailer delivered adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations of 8 cents that came in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate but declined 50% from the prior-year quarter, in spite of higher sales. We note that while Product sales declined 2% to $2,423 million, Service revenue surged 88% to $407 million.Gross profit fell 1% year over year to $667 million, while gross margin contracted 160 basis points (bps) to 23.6%. Operating income came in at $55 million, down from $58 million reported in the year-ago period. Operating margin shrunk 30 bps to 4.1%. The fall in the operating income was due to conversion costs and additional marketing investments.In the reported quarter, the Retail Division’s sales fell 8% to $1,244 million on account of planned closure of stores and adoption of the new revenue recognition standard that lower revenue by approximately $30 million. Comparable-store sales (comps) drop 4% due to lower transactions and fall in average order values. Segment operating income came in at $72 million, down from $112 million in the prior-year quarter. As the U.K. is dolling up for the royal wedding tomorrow, we may well regale in stocks of luxury goods that are being well-liked by investors. The luxury goods market is continuing its joy ride this year and expected to reach $182 billion Understandably, after a robust 2017 and a splendid first quarter, U.S. luxury goods’ stocks seem poised for a great year thanks to optimism surrounding steady economic growth, lower tax rates, strong wage growth and a robust earnings season.Strong revenues registered by a number of luxury brands along with an increasing number of millennials spending more on luxury goods bode well too.  This willingness to spend more can be traced back to high U.S. consumer confidence and consumer spending. Given this scenario, it makes good sense to indulge in luxury goods stocks. Luxury Goods Market on Steady Growth TrackThe U.S. luxury goods market witnessed a great 2017, with luxury spending growing 5% globally, according to management consulting firm Bain & Co. The S&P Global Luxury Index rose 27.9% last year. Interestingly, the personal luxury goods market grew globally in 2017, driven by robust local consumption and tourist purchases. Local consumption of personal luxury goods rose 4%, while tourist consumption grew 6%.The strength in U.S. luxury goods stocks continued through the first quarter of 2018, corroborated by a robust earnings season. Nordstrom, Inc. (JWN  -  Free Report) reported first-quarter adjusted earnings of 51 cents per share and revenues of $3.56 billion, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 42 cents and $3.47 billion, respectively. Revenues also increased almost 6% from $3.35 billion in the year-ago period. Other luxury companies expected to report earnings also seem confident of putting up a stellar show. In fiscal fourth-quarter 2017, PVH Corp. (PVH  -  Free Report) had projected its revenues to rise 7% in fiscal 2018, while constant-currency revenues were projected to grow 4% from fiscal 2017. Shares of PVH Corp have surged 55.6% in the past year, while Michael Kors Holdings Limited (KORS  -  Free Report), Nordstorm, Inc. (JWN  -  Free Report) and Ralph Lauren Corporation (RL  -  Free Report) have rallied 83.2%, 25.2% and 59.2%.Moreover, according to Bain & Co, the global luxury goods market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of 4-5% over the next three years, while the personal luxury goods market is expected to reach €295-€305 billion by 2020. Favorable Economic ScenarioThe U.S. economy is stepping up, giving the luxury goods market a solid boost. Higher wages, a low jobless rate and upbeat consumer confidence, all indicate a bullish economy.Moreover, U.S. consumer confidence touched 128.7 in April, surpassing expectations of 126 and recovering from its fall in March. Also, U.S. consumer spending is once again increasing as evident from a retail sales rise in April. According to JP Morgan, consumer spending is running at an annualized rate of 2.4% in the second quarter, double the pace in the first. This positive sentiment is definitely going to reflect on increased purchase of personal luxury goods. Our Choices Luxury goods stocks have been doing well for some time now. Moreover, with positives such as a recovering economy, lower tax rates and business-friendly policies, high consumer confidence, and robust consumer spending, luxury brands are poised for growth in 2018.While binging on luxury goods stocks looks like a smart option now, picking winning stocks may be difficult. Year 2018 so far has been marked by increased government borrowing costs. This is especially true as growing inflationary pressure is building up the case for aggressive rate hikes, pushing yields higher. According to CME, there is 51% chance of four interest rates hike this year.The 10-year Treasury yields, which are a key driver of global borrowing costs, jumped to a 7-year high of 3.12%. The latest spike came on the heels of higher oil price, which is back to $80 per barrel level, and upbeat April retail sales. Worries about growing supply of government debt are also causing the spike in yields (read: ETF Strategies to Play the 7-Year High Benchmark Yield).Pros and ConsA rising rate environment is highly beneficial for cyclical sectors like financial, technology, industrials and consumer discretionary. Banks are at the most advantageous position as they seek to borrow money at short-term rates and lend at long-term rates. If interest rates rise, banks would be able to earn more on lending and pay less on deposits. This would expand net margins and bolster banks’ profits. Also, insurance companies are able to earn higher returns on their investment portfolio of longer-duration bonds.Higher interest rates usually indicate a healthy economy, which in turn leads to greater consumer power. An improving economy coupled with higher consumer confidence is making the consumer discretionary sector tempting to investors amid higher yields. The technology sector should benefit as rising interest rates usually correlate with an economy that is gaining strength and is expected to grow at a faster pace, leading to increased IT spending (read: 5 Niche Tech ETFs Hitting All-Time Highs).Although higher rates would attract more capital to the country, boosting the U.S. dollar against the basket of other currencies, it would have a huge impact on commodity-linked investments, implying that a rising rate environment will hurt a number of segments. In particular, high dividend paying sectors such as utilities and real estate would be the worst hit, given their higher sensitivity to rising interest rates. Additionally, securities in capital-intensive sectors like telecom would also be impacted by higher rates.Further, higher rates would also result in tighter lending conditions and curtail consumer spending on a wide range of products like cars and houses. This will in turn dent profitability across various segments. Further, businesses will also face higher loan rates over time.Given this, we have highlighted ETFs & stocks from the sectors that will benefit from higher rates and the ones that will be badly impacted.Sectors to WinFinancialsThe ultra-popular Financial Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLF  -  Free Report), with AUM of $32.9 billion and average daily volume of 61.6 million shares, offers broad exposure to the sector with banks making up for 44.9% of the portfolio. The fund charges 13 bps in annual fees and has a Zacks ETF Rank #1 (Strong Buy).With a market cap of $36.98 billion, State Street Corporation (STT  -  Free Report) is one of the leading providers of financial services to institutional investors, including investment servicing, investment management and investment research and trading. The stock has above industry average earnings growth estimate of 30.59% for this year. It carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) and a VGM Score of B.Consumer DiscretionaryThis Zacks #1 Ranked Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLY  -  Free Report) offers exposure to the broad consumer discretionary space with key holdings in Internet & direct marketing retail. It has AUM of $13 billion and trades in an average daily volume of nearly 6 million shares (read: 6 ETFs to Ride On Amazon's Blowout Q1).Global accessories, footwear and apparel company Michael Kors Holdings Limited (KORS  -  Free Report) has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) and a VGM Score of B. Its earnings are expected to grow 5.9% for this year. The stock has a market cap of $9.81 billion.TechnologyiShares U.S. Technology ETF (IYW  -  Free Report) provides exposure to U.S. electronics, computer software and hardware, and informational technology companies. With AUM of $4.1 billion and average daily volume of 250,000 shares, the fund carries a Zacks ETF Rank #2.Lam Research Corp. (LRCX  -  Free Report), which designs, manufactures, markets and services semiconductor processing equipment used in the fabrication of integrated circuits, has a Zacks Rank #1 and a VGM Score of A. It is expected to see above-industry earnings growth of 75.79% for this fiscal year (ending June 2018) and has a market cap of $33.17 billion.Sectors to LoseReal EstateSchwab U.S. REIT ETF (SCHH  -  Free Report), having AUM of $4.1 billion and average daily trading volume of 664,000 shares, offers broad exposure to real estate sector. Myriad Genetics, Inc. (MYGN  -  Free Report) is scheduled to report third-quarter fiscal 2018 results on May 8, after the closing bell.Last quarter, the company posted a positive earnings surprise of 29.2%. Moreover, Myriad Genetics beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the trailing four quarters, the average being 20.2%.Let’s take a look at how things are shaping up prior to this announcement.Factors Influencing Q3 ResultsSimilar to last quarter, Myriad Genetics is expected to gain from strong Molecular Diagnostics performance, led by solid contributions from the GeneSight, EndoPredict and Prolaris tests.Per the company, the GeneSight test represents significant opportunities. As GeneSight is placed in a highly under-penetrated preventive care market, the product has huge growth potential. Management expects consistent growth in GeneSight test revenues in the quarters ahead.Myriad Genetics, Inc. Price and EPS Surprise Myriad Genetics, Inc. Price and EPS Surprise | Myriad Genetics, Inc. QuoteWe also encouragingly note that, over the last few months, Myriad Genetics has been making encouraging progress with the EndoPredict test. During the second quarter of fiscal 2018, the company announced the finalization of LCD from Noridian for EndoPredict, thereby expanding the total coverage to around 90% of the U.S. market.  Further, in fiscal 2017, the company received reimbursement approval for EndoPredict in France, Quebec and in some additional German sites. Moreover, according to Myriad Genetics, EndoPredict presents a global market opportunity of more than $600 million annually, with high demand in countries like Canada and the United States.Further, management’s expectations of double-digit volume growth in fiscal 2018 for GeneSight, Vectra DA and Prolaris, all of these make up the chunk of the Molecular Diagnostics portfolio, buoys optimism.The Prolaris testing volumes grew double digits in the last reported quarter as well. We are also encouraged by the company’s receipt of a positive final Local Coverage Determination to expand Medicare coverage of the Prolaris test from Palmetto GBA in the first half of 2017. Moreover, management seems upbeat about the prospects of the Prolaris test as it represents a global market opportunity of approximately $1.5 billion annually. We expect Myriad Genetics to continue to witness year-over-year growth in Hereditary Cancer volumes. Moreover, the last reported quarter was the fourth consecutive quarter, where the volume growth was led by encouraging response to the newly launched riskScore test under its myRisk Hereditary Cancer testing portfolio.  Management believes that the company is well-positioned in the breast cancer testing space for fiscal 2018, courtesy of encouraging Hereditary cancer volumes on steady growth and predictable long-term pricing. Thus, we believe the company is positioned to cash in on the huge potential in the breast cancer screening market.On the flip side, unfavorable foreign currency translation continues to pose threat. These shoes can also be connected to the MapMyRun app. Meanwhile, the company’s continuous efforts to expand its product portfolio  has helped it to outperform the industry over the past month. In the investment field we cannot scoop up handsome returns if we shy away from risky stocks. The strategy is true to some extent, especially when the market is bullish. But, we should also be ready to accept huge loss if the market turns bearish.We have developed an investment strategy which clearly shows that lucrative returns can also be generated from less risky stocks. This may sound surprising but it is true.Meaning of BetaBeta measures the volatility or risk of a particular asset in comparison to the market. In other words, beta measures the extent of a security’s price movement relative to the market. In this article, we are considering the S&P 500 as the market.If a stock has beta of 1 then the price of the stock will move with the market. So, the stock is more volatile than the market if its beta is more than 1. In the same way, the stock is not as volatile as the market if its beta is less than 1.For example, if the market offers a return of 20%, a stock with beta of 3 will return 60%, which is overwhelming. Similarly, when the market slips 20% the stock will sink 60%, which is devastating.The Winning StrategyWe have taken beta between 0 and 0.6 as our prime criterion for screening stocks that are less volatile than the market. But this should not be the only factor to be considered while selecting a winning strategy. We need to take into account other parameters that can add value to the portfolio.Percentage Change in Price in the Last 4 Weeks greater than zero: This ensures that the stocks saw positive price movement over the last one month.Average 20 Day Volume greater than 50,000: A substantial trading volume ensures that the stocks are easily tradable.Price greater than or equal to $5: They must all be trading at a minimum of $5 or higher.Zacks Rank equal to 1: Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stocks indicate that they will significantly outperform the broader U.S. equity market over the next one to three months.Here are five of the seven stocks that qualified the screening:Based in New York, G-III Apparel Group, Ltd. (GIII  -  Free Report) is a leading designer of apparel for men and women. The company managed to surpass the Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings in three of the last four quarters. We are also expecting the company to witness year-over-year earnings growth of 2.1% for fiscal 2018.Michael Kors Holdings Limited (KORS  -  Free Report), based in London, the United Kingdom, is also a leading distributor of apparel for men and women. The company beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings in all the prior four quarters. Also, the fiscal 2018 Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings has been revised upward over the last 60 days.Based in Scottsdale, AZ, Magellan Health, Inc. (MGLN  -  Free Report) is the leading healthcare management player. The company beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings in three of the prior four quarters. On top of that, for 2017, we are projecting the stock to report year-over-year earnings growth of almost 24%.The Boston Beer Company, Inc. (SAM  -  Free Report), based in Boston, MA, is the largest craft brewer in the United States. The firm has managed to surpass the Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings in all the prior four quarters, with an average positive surprise of 63.4%.On top of that, over the last 60 days, the Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings in 2017 has been revised upward.Headquartered in Washington, FTI Consulting, Inc. (FCN  -  Free Report) is the leading provider of specialized consulting services. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2017 earnings has been revised upward over the last 60 days.You can get the rest of the stocks on this list by signing up now for your 2-week free trial to the Research Wizard and start using this screen in your own trading.
